Title: Department of the Army, Fort Leonard Wood
Comment: Please post this letter from the Department of the Army, Fort Leonard Wood, Missouri, in DOT-OST-1996-1167.  Call Kevin at x63176 if you have any questions.

Title: Mayor John A. Spring
Comment:
I am delighted to support and recommend Hyannis Air Service/Cape Air to provide EAS for Quincy, Illinois. We are most impressed with Cape Air's 20 years of history in providing air service as a commercial carrier. We recently met with Dan Wolf, CEO of Cape Air and were most impressed with his honest answers to our questions and concerns. Mr. Wolf did not promise anything he and his company cannot deliver on. We basically found Cape Air to be consistent throughout the process, their proposal has remained unchanged since presented to the USDOT. 

The one area we would like to see addressed is a possible code-share with American Airlines in St. Louis. I believe AA is willing to work with Cape Air to make this possible.

I will be sending a formal letter of recommendation to Mr. Dennis DeVany of USDOT supporting the selection of Cape Air for the Quincy EAS service.

Mayor John A. Spring
City of Quincy

Title: Paul Dwight Miller
Comment:
Warbelow's ships freight for my 3 businesses in Central, AK -- Steese Roadhouse, Steese Highway Fuel, and Central Electric, Inc.  This is an important service for us, particularly in the winter when travel by road is hazardous and time consuming --as inclement weather may require an overnight stay in Fairbanks.  

Warbelow's has always been very courteous, efficient and effective.  As the owner of an electric utility, I can attest that emergency freight services from Fairbanks as provided by Warbelow are important at times to keeping the lights and heat on in Central.  I have always been pleased with Warbelow's service in this regard.  I can only speak highly of Warbelow's Air Ventures.

                                                     Paul Miller

Title: Blayne Dee Baxter
Comment: I have used Rozol for 4 years. I have seen good results in controlling black tail prairie dogs. I have not seen any prairie dogs on the ground for anything to eat them. They must die in the hole. Without Rozal to control prairie dogs on our pasture or on neighbors pasture our farm would be overran and unfamable. Without Rozol we woul lose our alfalfa farm. It' a safe and reliable product. Thank you Blayne Baxter

Title: Robert H. and Joan K. Reyell
Teresa Childres Ray
Comment:
Gaston Hospice 
258 E. Garrison Blvd.
Gastonia, NC


June 16, 2009



Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services
Department of Health and Human Services
Attention: CMS-1420-P
P. O. Box 8012
Baltimore, MD 21244-8012

Re:	Comments on Medicare Program; Proposed Hospice Wage Index for 
Fiscal Year 2010; Proposed Rule; 74 Fed. Reg. 18912 (April 24, 2009), CMS-1420-
P
Dear Sir or Madam:
I appreciate the opportunity to comment on the Proposed Hospice Wage Index 
rule for FY2010, issued by the Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services (“CMS”)  
My comments are specifically directed to the section entitled “FY 2010 Hospice 
Wage Index”.
	As the Director of Counseling Services of a hospice program, I have a 
substantial interest in the proposed changes to the Medicare hospice wage index 
for fiscal year 2010.  Hospice is an exceptional benefit that combines the 
attributes of excellent patient care and demonstrated cost savings to the Medicare 
program.  A recent independently conducted (funded under a grant from the 
Robert Wood Johnson Foundation) study conducted by Duke University 
demonstrated that hospice use reduced Medicare spending by an average of 
$2,309 per beneficiary.  These cost savings, when spread across the entire 
hospice patient population, result in a net reduction in end of life care expenses in 
excess of $2 billion. Over and over, I hear from the family members of patients that 
we serve that they wish they had known about hospice sooner.  
FY 2010 Hospice Wage Index
I strongly disagree with the proposed elimination of the Budget Neutrality 
Adjustment Factor (“BNAF”) used in the computation of the hospice wage index.  
After Congress stepped in, and delayed implementation of the first year of this 
regulation, the next phase of this implementation is projected to reduce Medicare 
hospice payments by 3.2% for fiscal year 2010, beginning October 1, 2009.  A 
reduction of 3.2% may not seem significant, but it needs to be put into the proper 
context.  A June 2008 report by the Medicare Payment Advisory Commission 
(“MedPAC”), found that overall hospices’ Medicare margins were only 3.4%, and 
such a cut will result in many hospices operating in a deficit.  This reduction will 
have a significant negative impact on hospice programs in my community and 
around the country.  Many hospices will be forced to institute hiring and wage 
freezes and in some cases layoffs and wage reductions. With the unemployment 
rate approaching 10% around the country, this course of action seems extremely 
imprudent and contrary to the current Administration’s goal of preserving jobs and 
stimulating growth.
As a senior leader in my program, I will have no choice but to reduce my service 
area, reduce staffing levels, cut back on services or undertake other drastic 
actions to absorb these unwarranted and ill-conceived reimbursement cuts.  
Currently, we plan to (insert your planned actions regarding staffing, service areas, 
etc.)
I strongly encourage CMS to withdraw the proposed elimination of the BNAF, 
particularly at this time in light of the fragile state of the Unites States economy.  
The same rationale used by Congress and President Obama in enacting the 
American Recovery and Reinvestment Act of 2009, which delayed the original 
implementation date of the phase-out of the BNAF, still applies in today’s 
economic climate.
I appreciate the opportunity to submit comments.
					Sincerely,

					Terri C. Ray, MA, LPC
			                         Director of Counseling Services
                                                                                Gaston Hospice

Title: Mike Junkins
Comment:
There are so many road blocks in the way pertaining to the hiring process.  We
can't ask certain questions, we can't obtain truthful information from previous
employers because they are under a gag order.  We are unable to know before
hiring any person exactly what they did before seeking employment from us.  We
need to have the information corridors opened so that drug and alcohol abusers
cannot get through the cracks.  We need to be able to identify these people
before they are accepted for employment.  Once they are on the rolls they become
a liability.  We need to know if they were released from employment from their
last employer for drug and/or alcohol related problems so that we might assess
this before hiring a new employee.  It's like hiring from a grab bag with a
blindfold on because information becomes so sensitive that no one can relay it
or receive it. Possibly, before placing new regulations into the mix we could
also implement a national register where employers can find out about a persons
past work history before making a hiring decision.  Similar to the register of
sex offenders that can be found on the internet.  We need a way of looking at
what a person has done because the truth is hard to come by when a person is
broke and in need of a job.

Title: Armando Acuna Martinez
Comment:
Dear Sir:  I was presently working as a Public Bus Driver for over 10 years and had 
been drug and alcohol tested several times over that 10 year period.  I was 
recently drug and alcohol tested (March 17, 2009) and results came up positive for 
a minute amount of marijuana and was fired from my job.  First of all I don't do 
drugs except a prescribed drug called olanzapine that I'd stopped taking before I'd 
returned to work (March 2,2009).  The questions I have are:  didn't I have a right to 
another urinalysis even after explaining that I don't do drugs and even after I'd 
gotton a Doctors letter stating the prescription drug?  Also, shouldn't I have been 
given a urinalysis upon my return to work on March 2nd?

                                                        Sincerely,  Armando A. Martinez

Title: Patricia Ann Blackwell-Marchant
Comment:
Please make it your policy to be respectful of all people needing assistance.  
The restrictions you're considering are discriminatory and intrusive, in my 
opinion.

Thanks for your prompt action in this matter.

Sincerely,

Pat Blackwell-Marchant

Title: Tim Crouch
Comment:
Please adopt strict, enforceable regulations to protect airline passenger rights
to be treated with dignity and fairness.

The airline industry has shown time and again to be incapable of self regulation
in this area.  Therefore, the Federal government must step in and develop
strict, common sense regulations which apply to ALL airlines mandating the the
health, wellbeing and rights of passenger will be protected.

I do not believe the three hour tarmac time frame outline in the proposal is
acceptable.  It should be shortened to a maximum of two hours.  Airlines who
have knowledges of departure delay issues should be restricted from boarding
passengers until these are completely resolved.  Airlines should be responsible
for reasonable accommodations who incur complication with connecting flights. 
Passengers must be provided avenues of timely reporting and redress, including
full refund of all travel related expenses.

Agency oversight must include timely reporting, prominent posting of passenger
rights and strict penalties for non-compliance.

It is both time and appropriate that the airlines be held to a higher standard
for passenger rights and carrier responsibility.  The Federal government must be
the ones to actively impose these standards, ensure they are strictly enforced
and severely penalize  non-compliance.

Thank you

Title: Daniel S. Guerra
Comment:
The airline industry needs to be held accountable for its chronic delays and poor 
treatment of passengers.  The industry is opposed to meaningful regulation and 
instead favors self regulation.  The fact of the matter is that the industry has had 
years to correct its shortcomings, but hasn’t done so.  In fact, industry 
performance has gotten worse and passenger satisfaction has declined in recent 
years.  I would favor a more comprehensive rulemaking procedure in which the 
DOT created industry wide minimum standards rather than allowing individual 
airlines to create their own plans of response.  Barring that, I believe DOT should 
move forward with the proposed rules.
The airline industry’s contention that the free market will drive the players in the 
industry to meaningfully self-regulate is absurd.  The industry is too consolidated 
with a few airlines providing the majority of flights in many regions of the country.  
There are insufficient competitive forces to provide consumers with the options 
necessary to choose one airline over another because one provides better delay 
contingency plans than another.  This is not an efficient market, consumers 
cannot readily use demand side pressure to force airlines to change.  Regulation 
in this field is appropriate.
It is amazing how so many of the airlines and airline associations can pay lip 
service to the need for a passenger’s bill of rights and the assurance that they 
have their own protective systems in place.  Yet at the same time, they are 
unwilling to make guarantee these procedures contractually for fear of liability?  It 
would seem to me that liability would only ensue if the airlines failed to meet their 
own policies and procedures.  And if they are committed to the ideals embodied in 
those policies, this would only occur on rare occasions.  If the airlines are 
unwilling to stand by their individualized procedures enough to risk liability, then 
following those plans must not be a high priority for the airlines.  It seems logical 
that, this being the case, external pressure in the form of liability for breach of 
contract, would be a suitable means of inducing the airlines to make customer 
satisfaction a priority.  
Please go forward with these rules and protect consumers from abussive use of 
power by the airlines.  Thank you for your time.
Sincerely,

Title: Ryan McCord
Comment:
I am writing in support of the adoption of uniform standard time intervals that
would invoke the carriers' obligations under their contingency plans.  I support
both standards: the maximum time that would trigger the plan, and the maximum
time after which carriers would be required to allow passengers to deplane. 
These uniform standards are necessary to ensure that the carriers create
effective contingency plans - not merely plans that minimize their costs. 
Currently, the DOT proposes to exclude any uniform standards from the final rule
because "the Department should not substitute its judgment in this area for that
of the air carriers."  The DOT currently regulates nearly every aspect of the
business and operations of commercial carriers. The argument that the DOT should
not step in "in this area" - protecting passengers - is misplaced.  A simple
provision that sets a maximum time interval is not interfering in the technical
decisions of the carriers.  While, as the ATA asserts, contingency plans "must
be tailored to fit" each carrier's "facilities, equipment, operating procedures
and network," setting a time interval does not substantially invoke any of these
concerns.  Whether an airline has a three hour deplaning requirement set by the
DOT, or a three and a half hour interval set by its own internal contingency
requirement will not impair the airline's operations or ability to be flexible
under different weather and airport capacity limits.  But setting a uniform DOT
limit will significantly benefit the traveling public.  Passengers will know
that no matter the specific airline they have selected, they are entitled to
certain rights within a known time while sitting on the tarmac.  Perhaps a few
passengers out of a thousand read the specific carrier's contract of carriage,
but a uniform industry standard set by the DOT would quickly become common
knowledge among travelers.  This knowledge in turn would force the airlines to
live up to contingency plans in the contracts.  

As a specific recommendation for the time intervals, I believe that after one
and a half hours, the carriers should be required to discharge their obligations
under their contingency plans.  And after three hours, passengers should be
permitted to deplane.  Of course, this second requirement can still have some
built in flexibility.  Some discretion should be left in the hands of pilots to
decide whether to return to the gate.  But this does not mean that the
discretion cannot be standardized across the industry.  If a plane is, in the
ATA's hyperbolic scenario, "the next in line to take off," the pilot would not
be required to return to the gate.  And of course, if a plane were quarantined
for health reasons, passengers would not be permitted to deplane.  But these
kind of rare cases can easily be dealt with in the final rule, while still
adopting a uniform standard that benefits travelers.

Title: Anonymous
Comment:
As a frequent traveler on commercial airlines, I want to express my support for this 
proposed rule to enhance airline passenger protections.  Passengers and airlines 
alike will benefit from giving increased clarity and predictability to airline travel.  
While many of the specific provisions of this rulemaking might seem like common 
sense measures for airlines to adopt, in some cases they have not been adopted 
by airlines on their own. It is time that the Department of Transporation makes sure 
airlines have reasonable procedures in places for dealing with unforeseen, adverse 
circumstances, and that they clearly communicate these contingency plans and 
procedures to their passengers upfront.  This will go a long way toward making air 
travel more humane for those of us who regularly use it. 

It is not enough to rely on market forces to correct poor customer service. When 
inadequate checks on bad planning and procedure are in place, mere 
inconvenience can become a much more serious problem for all passengers.  
Though complying with these changes will likely involve some cost to the airlines, 
customers will be much more willing to travel by plane if they know that these 
safeguards are in place and they know what they are.  A rulemaking by the DOT is 
an appropriate means of assuring that there is a floor of decency in customer 
service below which no airline can sink.

Title: National Business Travel Association
Comment:
February 6, 2009

Department of Transportation

Office of the Secretary

14 CFR Parts 234, 259, and 399

[Docket No. DOT-OST-2007-0022]

RIN No. 2105-AD72

Enhancing Airline Passenger Protections

The National Business Travel Association (NBTA) submits the following 
comments in response to the Department of Transportation’s (DOT) Proposed 
Rulemaking (NPRM) concerning its proposals to enhance airline passenger 
protections.  

NBTA is the world’s premier business travel and corporate meetings organization. 
NBTA and its regional affiliates – NBTA Asia Pacific, the Brazilian Business Travel 
Association (ABGEV), NBTA Canada, NBTA Mexico, and NBTA USA – serve a 
network of more than 15,000 business travel professionals around the globe with 
industry-leading events, networking, education & professional development, 
research, news & information, and advocacy. NBTA members, numbering more 
than 4,000 in 30 nations, are corporate and government travel and meetings 
managers, as well as travel service providers. They collectively manage and direct 
more than US$200 billion of global business travel and meetings expenditures 
annually on behalf of more than 10 million business travelers within their 
organizations.

Through the efforts of its member committees and professional staff, NBTA 
monitors developments in the business travel field and provides time-sensitive 
research and critical industry information.  The association also takes the 
industry’s story to the media and the public and represents the industry’s 
interests on Capitol Hill.  Committee to the advancement of the business travel 
profession, NBTA offers numerous education and training opportunities and holds 
an annual International Convention and Exposition.  

General Comments

DOT is seeking comment on whether it should adopt a rule to enhance airline 
passenger protections by requiring carriers to adopt contingency plans for lengthy 
tarmac delays and incorporate them in their contract of carriage; require air 
carriers to respond to consumer problems; deem operating a chronically delayed 
flight to be unfair and deceptive; require carriers to publish delay data; require 
carriers to publish complaint data; require on-time performance reporting for 
international flights; and require carriers to audit their compliance with their 
customer service plans.

The comments below are generally similar to those submitted by NBTA on 
January 22, 2008.  Generally NBTA believes that customer service is a market-
driven issue, with purchasers able to make informed buying decisions based on 
facts related to airline service.  As certain types of information are only in the 
possession of air carriers, NBTA generally supports greater transparency and 
reporting requirements so long as such requirements provide useful information to 
the airline passenger and/or their purchasing agent and can be conducted with 
reasonable costs.  Certain parts of the proposals in the proposed rule, however, 
do not meet that test.  Moreover, while NBTA believes the federal government has 
an interest in mandating certain baseline consumer protections for airline 
customer service—or “passenger rights”—in general, airlines are in a much better 
position to ascertain what their customers expect and whether certain practices 
are worth the cost they entail.  Basic economics dictate that government 
mandates create private sector costs, and those costs are going to be borne, 
directly or indirectly, by the traveling public.

Contingency Plans
DOT seeks comment whether an air carrier operating a domestic service should 
be required to develop and publish a contingency plan for long ground delays on 
the tarmac for all its flights and incorporate this plan into the contract of carriage.  
Were this required, DOT indicates that passengers would gain the opportunity to 
sue an airline if the airline did not abide by that plan.  Carriers would be required to 
retain for two years information related to on ground delays that lasted for at least 
four hours.  

NBTA does not support generally requiring carriers to develop and publish 
contingency plans.  While NBTA supports carriers developing contingency plans 
and adopting recommendations set forth by the DOT Tarmac Delays Task Force, 
actions regarding use and implementation of such plans should not be required by 
regulation.  NBTA believes that airlines that fail to adopt or utilize contingency 
plans are extremely likely to provide poor service to passengers in lengthy delay 
situations, and such carrier are likely to be considered a much less desirable 
travel option.  Unfortunately, the causes of any specific lengthy tarmac delay is 
likely to be a combination of fact-specific occurrences related to weather, 
mechanical problems, or other factors.  We continue to believe that an airline, 
working through its pilot with local air traffic control and airport operators, is more 
likely to resolve a tarmac delay in a manner most beneficial to the largest number 
of passengers, than trying to resolve through previously-prepared scenarios.

For a market driven approach to be effective, NBTA does support requiring airlines 
to maintain and publish descriptions of lengthy tarmac delay situations.  


Response to Consumer Problems

The proposed rule seeks comments on a series of new requirements for air 
carriers to respond to consumer complaints.  These proposals would require air 
carriers to designate an employee at every airport who is responsible for 
monitoring the effects of flight delays, flight cancellations, and lengthy tarmac 
delays on passengers and who has input on decisions such as which flights are 
subject to the longest delays.  Air carriers would also be required to publish all 
information necessary for filing a complaint with the airline.  Finally, airlines would 
be required to send a response to each consumer complaint it receives within 30 
days.  

NBTA feels that this type of micromanagement of airlines customer service is 
unnecessary to meet the needs of business travelers.  Most, if not all, airlines 
have customer service departments specifically designed for this type of mission 
and have specific managers to handle key client needs.  Regulating a well-
established practice would unnecessarily burden the air carriers and create 
duplicative and redundant services.  How carriers respond to flight cancellations 
and other service problems is a key factor by which purchasers make their buying 
decisions.  Therefore, NBTA believes that diverting attention away from this 
business relationship to meet government-mandated solutions would be an 
unproductive endeavor.  

The cost of creating new customer service positions at each airport is also of 
great concern to NBTA.  Requiring airlines to enhance their physical customer 
service at airports may divert resources from customer service methods, such as 
customer service available by Internet or phone, that are more efficient for carriers 
to administer.  
 
Chronically Delayed Flights as Violations

The proposed rule would require a ‘chronically delayed flight’ as a flight that 
operates at least 45 times per quarter and is more than 15 minutes late 70% of 
the time.  

NBTA supports this new proposal as a helpful “bright line” standard that will force 
air carriers to meet baseline performance standards in order to advertise a flight.  
The proposed rule accurately states: “Consumers’ reliance on chronically 
inaccurate schedules works in their detriment both personally and professionally.”  
One of the key recommendations made by the DOT Inspector General’s office at 
several Congressional hearings was to provide DOT the tools and recourses to 
adequately pursue passenger’s rights issues.  NBTA supports adding this 
additional legal tool to the Secretary’s disposal. 

Require Carriers to Publish Delay Data on their Web Sites

The proposed rule would require airlines and travel agencies to provide on-time 
performance information on their websites as part of customers’ online 
transactions for purchasing tickets.  

NBTA supports requiring carriers to provide performance data to prospective 
purchasers so long as these requirements are aligned with performance reports 
that carriers must file with DOT.  NBTA recognizes that DOT is conducting an 
additional rule-making related to flight delays, and encourages DOT to align the 
requirements that might emerge from that rule-making with any new mandates in 
this area.  

Require Carriers to Publish Complaint Data on their Web Sites

The proposed rule would require that carriers publish an aggregate count of 
specific complaints filed by passengers on their Web sites.  

While NBTA appreciates the spirit of advancing transparency in the rule, requiring 
an air carrier to specifically highlight its complaints does not appear to offer 
meaningful value to prospective purchasers.  Many complaints would not fall into 
simple categories easily classified into aggregate data fields.  Furthermore, 
categorization of complaints would fail to distinguish the severity and rational of 
complaints.  For example, the proposed rule does not appear to require distinction 
between problems caused purely by airline issues and those that are the result of 
some uncontrollable factor such as the weather.  The ambiguity of complaint 
classification would also lead carriers to adopt disparate standards, which would 
make enforcement problematic.  In addition, many complaints are resolved over a 
period of time, requiring a constant reshuffling of data fields and arbitrary decisions 
whether a specific complaint was resolved.  

Require Carriers to Report On-Time Performance of International Flights

The proposed rule would require foreign carriers to report on-time performance for 
international flights.  

NBTA supports this requirement as a reasonable mechanism to bring greater 
transparency to a growing market of increasing significance to NBTA and its 
international partners.  NBTA encourages DOT, however, to align any new 
reporting requirements as much as possible with current requirements applicable 
to purely domestic flights.  In addition, to the extent such information can be 
communicated via transmissions mechanisms already in place for other purposes, 
such as the Advanced Passenger Information System, the new requirement may 
be implemented in a cost-effective manner.  

Carriers’ Adherence to Customer Service Plans

The proposed rule would require carriers to audit their adherence to their own 
customer service plans.  It also seeks comment whether carriers who do not have 
such plans should be required to adopt one and what might be included and 
whether they should be incorporated in their contract of carriage.  

It is difficult to imagine that self-audits of customer service plans will create 
significant credibility for such plans.  NBTA supports providing the DOT IG with 
resources to conduct audits of carrier customer service, whether they have 
adopted a specific plan or not, to improve public information about airline 
performance.  However, recognizing the cost of compliance, NBTA suggests that 
such audits be conducted no greater than every three years and that they be 
conducted at similar times in the year to provide accurate comparative 
information.  

As mentioned under the issues of contingency plans, NBTA believes that 
customer service is best left to market forces, subject to the baseline passenger 
rights.  

Retroactive Applicability of Amendments to Contracts of Carriage

DOT seeks comments on whether customers on the same flight should be 
subject to the same contract of carriage if changes or amendments occurred 
between passengers’ purchases.

NBTA believes that customers flying on the same flight should be subject to the 
same contract of carriage terms regardless of when their ticket was purchased.  
Often times business travelers schedule their trips at the last minute and should 
not be subjected to different regulations due to the nature of their business.

Such a practice could have potentially detrimental effects to airline customer 
service as well.  Providing customers on various flights with different responses 
and compensation would complicate the process and likely require additional 
staffing in airline customer service departments. 

Effective Date

The proposed rule would require airlines to adopt plans for compliance within 180 
days of the publishing date of the final rule.  It seeks comments on whether that 
gives airlines sufficient time for implementation.  

If implemented, some of the rules would require significant changes to airline 
practices resulting in the need for additional implementation time.  NBTA believes 
a reasonable effective date should be established by DOT after determining the 
impact the final rule will have on air carriers.

Title: Aviation Consumer Action Project
Comment:
March 9, 2009 

Hon. Ray LaHood
Secretary of Transportation
U.S. Department of Transportation
1200 New Jersey Avenue, S.E.
Washington, D.C. 20590

Subject:	Comments of FlyersRights.org on NPRM
?Enhancing Airline Passenger Protections?

Reference:	14 CFR Parts 234, 253, 259, and 399
Docket No. DOT-OST-2007-0022
RIN No. 2105-AD72

SUBJECT:	The Aviation Consumer Action Project (ACAP) opposes the subject 
NPRM (Item 1) as an unlawful delegation of DOT authority and responsibility to 
regulate airlines in the public interest by delegating this function the airlines 
themselves.  As written it is an anti-consumer regulation that would take away 
existing common law tort rights of airline passengers for false imprisonment and 
negligence in situations of long confinements on the tarmac of 3-11 hours, that 
airlines now subject approximately 300,000 passengers a year to, and substitute 
an unenforceable contract cause of action.  ACAP supports Items 2-7 of the 
NPRM. 


Dear Secretary LaHood:

	The Aviation Consumer Action Project (ACAP) was founded in 1971 as 
501(c ) 3 nonprofit organization that acts as voice for air travelers on issues of 
safety, security and airline consumer rights and interests.  It has held 
longstanding membership on the FAA Aviation Rulemaking Advisory Committee 
(ARAC) and the Aviation Security Advisory Committee.  We have testified before 
Congress on the issues in this NPRM and filed comments with DOT.  

	I have been executive director of ACAP since 1997 and as an attorney 
have represented ACAP, individual consumers and Flyersrights.org (fka the 
Coalition for an Airline Passengers Bill of Rights) in the federal and state courts on 
the issues addressed in this NRPM.

1.  Putting Contingency Plans in the Contract of Carriage.

	This NPRM (1) is a last gasp Bush Administration/Airline Industry effort 
to turn over DOT regulatory authority to the regulated party.  It would lead to a 
multiplicity of unenforceable ?standards? and ?plans.?  Some airlines already are 
using a 4 to 6 hour guideline for tarmac confinements.  As there is presently no 
federal standard, state common law standards for negligence and false 
imprisonment, state criminal statutes involving unsafe operation of aircraft and 
wrongful imprisonment or reckless endangerment, and possibly constitutional 
protections against unreasonable seizure are the only legal protections airline 
passengers have against indefinite tarmac confinements.  

	Most airlines now have or claim to have contingency plans to deal with 
flight disruptions of more than 2 hours.  But they are vague and commonly ignored 
(e.g. American Airlines has a contingency plan that is supposed to be activated 
after a 2 hours of delay but it was been found by the OIG to have been ignored and 
violated repeatedly in a Sept. 2007 report of its 12/29/06 mass diversion and 
stranding of over 100 flights involving over 10,000 passengers).  Such plans are 
vague and there is nothing in them that a airline passenger can really enforce in a 
contract action.  Such plans placed in the contract of carriage would just be 
another way for airlines to absolve themselves of responsibility for long tarmac 
delays, diversions and confinements.

	These confinements of 3- 11 hours now affect approximately 300,000 
passengers per year and have led to a national outcry and the formation of a 
national grass roots organization, Flyersrights.org with over 24,000 members.  The 
claims of the Air Transport Association that tarmac confinements have declined 
are false or at least unproven.  The DOT BTS only recently began collecting these 
statistics in 2008 and has had to remove the data presented by the airlines 
as ?corrupted? and therefore unreliable.

	The proposed regulation would wipe out existing legal protections and 
in our view would lead to more not less tarmac confinements as each airline would 
be in effect be able to write its own rule.  Such an unlawful delegation of DOT 
regulatory authority  would no doubt be challenged in court.   

	The age of self-regulation and deregulation whether in the financial 
industry, air safety, food safety, or airline consumer protection is over.  It has been 
thoroughly discredited by scandals and disasters over the past two years and 
even rejected by many of its former advocates.  The Obama DOT must reject the 
mantra of former DOT Secretary Peters that the ?market? will solve all consumer 
problems.  Senator and Candidate Obama endorsed airline passenger rights 
legislation that would outlaw tarmac confinements of over 3 hours, which this 
NPRM would clearly not do.  
	
	When an airline passenger brings an action in state court,  the airline 
almost invariably has it removed to federal court on grounds of federal preemption.  
The defendant airline will then file a series of motions to have the case transferred 
to its home state, often far from the consumer passenger?s residence.  The cost of 
such litigation far exceeds the individual claims for ordinary delays or tarmac 
confinements.  The airlines are generally successful in having such lawsuits 
dismissed, discouraged or abandoned.  Indeed a review of cases under CCH 
Aviation cases shows that virtually the only breach of contract cases brought 
under the contracts of carriage successfully involve cargo shipments by 
commercial shippers.   You can view the many technical defenses Recent cases 
involving passenger strandings which include  Ray v American Airlines, Inc. US 
DC WD AR 08-5072, Hanni v American Airlines, Inc. US DC ND CA 08-732; 
Harper v American Airlines, Inc. US DC ND AL 08-________ (filed 12/29/08); 
Biscone v JetBlue Airways Corp., NYS SC Queens Co. 3776/2008.  The motions 
to dismiss or transfer or for summary judgment filed by the airline defendants can 
be viewed online at Public Access to Court Electronic Records (PACER) or the 
electronic dockets of the New York State Uniform Court System web site.

	Under the Class Action Fairness Act of 2005 (CAFA) (perhaps better 
described as the Consumer Class Action Elimination Act of 2005), nearly all state 
consumer class actions (which involves any case with a potential total claim over 
$5 Million) are removed to federal court where the bar is so high for certification 
that very few consumer class actions have ever been certified since this statute 
went into effect.  In the 5th Circuit which is the home of American, Southwest and 
Continental Airlines, none have been certified.  

	As to the issue of tarmac confinements, only one 1999 case against 
Northwest Airlines has been certified as a class action to our knowledge, and that 
occurred in Michigan state court involving confinements of up to 9 hours of 4,000 
passengers prior to the enactment of CAFA. Only through class actions in federal 
court or in local small claims court is it possible for airline passengers to judicially 
enforce breach of contract to tort claims that do not involve serious physical injury 
or death.  And since a class action requires that many passengers be involved 
with common facts and law, only mass stranding events would normally qualify.

	Some airlines already provide for compensation for delays and 
associated expenses of overnight lodging in their contracts of carriage, but these 
provisions are not as a practical matter enforceable and are frequently ignored or 
avoided entirely by airlines coding nearly every delayed or canceled flight as 
weather or FAA Air Traffic Control related.  There is no effective oversight by DOT 
and no fines of substance for airline violation of their own contracts or customer 
service plans or contingency plans or internal policies, and none seems likely in 
the foreseeable future.

	The NPRM if adopted would mean domestic US airline passengers 
would have rights inferior to those provided to international passengers under the 
Montreal Convention of 1999.  Under Art. 19, passengers may recover damages 
for delay of up to  about $6,400 on a near strict liability basis.  An airline to avoid 
liability has the burden of proving that it took all reasonable steps to avoid the 
delay or that the delay was impossible to avoid.  Damages include compensation 
for inconvenience as well as out of pocket losses and this treaty overrides the 
limitations or exclusions commonly found in domestic airline contracts of carriage, 
which make promises in those contracts largely illusory.  

	Should NPRM (Item 1) be adopted in any form, it should include 
provisions in domestic contracts of carriage a) requiring payment of litigation 
expenses of the passenger should s/he substantially prevail in the lawsuit, b) be 
no less favorable to domestic passengers than international passengers, c) should 
specifically authorize suits in state as well as federal courts, d) authorize class 
actions where appropriate, with the consumer class representative receiving a 
reasonable sum in compensation his time and representational responsibilities of 
the class, payment of class notification expenses by the airline defendant, plus 
treble damages or minimum compensation of  four times the ticket price, and e) 
have a hard 3 hour passenger right to deplane plus delay compensation of $10 per 
minute for on ground confinements over 3 hours. 

	Only with such pro-consumer provisions will airlines have an incentive 
to change their existing practices of ignoring passenger complaints and claims 
with impunity or offering only token compensation such as discount coupons or 
restricted vouchers.


	Items 2-7.  ACAP has long advocated for Truth in Scheduling regulation 
as a first line of defense against congestion delays caused by over scheduling by 
airlines.  These proposed measures are in line with our recommendations and 
would address the No. 1 airline passenger complaint:  flight delays.   As 
scheduling has been decontrolled airlines now have incentives to unrealistically 
schedule flights at popular times for competitive reasons, which in turn leads to 
unnecessary congestion at major choke point airports like NYC and Chicago.  
These regulations should allow consumers to avoid chronically delayed flights, 
should eliminate deceptively scheduled flights, and help relieve congestion delays 
at choke point airports.
 
	We generally support the comments of Flyersrights.org .  

	
	  				Very truly yours,


					s/
					Paul S. Hudson
					Executive Director
					Aviation Consumer Action 
Project
					4411 Bee Ridge Road #274
					Sarasota, Florida 34233
					(410) 940-8934
					Acapaviation@yahoo.com

Title: City of Atlanta Department of Aviation
Organization Name: City of Atlanta Department of Aviation
Submitter Representative: Benjamin R. DeCosta, A.A.E., Aviation Manager

Title: Airports Council International-North America
Comment:
ACI-NA’s members are the state, local and regional government entities that own 
and operate commercial service airports in the United States and Canada.  It is 
important that the Department consider ACI-NA’s comments because an airline’s 
failure to provide on-time performance has a significant impact on airport 
operations and facilities.  The effect of chronically delayed flights is even more 
severe as passengers often lose confidence in the operations at the airport, which 
could result in booking future flights at another airport or the use of an alternative 
mode of transportation, if possible. This impacts the finances of the airport and the 
economy of the local community. 

The impact at smaller airports is even more pronounced. The Department should 
keep in mind that delayed flights at the smaller (feeder) airports have a greater 
adverse effect on the ability to make connections at the hubs and are more 
disruptive to passengers.

Title: Aviation Consumer Action Project
Comment:
March 9, 2009 

Hon. Ray LaHood
Secretary of Transportation
U.S. Department of Transportation
1200 New Jersey Avenue, S.E.			CORRECTED
Washington, D.C. 20590

Subject:	Comments of Aviation Consumer Action Project on NPRM
“Enhancing Airline Passenger Protections”

Reference:	14 CFR Parts 234, 253, 259, and 399
Docket No. DOT-OST-2007-0022
RIN No. 2105-AD72

SUBJECT:	The Aviation Consumer Action Project (ACAP) opposes the subject 
NPRM (Item 1) as an unlawful delegation of DOT authority and responsibility to 
regulate airlines in the public interest by delegating this function the airlines 
themselves.  As written it is an anti-consumer regulation that would take away 
existing common law tort rights of airline passengers for false imprisonment and 
negligence in situations of long confinements on the tarmac of 3-11 hours, that 
airlines now subject approximately 300,000 passengers a year to, and substitute 
an unenforceable contract cause of action.  ACAP supports Items 2-7 of the 
NPRM. 


Dear Secretary LaHood:

	The Aviation Consumer Action Project (ACAP) was founded in 1971 as 
501(c ) 3 nonprofit organization that acts as voice for air travelers on issues of 
safety, security and airline consumer rights and interests.  It has held 
longstanding membership on the FAA Aviation Rulemaking Advisory Committee 
(ARAC) and the Aviation Security Advisory Committee.  We have testified before 
Congress on the issues in this NPRM and filed comments with DOT.  

	I have been executive director of ACAP since 1997 and as an attorney 
have represented ACAP, individual consumers and Flyersrights.org (fka the 
Coalition for an Airline Passengers Bill of Rights) in the federal and state courts on 
the issues addressed in this NRPM.

1.  Putting Contingency Plans in the Contract of Carriage.

	This NPRM (1) is a last gasp Bush Administration/Airline Industry effort 
to turn over DOT regulatory authority to the regulated party.  It would lead to a 
multiplicity of unenforceable “standards” and “plans.”  Some airlines already are 
using a 4 to 6 hour guideline for tarmac confinements.  As there is presently no 
federal standard, state common law standards for negligence and false 
imprisonment, state criminal statutes involving unsafe operation of aircraft and 
wrongful imprisonment or reckless endangerment, and possibly constitutional 
protections against unreasonable seizure are the only legal protections airline 
passengers have against indefinite tarmac confinements.  

	Most airlines now have or claim to have contingency plans to deal with 
flight disruptions of more than 2 hours.  But they are vague and commonly ignored 
(e.g. American Airlines has a contingency plan that is supposed to be activated 
after a 2 hours of delay but it was been found by the OIG to have been ignored and 
violated repeatedly in a Sept. 2007 report of its 12/29/06 mass diversion and 
stranding of over 100 flights involving over 10,000 passengers).  Such plans are 
vague and there is nothing in them that a airline passenger can really enforce in a 
contract action.  Such plans placed in the contract of carriage would just be 
another way for airlines to absolve themselves of responsibility for long tarmac 
delays, diversions and confinements.

	These confinements of 3- 11 hours now affect approximately 300,000 
passengers per year and have led to a national outcry and the formation of a 
national grass roots organization, Flyersrights.org with over 24,000 members.  The 
claims of the Air Transport Association that tarmac confinements have declined 
are false or at least unproven.  The DOT BTS only recently began collecting these 
statistics in 2008 and has had to remove the data presented by the airlines 
as “corrupted” and therefore unreliable.

	The proposed regulation would wipe out existing legal protections and 
in our view would lead to more not less tarmac confinements as each airline would 
be in effect be able to write its own rule.  Such an unlawful delegation of DOT 
regulatory authority  would no doubt be challenged in court.   

	The age of self-regulation and deregulation whether in the financial 
industry, air safety, food safety, or airline consumer protection is over.  It has been 
thoroughly discredited by scandals and disasters over the past two years and 
even rejected by many of its former advocates.  The Obama DOT must reject the 
mantra of former DOT Secretary Peters that the “market” will solve all consumer 
problems.  Senator and Candidate Obama endorsed airline passenger rights 
legislation that would outlaw tarmac confinements of over 3 hours, which this 
NPRM would clearly not do.  
	
	When an airline passenger brings an action in state court,  the airline 
almost invariably has it removed to federal court on grounds of federal preemption.  
The defendant airline will then file a series of motions to have the case transferred 
to its home state, often far from the consumer passenger’s residence.  The cost of 
such litigation far exceeds the individual claims for ordinary delays or tarmac 
confinements.  The airlines are generally successful in having such lawsuits 
dismissed, discouraged or abandoned.  Indeed a review of cases under CCH 
Aviation cases shows that virtually the only breach of contract cases brought 
under the contracts of carriage successfully involve cargo shipments by 
commercial shippers.   You can view the many technical defenses Recent cases 
involving passenger strandings which include  Ray v American Airlines, Inc. US 
DC WD AR 08-5072, Hanni v American Airlines, Inc. US DC ND CA 08-732; 
Harper v American Airlines, Inc. US DC ND AL 08-________ (filed 12/29/08); 
Biscone v JetBlue Airways Corp., NYS SC Queens Co. 3776/2008.  The motions 
to dismiss or transfer or for summary judgment filed by the airline defendants can 
be viewed online at Public Access to Court Electronic Records (PACER) or the 
electronic dockets of the New York State Uniform Court System web site.

	Under the Class Action Fairness Act of 2005 (CAFA) (perhaps better 
described as the Consumer Class Action Elimination Act of 2005), nearly all state 
consumer class actions (which involves any case with a potential total claim over 
$5 Million) are removed to federal court where the bar is so high for certification 
that very few consumer class actions have ever been certified since this statute 
went into effect.  In the 5th Circuit which is the home of American, Southwest and 
Continental Airlines, none have been certified.  

	As to the issue of tarmac confinements, only one 1999 case against 
Northwest Airlines has been certified as a class action to our knowledge, and that 
occurred in Michigan state court involving confinements of up to 9 hours of 4,000 
passengers prior to the enactment of CAFA. Only through class actions in federal 
court or in local small claims court is it possible for airline passengers to judicially 
enforce breach of contract to tort claims that do not involve serious physical injury 
or death.  And since a class action requires that many passengers be involved 
with common facts and law, only mass stranding events would normally qualify.

	Some airlines already provide for compensation for delays and 
associated expenses of overnight lodging in their contracts of carriage, but these 
provisions are not as a practical matter enforceable and are frequently ignored or 
avoided entirely by airlines coding nearly every delayed or canceled flight as 
weather or FAA Air Traffic Control related.  There is no effective oversight by DOT 
and no fines of substance for airline violation of their own contracts or customer 
service plans or contingency plans or internal policies, and none seems likely in 
the foreseeable future.

	The NPRM if adopted would mean domestic US airline passengers

for delay of up to  about $6,400 on a near strict liability basis.  An airline to avoid 
liability has the burden of proving that it took all reasonable steps to avoid the

	Should NPRM (Item 1) be adopted in any form, it should include 
provisions in domestic contracts of carriage a) requiring payment of litigation

no less favorable to domestic passengers than international passengers, c) should

minute for on ground confinements over 3 hours. 

	Only with such pro-consumer provisions will airlines have an incentive 
to change their existing practices of ignoring passenger complaints and claims 
with impunity or offering only token compensation such as discount coupons or 
restricted vouchers.


	Items 2-7.  ACAP has long advocated for Truth in Scheduling regulation 
as a first line of defense against congestion delays caused by over scheduling by 
airlines.  These proposed measures are in line with our recommendations and 
would address the No. 1 airline passenger complaint:  flight delays.   As

These regulations should allow consumers to avoid chronically delayed flights,

	We generally support the comments of Flyersrights.org .  

	
	  				Very truly yours,


					s/

					Executive Director
					Aviation Consumer Action 
Project

Title: Air Transport Association of America, Inc.
Organization Name: Air Transport Association of America, Inc.
Comment: ATA comments for Docket Number DOT-OST-2007-0022.

Title: Consumer Action, Consumer Federation of America, Consumers Union, National Consumers League and U.S. PIRG
Comment:
The letter below and attached is concurrence by 5 leading national consumer
groups with the detailed flyersrights.org submission in this docket, which I
have endeavored to attach it to (if this somewhat clunky government web
interface works). Thank you for your consideration of our submission..

On behalf of the groups,
Ed Mierzwinski
U.S. PIRG

--------------------------LETTER FOLLOWS AND IS ATTACHED -------------------------

Consumer Action
Consumer Federation of America
Consumers Union
National Consumers League
U.S. PIRG

March 19, 2009

FAX (202) 493-2251

Document Management Facility
U.S. Department of Transportation
1200 New Jersey Avenue, S.E.
Washington, D.C. 20590-0001

Re:		Notice of Proposed Rule Making:
		Enhancing Airline Passenger Protections

Reference:	14 CFR Parts 234, 253, 259, and 399
Docket No. DOT-OST-2007-0022
RIN No. 2105-AD72

Ladies and Gentlemen:

We the undersigned national organizations together representing hundreds of
millions of consumers in the United States wish to have our views considered on
the proposed regulation under consideration by the U.S. Department of
Transportation on “Enhancing Airline Passenger Protections.”

In general, our organizations support DOT’s taking an activist role in issuing
regulations that protect airline passengers during long tarmac delays, that
assure that air travelers will receive timely and accurate information from
airlines when there are flight delays, and that provide for the effective
enforceability of DOT requirements directly by passengers in state courts on
understandable provisions in airline Contracts of Carriage, along with an
activist DOT enforcement program.  Thus we support the proposals in the NPRM but
believe they should be strengthened.

Specifically, we are opposed to the DOT concept that would turn Federal
regulatory authority over to individual airlines -- who would each decide how
much protection to offer airline passengers stuck on airline aircraft at
airports for many hours.  In lieu of setting minimum Federal standards for
airlines to provide water, food, working restrooms, comfortable cabin
temperatures and an option to deplane when it is safe to do so, DOT is proposing
to let each U.S. airline set its own guidelines without any Federal review and
approval.


National Consumer Groups, 19 March 2009, Page 2 of 2
Notice of Proposed Rule Making:  Enhancing Airline Passenger Protections

Reference:	14 CFR Parts 234, 253, 259, and 399
Docket No. DOT-OST-2007-0022
RIN No. 2105-AD72



We support the recommendations of FlyersRights.org in the extensive comments
they filed on March 9 on each of the sections of the NPRM.  

Thank you for considering our views on this important consumer issue. Please
contact Ed Mierzwinski at U.S. PIRG with questions (edm@pirg.org or 202-546-9707).

Sincerely,


Linda Sherry
Director National Priorities
Consumer Action

Travis Plunkett
Legislative Director
Consumer Federation of America

Ellen Bloom
Federal Advocacy Director
Consumers Union

Sally Greenberg
Executive Director
National Consumers League

Edmund Mierzwinski
Consumer Program Director and Senior Fellow
U.S. PIRG

Title: Anonymous
Comment: THANK YOU.  HOORAY for Passenger Rights. Don't let the airlines wiggle out using the escape clauses.

Title: Terry Lloyd
Comment: This rule is fair to both passengers and the airlines. The airlines poor perfromance in this area, and unwillingness to do the right thing has brought this regulation upon thmeselves.

Title: Peter Van Arkens
Comment:
I am encouraged by this legislation, but there are still too many loopholes. One of the criteria states "that if the control tower deems the return of a plane to be disruptive to normal airport operations, then that individual in the control tower can deny the plane a return to a gate." To the average traveler, we would never be informed of the real reason why the long delay, but the wording on this opens up a whole new set of issues, including the opportunity for collusion between the airlines and the control tower staff, where this excuse can be used on a regular basis and we the people, have nothing to say about it unless one goes into a very deep (and expensive) investigation as to why the control tower made this call. It's not tight enough, so it needs to be revisited again and reworded, in my opinion, so as to offer more transparency as opposed to "the decision was made and cannot be changed" method of operations. Too often we, the paying public, are herded into an area where we are simply told that this is the way it is and if you do not agree, you can write your state representative or Congressman (or woman) and voice your opinion. But, we all know that this usually doesn't too far and most of us do not have enough time at our disposal to chase this down. let's protect the high airfare-paying public from the very beginning and making this legislation a lot tighter, so there are no misunderstandings or surprises and that we are all working off the same sheet of music, please.

Thank you@

Title: Jeff Hall
Comment:
YES!!! Thank you for the three hour limit for airlines to hold passengers hostage! Thank you for the large penalties imposed if they attempt to go beyond three hours!!!
Thank you!

Title: Khalil Urfali
Comment: This is excellent, and long overdue. Airline passenger protections as they currently stand are weak and mostly meaningless and this new development is a great step towards creating a more meaningful set of rules protection consumers. Congratulations and well done!!!!!

Title: Michael McManus
Comment:
I hope this company is for real and not a ploy (scam) to make money from out-of-
work pilots.  An application fee of $50.00, with 500 apps (claimed by company) a 
week can equal a take of $25,000 a week and $100K a month.  In today's job 
market that would be a new low and nearly as bad as the Madoff scam, but not in 
total dollars.  
It costs a serious amount of cash to operate a 747 coast-to-coast in fuel.  Let's 
not forget all the other costs associated in running an airline.

Title: George Marshall Worthington
Organization Name: World Foundation for Medical Research and Prevention

Title: Karen Sue Marshall
Comment:
The Honorable Mary Peters
Secretary
U.S. Department of Transportation
1200 New Jersey Ave., SE
Washington, DC 20590

RE: Docket DOT-OST 2008-0252

Dear Madam Secretary:

Having been furloughed from American Airlines nearly six years and facing the 
potential of having my rights to return to work expire, I am urging you to seek job 
assurances from American Airlines when considering their application for anti-trust 
immunity with its   partner British Airways.

While other carriers have received anti-trust immunity, this one is unique.   
American Airlines still has thousands of workers on lay off as a result of its DOT 
approved merger with TWA and the events of 9/11.

These workers deserve to have consideration and assurances they will remain on 
the recall list, in exchange for any immunity granted by the Department of 
Transportation.

I urge you to ensure that any agreements reached include provisions and oversight 
to protect the interest of these workers in this time of economic uncertainty. 

Sincerely,
 
Karen Marshall
Furloughed AA Flight Attendant

Title: Sandra Lynn Skaggs
Comment:
As a tax paying citizen, I am asking that the government does not give American 
Airlines any special considerations until they do the right thing by the furloughed 
TWA Flight Attendants.  There are many of us, some with 20yrs or more of 
service, still on furlough.  American Airlines would love to see us disappear, well 
we won't, please help us in our fight for unlimited recall rights. 


DO THE RIGHT THING...............................

Thanking you in advance,
Sandra L. Skaggs, Furloughed ex-TWA Flight Attendant

Title: Danny J. Burgin
Comment:
I do not understand why granting these two carriers antitrust immunity to 
coordinate air service is mired in the mud at the DOT. The DOT granted other 
major U.S. carriers immunity years ago, but continues to subjugate American to 
financial discrimination. You need to be helping the U.S. traveler move around the 
globe seamlessly by allowing ALL U.S. carriers to compete. This smacks of 
politics and favoritism. You do not help me, the traveler, by putting restrictions on 
a deregulated market. British Airways is not buying control of American so why is 
the DOT trying to restrict our options. Not approving the merger does nothing to 
change the status quo in London’s Heathrow airport while approving it might 
actually open some slots that could be had by others. Air service is expensive for 
a multitude of reasons. One of those reasons should not be the onerous 
application of government bureaucracy.

Danny Burgin
2817 Meadow Glen Drive
Flower Mound, TX 75022

Title: Martie M. Hambas
Comment:
I am an America Airlines employee on furlough facing a future of uncertainty 
because of American Airlines's failed promise in 2001 during the TWA purchase; 
to merge the two groups in a fair and equitable way. I was stapled to the bottom of 
the entire groups seniority list even though I had been hired in 1979.
I along with my family ,comprised of six children, watched as I became 
unemployed after American accepted the grant money afforded them for the down 
turn in business caused by 9/11. I had first been forced to commute to St. Louis 
from New York to continue to work, before being laid off while, Flight Attendancts 
with 2 years of seniority retained their jobs and replaced mine ; first in New York, 
and then in St. Louis solely because they were hired initially by American Airlines.
All other airline employers that accepted funds from our federal government, and 
therefore generated from our tax dollars, have granted their work groups recall 
rights before they will begin to hire off the street  when business improves, all I 
ask is that you tie this requirement to American's approval for this Alliance 
Agreement and ensure that future jobs in the US won't be lost as well..
Sincerely,
Martie M. Hambas

Title: Francine J. Waskiwicz
Comment:
Dear Madam Secretary,
I have been a flight attendant for almost 40 years.  When AA purchased TWA, the 
company and the union placed us on the bottom of the seniority list.  As a 
consequence, I was laid off for 4 years while others with 1 year seniority were still 
flying.  This in itself is a travesty and should be addressed.  However, the union and 
company are negotiating and implementing ways to increase furloughs and prevent the 
thousands who are still awaiting recall to fall off the list.
If it is not possible for the government to step in and give the TWA flight attendants their 
rightful seniority, please at least extend the recall rights for those of us on the street and 
those of us who may be soon.  By the way, we are all over 40 years old and many are 
in our 50's and 60's. 
There should be unlimited recall rights.  We lost most of our retirement with Carl Ichan 
and need this job.

Thank you,
Francine Waskowicz

Title: Takona Eileen Scauflaire
Comment:
American Airlines has not dealt fairly with the employees they left behind when 
allowed to merge with TWA.  They made assurances to regulators about keeping 
the employees as well as the routes and then layed off 100% of the flight 
attendants and over 80% of the rest of them.  They also caused a lot of disruption 
for consumers when they abandoned many routes and cut the St Louis hub 
drastically after the same merger.  Regulators must get cooperation from AA to 
make sure that all former TWA employees stay on the recall list until the company 
is able to use them (like the pilots.)  In addition allowing these companies to 
cooperate should not come at the detriment of American jobs or consumers.

Title: Nancy Dietrich
Comment:
I was furloughed from TW/AA after 23 years.  I am currently working for AE and 
making less money now than I was in 1982 at Ozark Airlines.  I need my job at 
AA back!  This potential agreement threatens my eventual recall.  Please see that 
we are not further harmed by this action.  I am 55 years old and would like to fly at 
my previous rate of pay for several more years.  Thank you.

Title: Monica Lane
Comment:
i am one of the many former twa people still out of my job after 6 years as a result 
of american airlines acquiring twa.  please please please don't let more us jobs fall 
by the wayside.  as a condition of anti trust immunity for american airlines and 
british airways, please ensure that language is included to extend the recall rights 
to indefinite and unlimited for those of us still out on the street with american 
airlines.  thank you.  monica lane

Title: Carol Harvey
Comment:
The Honorable Mary Peters
Secretary
U.S. Department of Transportation
1200 New Jersey Ave., SE
Washington, DC 20590

RE: Docket DOT-OST 2008-0252

Dear Madam Secretary:

As one of thousands of furloughed American Airlines flight attendants still layed off 
for nearly six years since 9-11, hear our plea.  We are fast approaching the time 
where our rights to return to work expire. I am asking you to seek job assurances 
from American Airlines when considering their application for anti-trust immunity 
with its partner British Airways.

While other carriers have received anti-trust immunity, this one is unique.   
American Airlines still has thousands of workers on lay off as a result of its DOT 
approved merger with TWA and the events of 9/11. 

Senator Claire McCaskill is very familiar with the unfortunate circumstances of  
these former TWA workers with airline careers crippled by 9-11 and the actions of 
American Airlines, and its flight attendant union. Many with over 20 years of 
experience, still desire the chance to finish their careers and regain the ability to 
retire with pensions and benefits they worked hard for.

These workers deserve to have consideration and assurances they will remain on 
the recall list, in exchange for any immunity granted by the Department of 
Transportation.

I urge you to ensure that any agreements reached include provisions and oversight 
to protect the interest of these workers in this time of economic uncertainty. 

Sincerely,
Carol L. Harvey

Title: Maria Stallings
Comment:
The Honorable Ray H. LaHood 
Secretary
U.S. Department of Transportation
1200 New Jersey Ave., SE
Washington, DC 20590

RE: Docket DOT-OST 2008-0252

Dear Mr. Secretary:

Having been furloughed from American Airlines nearly six years and facing the 
potential of having my rights to return to work expire, I am urging you to seek job 
assurances from American Airlines when considering their application for anti-trust 
immunity with its partner British Airways.

While other carriers have received anti-trust immunity, this one is unique. 
American Airlines still has thousands of workers on lay off as a result of its DOT 
approved merger with TWA and the events of 9/11.

These workers deserve to have consideration and assurances they will remain on 
the recall list, in exchange for any immunity granted by the Department of 
Transportation.

I urge you to ensure that any agreements reached include provisions and oversight 
to protect the interest of these workers in this time of economic uncertainty. 

Sincerely,
Maria Stallings

Title: Deborah Nightingale
Comment:
I am urging you to seek job assurances from American Airlines when considering 
its application for anti-trust immunity with its partner British Airways.

While other carriers have received anti-trust immunity, this one is unique.   
American Airlines still has thousands of workers on lay off as a result of its DOT 
approved merger with TWA and the events of 9/11.

These workers along with those who were only recently recalled deserve to have 
consideration and assurances that they will remain employed and/or on the recall 
list, in exchange for any immunity granted by the Department of Transportation.

Our country is already faced with many thousands who are unemployed. 
I urge you to ensure that any agreements reached include provisions and oversight 
to protect the interest of the AA employees, including those waiting to be recalled 
to their jobs in this time of economic uncertainty.

Title: Tracy Kay Searles
Comment:
The Honorable Ray H. LaHood 
Secretary
U.S. Department of Transportation
1200 New Jersey Ave., SE
Washington, DC 20590

RE: Docket DOT-OST 2008-0252

Dear Mr. Secretary:

Please HELP.  The 2 year extension that wonderful Claire McCaskill gained for us 
TWA'ers is going to expire in approximately one year.  We have a website that 
keeps us going, that gives us hope, that keeps us united.  It is on myfamily.com.  
We have had it since we were furloughed.  We are ladies and gentleman in our 
30,s 40's and 50's still missing our airline career which we offered our 
professionalism and loyalty to for many years.  As you know, the "fair and 
equitable" treatment by American Airlines (quote:  "Two great airlines, one great 
company") --- except they stapled us to the bottom - below 20 year olds that had 
2 years with the company (I had 20 plus) when furloughed.  I miss my job and 
have grieved for it.  I was layed off shortly before my husband was diagnosed with 
terminal cancer.  Not only was my cherished career taken from me - also Bob, my 
husband.  I can't get him back, but I want my job at American Airlines back.  
Please HELP.


Having been furloughed from American Airlines nearly six years and facing the 
potential of having my rights to return to work expire, I am urging you to seek job 
assurances from American Airlines when considering their application for anti-trust 
immunity with its partner British Airways.

While other carriers have received anti-trust immunity, this one is unique. 
American Airlines still has thousands of workers on lay off as a result of its DOT & 
DOJ approved merger with TWA and the events of 9/11.

These workers deserve to have consideration and assurances they will remain on 
the recall list, in exchange for any immunity granted by the Department of 
Transportation.

I urge you to ensure that any agreements reached include provisions and oversight 
to protect the interest of these workers in this time of economic uncertainty. 

Sincerely,

Tracy K Searles
TWA Payroll Number  65090
314-496-7623

Title: Maria Delgado O'Kane
Comment:
The Honorable Ray H. LaHood 
Secretary
U.S. Department of Transportation
1200 New Jersey Ave., SE
Washington, DC 20590

RE: Docket DOT-OST 2008-0252

Mr. Secretary:

I am an American Airlines flight attendant on furlough. I was furloughted by AA in 
November 2002 after their acquisition of TWA where I had 15 years seniority.  
American Airlines still has thousands of workers on lay off as a result of its DOT & 
DOJ approved merger with TWA and the events of 9/11. This merger effectively 
wiped-out decades of hard-earned seniority for all TWA employees. 

I am urging you to seek job assurances from American Airlines when considering 
their application for anti-trust immunity with its partner British Airways. My recall 
rights will expire in Nov. 2009, and will have lost the 16 years I have invested in my 
airline career and retirement benefits. American Airlines will go on to hire 
inexperienced cheaper workforce and thus cheat former workers of their 
livelihoods, careers and their retirements.
 
These workers deserve to have consideration and assurances they will remain on 
the recall list, in exchange for any immunity granted by the Department of 
Transportation. I urge you to ensure that any agreements reached include 
provisions and oversight to protect the interest of these workers in this time of 
economic uncertainty. 

Sincerely,
Maria D. O'Kane

Title: Gerald Wesley Hubbart
Comment:
The Honorable Ray H. LaHood 
Secretary
U.S. Department of Transportation
1200 New Jersey Ave., SE
Washington, DC 20590

RE: Docket DOT-OST 2008-0252

Dear Mr. Secretary,

I am one of the very unfortunate TWA flight attendants who was furloughed from 
American Airlines more than six years ago.  I continue to face the potential of 
having my rights to return to work expire, even though I HAD NEARLY 17 YEARS 
EXPERIENCE.  Therefore, I am urging you to seek job assurances from American 
Airlines when considering their application for anti-trust immunity with its partner 
British Airways.

While other carriers have received anti-trust immunity, THIS ONE IS UNIQUE. 
American Airlines still has thousands of workers on furlough as a result of its DOT 
& DOJ approved merger with TWA and the events of 9/11.

I and ALL OF MY COWORKERS DESERVE to have CONSIDERATION and 
ASSURANCES that we will remain on the recall list, IN EXCHANGE FOR any 
IMMUNITY granted by the Department of Transportation.

I URGE YOU to ensure that any agreements reached include provisions and 
oversight  TO PROTECT THE INTERESTS of me and my coworkers in this time of 
economic uncertainty. 

Sincerely,

(Gerald Wesley) Wes Hubbart

Dear Sirs,

    Please support the American Airlines.flight attendants who have still not
returned to work and extend the recall for us.  I was a flight attendat for 26
years with TWA and have not been to work in almost six years after the merger
with AA. I was laid off after the horrendous event of 911.   I would like my job

extension of recall so there is that hope to return
                            Patricia McBride

RE: Docket DOT-OST 2008-0252

Dear Mr. Secretary:

Having been furloughed from American Airlines nearly six years and facing the 
potential of having my rights to return to work expire, I am urging you to seek job 
assurances from American Airlines when considering their application for anti-trust 
immunity with its   partner British Airways.

While other carriers have received anti-trust immunity, this one is unique.   
American Airlines still has thousands of workers on lay off as a result of its DOT 
approved merger with TWA and the events of 9/11.

These workers deserve to have consideration and assurances they will remain on 
the recall list, in exchange for any immunity granted by the Department of 
Transportation.

I urge you to ensure that any agreements reached include provisions and oversight 
to protect the interest of these workers in this time of economic uncertainty. 

Sincerely,

Lisa Woznicki
American Airlines Furloughed Flight Attendant

Title: Yvonne Perano
Comment:
The Honorable Ray H. LaHood
Secretary
U.S. Department of Transportation
1200 New Jersey Ave., SE
Washington, DC 20590

RE: Docket DOT-OST 2008-0252

Dear Mr. Secretary,

I am asking that before this anti-trust immunity is even entertained by our 
government, that you review the very real possibility of even more job losses within 
the US airline industry. We have suffered unprecedented layoffs since 9/11 and 
any agreements with foreign countries and U.S. companies should be certain to 
include protections with regard to U.S. workers. 

American Airlines already employs hundreds of foreign nationals, even though 
there are over a thousand U.S. citizens currently furloughed at American that 
could use those jobs and contribute to our country's tax base. We must have job 
security assurances from American Airlines before they are permitted to enter into 
any agreements with foreign countries or carriers.

I am a former TWA flight attendant with 30 years of experience who has been laid 
off twice since 9/11. Of approximately 4,000 former TWA flight attendants at the 
time of American Airline's acquisition (which was sanctioned by our own 
government), there are presently only 250 who are actively flying . 1,261 are 
currently furloughed. Most of my fellow furloughees have worked 25 years or more 
in the airline industry and deserve to have consideration and assurances that they 
will remain employed and/or on the recall list if this anti-trust immunity is granted.

Our country is already faced with many thousands who are unemployed. I urge 
you to ensure that any agreements reached will include provisions and oversight 
to protect the interest of the American Airlines employees, including those waiting 
to be recalled to their jobs.

Thank you for your consideration.

Sincerely,

Yvonne Perano

Title: Hubert Horan
Comment: The attached file contains public comments in response to the Joint Applicants Supplemental Comments of 8 September

Title: Samuel Chan
Comment: I strongly urge the Department of Transport to give antitrust immunity to the airlines involved. It is totally unfair for oneworld alliance to be left out when the two other alliances, namely Skyteam and Star, already have such benefits. If it is not awarded, I am unsure if oneworld would survive in this very competitive environment. Otherwise, if not awarded, I hope DOT would take back all the immunity approvals and make it fairer. As a consumer, I would very much like these changes for better convenience and fares.

Title: Samuel Chan
Comment: I also wish to dismiss Virgin Atlantic's objection to this immunity. Virgin Atlantic has long been a close partner of Star Alliance (through codeshares), thus would rather have Star have these benefits. Therefore, I think it is unreasonable for DOT not to give antitrust immunity to the airlines involved. The benefits far outweigh the negatives raised by Virgin.

Title: Christian W. Simmons
Comment:
VPSI, Inc., a private provider of public transportation and the nation's premier 
provider of commuter vanpools, wishes to comment DOT staff for the proposed 
rulemaking to implement the eligibility changes to TIFIA required by SAFTETEA-
LU.

VPSI requests clarification regarding the eligibility changes outlined in Section 
80.7.  Pursuant to the authorizing sections of SAFTETEA-LU, the NPR indicates 
that eligible projects must be contained within an approved STIP at the time the 
credit instrument with DOT is entered into.  What the NPR does not cover is 
situations where the project may not be required to be contained within a STIP.  
The question of staff is whether they plan to cover such a situation within their final 
rule.

One scenario that could cover this situation is a request of capital assistance from 
a private provider of public transportation that provides an interstate service.  Given 
that the service covers multiple states, and the capital provision is coming from a 
private provider, this type of situation may not be contained within a STIP.  Does 
DOT plan on covering this scenario in the final rule?

A second scenario that might apply to this situation is a request of capital 
assistance from a private provider of public transportation where operations in any 
one particular state may not meet eligibility thresholds, but that their collective 
operations may meet those thresholds but for the STIP requirement.  Does DOT 
plan on addressing projects of national scope that do not fit within current planning 
requirements under the final rule?

Title: Marvin Dean
Comment:
Kern Minority & Black Contractors Assiocation 
Assist SBE/MBE/WBE/DBE/SEC-3 get certificate
Get Ready-Able & Quaified to do Public Sector Contracting
We assist local agencies thoughout San Joaquin Valley& caltran commenting on

We believe the Disadvantage Business Enterprise program & goal is not strong

We will not oppose DOT 3year DBE approval recommendation, but request that
