Title: Roger E. Bierbaum (Iowa Department of Transportation)
Comment:
Federal Register: April 8, 2009; Docket OST-2009 DBE Potential Program 
Improvements in 49 CFR Part 26
 
This NPRM proposes changes on 5 matters:
    1.  Counting of items obtained by a DBE subcontractor from its prime 
contractor -   The current DBE regulations doesn't allow the counting of supplies 
and materials purchased from the prime contractor.  This may put a contractor at 
a competitive disadvantage bidding a project where they are the only supplier of a 
product needed by subcontractors (e.g. the contractor owns all the ready mixes in 
a geographic area).  Other bidders can count the full DBE quote for subcontract 
(including materials) but the contractor with the ready mix must deduct the cost of 
concrete sold to the DBE firm.  The Iowa Department of Transportation (DOT) feels 
the prime contractor should be allowed to count the cost of material/supplies sold 
to a DBE firm IF the DBE firm was not required to purchase the materials from the 
prime AND the cost of the materials sold to the DBE firm was at the same price 
the prime was quoting the cost of these materials to other contractors bidding the 
project.  We feel the biggest potential for abuse is in areas where the recipient is 
getting only one bidder and a contractor could increase their DBE commitment by 
artificially increasing the cost of materials sold to DBE firms.  We feel a recipient 
could independently check that the contractor was not overcharging DBE firms or 
the recipient could have a process where they react to complaints from other 
contractors as a method to ensure a contractor is not overcharging DBE firms to 
increase their DBE commitments.

    2.  Unbundling of contracts into smaller contracts – The Iowa DOT agrees it is 
in the best interest of our construction industry to have small contracts for which 
small contractors can complete and develop into larger contractors.  However we 
do not believe the US DOT should mandate it to their recipients. Rather we believe 
that the US DOT should provide guidance to recipients and expect some 
justification if the recipient is not offering some contracts for small contractors to 
complete for.
    3.  Improvement to the DBE application form – The NPRM suggestion is to 
make the standard DBE application form more comprehensive so individual 
recipients are not asking for additional information from applicants.  The NPRM 
also suggests changes to make the application form simpler to complete by DBE 
applicants. While the Iowa DOT supports both suggestions they seem to run 
counter to each other.  The Iowa DOT supports the formation of a task group to 
provide recommendations on a universal, comprehensive DBE Application Form 
which would be used by all recipients without additional information needed from 
the DBE applicant by individual recipients.  The NRPM also suggests recipients 
consider factors other than the $750,000 PNW for economically disadvantaged.  If 
other factors are to be considered the Iowa DOT feels they need to be consistent 
among all recipients rather than having each recipient develop their own factors for 
economically disadvantaged.  Therefore the other factors for recipients to consider 
should be listed in the regulations.
    
4.  Program Oversight - The NPRM suggests several changes to the regulations to 
facilitate interstate certification.  The Iowa DOT believes the DBE program has one 
set of certification requirements.  Therefore we feel that the submittal of the 
identical certification materials to multiple states is burdensome for DBE 
applicants.  We feel if all recipients follow the same DBE certification 
requirements then a firm certified by one recipient should be certified by all other 
recipients.  Therefore we believe a unitary certification system operated by the US 
DOT should be put into place.  If this is not possible to have one certification 
process by the US DOT then a reciprocal DBE certifications between recipients 
should be implemented with a challenge process that allows other recipients to 
challenge a certification which should ensure a recipient does not incorrectly 
certify a firm that doesn’t meet the federal DBE requirements.    

5.  Termination of a DBE for convenience - Some recipients allows the prime 
contractor to terminate a DBE for convenience once the prime contractor has 
achieved their DBE goal.  The Iowa DOT believes the contractor makes DBE 
commitments to the named DBE firms at the time of award and each named DBE 
firm must complete their commitment to each firm for the dollar amount they have 
agreed to as part of the prime contractor obligations. Therefore a contractor should 
not be able to cancel a commitment to a DBE firm just because they have used 
other DBE firms for work on the contract and have already exceeded the dollar 
amount of their overall DBE commitment.  A second proposal would require the 
prime contractor to subcontract additional work added to the contract to the DBE 
firm who performed the original work for this item on the contract.   The Iowa DOT 
feels DBE usage on change orders (e.g. additional work) should be addressed on 
an individual contract basis rather than having the federal regulations mandate 
additional regulations which may not fit every situation.  We feel it is the 
recipient’s responsibility to achieve their annual DBE goals and they should be 
given flexibility on how they achieve it.

Title: George Leonard Harris
Comment:
1) Counting of DBE credits- This is acceptable as long as the credits are not
provided or counted for other Federal or State programs. They must be unique
credits and once credited, can't be used again

2) Way to encourage recipients to break up contracts - Many studies point out
that by bundling products and services, costs and delivery terms increase. This
should be a large selling point to break up requirements. The basis of decisions
in this area is a thorough market analysis combined with a detailed spend
profile and supplier capability matrix. Recipents can also be required to
evaluate breakout as part of their procurement planning activity.

3) Improving the forms- No comment but the number of fields should be reduced.
What about having the applicant certify just like contractors certify their
business size. That would do away with the form altogether. Check out the State
of Maryland and State of Connecticut processes.

4) Improving Program Oversight- Evaluate the procurement plans for contracts
over $100,000 to ensure that the recipients have evaluated and documented
breakout opportunities; Use self surveys for field compliance; Test program
compliance on project sites; Ensure that the recipients are documented how they
are developing their annual plans; Interview DBEs doing business with recipients
to confirm programs; Look at trends and if they are improving, ask for
corrective actions; an on-line compliance tool can be created to track all 450
grantees

5) Reducing burdens- Reciprocal arrangements should be in place such that if one
State DOT has approved the DBE, it is accepted in all States. Requirements to
have DBEs meet requirements of all 50 States based on narrow differences in
State programs is extremely counterproductive.

Title: Mid-Ohio Regional Planning Commission
Comment:
The Mid-Ohio Regional Planning Commission, an MPO, is providing comments on 
the "facilitating interstate certification" issue.

We strongly favor a DBE certification national reciprocity (within the existing UCP 
network), perhaps where the state that the firm is based in, is solely reponsibe for 
certification (that is then accepted by the other states).  In that the DBE 
certification standards that the states (UCPs) apply should be relatively-consistent 
nationwide (is based on the same set of DOT rules), a single certification of DBEs 
in the U.S. seems to make sense.  Having a state by state DBE certification 
requirement or even a reciprocity agreement among a few states (little sign that 
states are interested in this, in any case) unnecessarily imposes an additional 
burden on DBE firms, and others.

This is an issue for us because our contracts (where we require consultant 
services) are typically for professional, specialized technical work, and are 
relatively small, in the under $400,000 federal dollars range.  Many of the prime 
contractors that we require are not located in Ohio and, in turn, the primes often 
select DBEs (subcontractors) that are also located in other states and regions of 
the country.  Often, to meet the MPO DBE goal, more than one DBE firm is 
included in the contract work.  Under current rules, it is our understanding, that to 
get DBE firm participation 'credit,' we are required to have these DBEs get certified 
in Ohio, if they are not already.

We feel that this puts an unnecessary extra burden on the DBEs and on the 
prime contractor (and on us), for the relatively small, non-construction contracts 
that we have.  This is in cases where the prime is already putting in the extra 
effort to meet or exceed our contract DBE goal (usually 12%).  We would like to 
be free to accept DBE certfications from other states, and eliminate the step of 
getting Ohio UCP certification (unless the firm is based in Ohio).

Again, one way to do this might be to make the home state of a firm provide 
certification, as the home state UCPs are probably in the best position to 
determine eligibility and to keep DBE status current (perhaps, eventually, DOT 
could maintain a single database of all eligible DBEs, accessible via the DOT 
website).  There could then be a mandatory presumption (without additional 
documentation required) that the firm is certified per DOT requirements.  This 
would simplify the certification process and delays to potential DBEs, and for 
others involved in the process.

If states want to be able to verify the certification documents provided by a DBE 
firm, the state that did the certification could be required to provide the application 
package, and an opportunity for contesting the certification provided.  If it turns out 
that some states are not performing the certifications per DOT requirements 
(perceived uneven quality of certifications), this could be addressed on an 
individual state basis.

Thanks for the opportunity for comment.

Title: Outreach Process Partners
Comment:
Dear Sir/Madam:

This purpose of this letter is to comment on the proposed rulemaking related to 
the Department of Transportation’s DBE Program—specifically the Revised DBE 
Certification Application and Personal Net Worth Statement.  

Outreach Process Partners, Inc. (OPP) is a woman-owned small business that 
participates in the DBE program and we appreciate the opportunity to comment.  
Specifically:

Date of Birth and Retirement Savings: We agree strongly that date of birth should 
be included in the application and a reasonable, age-appropriate allowance for 
retirement savings be excluded from the Personal Net Worth (PNW) calculation.  
Under the current program, all 401-k, IRA and similar retirement savings accounts 
are calculated in PNW.   This gives an unfair advantage to younger individuals and 
individuals with pension plans.  For individuals with pension plans, only the 
income from the pension is considered—not the financial value of the pension 
itself.  These pensions are typically life-long and adjust upward with Cost of 
Living.  To purchase a similar annuity plan would cost hundreds of thousands of 
dollars.  Likewise, including retirement savings in the PNW give an advantage to 
younger applicants (with less experience) over older applicants who have 
responsibly saved for their retirement. Our recommendation is to develop a 
reasonable calculation of responsible retirement savings based on age—and 
exclude that amount from the PNW total.

Overall Household PNW:  We also agree that overall household assets should be 
considered in the PNW. As you mentioned, the current program encourages the 
titling of assets in other household member’s names. Likewise, focusing on 
spouses is yet another disincentive for couples to get married in our society.  The 
current rate of births of unwed babies in the U.S. is approaching 50%.  This is 
fueled in part by policies that penalize marriage—as this one does.  We believe 
the overall assets of the household—individuals living at the same address, 
regardless of family ties—should be factored into the PNW.  This would level the 
playing field between those who are married and those who are simply living 
together, especially if they have been living together for over a year (clearly a 
committed relationship). If an individual claiming disadvantage is living in a palace 
with all of his/her bills paid, they are not economically disadvantaged—in fact they 
are quite advantaged over the rest of us with bills to worry about while trying to 
make a business succeed.  In this model, the total household assets should not 
exceed 2X the individual PNW limit.

Thank you for the opportunity to respond to this announcement. We appreciate 
the opportunity to participate in the DBE program and your efforts to make the 
program fairer.  Please do not hesitate to contact me if you have any questions or 
require further clarification.

Sincerely,



Janice Roper-Graham, ABC
President

Title: Washington State Department Transportation
Submitter Representative: Stephen T. Reinmuth, Chief of Staff
Comment: Attached are comments from the Washington State Department Transportation.

Title: Ane Coyle,Esq
Comment:
June 30, 2009

Via electronic submission and mail

Mr. Ray LaHood, Secretary
Dept. Of Transportation
1200 New Jersey Ave SE
West Bldg., Ground Flr.
Room W12-140
Washington D.C. 20590-001

RE: DBE Program; Potential Program Improvements 
       Docket No OST-20009 
       Agency: Office of the Secretary, DOT

Dear Mr. LaHood, 

Thank for the opportunity to provide comment on the proposed rulemaking
regarding 49 CFR Part 26. As an attorney, I have represented small, socially and
economically disadvantaged businesses seeking participation as a DBE in
federally-assisted contracts in all but two of our nation’s states. Thus, I have
developed a great deal of practical experience and knowledge of the
administration of Part 26 and its effectiveness at leveling the competitive
playing field for DBEs seeking participation in such contracts.	

PROPERLY EMPHASIZE PART 26 OBJECTIVES REGARDING INCREASED DBE COMPETITIVENESS 

While the Objectives of Part 26 include ensuring that only qualified DBEs are
certified for participation in this program, the program’s written objectives
place much more emphasis on increasing a DBE’s ability and opportunity to
compete for federally-assisted contracts. In practice, however, recipients
throughout the nation place the largest amount of their resources on the
certification objective, with post-contract-award compliance enforcement drawing
the second largest share of a program’s energies. The “playing field”—or RFP
solicitation and pre-award competitive process, is largely ignored. Given this
context, it is not surprising that there are no studies that present a
statistically significant improvement in the competitiveness of DBEs for
DOT/FAA-assisted contracts, much less any study that concludes that any
improvement can be directly attributed to the implementation of Part 26.

In terms of competition for the award of a contract, the only real DBE program
mechanism designed to effect the “playing field” is the program’s monitoring of
a Prime’s “good faith effort” in complying with the contract’s “DBE
Participation Goal”. However, Primes and program administrators throughout the
nation engage in a myriad of practices that result in the appearance of
compliance with Part 26 regulations, but that, in substance, circumvent the
intent of the program and regulations. 

Some of those practices, as engaged in by Primes, include:

1)	Submitting “Good Faith Certification” forms which fail to list all DBEs that
presented themselves to the Prime as Ready, Willing, and Able (RWA) DBEs for the
project. Thus, when a DBE program administrator contacts the DBE’s on the Good
Faith Certification form, the administrator is never made aware of other DBEs
that expressed to that Prime its interest in participating in the project/contract.
2)	Engaging in negotiations with, and obtaining commitments from, DBE firms even
though its (the Prime’s) intent is to submit a Proposal with a “Good Faith”
waiver request, and with the intent of submitting a proposal that omits the
committed DBE.
3)	Sending “blast” solicitations of participation to DBE’s whose business is in
no way related to the subject matter of the project.
4)	Rejecting interested DBEs on the grounds that:
a)	“The DBE is redundant to the team”—i.e. that the Prime will go with a NON-DBE
to obtain the services or materials provided by the DBE. This justification is a
blatant rejection of the overall intent of Part 26, and, ergo, ought to be a
presumption of non-compliance with Part 26;
b)	“The selection committee will only count black-owned DBEs towards the DBE
participation goal.” This reason is given even where no properly-supported
race-specific goal has been created, as in the City of Birmingham;
c)	“The selection committee will only count local DBE’s towards the DBE
participation goal.” This reasoning is farcical given that projects which
trigger DBE program requirements are usually sought after by Primes and DBEs
from across the region, and even from across the nation; and
d)	“The RFP mandates consideration of only DBEs that are on the local DBE
list.”This justification is given even where the RFP clearly allows for
out-of-state DBE participation in the contract (which, by the way, is allowed on
most of the RFPs that I have read).
 
These types of practices are common throughout the industry, and are used to
such an extent that Primes everywhere are engaging in conduct that strongly
suggests that they consider compliance with DBE program requirements, especially
at the contract competition phase, as an optional rule of play on this playing
field. 

Thus, it is critical to the substantive implementation of Part 26 that DBE
programs close these gaps by either requiring the Prime to pull DBEs from a
national list of DBEs or by maintaining a reporting mechanism whereby all DBEs
can learn of RFPs and all interested DBEs can register their interest in
participating in any given project, or by requiring both activities. By
requiring both, a DBE compliance officer can refer to the “Interest
Registration” list to use in the verification of a Prime’s good faith efforts,
and Primes will be less able to avoid real compliance with Part 26. 

RECOGNIZE THE CHARACTERISTICS OF THE PLAYING FIELD IN THE ADMINISTRATION OF PART 26

Please also consider the following situational factors that contribute to
reducing the effectiveness of Part 26 in achieving its “playing field” objectives:

1)	Participants in federally-assisted contracts come from a regional and a
national pool of contractors and sub-contractors. Yet, DBE programs base their
disparity studies and “market area” on a much smaller geographic area. This
basis, and the recipient’s resulting “pool” of DBEs, falls egregiously short of
a real or accurate reflection of the actual playing field for these contracts.
To compound the problem, project administrators occasionally require a currently
certified out-of-state DBE to be “in-state” certified before the RFP submittal
deadline. These practices demonstrate that being a certified DBE hardly gets the
disadvantaged business unto the playing field, much less able to move about it
with the other competitors.
2)	Primes are usually large firms that also often have internal marketing
departments with teams of 10, 20, or more individuals to prepare proposals.
Truly small, socially and economically disadvantaged businesses do not have such
resources, and often cannot afford to allocate staff to the writing of
proposals, even though they are competent to deliver on the project. Currently,
I know of no recipient that addresses this situation.
3)	Often Primes further restrict the DBE’s competitiveness by requiring the DBE
to commit exclusively to that Prime and/or prohibit the DBE from participating
in any other Prime’s team. 
4)	Project administrators do not, as an industry practice, allow DBE
sub-contractors to compete independently from non-DBE Primes for portions of a
federally-assisted contract. Further, it is unrealistic for a DBE—especially a
professional services DBE, to spontaneously indicate their interest in a project
by submitting a proposal or cost estimate to a Prime, as the DBE will not be
privy to the Prime’s approach to the project and to the Prime’s intended scope
of work for any necessary team members. Here again, the DBE is ineffective as a
real competitor for any portion of the federally-assisted contract.
5)	Large Non-DBE Primes do not compete for the federally-assisted contracts that
are too small to trigger compliance with Part 26. Yet, project administrators
are not required to consider DBEs participation for these contracts, even though
many DBEs would appreciate increased opportunity to compete for them.

In order give substance to the implementation of Part 26, DBE program
administrators must routinely survey and educate themselves as to the practices
occurring during the RFP process, and must use that information to develop
initiatives that are narrowly tailored to achieve the Part 26 objectives
regarding DBEs’ competitiveness and opportunities.

REQUIRE CERTIFICATION VIA RECIPROCITY

The current practice by ALL recipients of refusing to recognize out-of-state
DBEs imposes an unfair and excessive burden on socially and economically
disadvantaged businesses, and unreasonably restricts the DBEs ability to compete
for any federally-assisted contract in which it is RWA to participate. This
situation must be corrected.

A survey of my own DBE clients demonstrates that Part 26 has done little to
strengthen DBEs’ competiveness for federally-assisted contracts. In fact,
participation in the DBE presents as an unjustifiable cost to the economically
disadvantaged business. I found that, on average, my DBE clients spent $1.80 to
be awarded $1.00 as a DBE on federally-assisted contracts. The survey also
demonstrates that my DBE clients spent an average of 8.5 hours completing the
certification application (excluding site-visit), and an average of $600 in
incidental costs to prepare and submit the application. 

Given that transportation construction projects are not the type to repeat
themselves frequently, contractors and DBEs whose mainstay is transportation
construction must seek work across a wide geographic range. However, even though
the CFR’s allow for certification via reciprocity, only two states in fifty have
offered even a truncated certification process. Not one state offers
certification via reciprocity. Thus, a DBE must submit complete certification
applications to many recipients if it wants to be considered as a DBE
participant for transportation projects occurring throughout its own market area.

This situation is untenable and undermines the entire DBE program. 

Its continued existence is made even more egregious given that the certification
process and form is narrowly prescribed by Part 26 and that recipients are
mandated not to stray from the process or the form. That recipients are allowed
to claim a general distrust of other recipients’ certification process is
unreasonable and shoves the burden of the program on the very entities the
program is designed to benefit: socially and economically disadvantaged businesses.

Certification via reciprocity should be the rule. Further, once certified under
a Part 23 or Part 26 administered program, the DBE should be listed as a
properly certified DBE throughout the nation. It should then be the
responsibility of the recipient to demonstrate cause for requiring submittal of
an application from a properly certified DBE. 

DEVELOP, IMPLEMENT, AND MONITOR A STRONGER OVERSIGHT PROGRAM FOR NON-PRIMARY
RECIPIENTS

Currently, Non-Primary Recipients number in the hundreds once municipalities and
regional transportation organizations are tallied. Yet, even though these
entities are required to comply with Part 26, I rarely find that such a
recipient has substantively met the requirements of the Part. Almost every
recipient-municipality or recipient-regional transportation entity that I have
encountered has either deviated grossly from the Parts’ requirements and
objectives, or has simply wholly failed to meet them. 

Further, it is not uncommon for such a recipient to issue an RFP, yet to make no
information available regarding their DBE program, its staff, its policies, or
its monitoring and enforcement strategies. A recipient’s failure to publish or
to provide public access to any DBE program statements, mechanisms, etc. renders
the recipient’s participation goals easily ignored or manipulated by Primes and
even by project managers, as happened recently in the City of Birmingham.
Further, when the recipient does not advertise information on how, or to whom,
to present concerns about their DBE program, the contract award process, etc.,
this leaves the concerned party with little recourse other than to pursue a
formal complaint or litigation to resolve what may be best resolved informally.
Unfortunately, it is also not uncommon for federal offices that are responsible
for oversight of these recipients to be completely unaware of the recipient’s
non-compliance.

Thus, a comprehensive oversight or auditing program of Non-Primary Recipients’
DBE Program would be instrumental in providing information to recipient DBE
program administrators. Further, every recipient that issues a RFP should be
required to coincidentally publish the entirety of their DBE program policies
and enforcement mechanisms, as well as the contact information for the office or
personnel responsible for processing concerns and complaints, whether formal or
informal. Failure to do so should trigger a timely audit and imposition of
appropriate adjustments.

SUMMARY OF COMMENTS

For the following reasons, current administrative policies and procedures
greatly reduce Part 26’s effectiveness at creating opportunities for DBE
participation in federally-assisted contracts, and impose significant undue
burdens on DBE’s seeking participation in the Part 26 program. 

First, DOT civil rights officers and DBE program administrators across the
country place the majority of their programs’ energies on the certification
process. This practice is at the expense of developing, implementing, and
monitoring policies and procedures which provide substance to Part 26’s other
objectives, especially those intent on leveling the “competitive” playing field
and creating opportunities for DBE involvement in federally-assisted contracts. 

Second, because DBE programs, policies, and administrators fail to implement and
monitor substantive programs aimed at the RFP solicitation process,
non-disadvantaged firms continue to engage in a myriad of techniques that
circumvent DBE participation goals and render the program without substance.

Third, DBE program administrators across the country deviate from the intent and
letter of Part 26’s certification procedures and form. Part 26 creates a
narrowly-tailored certification process that requires use of a specific form.
However, most recipients claim that others’ certification process is so
deficient that they require the DBE to “re-apply” by submitting an entirely new
application. Recognition of Part 26’s focus on uniformity of process and on
assistance to the DBE is obliterated by the failure of every single recipient to
offer certification via reciprocity. 

Fourth, DOT Civil Rights Regional offices have not published nor implemented an
oversight policy or program that specifically regulates the DBE programs of the
hundreds of Non-Primary Recipients of federal transportation monies. These
Non-Primary Recipients are often municipalities or regional transportation
bodies that are also required to comply with Part 26. However, the large
majority of these recipients that I have encountered fail the requirements, and
the objectives, of Part 26, in any number of ways. Further, it is extremely
difficult to find the recipients’ DBE program material or officers’ contact
information, and the intent of Part 26 is often subverted into serving the
recipient’s unique agenda. Thus, Part 26 is rendered without substance in a
large number of areas throughout the country.

To address these concerns, please consider the following broadly described
changes to the administration of Part 26:
1)	Adjust administrative emphases to better encompass all stated objectives of
the programs, giving more balanced attention to the objectives of;
		a) ensuring “nondiscrimination in the award and administration of
                                  DOT- assisted contracts”(§26.1(a)); 
		b) creating “a level playing field on which DBEs can compete fairly for
                                 DOT-assisted contracts” (§26.1(b)); and
		c) removing “barriers to the participation of DBEs in DOT-assisted 		         
                                  contracts”(§26.1(e)).
2)	realize and incorporate a thorough understanding of actual competitive
practices into DBE programs’ enforcement and monitoring procedures;
3)	Require all recipients to honor another recipient’s certification—i.e. for
all DBEs that were properly certified by their home-state, presume certification
via reciprocity is the appropriate path for certification by all other
recipients or DBE programs; and
4)       Implement a comprehensive and public auditing program regarding Non-Primary
Recipients’ DBE programs (such as those required of municipalities and regional
transportation organizations), and make information gleaned from the audits
available to all DBEs and DBE program administrators throughout the country.

CONCLUSION

In conclusion, my experience with Part 26 leads me to conclude that oversight of
this program must occur under the philosophy that the program’s ultimate
objective is not to define the players or to effect the people, but to effect
the process.

Thank you for your consideration of my comments. If you have any questions,
please feel free to contact me at 512-496-0606.

Sincerely, 


Anne Coyle
Attorney at Law

Title: Elizabeth Michelle Nury
Comment:
June 30, 2009

U.S. Department of Transportation
1200 New Jersey Avenue, SE
West Building Ground Floor
Room W12-140
Washington, DC  20590-0001

RE:  	Office of the Secretary, DOT
	Docket Number OST-2009

To Whom It May Concern:

My company, Beth’s Barricades, became a certified DBE through the PaUCP 
program in 2006. I recently submitted my recertification packet to the Allegheny 
County PaUCP office and while completing the Recertification Application, I 
concluded that the program application is outdated. Specifically, the Personal Net 
Worth Statement should be revised to exclude IRA/other retirement account as an 
Asset.   

By placing IRA or other retirement account under the Assets table, the 
Disadvantaged Business Enterprise Program is encouraging business owners to 
consider cashing out their retirement funds and using them as a potential crutch 
for their business.  Why endorse funding a business this way when significant 
lack of retirement funds is a prevalent theme within America today?  

According to the 2008 Retirement Confidence Survey (Employee Benefit Research 
Institute and Matthew Greenwald & Associates, Inc.):
•	Twenty-five percent of women have neither retirement savings nor other 
savings, compared with 18 percent of men.  
•	62% of Men and 63% of Women expect to work for pay in retirement. 
Women highlighted keeping company health insurance and wanting money to 
make ends meet as the main reasons.
•	In recent years, savings outside of pensions has actually been 
negative.  The lack of individual saving outside of pensions is confirmed by the 
2004 Survey of Consumer Finances, which shows the typical household is 
approaching retirement with less than $30,000 of financial assets.     

Within the past 25 years, the retirement landscape has dramatically changed.  
Due to escalating costs, the days of a company taking care of its employees via a 
defined benefit pension plan are gone. Today, employees are encouraged to 
contribute to their primary retirement vehicle, the company sponsored 401(k) plan, 
and pay a portion, if not all of their health care costs. 

In addition, the Federal Government retirement plans, Social Security and 
Medicare, face their own challenges.  Social Security will provide less in the future 
than it does today because of increased retirement age from 65 to 67, and 
Medicare Part B premium will increase from 9.4% to 11.8% in 2030.  
Acknowledging the uncertainty of Social Security, Medicare and lack of individual 
retirement savings, President Obama has proposed an automatic workplace 
pension plan and mandatory enrollment in IRAs to strengthen retirement savings.  

Consequently, the onus of funding retirement now falls solely on the individual’s 
shoulders.  If the retirement plan is consistently funded over a period of time, the 
employee can obtain his long-term goals.  

If the Disadvantaged Business Enterprise Program would still like to include the 
IRA or other retirement account as an asset, a solution would be to include it as 
an asset only if the individual is older than 59 ½  and has redeemed/converted his 
retirement account.   In this case, the amount listed under assets would be the 
redeemed amount less any taxes.  If the individual is less than 59 ½, the 
IRA/other retirement account should be excluded.  

In conclusion, I strongly encourage the Disadvantaged Business Enterprise 
Program to exclude IRA/other retirement account as an Asset on the Personal 
Net Worth Statement.   Due to proposals supported by the Federal Government 
and President Obama and the disappearance of the traditional defined benefit 
pension plan, the individual has no choice but to control his own retirement 
destiny through contribution to any available retirement accounts.     



Sincerely,


Elizabeth M. Nury
President
Beth’s Barricades

Title: State of Hawaii Department of Transportation
Organization Name: State of Hawaii Department of Transportation

Title: Susan MacAdams
Comment:
This sixth concern regards additional limitations on the discretion of prime
contractors to terminate DBE’s for convenience, once the prime contractor has
committed to using the DBE as part of good faith efforts. The intent of the
revisions is to make more meaningful the commitment of the prime contractor to
the particular DBE firm that was part of the contract award process. 

It is recommended that the sixth concern be revised to include the wording,
“When a prime contractor has relied on a commitment to a DBE firm to meet all or
part of a contract goal, the prime contractor could not terminate the DBE firm
for convenience without the recipient’s written approval, based on a good cause
for termination.” 

DBE firms invest large sums of time and financial energy during the proposal
process and are terminated before the initial percentage goals have been met.
The larger firms use a "Divide and Conquer" technique, intimidating smaller
firms with the the threat that they will not be able to work with the larger
firm again. This abuse should be recognized by the DOT and addressed. This
clause should protect the DBE from this type of activity. Without this
protection, the smaller firms are pitted "Brother against Brother," and the
cohesion of the Small and Disadvantaged Businesses group organizations is
thereby diminished. Who is promised the work and who later gets the work are two
different firms sitting at the same table, trying to get along. There is a lot
of tension in the air. This is not a good working atmosphere. Also, one never
knows when the big firm might change their mind, which has a tremendous impact
on the financial stability of the small firms.

Also recommended is an amendment to section 26.53 to “require the recipient, as
a result of a change order, to approve a decision by the prime contractor to
give a significant increment of work to a second DBE subcontractor without the
initial DBE subcontractor meeting all or part of its contract goal.” 

Currently, large pieces of transportation design assigned to one firm, are
transferred to a second firm under the guise of a change order. The change order
may be minimal, but a much larger body of work is attached to it and then
transferred to a second firm. This leaves the first firm out in the cold.

Recommended is an amendment to section 26.53 to “require the recipient, as a
result of a change order, to approve a decision by the prime contractor to give
a significant increment of work to a second DBE subcontractor without the
initial DBE subcontractor meeting all or part of its contract goal.” In other
words, the first DBE should be notified and allowed to discuss the change order
and the ramifications to their original work.

Thank you for your interest in these matters,
Susan MacAdams, Principal
MacAdams Transit Consultants
Trackwork and Alignment
Baltimore, Boston, Washington DC, Los Angeles Red, Blue and Green Lines

Title: Diversity Matters 2 US, LLC
Comment:
July 6, 2009

Docket Numbers OST-2009-0081 and OST-2009-0082

Office of the Secretary
Docket Management Facility
U. S. Department of Transportation
West Building Ground Floor, Room W12-140
1200 New Jersey Avenue SE
Washington, DC 20590-0001

In response to USDOT Docket Numbers OST-2009-0081 and OST-2009-0082 
issued April 8, 2009, Diversity Matters 2 US, LLC (“DM2US”), an independent 
consulting firm specializing in DBE participation and Buy America compliance, 
respectfully submits the following comments:

DM2US would be honored to participate in the stakeholder meetings that bring 
together prime contractors, DBEs and state and local government representatives 
to discuss ways of improving administration of the DBE program. During my 15-
year career, I have managed more than $200 million in subcontract awards and 
payments to DBE, MBE and WBE subcontractors and provided DBE and Buy 
America training to more than 400 employees worldwide. 

The comments stated below may contain excerpts from the author’s previous 
written statements to USDOT, FTA, FTA recipients, APTA, and/or other transit-
related and/or supplier diversity-focused organizations.  


Docket Number OST-2009-0081
How recipients set overall goals

Although the actual results of my past TVM annual goal-setting projections (i.e., 
each FY’s actual DBE goal attainment) were relatively accurate, it was an 
extremely challenging and time-consuming responsibility to “guesstimate” 
specifically when all subcontracts (not just DBE’s) would be awarded because 
production/delivery schedules changed so frequently.  The DOT might consider 
giving recipients the choice between an annual DBE goal and a 2 year fiscal 
period with the option of revising their goal after the first year. 

A significant percentage of government officials are elected during even-numbered 
years (e.g., 2006, 2008, etc.) and subsequently begin their term the following 
January of an odd-numbered year (e.g., 2007, 2009, etc.).  These newly (re-)
elected government officials may inherit existing transportation multiple-year 
budgets/projects/proposals and/or develop new ones based upon needs, funding 
and their personal views toward public transportation.  This ever-changing political 
landscape makes it difficult for recipients to accurately estimate a DBE goal 
beyond one year.

A far more important issue is how goals are set. Although recipients may be 
required to publish their annual DBE percentage goals (perhaps broken down by 
race-conscious and race-neutral amounts), I’ve yet to see any that define how 
they established their percentage.  These DBE goal public notices often state that 
their methodology is available for inspection (only) on-site for (only) 30 days.  
Recipients should be required to post their DBE goal-setting methodologies on 
their website so that bidders/proposers (both DBE and non-DBE) can see for 
themselves which workscopes were/are identified for “ready, willing, and able” 
DBEs.  It’s not well understood at the prime and subcontractor level why this 
information is so difficult to access, especially since public (i.e., taxpayer) funds 
are involved.  Some speculate that, with some recipients, politics may affect DBE 
goal percentages more than available workscopes and therefore expanded public 
access could reveal unsubstantiated goal-setting methodologies.

Establishing an overall fiscal DBE goal, regardless of the time period, is similar to 
projecting sales/income and awards/subcontracts in any organization – it’s based 
upon the larger actual known contracts awarded and pending awards (e.g., 
Notices to Proceed). Some contracts are simply more conducive to DBE 
participation than others.  The DBE goal for any specific time period should 
depend upon various factors such as the type of work involved, the location of the 
work, and the availability of qualified ready, willing and able DBEs. 

Within the passenger railcar industry, some bids are for the remanufacturing 
(refurbishment) of existing vehicles. Since recipients’ DBE goal-setting guidelines 
are neither restricted nor perhaps monitored by the FTA on remanufacturing bids, 
recipients sometimes set DBE goal percentages that, in some cases, are 
technically and/or commercially unattainable. Some recipients set the same 
percentage DBE goal on every eligible bid based upon the anticipated total 
contract value, regardless of available workscopes for ready, willing, and able 
DBEs.  

Some recipients actually do compare NAICS codes and their corresponding 
workscopes to the items needed to build their railcars when establishing DBE 
goals.  However, NAICS codes do not necessarily mean any or all DBEs within a 
certain NAICS code actually possess the capability to perform on a railcar 
contract. For example, there are several DBE truckers and transportation 
suppliers located throughout the country. Included in this list are dump trucks, 
gravel haulers, and food delivery vehicles. However, there are very few, if any, 
DBEs capable of transporting 85-foot carshells or over-dimensional components 
(e.g., locomotive truck assemblies containing traction motors, wheels, and axles). 
The most practical way for a recipient to accurately measure the number of 
capable DBE firms within certain NAICS codes on a railcar contract bid is to 
closely examine the bid specification and determine who is technically qualified to 
perform the work.

Currently, some recipients’ DBE directors do not discuss with their own 
procurement departments what DBE goals they believe are attainable prior to their 
bid specification’s release. It’s time to re-build and strengthen this very important 
relationship.  Recipients need to bring together their engineering, procurement, 
new bids, contract management and DBE departments in order to agree on what 
is a reasonable, attainable DBE goal for each specific contract. Anticipated prime 
bidders and experienced, eligible DBEs could also be involved in the goal setting 
process.  Once a sensible DBE goal is established, prime bidders should make a 
commitment to meet and exceed that goal.
 
Docket Number OST-2009-0082
DBE Program; Potential Program Improvements


Counting of DBE credit for items obtained by DBE contractors from other sources, 
particularly the prime contractor for whom they are working on for a particular 
contract.

Option 1 should remain unchanged to help insure the spirit and intent of the DBE 
program.  Unfortunately, too many individual decision-makers on the prime 
contractor/subcontractor side do not understand the value of supplier diversity.  
Some of these individuals view DBE participation as a recipient- and/or FTA-
mandated cost-driver and will do nearly anything to inflate their DBE “numbers” 
while reducing their DBEs’ actual workscopes.

I strongly agree with the USDOT’s response to Ohio DOT that “doing so (i.e., 
counting the prime contractor’s materials issued to the DBE subcontractor) would 
have the effect of permitting prime contractors to meet the DBE goals while 
minimizing the actual contributions they need to obtain from DBEs.”  The 
USDOT’s Part 26 rule issued in 1999 significantly reduced the damaging practice 
of “backsubbing.”  Why would we now go back to the days of “pass-through” 
DBEs receiving large “sweetheart” deals from prime contractors and not 
performing commercially useful functions?

Both Option 2 and Option 3 opens the floodgates to “backsubbing” and will likely 
encourage prime contractors to inflate their internal “mark-ups” and overhead 
costs before “selling” it their DBE subcontractors.  Even if these prime contractor 
mark-ups and overhead costs are true and accurate costs, how does the FTA 
and/or their recipients challenge, audit, and accept or reject these alleged costs?  
Politically-connected DBEs performing minimal actual work will secure the lion’s 
share of “sweetheart” subcontracts while the legitimate value-added DBEs will be 
excluded.

The competition among railcar prime contractors is fierce and the successful 
bidder often wins the contract (whether negotiated or lowest 
responsive/responsible) with razor-thin profit margins.  Since these large prime 
contractors buy and/or produce their needed materials in such large quantities, 
it’s far more cost-efficient for them to make/buy as much as they can “in-house” 
and then “feed it back” via a DBE “pass-through”  to maximize DBE amounts while 
minimizing actual DBE participation.  This practice doesn’t level the playing field 
and significantly excludes many smaller DBEs from even showing up for the game 
(i.e., compete for and win business).

USDOT’s “question about normal industry practices…on a project in which DBE 
participation is not at issue…” in which the prime contractor does “typically simply 
make the commodity available on the job site, hiring the subcontractor just to do 
the installation work” nicely addresses the “backsubbing” problem.  If the prime 
contractor has a manufacturing or distribution facility for the commodity involved, 
the prime contractor does not “commonly sell the commodity to the 
subcontractor, who is then reimbursed by the prime contractor for the sale price 
as part of the subcontract price.”  Adding two additional steps needlessly 
increases the time and effort of labor and documentation costs to duplicate 
paperwork.  No one would bother to make that type of arrangement because it’s 
simply not cost-effective to extend the paper trail. Although it would lead to higher 
(i.e., artificially inflated) reported DBE participation, it would undermine, to an 
overwhelming extent, the principle of DBE participation.  

As stated in Section 26.55(c)(2), a DBE does not perform a commercially useful 
function if its role is limited to that of an extra participant in a transaction, 
contract, or project through which funds are passed in order to obtain the 
appearance of DBE participation.”  
Since the DOT has made so many improvements to the DBE program - especially 
since the 1999 issuance of Part 26 – it’s difficult to justify regressing back to 
this “good old boy” approach. If the USDOT allows “backsubbing” to re-emerge, 
the creditability of the entire DBE program will be at risk.  

Option 4 is too extreme and would destroy business opportunities for DBE 
distributors (i.e., “regular dealers”).  If you examine a cross-section of Transit 
Vehicle Manufacturer (TVM) contracts among various recipients’ contracts, you’re 
likely to see half or more of a contract’s overall DBE “counting value” is derived 
from DBE distributors. Furthermore, it’s not uncommon for prime contractors to 
actively assist/mentor DBEs in sourcing supplies/services the DBE needs to 
distribute to the prime contractor.  A legitimate DBE distributor provides value-
added, secure, just-in-time, warehousing and inventory control services that the 
prime contractor can’t often perform itself in a cost-effective and efficient manner.

If Option 4 were enacted, recipients would be forced to significantly lower their 
DBE goals because the number of ready, willing and able DBE distributors would 
be excluded from the formula.  

Although not addressed specifically in this ANPRM, one area that seems to be 
abused occasionally by primes and larger non-DBE subcontractors (and not 
necessarily known by the FTA’s recipients) on major contracts (e.g., $50 million 
or more) is the practice of overstating a DBE’s actual “counting value” as 
described in Section 26.55(e).   Non-DBE primes and larger non-DBE 
subcontractors sometimes claim DBE regular dealers (worth 60% counting value) 
as manufacturers (worth 100% counting value) and/or claim “brokers” (i.e., neither 
manufacturers nor regular dealers worth only fees and commissions – perhaps 
only 5% to 10%) as regular dealers (worth 60% counting value).  

DBE manufacturers must perform more than mere kitting and re-labeling or turning 
a few screws to earn their 100% counting value.   DBE regular dealers must 
provide distribution services beyond that of a mere broker (who pushes a few 
papers yet rarely or never actually handles or even sees the product) to earn their 
60% counting value.  There is a wide discrepancy when comparing different 
recipients concerning how closely they monitor this improper behavior.  
Unfortunately, those non-DBE primes and larger non-DBE subcontractors that 
ignorantly view the DBE program as a burdensome mandate (instead of 
understanding the value of supplier diversity) and/or are more concerned with 
reporting higher (albeit illegitimate) DBE goal percentages may take advantage 
of “don’t ask, don’t tell” monitoring practices.  

One way to improve DBE “counting value” accuracy is for the DOT to define 
minimum standards for recipients’ DBE certification approval letters.  Upon issuing 
DBE certification letters, recipients should list the firm’s NAICS codes, matching 
workscopes/areas of expertise and corresponding DBE credit percentages (i.e., 
100 percent, 60 percent, fees and commissions), especially for those DBEs 
capable of performing as both a manufacturer and a distributor. Failing to do so 
encourages prime contractors to misrepresent the legitimate workscope 
contributions of potential DBE suppliers.  Reporting higher total contract dollars 
may “look good on the resume of a DBE to say that it had completed a relatively 
large project” but success in business should be based on actual performance of 
a commercially useful function.


Ways of encouraging recipients to break up contracts into smaller pieces that can 
more easily be performed by small businesses like DBEs, known as “unbundling.”

One of the inherent problems of the DBE rule from the transit vehicle manufacturer 
(TVM) perspective is that TVMs are required and expected to operate within rules 
better-suited for the construction side of transportation (e.g., building roads, 
bridges, tunnels, etc.).  Construction contracts by nature are more conducive to 
unbundling because there are not as many technical/engineering system 
integration requirements that essentially disqualify smaller companies in the TVM 
arena. In the passenger railcar industry, roughly 80% of the total materials are 
major components (e.g., propulsion, brakes, carshells, etc.)  It’s impractical and 
unrealistic, if not impossible, for recipients to unbundle many of a railcar’s major 
components.  For example, would the FTA expect a recipient’s engineer or 
program manager to unbundle its railcar HVAC unit so that the condenser is 
sourced out separately from the compressor while others bid on the metal 
fabrication or hardware or wiring – and then have others bid to build it? Would 
anyone buy an HVAC system for their own home in that manner?  Would it be 
cost-efficient?  

Many recipients require prime contractors to subcontract only to those major 
subsystem suppliers that are technically qualified to meet the recipient’s specific 
technical specifications (e.g., propulsion, auxiliary power, braking system, etc.). 
Generally, DBEs do not meet these major subsystem technical specifications. If 
you surveyed the 10 largest recipients and asked their program/project managers 
to send a list of their “technically approved” major system railcar component 
suppliers, you’d find very few, if any, DBEs on that list.  It’s not that DBEs aren’t 
capable of providing major components on a railcar – in fact, some already are 
and/or many more may be if given the opportunity.  However, in order to provide 
multi-million dollar major railcar components, a company’s sales level (i.e., 26.65 
term “gross receipts”) needed to offset the manufacturing costs (e.g., equipment, 
facilities, material, labor, engineering, etc.) would likely cause a DBE to lose its 
eligibility.  In other words, DBEs that build their business up to compete as a 
prime contractor are somewhat subsequently penalized by their success. 

A prime contractor’s ability to obtain second-tier DBE participation on the railcar 
major subsystems is limited by the amount they derive from non-DBE major 
system suppliers. If these non-DBE suppliers are single- or sole-source-listed by 
the recipient in the bid specification, the prime has no control over those suppliers’ 
level of second-tier DBE participation. Hence, many non-DBE major system 
suppliers offer minimal second-tier DBE participation, especially on a responsive 
approach contract. However, if there is more than one non-DBE supplier 
technically qualified by the recipient, the prime contractor should consider the 
potential subcontractor’s second-tier DBE participation as an important sub-bid 
evaluative criterion. 

Taking into account the limited DBE participation available on railcar major 
subsystems, prime contractors must maximize DBE participation through direct 
purchases from DBEs that provide supplies and services that are not within the 
major systems, such as metal fabrication, wire/cable and industrial hardware.  

Recipients can expand opportunities for DBEs another way.  Since all recipients 
now maintain a database of certified DBEs, they could cross-match the various 
workscopes contained within their bid specifications to each DBE’s NAICS 
Codes.  The recipient could “bulk e-mail” their bid specifications and a list of 
(anticipated) prime bidders to all cross-matched DBEs to bid upon (multiple) 
workscopes.  To illustrate this point, let’s presume metal fabrication, wire/cable, 
and industrial hardware are contained on all railcar bid specifications.  In this 
instance, a recipient issuing any railcar bid spec would automatically e-mail 
railcar bid specifications to any and all DBEs whose NAICS Codes correspond to 
metal fabrication, wire/cable, and industrial hardware.  Some TVMs and other 
prime bidders with a proactive DBE participation program are already utilizing this 
approach to enhance supplier diversity.

Contact unbundling should be done whenever and wherever practical.  The Mentor-
Protégé program could enhance contact unbundling in the railcar industry for 
everyone if the funding level increased and the administration/implementation was 
improved.  


Potential ways of improving the DBE application and personal new worth (PNW) 
forms.

There’s inconsistency in how recipients develop their PNW statements and 
interpret the financial data reported by DBE applicants. Some DBEs (and their 
accountants) find these forms both confusing and misleading.  If a DBE owner’s 
primary residence and the equity in their business doesn’t count toward their 
PNW, then some owners don’t understand why various recipients “dig deeper” 
than others into the DBE’s personal assets outside of their business. Instead of 
allowing recipients to (re)create additional burdensome and potentially intrusive 
documentation requirements, the DOT should standardize the PNW statement for 
all recipients or at least publish a “draft” version for industry comment via a future 
NPRM.

If any changes are made to what’s included/excluded in a DBE owner’s PNW, the 
owner’s equity should still remain excluded.  If a DBE owner’s primary residence 
is to be considered, the $750,000 cap must be raised.  Calculating ever-changing 
local real estate market values (e.g., a house in Buffalo is worth less than a 
similar house on Long Island) and/or cost of living adjustments may open up a 
never-ending debate.


Potential ways of improving program oversight.

Requiring prime contractors to report actual payments to DBEs, instead of the 
subcontract award amount, should keep everyone honest and accountable. The 
true value of any DBE program should always be measured by actual 
performance, not promises. The MARTA in Atlanta audits their prime contractors’ 
reported DBE supplier payments each quarter by directly contacting each “listed” 
DBE to verify the prime’s most recent and cumulative payments. 

Recipients have a choice between handling bidder compliance with contract goals 
as a matter of responsiveness (committing to specific DBE subcontractors “up-
front” in their bid submittals) or responsibility (committing to a DBE contract goal, 
but selecting DBE suppliers after the recipient has awarded the contract to the 
prime contractor). Many recipients prefer the responsiveness approach as a 
deterrent to bid-shopping while others believe the responsibility concept offers a 
more flexible and cost-effective approach. 

The DOT maintains that recipients should continue to use their own discretion on 
this issue.  However, my experience has shown that, on applicable DOT-assisted 
contract bid solicitations issued since the 1999 issuance of the Part 26 DBE rule, 
nearly all recipients have required prime contractors to abide by the 
responsiveness approach. In essence, this means guaranteeing all DBE 
subcontracts up front in their bid proposals through “DBE Letters of Intent.” 
Excerpts from Section 26.53 (b) reveal why recipients so consistently utilize the 
responsiveness approach in their bid solicitations: 
“In your solicitations for DOT-assisted contracts for which a contract goal has 
been established,…All bidders/offerors will be required to submit the following 
information to the recipient [recipient]…: (i)The names and addresses of DBE 
firms that will participate in the contract; (ii) A description of the work that each 
DBE will perform; (iii) The dollar amount of the participation of each DBE firm 
participating; (iv) Written documentation of the bidder/offeror's commitment to use 
a DBE subcontractor whose participation it submits to meet a contract goal; (v) 
Written confirmation from the DBE that it is participating in the contract as 
provided in the prime contractor's commitment;…”

Perhaps the reason the responsibility approach isn’t utilized by recipients is that 
this important option is (unintentionally) buried 12 paragraphs later in Section 
26.53 (e) which states:
“In a ‘design-build’ or ‘turnkey’ contracting situation, in which the recipient 
[recipient] lets a master contract to a [prime] contractor, who in turn lets 
subsequent subcontracts for the work of the project, a recipient may establish a 
goal for the project. The master contractor then establishes contract (DBE) goals, 
as appropriate, for the subcontracts it lets. Recipients must maintain oversight of 
the master contractor's activities to ensure that they are conducted consistent 
with the requirements of this part.”

These excerpts from the “Preamble” (or Background Information) section of the 
1999 issuance of the Part 26 DBE rule offer a good argument relevant to the 
railcar industry:
“…In a sense, the master contractor stands in the shoes of the recipient 
[recipient]. On design-build contracts, the normal process for setting contract 
goals does not fit the contract award process well. At the time of the award of the 
master contract, neither the recipient nor the master contractor knows in detail 
what the project will look like or exactly what contracting opportunities there will 
be, let alone the identity of DBEs who may subsequently be involved. In these 
situations, the recipient may alter the normal process, setting a project goal to 
which the master contractor commits. Later, when the master contractor is letting 
subcontracts, it will set contract goals as appropriate, standing in the shoes of the 
recipient…”

Some recipients prefer the responsiveness approach because some prime 
contractors commit to using specific DBEs in meeting their contractual goal and 
subsequently don’t honor their commitment (i.e., they don’t walk the talk). The 
solution is simple. Recipients should include in their contracts a financial penalty, 
equal (or greater) to the DBE shortfall amount, that the prime contractor must pay 
the recipient. Furthermore, the recipient must enforce this policy. 

Some recipients claim they prefer the responsiveness approach to avoid “bid 
shopping.” It is important to note the difference between bid shopping and 
competitive bidding. Bid shopping is when a prime contractor reveals the bid price 
of their potential DBE subcontractors to competing DBE subcontractors and 
requests that they beat the original price. This kind of bid shopping (DBE or non-
DBE) should never be allowed because it’s unethical to reveal proprietary 
information. However, allowing prime contractors to request competitive bids after 
the recipient has awarded the contract is not bid shopping - it’s capitalism. Since 
most recipients make awards to the lowest responsible bidder, it would make 
sense that prime contractors (if so compelled) should be able to use the same 
system to select their subcontractors, DBE or not.  Although some DBEs argue 
that this competition forces them to submit bid prices that are too low to provide 
them a reasonable profit margin, any business owner (DBE or not) must 
understand what constitutes a sensible, profitable bid. A DBE owner should be 
exposed to the same risks and rewards as any other entrepreneur. 

The practice of guaranteeing contracts with DBE firms prior to a contract award 
has been advocated in other business sectors, especially construction. In a fixed-
price construction bid, (when the design is substantially or totally defined and the 
contractor is dealing primarily with first-tier subcontractors whose scope of work 
can be determined based on that completed design), such a “lock-in” may make 
sense in order to assure achievement of a DBE goal. It’s widely acknowledged 
that the railcar industry differs from construction in that most DBE subcontracting 
opportunities are defined months and even years after a contract award. 
Recipients do not finalize many engineering designs until they have received and 
accepted the prime contractor's first prototype vehicle(s). A prime contractor’s 
ability to increase DBE participation is best-served when they’re entrusted with 
the responsibility for awarding DBE contracts throughout the duration of their 
multiyear contracts.  As an example, wire/cable assemblies are needed on a 
railcar remanufacturing project. How can a prime contractor or their potential major 
system suppliers guarantee up-front specific DBE names, workscopes, and 
dollars on a multi-year contract when the DBE wire/cable assembly firm won’t 
know the cost of copper six months hence?

A prime contractor’s procurement process is affected by provisions that 
encourage the use of second-tier DBE subcontractors, but that also require 
primes and their non-DBE major suppliers to obligate workscope and price to 
DBEs before the recipient’s award date. That, in effect, means that prime 
contractors and their non-DBE major system suppliers have almost no ability to 
adjust scope or price to conform to post-award approvals of neither major 
component specifications nor the prime contractor’s final executed purchase order 
with DBE suppliers. This subverts the normal relationship between contractor and 
subcontractor and places everyone, including the DBE, at risk of realistic 
adjustments to workscope and price.

When recipients require prime contractors to abide by the responsiveness 
approach, the few larger, well-established DBEs (who are capable of providing 
multiple subsystems) receive the lion’s share of the DBE subcontracts, effectively 
shutting out many up-and-coming DBEs who need more opportunities. When 
given the flexibility to select their DBE subcontractors throughout a contract’s 
duration, primes can often double the number of DBE participants. The overall 
contract DBE participation amount doesn’t necessarily increase (although it often 
does), but many more DBEs subsequently get a piece of the pie.

Prime contractors should be willing to contractually obligate themselves to an 
attainable DBE contract goal suggested by the recipient and should guarantee 
that level of DBE participation by certified DBE firms throughout the lifetime of the 
contract. The elimination of the requirement to obligate proposers to specific DBE 
firms for specific dollar amounts prior to contract award is in the best interest of all 
parties. DBEs participating in the bidding process throughout contract duration 
would be afforded more opportunity to compete and grow.


Potential ways of reducing burdens on firms seeking certification as DBEs in more 
than one state

My review of dozens of recipients’ DBE directories reveals no common format. 
Some directories sort alphabetically only by company name, others only 
numerically by NAICS code, and others only by workscope alphabetically (most 
useful of the 3). Even worse, many recipients will publish their DBE directories in 
only.pdf format or hard copy. This cumbersome format makes it impossible for 
anyone to sort and customize a list of potential DBEs that match their 
subcontracting needs.  The DOT should consider requiring all recipients to develop 
an on-line user-friendly DBE database similar to the NYSDOT’s that enables any 
user to sort and customize a potential DBE subcontractor list to meet their 
specific needs. 

Since out-of-state recipients aren’t required to accept an out-of-state DBE 
applicant’s home state certification, out-of-state DBE applicants often face 
unnecessary delays and unending requests for repetitive documentation.  Some 
recipients tell me they believe their own internal DBE application approval process 
is more thorough than an out-of-state DBE applicant’s home state recipient’s 
process and therefore they fear that the out-of-state applicant may have slipped 
through the path of least resistance.  If this is truly a concern, then perhaps the 
DOT should standardize a minimum set of application review procedures that all 
recipients must follow to insure no illegitimate applicants slip through the system.  
Since gathering 50 states’ worth of recipients’ DBE managers for discussion, 
resolution and training is unlikely, perhaps each of the 10 FTA Regional 
Administrators could work within their own geographic areas to standardize DBE 
application processing procedures.  

If you surveyed the larger recipients across the country and asked them to name 
the most thorough out-of-state recipients administering DBE certification, you’re 
likely to narrow it down to a short list.  The DOT could then observe the best 
recipients to see what makes them successful.   The New York MTA DBE 
certification process appears to be well-respected throughout at least the 
Northeast US (if not nationwide).  Although a “one state fits all (states)” scenario 
may be too large of a pill for recipients to swallow today, perhaps a DBE’s initial 
certification should be reciprocal within their FTA regional area for one year and 
then reciprocated on a national basis after 2 or 3 years. 

The recipient’s decision-making timeline in Section 26.83(k) is a major roadblock 
for DBE applicants because the 90-day “decision clock” never starts ticking 
until “receiving from the applicant firm all information required under this part.”  All 
information includes the recipient’s review of all of the DBE’s application 
documentation, the recipient’s “desk audit,” and the recipient’s on-site visit.  
DBEs sometimes wait several months waiting for recipients to schedule an on-site 
visit following their initial desk audit.  Recipients sometimes tell DBEs that, due to 
a lack of funding and/or travel authorization restrictions, the on-site visit is 
postponed until further notice.  In essence, the 90-day clock might not begin 
ticking until several months after a DBE submits their application.  Meanwhile, 
legitimate DBEs lose contracting opportunities because they lack certification.  
It’s a lose-lose Catch-22 because recipients will only count certified DBEs toward 
a bid/contact goal but recipients can’t/won’t certify pending DBE applicants before 
a bid due date.

Closing Statement

When you consider the transit industry’s ultimate customer base (the riders), 
minorities and women represent a significant portion, and perhaps a majority, of 
the market. It stands to reason that minorities and women should also be a 
significant part of the supplier base. Supplier diversity is a tremendous value to 
everyone and must succeed at every level.  DM2US thanks the DOT for their 
outstanding continuous efforts toward improving the DBE program and this 
opportunity to submit comments.

Please contact me whenever I may be of assistance. 

Respectfully yours,

 

Bob Nixon, President
Diversity Matters 2 US, LLC

Company overview

Diversity Matters 2 US, LLC (“DM2US”) is an independent consulting firm 
specializing in DBE participation and Buy America compliance. DM2US’s DBE 
services include maximizing networking/bidding opportunities, organizational team 
training on supplier diversity, assisting DBEs through the certification application 
process, analyzing bid specification documents, verifying prime contractor’s DBE 
participation including 2nd-tier, evaluating “Good Faith Efforts” documentation, 
validating DBE “Counting Value” and “Commercially Useful Function,” preparing 
DBE reports for submittal to recipients and USDOT, and evaluating Pre-Bid/Post-
Award compliance issues including prompt payment and change orders.

Title: Winifred Au
Comment:
Contract Unbundling: Recommendations - require unbundling on all 
projects/contracts including design-build contracts. 

DBE Certification Application and Personal Net Worth Statement: 
Recommendations - streamline the current lengthly application form. Personal 
networth of $750,000 should exclude of retirement funds, such as IRA and 401K, 
from the networth consideration. Current networth of $750,000 is not realistic for a 
high cost urban cities such as California and NY.

Program Oversight: Recommendations - require federal fund recipient agencies to 
monitor, track, and audit for compliance with the commitment of DBE goals. 
Audits should be performed not only at the contract/project closeout but also 
during the progress of the contract so that remedial measures, if required, can be 
enacted and mandated.
