Title: Maryland Department of Transportation
Comment:
Office of the Secretary, DOT
49 CFR Part 26

Docket No. OST-2009-0082

The Maryland Department of Transportation (MDOT) welcomes the opportunity to 
comment on the United States Department of Transportation (USDOT) advance 
notice of proposed rulemaking (ANPRM), which seeks input on six issues of 
concern to participants in the Disadvantaged Business Enterprise (DBE) 
Program.  MDOT has three modal administrations that participate in the DBE 
Program – the Maryland Aviation Administration, the Maryland Transit 
Administration and Maryland’s State Highway Administration.

1.  Counting or DBE credit for items obtained by DBE subcontractors from other 
sources, particularly the prime contractor for whom they are working (§ 26.55(a)(1))
 
If there are to be any changes to the current regulations, MDOT supports Option 2 
that leaves the basic structure of section 26.55(a)(1) intact but permits recipients 
to make exceptions based on criteria stated in an amendment to the regulation.  
MDOT supports Option 2 because it helps recipients (i) ensure that DBE credit is 
given only for contributions made by DBE firms, and (ii) avoid issues concerning 
whether a DBE is actually controlling and managing its work on a given project.  
Any regulatory change that maintains the separation between the work performed 
by the prime and the work performed by the DBE will facilitate the recipient’s 
ability to monitor the independence of DBE subcontractors.  If USDOT pursues 
Option 2, MDOT suggests the amendment include an exception that allows 
counting of proprietary items provided by prime contractors to DBE firms when 
those proprietary items are required under the terms of the bid documents.  (By 
proprietary item, we refer to those products or services manufactured or offered 
under exclusive rights of ownership, including rights under patent, copyright, or 
trade secret law.)  MDOT further suggests that the process for granting this 
exception include submission of a certification by the prime that the cost of these 
items is fair and reasonable.

2.  Contract Unbundling (race neutral measure under § 26.51(b)(1))

MDOT believes that unbundling of contracts for purposes of increasing DBE 
participation should be left to the discretion of each recipient because the 
contracting agencies are in the best position to determine what contracts are 
suitable for unbundling.  Thus, MDOT would not favor mandatory unbundling.  
Rather, MDOT would support the development of procedures to facilitate 
cooperation among small businesses and DBE firms (including the formation of 
joint ventures) to allow them to better compete for larger contracts.     

 3.  Certification Application (§ 26.83(c)(7)) and PNW Statement

Although MDOT is in favor of allowing DBE applicants to continue to provide their 
own version of a personal net worth (PNW) statement, we suggest that the DBE 
regulations discourage the use of SBA Form 413 and specify the required data in 
more detail.  It would be helpful if the PNW instructions described those items 
most often omitted or incorrectly listed, e.g. the value of the owner’s primary 
residence and the value of stock held in the applicant firm.  MDOT further supports 
asking applicants to submit W-2 “Wage and Tax” statements because that data 
can illuminate a key component of business operations – owner and employee 
remuneration.

4.  Program Oversight

MDOT would welcome USDOT guidance on strategies for enhanced compliance, 
enforcement, and oversight, and recommends comprehensive and routine training 
of recipients’ staff by USDOT experts.  A best practice for ensuring the integrity of 
the DBE program is to require certifiers to adhere to their respective state ethics 
laws and regulations. 

5.  Interstate Certification (§ 26.81(e) & (f))

As a co-creator of and participant in the MD/VA/DC reciprocity program, MDOT 
believes that interstate reciprocity reduces the burden on firms seeking multi-state 
certification and facilitates cooperation among recipients.  MDOT, however, does 
not support a regional or national “rebuttable presumption of eligibility” given the 
significant procedural and resource differences among recipients’ certifying 
offices.  MDOT also agrees that fraud and error are more likely to occur with 
nationwide certification, and feels strongly that, under any approach, recipients 
must be able to deny an application if the firm is, based on reasonable grounds, 
ineligible for certification.  Further, although MDOT is hesitant to rely on outdated 
on-site reviews, we believe fiscal realities would make periodic updates to on-site 
reviews impossible without the use of USDOT funds.  As an alternative, MDOT 
suggests that recipients under reciprocity programs retain the option of 
conducting their own “updated” on-site review when the original on-site is 
outdated.  

6.  Termination for convenience and substitution (§ 26.53(f)(1) & (2))
 
MDOT supports any limitations on a prime contractor’s ability to remove DBE 
firms for convenience.  MDOT believes the commitment to a particular DBE during 
the procurement process should be a meaningful commitment, and a prime 
contractor should not be allowed to alter or amend its initial affirmative action plan 
without the express consent of the contracting recipient.  USDOT guidelines for 
determining whether the circumstances support approval of the termination and/or 
substitution, including specific examples, would be helpful.

This comment was prepared by the MDOT Office of Minority Business Enterprise, 
the designated DBE/MBE certification office for the State of Maryland, 7201 
Corporate Center Drive, Hanover MD 21076.  The point of contact is Mr. Micah 
Watson at 410-865-1258 or mwatson@mdot.state.md.us.

Title: Anonymous
Comment:
DOT-Office of the Secretary
Docket No. OST-2009

ANPRM-COMMENTS DUE JULY 7, 2009

The comments below are suggestions on different methods that can be discussed 
further and potentially used to improve the DBE Program.  The methods are meant 
to assist in providing ideas that may help to lessen a lot of the ongoing 
administrative issues that continue to plague the DBE Program and cause 
unnecessary certification delays, incorrect certification/decertification decisions, 
varied interpretations on DBE program requirements, etc. 

1.	COUNTING OF DBE CREDIT FOR ITEMS OBTAINED BY DBE 
SUBCONTRACTORS FROM OTHER SOURCES, PARTICULARLY THE PRIME 
CONTRACTOR FOR WHOM THEY ARE WORKING ON A GIVEN CONTRACT; 
(no comment at this time)

2.	WAYS OF ENCOURAGING RECIPIENTS TO BREAK UP 
CONTRACTS INTO SMALLER PIECES THAT CAN MORE EASILY BE 
PERFORMED BY SMALL BUSINESSES LIKE DBES, KNOWN AS 
UNBUNDLING;

a.	WHAT STEPS DOT CAN TAKE TO FOSTER UNBUNDLING, 
ADVOCATE GREATER USE OF THE TECHNIQUE
i.	Ensure that when unbundling does occur, recipients DO NOT still 
place a goal as this has been happening with some of the unbundling that has 
taken place; Reiterate that not ALL contracts require, warrant, need a goal.
ii.	Require that each recipient unbundle the % of contracts equal to their 
annual goal; for example if their annual goal is 15% and they let out about 20 
contracts that year- then at least 3 MUST be small enough for small businesses 
to compete successfully; perform as a look ahead based on past year’s goal 
achievement (this is not a set-aside or quota as ALL interested firms, DBE and 
non-DBE, can bid on these smaller projects).
iii.	Recipients must show what proactive measures (specific details) they 
took during the year to ensure that there was DBE participation via race-neutral 
means in their Annual DBE Accomplishment reports (December-DBE/March-
ACDBE).
iv.	Recipients must give credit to Primes when they provide evidence that 
Primes unbundled contracts to attract small businesses 
v.	Provide a monetary incentive (more federal grant money?) to recipients 
who unbundled and achieve small business participation via those contracts; in 
alternative- recipients in a region vie for 1 federal grant that is awarded based on 
who achieved the highest DBE participation via unbundling.

3.	POTENTIAL WAYS OF IMPROVING THE DBE APPLICATION AND 
PERSONAL NETWORTH (PNW) FORMS;

a.	NATIONAL DATABASE FOR UCPs TO ACCESS. The database 
should include (1) firms certified as DBE and in which states certified; and (2) 
firms that have been decertified and reasons for decertification, (3) copies of site 
visit reports. The database should only be accessible by UCPs and no personal or 
financial information will be released unless DBE provides written consent. 
Ongoing Maintenance and cost of this may be an issue but perhaps is handled by 
all UCPs paying for a portion of it with additional federal aid? Or to be funded 
directly by DOT, or funding through application fees for multistate certification, or 
by fees charged to Primes for confirmation of a DBE’s certification.
i.	Nationalize only the PNW/Business Size Review by FAA/DOT in 
Washington, DC; a small fee can be assessed to each state to offset cost of 
CPAs, consultants, etc. This centralizes this piece of the certification process 
and allows states to continue to review other areas of application and local 
information and may help to decrease number of certification appeals to DOT and 
subjective/varied interpretations of PNW.
b.	Place UCP Application on FAA/DOT website or OSDBU and that is the 
ONLY place that applicant can obtain the application and submit to UCP; 
guarantees that the same application is used by all.

4.	POTENTIAL WAYS OF IMPROVING PROGRAM OVERSIGHT

a.	UCPs required to submit an annual audit report to FAA detailing the 
year in review of certification, decertification, mandatory on-going training/refresher 
course on certification for certifiers;
b.	Alternative FAA/DOT surprise audits and take a sampling of 
certifications/decertifications and review for consistency.
c.	Ongoing case file history on OSDBU website or FAA/DOT website that 
details actual cases (certifications/decertifications) what was the outcome
d.	DOT/FAA do an annual certification training every year; with breakout 
sessions specific to certain areas of interest (PNW- i.e. count of retirement); if 
cost is issue- do webinar.
e.	All certifiers should be required to take training and pass a test and 
achieve a certain grade to be able to be a certifier? FAA/DOT perform regional 
training sessions (4x a year)-required as mandatory for all UCPs and certification 
staff to attend.
f.	All applicants asked to send comments on the application process to 
DOT/FAA after certification decision made; no incentive to do so but those who do 
may provide ongoing insight on issues that need to be resolved with the process. 

5.	POTENTIAL WAYS OF REDUCING BURDENS ON FIRMS SEEKING 
CERTIFICATION AS DBEs IN MORE THAN ONE STATE

a.	NATIONAL DATABASE FOR UCPs TO ACCESS. The database 
should include (1) firms certified as DBE and in which states certified; and (2) 
firms that have been decertified and reasons for decertification, (3) copies of site 
visit reports. The database should only be accessible by UCPs and no personal or 
financial information will be released unless DBE provides written consent. 
Ongoing Maintenance and cost of this may be an issue but perhaps is handled by 
all UCPs paying for a portion of it with additional federal aid? Or to be funded 
directly by DOT, or funding through application fees for multistate certification, or 
by fees charged to Primes for confirmation of a DBE’s certification.
b.	Absolutely require a time-limit within which certifying entity MUST 
respond to new certifying entity seeking site visit report; (30 days).  This has been 
an ongoing issue for certified DBEs seeking certification in other states as original 
certifying entity has not always been timely in responding to new agency seeking 
site visit report. 
c.	All currently certified firms in one state seeking certification in another 
state MUST be put on a fast track (30 days or less) application process after 
showing proof of out of state certification and submittal of all documents within 
their power, and pending opportunity (LOI) (does not include site visit report to be 
submitted by certifying entity). 
i.	FAA/DOT maintains a database of all site visit reports only to be 
accessible by UCPs as needed.
d.	National Certification Reciprocity is acceptable if there is National 
Certification Training that is mandatory of all certifiers otherwise issues regarding 
Forum Shopping etc will happen.
e.	Split entire U.S. into 8 regions and require that states that fall in those 
regions form a Regional UCP and that they have a mandate on how certification is 
to be handled; this mandate should be uniform for all 8 regions and 
reviewed/approved by FAA/DOT- Appoint a Regional UCP Director for each region 
from FAA/DOT who should receive annual/quarterly reports on Regional UCP’s 
program.

Title: Deirdre D. Kyle
Comment:
Federal Register, Volume 74, No. 66, dated April 8, 2009 proposes several 
options that would allow recipients to count supplies purchased from or equipment 
leased from prime contractors.  Based on experience monitoring projects, D. 
Wilson Consulting Group strongly believes that this rule should not be changed.  
An example of a the abuse that could and probably will occur if this rule is 
removed actually occurred on a project that D. Wilson was a participant.  A DBE 
purchased a large piece of machinery (a truck) that the DBE never saw nor used.  
At the end of the project, the prime contractor was going to “buy” the truck back 
from the DBE for $1.  We have seen examples of DBEs leasing equipment from 
prime contractors; however, the DBE never conducted work on the leased 
equipment.  We strongly urge DOT not to change the language in section 26.55(a)
(1).

 

We believe that methods to encourage unbundling would be beneficial for the DBE 
program.  Recently, in Colorado, CDOT gave scoring points on a design-build 
contract to proposers for unbundling parts of its project so that small businesses 
could have more of a chance to bid on large projects.  Therefore, we encourage 
DOT to add unbundling as an incentive—not as a requirement.

Title: Ohio Department of Transportation
Comment:
Thank you for the opportunity to comment on the potential program improvements 
to the Disadvantaged Business Enterprise Program.  Ohio would like to comment 
on Issue 1 - Counting Credit for Items Obtained by DBEs from Non-DBE Sources.

As noted in the supplementary information, the Ohio Department of Transportation 
requested a waiver of Section 26.55 in 2007 in order to recognize a long-standing 
practice among DBE firms in Ohio.  At that time, Ohio had a policy of allowing 
prime contrators to count DBE participation achieved from asphalt purchased by 
the DBE from the prime contractor's or its affiliate's asphalt plants. This policy 
reflected the market conditions in Ohio wherein ownership of asphalt companies 
had been condensed to a few select companies.  This coupled with the fact that 
Ohio's Construction and Material Specifications prohibited the hauling of hot mix 
from a distance greater tha 50 miles created a unique situation in Ohio where it 
was almost impossible for the DBE to submit a bid.  While Ohio recognized that 
the purpose of the exclusion of supplies and equipment purchased or leased from 
the prime contractor was to ensure that the DBE firm was independent and 
performing a commercially useful function (CUF), we believed that there were 
safeguards that could have been implemented to assure the Department that the 
DBE firm was actually responsible for negotiating price, determining quality and 
quantity, ordering material and installing and paying for material itself.

Ohio is pleased that the Department is now seeking comments on four potential 
options which attempt to address some of Ohio's and other stakeholder's 
concerns.  Ohio supports Option 3 which permits items obtained by DBEs to be 
counted regardless of the source.  This option provides a level playing field for all 
DBE firms in purchasing supplies and equipment, especially asphalt, and would 
allow the DBE firms to operate in a normal industry fashion.  Also, this option is 
consistent with the intent of the DBE program to provide a competitive playing field 
for DBE firms; it eliminates intentional inconsistencies in the program; and allows 
transportation departments the flexibility to adapt to marktet conditions within their 
own state.

Thank you again for the opportunity to comment.

Title: Southeastern Pennsylvania Transportation Authority - DBE Program Office
Organization Name: Southeastern Pennsylvania Transportation Authority - DBE Program Office
Comment:
The Southeastern Pennsylvania Transportation Authority (SEPTA) - DBE Program 
Office offers the following comments on five of the items being addressed in this 
ANPRM.

Item 1:	Counting Credit for Items Obtained by DBEs from Non-DBE Sources

Comment:	Option 1:  No change.  Leave the language of section 26.55(a)(1) as it 
is.


Item 2:	Contract Unbundling

Comment:	Over the past two – three years, our agency has seen an increase in 
the number of DBE contractors bidding on smaller contracts, and being 
successful as prime contractors.  It is our belief that some of these firms may be 
excellent candidates for joint venturing. Therefore, the suggestion with the most 
merit for advocating the inclusion of small and disadvantaged businesses in larger 
federal contracting opportunities would be to facilitate DBE “joint venturing”.  Joint 
venturing could be included as a business development strategy within the 
recipient’s DBE Program. This concept would have to be promoted through 
collaboration between recipients, minority and women business organizations, 
minority business chambers, and small business development agencies.  
However, persuading DBEs that joint venturing is a viable means to business 
growth may not be readily acceptable to many small business owners, unless 
advocated through the respective organization/agency memberships.   Addressing 
the fears and apprehensions of DBEs to take this next step could be a major 
obstacle.  The focus would have to be those DBEs who are established 
businesses, have successfully participated in the DBE Program in a 
subcontracting capacity, or have participated as a prime contractor on small 
contracts.  Communication, education, and technical support, together with 
conducting thorough capability assessments, would be key components to the 
formation and success of joint ventures among DBEs.


Item 3:	Revised DBE Certification Application and Personal Net Worth 
Statement

Comment:	We offer the following suggestions:
a) The regulations should clarify whether or not a firm must be in business for a 
certain period of time (e.g., at least two (2) years) prior to applying for DBE 
certification vs. the current regulation which states, in part, “Nor must you refuse 
to certify a firm solely on the basis that it is a newly formed firm.”

b) Section 1: Certification Information, Part A. Prior/Other Certifications - Require 
that the application be completed in its entirety regardless of whether the firm is 8
(a) or SDB certified.  Clarification is required on the Memorandum of 
Understanding between the U.S. DOT and the SBA.  If a firm is 8(a) certified, they 
should be certified as a DBE on a reciprocal basis; no additional certification 
application should be required.  Also, the reference to SDB certification should be 
removed since SDB certification does not follow the same strict requirements of 
the 8(a) and DBE Programs. 

c) We agree that the certification application should include more details 
concerning owners’ outside employment or other business dealings to include a 
description of the time spent at these operations and an explanation of how these 
activities do not conflict with their ability to manage the applicant firm.

d) The certification application should include a section for the applicant firm to 
provide the NAICS codes associated with their business.

e) Amend the Supporting Documents Checklist to separate the requirements for 
Corporations and LLCs – i.e., two separate sections.

f) Personal Net Worth Statement:
     1. It should be mandatory that the disadvantaged individual(s) include the 
information for their personal residence on the statement.
     2. Provide examples of “Personal Property” to assist applicants in completing 
this section and ensuring they disclose pertinent information.

g) Personal / Corporate Tax Returns – specify that the tax returns submitted must 
be all inclusive (i.e., all schedules; W2 forms; etc.) and must either be signed or 
be accompanied by an electronic submission receipt.


Item 5:	Facilitating Interstate Certification

Comment:	We support interstate certification, as well as nationwide reciprocity, 
with the stipulation that the Federal government take the lead and oversee the 
process.  A few recommendations would be:

     a) The reassessment date should be the same for firms certified on a 
reciprocal basis.  For example, a firm is certified in State A and applies to State 
B.  When State B reviews and certifies the firm, the firm’s reassessment date for 
State B should be the same as State A’s reassessment date.

    b) It should be a requirement that on-site reviews be conducted at certain 
intervals (e.g., every six years), or when a firm relocates its primary business 
location.


Item 6:	Terminations for Convenience and Substitution

Comment:	SEPTA currently requires prime contractors to submit a request for 
termination/substitution to include a thorough explanation of the reason for their 
request.  We require that they include with their request the substitute DBE firm
(s) that will now be participating, or their good faith efforts in meeting the contract 
goal.  The prime contractor must receive our approval prior to implementing any 
changes.  Additionally, if a prime contractor is issued a change order in the area 
of work on which a DBE is currently participating, and the DBE is still on-site, that 
DBE should participate in the change order.

Title: John Wayne Airport
Submitter Representative: Lawrence G. Serafini, Deputy Airport Director

Title: Western Association of State Highway and Transportation Officials
Organization Name: Western Association of State Highway and Transportation Officials

Title: Illinois Bankers Association
Comment: Please see attachment.

Title: X. A. D.
Comment: its so painful

Title: Melanie Jannery
Comment:
My first comment is why is this rule called "Nondiscrimination on the Basis of Disability in Air Travel" when it the airlines are choosing to blatantly discriminate against ME on the basis of my type of disability creating separate and not equal rules for the mentally ill.  Being mentally ill with my service animal I am required to give proof and required to warn them of my flying because I am mentally ill and use a service animal.

How can DOT's reasoning have anything to do with this being because of invisible disabilities because the mentally ill are the only ones required to give proof of disability and warning before flying!  Other invisibly disabled folks who might be seen using service animals are among folks who suffer from hearing loss, cancer, diabetes, AIDS, sleeping disorders, chronic pain, Multiple Sclerosis, and epilepsy.  

I ask why is this ruling named "Nondiscrimination on the Basis of Disability in Air Travel" when DOT has obviously created a separate list of rules for the mentally ill.  This is specific discrimination based on type of disability.  It if offensive and is just wrong!!!

Are people who use wheel chairs required to provide "proof" of disability prior to using a ramp or a lift?  I think not because it would be wrong!

The only difference I see is discrimination against the mentally ill in a "Nondiscrimination on the Basis of Disability in Air Travel" Ruling!

Please, let's come back to year 2009!  Thank You!

Melanie Jannery

Title: D. Smith
Comment:
People with all types of Service Animals should be treated the same way. 

I believe it is fair to require documentation so that people can fly with Emotional Support Animals, as they are not Service Animals and need not be highly trained. However, users of Service Animals should not be required to submit documentation or to give advance notice before travel. 

Almost all types of Service Animals can be, and often are, trained by their owners. Just as some psychiatric Service Animals are trained by professional programs.

If there are some issues with non disabled passengers falsely claiming their pets are Service Animals, then surely that is happening across the board. They will be claiming their animals as any type of Service Animal that assists with any type of invisible disability that Service Animals are typically used for, such as diabetic alerts or seizure alerts. I don't believe non disabled people who want to pretend their pet is a Service Animal will be choosing to pretend to have mental illness when there is any number of other invisible disabilities they could be pretending to suffer from. Yet, users of diabetic alert Service Animals and seizure alert Service Animals are not required to provide private medical documentation or advance notice of travel.

Users of all types of Service Animals should be treated equitably. It does not make sense to single out people who use Service Animals for psychiatric disabilities and place extra requirements on them. Either all users of Service Animals should be required to provide documentation and give advance notice of travel, or none should be required to do so. There should be no distinction due to the type of disability. Drawing a distinction because of the nature of a person's disability is discriminatory.

Please revoke the discriminatory rules that require documentation and advance notice of travel from users of psychiatric Service Animals.

Title: Angela Rena Leonora
Comment:
Office of The Secretary, DOT   Docket number OST-2009-0093

Based on research and reading concerns on both sides of this issue, I am in favor of DOT allowing its’ regulation to remain enforced. It is my understanding that air carriers will continue to allow PSD users a way of safe air travel by means of documentation and forty-eight hour notice but DOT also has to consider safe and comfortable travel for air travelers who are not disabled. If the regulation is eliminated, additional safety concerns could raise up to be major, dangerous and or critical to all passengers and air crew.

Title: Danetta Amschler
Comment:
How can a specifically discriminatory regulation be called "Nondiscrimination on the Basis of Disability in Air Travel"?  It is after all discriminatory since you've chosen to single out an entire category of the disabled to certify their disability down to a letter of documentation from their medical provider in advance of their travel.  The only way to make this right is to require this of all service dog users or of no service dog users.  After all, Emotional Support Animals, by law, are NOT service animals.  They don't have the training to do work or tasks to mitigate their handler's disability or even the requirement of basic public access manners. 

If your fear is "fakers", what makes you think they'd all be hiding amongst the users of emotional support animals and psychiatric service dogs?  Now that letters of documentation are required of these two groups, if "fakers" are a problem, they'll just move along to another class of invisible disability that doesn't require all the documentation such as medical alert.  So I really don't even see a point in the requirement for documentation from users of psychiatric service dogs - since after all a psychiatric service dog IS a service dog and NOT an emotional support animal.  If fakers are the problem, wouldn't it be better to institute a penalty for getting an animal into the passenger area that's not really a service animal instead of penalizing and discriminating against an entire class of the disabled?

Title: Veronica Morris
Comment:
Part 1: 
My psychiatric service dog has been specifically trained to recognize signs of a panic attack or bipolar mood swing. He is trained to alert me, and to ground me with deep pressure therapy and tactile stimulation until the episode passes, or until I can get to a place where I can take my "rescue" medications, which cause me to sleep for four hours. Using a service dog I need my "rescue" medications every 1-2 weeks. Before, I was using these medications daily. 

The last time I flew before having a psychiatric service dog, I fainted twice due to extreme anxiety, requiring medical assistance and oxygen, and nearly causing the plane to divert to another airport to let me deplane. Use of my service dog in the cabin has enabled me to fly without issue ten times since then.

A psychiatric service dog is very different from an emotional support animal. A psychiatric service dog has been trained to do work to mitigate the handler's disability, and to behave in public. Emotional support animals are not specifically trained to do these things. They are a class of pet that DOT has granted special access to. It takes 1-2 years to train a psychiatric service dog to mitigate the handler's disability and to behave in public. Your average emotional support animal has had as much (or little) training as your average pet.

The changes to the ACAA require psychiatric service animals (and only this type of service animal) to provide advanced notice and documentation. No other type of service animal is required to do these things. Additionally, these changes lump psychiatric service animals with emotional support animals. Emotional support animals are pets, psychiatric service animals are not. 

The purpose of the ACAA is to ensure nondiscrimination in air travel. Requiring people with one type of disability using a service animal to provide additional documentation, whereas no person with another type of service animal must provide it, is extremely discriminatory!

Title: Veronica Morris
Comment:
Part II: 
DOT enacted changes over worries people might fraudulently represent pets as psychiatric service animals, but it is just as easy to 'fake' a service animal that alerts to seizures or diabetes. Some people even purchase a guide harness to pass their pet off as a guide dog! Requiring notice and documentation for one class of service animal will encourage fraudulent activity for other types of service animals.

I encourage DOT to adopt measures other than documentation to weed out 'fake' service animals. The ADA provides two questions that can be asked to determine legitimacy (1) Is this service animal required because of a disability? 2) What type of assistance does this animal perform?). If an animal is disruptive or destructive, no matter if it is a service animal or not, it can legally be forced to leave:

DOT can ask these or similar questions for “credible verbal assurance”. Although not required by the ADA, DOT might require markings indicating service animal status (eg vest, service harness, leash slide, bandana, markings on a collar, etc).

I suggest DOT implement punishments for fraudulent service animal activity. If a person has fraudulently claimed a pet as a service animal, they should be refused service from that airline in the future (regardless of whether they have the animal with them). If the animal is disruptive or destructive during the flight, the passenger and animal can be forced to deplane, and/or refused their return flight while they have the animal accompanying them. Fines or jail time for fraudulent service animal activity could be implemented.

I support the Psychiatric Service Dog Society's positions. I urge DOT to be nondiscriminatory, and to outline questions that can be asked to provide "credible verbal assurance". I encourage DOT to provide consequences for fraudulent service animal activity. As to emotional support animals (pets), either DOT should require documentation, or they should exclude them from in-cabin air travel.

Title: Casey R. Mackey
Comment:
1) These changes discriminate against an entire class of people with disabilities 

2) Potential fraudulent activity is not a valid reason to discriminate against people with psychiatric service animals

3) Psychiatric service dogs are no more susceptible to fraudulent activities than any other type of service animal

Title: Bradley W. Morris
Comment:
The following comment is part four in a series of thirteen comments, the whole of which I have attached in pdf form with the first part of the series.
/__________/
(continued from “they are known as emotional support animals.” in another post)
/__________/
So it should not be surprising that there may be some overlap of the services provided by emotional support animals and service animals.   Some of the services listed in the previous answer require less training than others, and some gifted animals may be able to perform a couple of them naturally (without specific training).  So we should expect that there are some emotional support animals that can, without training, provide some of the same services a service animal can.  However, by definition none of an emotional support animal's disability-mitigating services are trained, and they will usually not exhibit any disability-mitigating behaviors that normally require training.  In contrast, an animal that is both trained to do work or tasks to mitigate a disability of its handler, and trained to behave properly in public (not just during air travel), is a service animal.  A service animal may perform a whole host of services that emotional support animals can't, especially the ones that require intensive training.
/__________/
(this response is continued in another post)

Title: Bradley W. Morris
Comment:
The following comment is part six in a series of thirteen comments, the whole of which I have attached in pdf form with the first part of the series.
/__________/
(continued from “Comparing services misses the forest for the trees.” in another post)
/__________/
Psychiatric service animals already belong to a protected class of animals (service animals), about which there has been no question as to the nature of their unimpeded access to travel.  If the DOT decides to allow another class of animals similar access to air travel (emotional support animals), that should not impugn the integrity of psychiatric service animals.  Take the prior example of the gifted,  untrained pet that is able to perform a disability-mitigating service for its mobility-impaired handler.  This doesn't make us think we should treat that pet the same as a service animal, even if the pet is able to behave properly during air travel.  Neither should it make us think that a mobility-assistance service animal should be treated with more suspicion than other service animals, even if the DOT were to allow the untrained pet to travel like it does emotional support animals.

Title: Bradley W. Morris
Comment:
The following comment is part nine in a series of thirteen comments, the whole of which I have attached in pdf form with the first part of the series.
/__________/
(continued from “both types of animals can perform.” in another post)
/__________/
The difference between emotional support animals and psychiatric service animals is in whether the animal is trained both to do work or tasks to mitigate the handler's life-limiting disability, and to behave properly in public.  DOT members should consider the following hypothetical situation.  Some pets of handlers with non-psychiatric life-limiting disabilities are not trained as service animals (both to do work or tasks to mitigate the handler's life-limiting psychiatric disability, and to behave properly in public), yet those pets are able to perform some of the same disability-mitigating services for their handlers as service animals could.  Imagine that these animals are allowed to travel with their handlers, just like emotional support animals do now.  What would be the basis for treating these animals differently than their service animal counterparts?  There is a strict analogy between this situation and that of emotional support animals and psychiatric service animals, so the principles used to answer the latter question should be the same as those used to answer the question to which this responds (about what would support different treatment for the groups in air travel).

Title: Bradley W. Morris
Comment:
The following comment is part thirteen in a series of thirteen comments, the whole of which I have attached in pdf form with the first part of the series.
/__________/
8. “The Department notes that the ACAA is a separate statute from the ADA. The ACAA is a specialized statute dealing only with transportation by air, in an environment in which a large number of people are confined within a limited space for what may be a prolonged period of time. The Department has long taken the position that accommodations for persons with disabilities, and DOT 
requirements for them, may justifiably differ between the air travel context and other contexts, such as places of public accommodation regulated by the Department of Justice under its ADA regulations. We seek comment on the application of this principle in the matter of PSAs and ESAs.”
/__________/
It is true that requirements for accommodations for persons with disabilities may justifiably differ between air travel and other contexts.  However, the differences should be limited to practical considerations, such as aisle width, restroom size, threshold height, etc.  The same ethical principles of non-discrimination should not be thrown out the window.  License for accommodation requirements to differ is not license to start from scratch with a new set of principles about which kinds of disabilities deserve external barriers to travel and which don't.  I encourage revisers of the ACAA to keep this in mind when considering whether certain revisions are acceptable, and moreover whether they are best in keeping with the principles that are intended to drive both the ADA and the ACAA.

Title: Kristin Segermark
Comment: People should not have to prove that they have a disability which requires a service animal in order for that animal to be able to fly with them.  Why make life harder on those who are just trying to get by like everyone else?

Title: Cynthia Lee Dodge
Comment:
I believe our justice system has made deplorable decisions against citizen's with mental disabilities by allowing the Department Of Transportation to change their May 2008 non-discrimination clause to now rule (effective May 2009), of the Air Carrier Access Act, to discriminate on the basis of ones disability by: Requiring the mentally ill who are accompanied by service dogs to give a 48 hour advanced notice before flying; Provide a letter from a licensed mental health professional; Disclose the nature of the person's disability and treatment (from the DSM-IV); And state that the service dog is medically necessary.
  Indeed, how would you feel if you were told ‘you can’t practice law, or secure a job at any airline facility because of your cognitive disability that requires you to have a service dog (or anyone with any type of disability at that).’
  This clearly illustrates discrimination, simply validating a sense of irrational reasoning of unprofessionalism that teeters on ignorance at its worst.
  I am the founder of a service dog self-help program that has won many prestigious awards. The training that goes into service dogs is astronomical. As throughout the years I came to realize that, regardless the disability, they don’t come in a “Fun-kit.” It takes a tremendous amount of hours, months and energy to get through such training.
  Please, I beg of you to listen to what you are demanding of the mentally ill. The fear and anxiety alone can set them back years, placing them at-risk of hopelessness, helplessness, and worthlessness. Leading them on a possible path of self-destruction and/or mutilation.
  Think, if it were your child, spouse, family member, friend, or you. How would you respond to this treatment? Please set the precedence to change such illegal discriminatory acts.
  Thank you for allowing me time and space to express the importance of protecting our liberty, freedom, and ‘equal’ civil rights.

Title: Beth Jannery
Comment: “Please Eliminate the documentation and advance notice provisions for Psychiatric Service Animals, but leave the provisions in effect for Emotional Support Animals.”

Title: Anonymous
Comment: The DOT is dscriminating against an entire class of people with disabilities because of a perceived (not proven) problem.  Fraudulent psychriatic service animals are not a valid reason to discriminate against people with mental disability!  There are already laws that deal with that, and why does the DOT think that the airlines are the only business that should get away with new rules not in line with our rights as outlined in the ADA?  Besides, psychiatric service dogs are not more susceptible to fraudlent activities than is any other type of service animal.  Dishonest people will simply start claiming their dog is a medical alert dog now, instead!  Whereas, an honest mentally disabled person must now go pay for an additional letter and now they're forced to disclose they have a mental disability.  I for one, do NOT want an airline to be keeping letters of any medical nature.  Next the regular business stores will start asking for a letter before I can enter their business.  Thanks for the HUGE step backwards in my access rights, DOT.

Title: Genelle Denzin
Comment:
I agree with the Psychiatric Service Dog Society's position.  The proposed changes discriminate against an entire class of people with disabilities.  Also, potential fraudulent activity is not a valid reason to discriminate against people with psychiatric service animals.  Psychiatric service dogs are no more susceptible to fraudulent activities than any other type of service animal.

This type of privacy invasion is similar to asking someone to explain why (and prove) they need a particular medication.  In this case, the medication is for a psychiatric condition, for which there is much stigma in our society, and so the privacy invasion is that much more outrageous.

Title: Amanda Kathryn Steward
Comment: I agree with the Psychiatric Service Dog Society's comments. Your choice to single out psychiatric service does is discriminatory and unconscionable.

Title: Jamie Crystal Murray
Comment: I completely support the Psychiatric Service Dog Society's position concerning the issues on the new ACAA regulations.  The new regulations do cause discrimination against the mentally disabled who use Service Animals, since the new requirements are only required of those with mental disabilities and no other category of the disabled.  The excuse used is not valid, since such use of "fake" Service Dogs can be in any category of disability, not just the mentally disabled.  I encourage the ACAA to only require such documentation for those who use Emotional Support Animals, since the lack of  training in these animals is not to the same standard as those with Psychiatric Service Animals.

Title: Bradley W. Morris
Comment:
Agency name:  Office of the Secretary
Dockett number:  OST–2009–0093
/__________/
The following comment is part one in a series of thirteen comments, the whole of which I have attached in pdf form with the first part of the series.  For easy reference I have numbered the section of the (request for comments) document to which I'm responding.
/__________/
1. “The letters of support for PSDS’ petition mention that PSAs are trained for public access and obedience (which a number of letters assume or say is not true of ESAs).  In fact, are ESAs trained to behave properly in public settings?  Note that, under the ACAA rules, airlines are never required to carry in the cabin an animal—even one that is assisting a person with a disability—that is not behaving appropriately in a public setting.”
/__________/
Emotional support animals may happen to be trained to behave properly in public settings, but are not by legal definition required to be trained.  An emotional support animal may, as a result of training or not, behave properly during airline travel.  However, this does not mean the animal is trained to behave properly in all the public settings in which a (psychiatric) service animal would be trained to behave, such as a grocery store, restaurant, library, classroom, workplace, etc.

Title: Bradley W. Morris
Comment:
The following comment is part two in a series of thirteen comments, the whole of which I have attached in pdf form with the first part of the series.
/__________/
2. “The letters of support for PSDS’ petition state that PSAs are trained to provide medically necessary, therapeutic, or other services for their users. However, the letters do not specify what any of these services are.  What are these services, and how, if at all, are they relevant to the use of a PSA during the user’s air travel or activities at the user’s destination?"
/__________/
The services a psychiatric service animal may provide are many and may be highly specific to the individual in question.  They may include alerting to panic attacks, reminding the handler to take medicine, orienting and grounding the handler via tactile stimulation, breaking dissociative episodes through tactile stimulation, leading the handler to a safe place during a post-traumatic stress disorder flashback, breaking obsessive-compulsive behaviors, providing tactile stimulation during severe major depressive episodes to encourage the release of mood-elevating hormones, waking up a hypersomniacal handler, etc.  Just as psychiatric disabilities may be highly individualized, so is which services the handler might require during air travel or at the destination—any one of the services listed might be needed during these times.

Title: Bradley W. Morris
Comment:
The following comment is part three in a series of thirteen comments, the whole of which I have attached in pdf form with the first part of the series.
/__________/
3. "With respect to travel on an aircraft, how do these services differ from those that would be provided by an ESA during a flight or at the passenger’s destination?  How, if at all, would any such differences justify treating ESAs and their users differently from PSAs and their owners in the context of air transportation?"
/__________/
Some individuals with mobility-related disabilities will specifically train service animals to help them keep their balance.  This does not mean that other people with the same mobility impairments automatically have service animals if they use a pet to steady themselves.  Service animals are trained to do specific jobs, whereas some pets may happen to do some of the same jobs without training for those jobs or training for full public access.  If those untrained pets perform a service that helps mitigate the handler's disability, and that disability is emotional in nature, they are known as emotional support animals.
/__________/
(this response is continued in another post)

Title: Bradley W. Morris
Comment:
The following comment is part five in a series of thirteen comments, the whole of which I have attached in pdf form with the first part of the series.
/__________/
(continued from “especially the ones that require intensive training.” in another post)
/__________/
While there may be a great disparity between the services an emotional support animal and a service animal may hypothetically provide, it is conceivable for there to be two animals that perform the same services, yet one is an emotional support animal and the other is a service animal.  There may be an extremely gifted animal that performs disability-mitigating services with no training, and a less gifted animal that has been specifically trained to perform those same services for a disabled handler.  This kind of situation could occur with a pet and a mobility-assistance service animal, respectively (or with a diabetes-alert service animal, or a seizure-alert service animal, etc.).  That would not cause us to think an individual with a mobility-assistance service animal should be allowed worse treatment when flying, just because there could be a talented pet that can help its owner in the same way without training.
/__________/
The question just isn't looking in the right direction (“how do these services [that a psychiatric service animal provides] differ from those that would be provided by an ESA during a flight or at the passenger’s destination?”).  This question makes it seem as if, were there no difference between the services performed by two individuals of the types in question, the status of a psychiatric service animal would be demoted.  Comparing services misses the forest for the trees.
/__________/
(this response is continued in another post)

Title: Bradley W. Morris
Comment:
The following comment is part eight in a series of thirteen comments, the whole of which I have attached in pdf form with the first part of the series.
/__________/
5. “Do these obviously significant functions that dogs called PSAs perform for their owners differ from those that would be performed for their owners by dogs called ESAs in a way that would support different treatment for the two groups in airline travel?”
/__________/
I cannot directly answer this question, but I can provide some guidance in thinking about how to answer it.  As I mentioned before, it is conceivable that there could be a psychiatric service animal and an emotional support animal that perform the same types of services for their handlers.  It is just as conceivable that a gifted, untrained pet could perform the same services for a handler with a balance-related disability (or a seizure-related disability, or a diabetes-related disability) as those that particular service animals could perform.  Here I repeat for emphasis:  the place to look is not at the overlap between the services that both types of animals can perform.
/__________/
(this response is continued in another post)

Title: Franco
Comment:
1) These changes discriminate against an entire class of people with disabilities

2) Potential fraudulent activity is not a valid reason to discriminate against people with psychiatric service animals

3) Psychiatric service dogs are no more susceptible to fraudulent activities than any other type of service animal

Title: Lisa J. Haynes
Comment:
Please repeal this restriction which causes undue hardship on an entire class of people with disabilities.

1) These changes discriminate against an entire class of people with disabilities 

2) Potential fraudulent activity is not a valid reason to discriminate against people with psychiatric service animals

3) Psychiatric service dogs are no more susceptible to fraudulent activities than any other type of service animal

Title: Bradley W. Morris
Comment:
The following comment is part ten in a series of thirteen comments, the whole of which I have attached in pdf form with the first part of the series.
/__________/
6. “We note that over the years, many individuals who travel with ESAs have stated that their service animals, in addition to being trained to behave properly in public settings and providing needed emotional/mental health support without which they cannot travel, do in fact perform specific physical tasks related, for example, helping lessen anxiety in stressful situations.”
/__________/
There is some confusion in this statement.  Emotional support animals are not service animals and vice versa, so anyone who claimed their animal was both an emotional support animal and a service animal could be correct about at most one of these classifications.  Of course, it is unclear whether the “many individuals” actually claimed their animals were simultaneously emotional support animals and service animals, or whether the animals were just assumed to be either emotional support animals or service animals by the reporting sources.  We simply cannot tell based on the information given.
/__________/
(this response is continued in another post)

Title: Bradley W. Morris
Comment:
The following comment is part eleven in a series of thirteen comments, the whole of which I have attached in pdf form with the first part of the series.
/__________/
(continued from “We simply cannot tell based on the information given.” in another post)
/__________/
More specifically, it is unclear whether any animal described in the manner quoted above is a service animal.  The description given is incomplete.  Whether the animal described is a service animal depends on its being trained both to do work or tasks to mitigate the handler's life-limiting disability, and to behave properly in public.  If an animal is “trained to behave properly in public settings and [provides] needed emotional/mental health support without which they cannot travel, [and does] in fact perform specific physical tasks related, for example, [to] helping lessen anxiety in stressful situations”, then we do not know whether the animal has been specifically trained to do those physical tasks or provide that support.  If the animal has not been specifically trained to do these things, the animal is technically an emotional support animal.  If the animal has been specifically trained to do these things, the animal is a service animal.
/__________/
Some individuals are not adept at expressing themselves accurately in interpersonal communication, and others are not adept at learning exactly what the distinctions are between emotional support animals and (psychiatric) service animals.  Given these variations in people, and especially considering the conflation of these terms in the recent ACAA revisions, it is understandable that even legitimate service dog handlers and emotional support dog handlers can come across as confused in their expression of their animals' status.

Title: Bradley W. Morris
Comment:
The following comment is part twelve in a series of thirteen comments, the whole of which I have attached in pdf form with the first part of the series.
/__________/
7. “Are there problems that airlines have encountered in the past with passengers initially claiming that their animal is an ESA and later characterizing that same animal as a PSA?”
/__________/
If the situation described in the question is one in which, in the very same situation, an individual claims an animal both as an emotional support animal and as a psychiatric service animal, such an individual either surely suffers from the confusion I describe in my last response above, or the individual is committing fraud.
/__________/
On the other hand, this question may also address a situation in which an individual flew with an animal as an emotional support animal, but at a later date flew with that same animal as a psychiatric service animal.  It should be noted that this by itself is not evidence of fraudulent activity.  A service animal still in training to become a psychiatric service animal may easily qualify as an emotional support animal, and later may be a genuine psychiatric service animal.  Also, a handler may at one time have an emotional support animal, not intending for it to become a service animal, and later life events may lead to that same animal being trained as a psychiatric service animal by the handler.

Title: Barry Morgan
Comment:
Good day,

As a disabled vet being treated for PTSD/TBI and numerous not so apparent physical issues and have a service dog to assist me. I honestly find it really hard to believe that the airlines are having issues in determining if someone is faking the need to have a service dog. I have had a hard enough time getting through airline security before I had the dog, put on no fly lists etc. I can not believe that the airlines are unable screen people if made to sign a form or state in a manner that CLEARLY reminds the handler that it is already federally (and some states) punishable offense to impersonate a service animal with fines seen as high as $20,000. And if they are faking there is now a record of this and can be prosecuted even after they are no longer passenger. 

I only say this as my injuries are unseen and if I leave my house without labeling my dog as a service animal via a huge collar and service dog vest I am challenged at every door and aisle – even though this is not required. As it is, I am often challenged by customers in a hyper critical way. It would be surprising to see someone put up with the verbal abuse and nitpicking that people provide me on a daily basis, let alone get stuck at an airport potentially for days on end having to deal with them and the security processes already there to just have a untrained pet with them.

The stress for me is already overwhelming enough that I prefer to drive from Michigan to Seattle for regular VA dr appnts. I have driven about 65,000 miles this year avoiding the airport and the uncertainty and inconsistency of how airports handle service animals and disabilities let alone me. It was hard enough before with the no fly lists and “yep this is allowed” and then land and go through security again and get the “no thats not allowed” randomness.

With that said, I fully agree with the Psychiatric Service Dog Society and if needed I would be happy to answer any questions.

Regards,
Barry Morgan

Title: Natalena Schvaneveldt
Comment: I agree with the Psychiatric Service Dog Society - These changes discriminate against an entire class of people with disabilities that, although invisible and difficult for some to understand, are legitimate. There are no real data regarding fraudulent service animals. Moreover, abuse of the emotional support animal category, while unfortunate, is not a valid reason to discriminate against those with psychiatric service animals. Indeed, psychiatric service animals are no more susceptible to fraud than other service animals.

Title: Wendy Leigh Corbridge
Comment:
Hi,
I've been spending time recently talking with the Psychiatric Service Dog Society with an issue near and dear to my heart.  I am hoping that you will read this email, and stop discrimination against psychiatric service animals in air travel. People with psychiatric service animals (and only people with that type of  service animal) must provide 48 hrs notice and a letter detailing our mental illness in order to fly with our psychiatric service animals.  This IS discrimination! People with all other types of service animals do not have to provide any notice or documentation.This means that in order to fly, a person using a psychiatric service dog must visit their psychiatrist at least a month before the flight to obtain such a letter. This also means that in case of an emergency in the family, I would not be able to take the first flight home.  I would have to wait a minimum of 48 hours in order to fly anywhere (if I already had the letter on hand), or else I would not be able to bring my psychiatric service dog.  Remember only people with psychiatric service dogs have to provide the letter and 48 hrs notice, all other types of service dogs can fly with no notice and no letter.The reason the DOT has enacted these changes is that they are worried people might fraudulently represent pets as psychiatric service animals in order for them to fly.  This is not a valid concern, however, as it is just as easy to "fake" a service animal that assists with hearing impairments, alerts to seizures, alerts to diabetic shock, alerts to chemical sensitivities etc.  I have even known people to purchase large dark sunglasses and pass their pets off as guide dogs, or rent wheelchairs to pass pets off as mobility assistance dogs!  Requiring 48 hours notice and a detailed letter containing PRIVATE medical information for only one class of service animal will simply encourage fraudulent activity with other types of service animals instead. PLEASE don't let the discrimination go on!

Title: Amanda
Comment: I fully agree with the Psychiatric Service Dog Society. There are some sweeping statements made that can't be proven like the fraudulent service animals, and these changes discriminate against a whole group of people.

Title: Anonymous
Comment:
I agree with the Psychiatric Service Dog Society's comments.
I would also like to point out that persons with mental illlness are often more easily stressed.  The extra requirements for them may worsen their illness.  Making access for them even harder than for a person with a different disability.  Placing extra requirements on the mentally ill is extremely discriminatory.  Also, regarding HIPAA, this is the type of medical condition most people prefer to keep private.

Title: Bradley W. Morris
Comment:
The following comment is part seven in a series of thirteen comments, the whole of which I have attached in pdf form with the first part of the series.
/__________/
4. “What, if any, distinctions have airlines drawn or attempted to draw between the two categories of animals, and what is the basis for any such distinctions?  It appears from some material in the supporting letters that PSAs do, in fact, provide services related to emotional support.”
/__________/
I won't speak as to airline policies, but the distinction between psychiatric service animals and emotional support animals is clear.  Psychiatric service animals are specifically trained both to do work or tasks to mitigate the handler's life-limiting psychiatric disability, and to behave properly in public.  Emotional support animals are not specifically trained both to do work or tasks to mitigate the handler's life-limiting psychiatric disability, and to behave properly in public. Emotional support animals, however, do mitigate the handler's life-limiting emotional disability.
/__________/
As clarified in my answer to the previous question, finding overlap between the services provided by psychiatric service animals and emotional support animals is to be expected, given an understanding of these categories.

Title: Nancy Tucker
Comment:
I agree with the Psychiatric Service Dog's Society regarding its opposition to stricter air travel requirements for people with psychiatric service dogs (PSDs). 

1) These changes discriminate against an entire class of people with disabilities

Title: Bradley W. Morris
Comment:
My comment is in response to Angela Rena Leonora's comment, which is as follows:
/__________/
“Based on research and reading concerns on both sides of this issue, I am in favor of DOT allowing its? [sic] regulation to remain enforced. It is my understanding that air carriers will continue to allow PSD users a way of safe air travel by means of documentation and forty-eight hour notice but DOT also has to consider safe and comfortable travel for air travelers who are not disabled. If the regulation is eliminated, additional safety concerns could raise [sic] up to be major, dangerous and or critical to all passengers and air crew.”
/__________/
The cryptic nature of this comment makes it difficult to address the poster's concerns.  She does not make explicit how eliminating the notice and documentation requirements for psychiatric service animal handlers would impinge on the safety and comfort of air travelers without disabilities.  Nor does she explain what her “additional safety concerns” are, or how they could “raise [sic] up to be major, dangerous and or critical to all passengers and air crew.”  The commentator may have valid concerns, but I would like to see what they are so I can figure out how they should enter the discussion.

Title: Ellen Elizabeth McCord
Comment:
The regulations differentiating psychiatric service dogs from other service animals are discriminatory and do not make sense.  In any public place, a gatekeeper can ask what my dog does for me--the task or tasks that mitigate my disability.  If that is sufficient to provide adequate verbal assurance in public accommodations, why not with air travel?

It is difficult to train a dog to alert to a medical condition that is classified as "psychiatric."  I have not flown on an airplane for many years because of the negative effects on my disability--effects that could cause medicinal or hospital intervention.  As I am preparing my service dog in training to respond/alert to the onset of these symptoms, I'm hoping that will allow me to fly to distant places to visit family, etc.  I do have a letter from my doctor specifically prescribing my service dog for what he treats as a both a medical and psychiatric disability.  Because it is bio-chemical in nature, it is both.  It's severity prevents me from working.  While medication addresses much of the biochemistry, it does not prevent dangerous flare-ups.  Why should you split hairs on whether my disability is medical or psychiatric?  It is both.  These regulations make absolutely no sense.  They do not prevent abuses by people wanting to circumvent service dog access laws.  They only violate privacy by creating a different class of disability.

Title: Psychiatric Service Dog Society
Comment: Please see the attached file for the official Psychiatric Service Dog Society comments.  This is the second attempt at submission, as no confirmation was received during the first attempt.

Title: Anonymous
Comment:
I agree with the Psychiatric Service Dog Society!

If you are trying to deter people faking, well that can happen with anything and it is not fair to punish/discriminate against those with real needs!

A simple letter or certified service dog certificate or something should be more than enough ... whatever you require for a blind or other handicap should be the same for invisible disabilities too.

Title: Silicon Valley Independent Living Center
Comment:
Silicon Valley Independent Living Center (SVILC) is a nonprofit organization run by and for people with all types of disabilities in Santa Clara County, California. SVILC wishes to offer comments on the new rules affecting people with psychiatric disabilities who use service animals.

The new rules single out people who use service animals for a psychiatric disability as opposed to another type of disability. This is not permitted under the Air Carrier Access Act, which states that an air carrier may not discriminate on the basis of physical or mental impairment. 49 USC 41705 (a) (1).

The references in the new rules to emotional support animals (ESAs) are spurious. Service animals, including psychiatric service animals, are rigorously trained to assist people with disabilities with specific tasks, in specific situations such as on an airplane flight. Thus, there is no reason to treat a service animal differently based solely on what type of disability its human partner has – and thus, to discriminate against the person based on that disability.

The Senate recently passed the Service Dogs for Veterans Act. Sponsored by Sens. Al Franken (D-MN) and Johnny Isakson (R-GA), the act will provide at least 200 service dogs to disabled veterans, half of whom will be veterans with psychiatric disabilities such as post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD). Under the new rules, airlines are free to impose onerous, discriminatory requirements on these veterans when bringing their new service dogs onto flights. Bear in mind that flying can be a particularly traumatic experience for veterans who have seen air combat. 

From the Air Carrier Access Act of 1986 to the Service Dogs for Veterans Act of 2009, Congress has clearly recognized the importance of service animals for all people with disabilities, including psychiatric disabilities. We ask that the Department of Transportation do the same.

Title: Robert A. Pannell
Comment: Many passengers ship animals as Cargo that are too big to fit in normal carry-on size kennels as well as many other passengers take their smaller animals with them on family vacations using carry-on kennels. The airlines allow this for a nominal fee. There are rare occurrences when an emotional support animal is presented by a customer. If the regulations requiring a letter from the patient's physician are eliminated, than all customers that want to transport their animals with them on vacation could simply state to airline personnel that they are emotional support animals. This could potentially cause many more animals to be transported leading to other areas of concern such as other passengers being allergic to animals. Currently, those passengers can simply be moved away from the animal but if there are substantially more animals on board this would become an issue and inconvenience others. It also would eliminate revenue opportunities for airlines which are struggling right now. I am against this proposal. It would be much less inconvenient for the passenger wishing to take an emotional support animal to simply call their physician and get a letter faxed to them than the other possible ramifications.

Title: Alan Michels
Comment: I agree with the Psychiatric Service Dog Society's position.  If the purpose of the special restrictions on people with psychiatric service dogs is to prevent fraud then action should be taken against the people who commit fraud.  As written it penalizes people who use psychiatric service dogs by invoking a waiting period before they can travel and the cost of a recent doctor's exam that is not required by other users of service dogs.

Title: Coy A. Lauer
Comment:
The requirement for specific documents and 48 hr. notice for air travelers with psychiatric service animals (PSA)  and emotional service animals (ESA) discriminates against persons with mental illness, is not in compliance with the ACAA nondiscrimination policy, and places an unfair hardship on PSA/ESA owners.  PSAs and ESAs  provide a valuable service to the disabled and should be treated the same as any other service animal.  To be singled out on the claim that some people are claiming pets as service animals is as wrong as racial profiling.  The animals behavior, not a persons type of disability or type of service animal, is the key.
It is my belief that if an individual is disabled for any reason, and claims that an animal is a service animal in accordance with the ADA, airlines need to accept this on faith unless the animal misbehaves.  If the animal does not meet minimum standards of behavior the airline can refuse to allow the animal in the cabin.  Since passengers spend time in the terminal and aircraft before leaving the gate, the airline staff can observe animals for problem behavior. 
As long as there are rules there will be people trying to cheat.  No system to stop fraud is perfect.  Discrimination against the mentally ill or others with service animals is not the way to stop fraud. 
Service animals can be an important tool for the mentally ill, and the services they perform vary widely.  Just having the animal present when symptoms occur, like an ESA, can be a significant help to some. 
The Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA) does not require specific training, certification or identification, but does requires a minimum level of behavior standards for the service animal. Businesses are prohibited from treating disabled individuals with service animals less favorably than other patrons.  The new rules also appear to be in conflict with the intent of the ADA as well as the ACAA nondiscrimination policy.

Title: Wendy L. Gee
Comment: I agree with the Psychiatric Service Dog Society's position.

Title: Lynn Martha Harvey
Comment: To not recognize the use of a Psychiatric Service Dog as an acceptable Service Dog is to discriminate against a large group of people.  The need for a Psychiatric Service Dog allows certain individuals the ability to interact with the public on a daily basis.  Understanding the rules of a Service animal is to allow a person to interact in the public without the use of another person.  When I take my PSD into public situations I am able to complete any task that I need in order for me to sustain health and welfare.  My PSD accompanies me to the grocery store, restuarants. any public forum where I am allowed.  She is properly trained and passes all required CGC and PAT formats.  It is my responsibility to see that she maintains a high degree of attention on me.  She can detect my mental changes and can lead/urge me to go to a non-confrontal place to regroup and reorganize my thoughts.  She can force me to recognize when my OCD has managed to come to the point that I cannot function outside of my home.  This document, if passed will require that I have a person with me at all times to insure that I do not cause myself any physical harm.  To deny us access is discrimination due to my disability.

Title: Anonymous
Comment: Psychiatric disabilities are not a subcategory in the ADA. No where else apart from airports are people with psychiatric disabilities required to provide any more or less information than any other disabled individual. It is time that the ACAA rules were modified so that the stigma of mental illness does not follow those who happen to use a service dog as a means of dealing with their disabilities. The current rules allow people with psychiatric disabilities to be legally discriminated against because additional requirements are made of these people. It is no easier for an airline employee to differentiate between an able-bodied faker and a person with epilepsy or diabetes than it is for such an employee to try to determine if a person does or does not have a psychiatric disability. The same standard should apply to all, whether it involves additional documentation or not.

Title: Kathryn Beals
Comment:
I support the PSDS's position. Mental illness is a well-documented disability that affects millions of people.  Many mentally ill individuals rely on service animals to complete everyday tasks that most take for granted.  It is unfair to discriminate specifically against the handlers of trained psychiatric service animals because of the threat of fraudulent representation. 

I believe that all types of service animals must be thoroughly trained and respectful of other passengers, and that poorly behaved animals of any type may be asked to leave.  A psychiatric service animal is different from an emotional support animal.  Unlike pets or emotional support animals, psychiatric service animals have been extensively trained to assist with specific medical symptoms and to behave in public places.  I fly frequently, and I have never been inconvenienced in any way by a service animal. 

I believe the DOT should recognize that fraudulent activities can occur with any form of assistance for the disabled.  Regardless of the type of assistance, it is still better to risk a few "bad apples" than to discriminate against an entire class of disability. If the DOT does not require other types of service animal handlers to provide notice or documentation, then psychiatric service animal handlers should be afforded the same rights.

Title: Ellen Adams
Comment: This seems to go against the ADA of 1990, which prohibits discrimination to anyone who "Has a physical or mental impairment that substantially limits one or more major life activities".  Well, just because you can't see it, anxiety and many other psychological issues can be just as problematic as a "physical" disability.  This legislation is not only insensitive, it is illegal.

Title: Bradley W. Morris
Comment:
Agency name:  Office of the Secretary
Docket number:  OST–2009–0093

This is the first part of a three-part comment, the whole of which I have submitted in pdf form with this first post.  In this comment I address the consequences of the DOT policy, as found in the current version of the ACAA, for those with disabilities and those who abuse the system designed to make unfettered travel easier for those with disabilities.  The scope of what follows is only intended to include service animal issues.  I therefore do not directly address emotional support animals (a category of pet).  I focus on the kind of fraud in which an individual without a disability feigns a disability to get a pet on the plane, not fraud in which someone with a legitimate disability falsely claims a pet as a service animal.
/__________/
Many kinds of disabilities are susceptible to fraud.  Many of these disabilities, when genuine, are conditions for which the use of a service animal can be appropriate.  Let's assume for the sake of argument that one kind of disability (we'll call it 'disability A') is preferentially counterfeited over other disabilities, in order to bring a pet onboard an aircraft.  (Note that there is no strong, publicly clear evidential support that there is a preferentially feigned disability.)
/__________/
If the ACAA requires documentation and notice only for disability A, the results are twofold.  First, those who have disability A are discriminated against, having more external barriers to free movement than both those with other disabilities, and those without disabilities.  Second, it is likely that the same people who were faking disability A to get their pets onboard will then fake different disabilities.  The consequence is that the abuse is merely spread to other categories of disabilities, without a significant drop in the total number of abuses.
/__________/
(continued in another posting)

Title: Tony Mendez
Comment: I am vehemently opposed to the proposed regulation as it is discriminatory to an entire class of disabled persons!

Title: Bradley W. Morris
Comment:
(Part 2 of 3)
/_____/
If fraudulent service animal activity is stopped for disability A, but spreads to other categories of disabilities, one of only two possibilities could follow.  The first is that there is no longer a kind of disability that is faked more than others.  In this situation, it seems that the DOT would not take action against people with disabilities other than disability A, since the DOT strategy has been to single out the group perceived as the largest threat.  (I will consider the possibility of uniform DOT treatment below.)  So the result of this first possibility is that people with disability A are discriminated against, while the total amount of faking does not decrease.
/_____/
The second possibility is that there is another, new kind of disability that stands out as a preferentially faked category.  If this happens, the DOT indicates it would take action similar to that originally taken against fraud involving disability A (“Should the Department encounter a pattern of abuse concerning service animals in other categories, we can consider additional safeguards with respect to those categories as well.” -Federal Register, 47903).  Such further action would again discriminate against people with a particular kind of disability, and again, forces frauds to choose from among the many remaining kinds of disabilities they can counterfeit.  So with the second of only two possibilities, the result is that the total amount of fraud does not significantly decrease, while the amount of discrimination and external hardship faced by those with select kinds of disabilities increases.
/_____/
The consequences of the only two possibilities that can result from the current DOT strategy show something infuriating, disheartening, and most importantly, unjust.
