The DOT has set itself up to promote systematic discrimination, with possibly increasing frequency, while the total amount of the very abuse that concerns its members remains the same.
/____/
(continued)

Title: John Caffery Hilliard
Comment: Please do not place additional requirements for psychiatric patients with service animals.  Having a psychiatric disability is enough of a challenge and a burden in and of itself, why create additional barriers and constraints on such disabled people.  Furthermore, I do not see a substantive difficulty to airlines or airline passengers caused by psychiatric service animals which are usually small and often unseen by airline passengers and crew.  Please compare the presence of human infants and children on commercial aircraft who can create an enormous noise strain in the cabin and absolutely filthy behavior and leaking of all matter of things from various orifices.  In comparison, the presence of a psychiatric service animal is minimal as it usually stays within a container, and by definition of being designated a psychiatric service animal, is well behaved.

Title: Michelle Scott
Comment:
Please be advised that I utilize a Service Dog.  While I have multiple disabilities, one is that I have anxiety attacks.  So, you could say that my dog is a PSD.  

I do not require proof or documentation of any of my other disabilities except for the use of my dog as PSD.  This is quite unfair.  Why should I have to provide proof of my mental status (within a 30 day period) to an airline personnel?  Are they doctors, are they trained to understand all medical conditions, do they have my medical history?

I could take drugs for my medical condition.  Instead, I take my DOG.  He provides all the assistance I need for the flight and has acquired over two years in training.  He keeps me calm and safe during a flight - therefore avoiding any problems during the flight.

A disability is physicial and/or mental.  To say that a physcial disability has one set of rules and a mental disability has a second set of rules is wrong.  A disability is a disability.  Fair is fair.

As a side note, most people that have properly trained service dogs have more than several years of training into their dogs and will be more than happy to demonstrate the ways the animals work for them.  It is clear to see if a dog is a service dog or not.

Title: Suzanne Edwards Brean
Comment: I believe that the ruling to discriminate based on the a person's disability is extremely wrong. I agree with the Psychiatric Service Dog Society that this rule is extremely bad.  It will not benefit the airlines, travelers with service animals of any type or the population in general.  A service animal is a service animal under the ADA without differentiation of the type of assistance the service animal provides.  People using service dogs (regardless of the type) have enough access issues with the government ignoring their own rules and regulations because a single agency doesn't want to "play nice" or feels they don't have to utilize the same playbook as everyone else.  This ruling is wrong, just plain wrong!  I have not ever heard of a person with a true service animal causing issues on a plane..Pet dog maybe, but not a service dog.  I ask that you change your ruling.

Title: Brian Jay Ecker
Comment: This proposed law will discriminate against those using Psychiatric Service Dogs under the direction of their doctors and I think that is wrong.

Title: Emily Lewis
Comment: It is ludicrous that people who use a service dog for a mental disability can not fly on public airlines without 48 hours notice. What happens if a loved one out of state/country becomes seriously ill or dies? A mentally diabled person with a service dog may be forced to miss spending last moments with that loved one, or miss saying good bye at a funeral! People with a physical disability are not discriminated against, and this would not be a concern for them in the same situations. We are talking about an act of serious discrimination, based on a persons disability, in a law used to protect people with disabilities FROM being discriminated against. This HUGE oversight needs to be corrected today.

Title: Bradley W. Morris
Comment:
(Part 3 of 3)
/__________/
This evaluation draws out the unreasonableness of what is implicitly a “whack-a-mole” strategy—there are just too many holes the moles can pop out of (disabilities the frauds can feign).  This leaves us with two more reasonable strategies to consider.  Either apply the same hardships to all persons with disabilities, or apply them to none of them.
/__________/
Creating barriers to free movement for those with disabilities, barriers not erected against those without disabilities, is much less than ideal.  This action would punish many who already have severe difficulties with which they must deal, while preventing the transgressions of a few.  It does not seem likely that a proper cost-benefit analysis would favor such discrimination, and it is hasty to enact policies that discriminate without appropriate study as to their consequences, positive and negative.
/__________/
Applying these considerations, the best course of action is to immediately eliminate the rule that discriminates against those with psychiatric service animals.  My hope is that members of the DOT are at least able to approximate this action.  If, however, members of the DOT feel that some policy that makes it harder for those with service animals to travel is appropriate, a full study should be done of the policy's major consequences, and this should be done *before* that policy is put in place.
/__________/
Addendum:  To be perfectly clear, I have expressed no opinion in this comment regarding whether emotional support animals (which are pets) should be allowed in-cabin, or whether their handlers should be required to provide notice and documentation.  My comment is limited to service animals, and especially the discrimination currently faced by handlers of psychiatric service animals.

Title: Welsey David Hagen
Comment:
This public comment is in strong opposition of the proposed rule entitled: 'Nondiscrimination on the Basis of Disability in Air Travel',  which in itself is a terrible title, as it does exactly the opposite of what the proposed rule states.

This rule proposal will: 

* discriminate against an entire class of people with disabilities

* Clearly, potential fraudulent activity is not a valid reason to discriminate against people with psychiatric service animals

* Please note that psychiatric service dogs are no more susceptible to fraudulent activities than any other type of service animal

Please abandon this misleading and discriminatory rule proposal.  Even if it becomes rule, can you imagine it will stand up to even the simplest Constitutional, ADA-based  and/or judicial challenge?

To save time and money that could be used on rulings that actually protect the disabled, I suggest you abandon this confusing and misleading legislation.

Why not make the penalty for faking a service dog more severe--punish those who are breaking the law and protect those that require the law for protection.  

Isn't that the most basic job of government?

Title: Byron Yan
Comment: I support the DOT's effort to eliminate a provision of the Air Carrier Access Act.

Title: Anonymous
Comment:
I agree with the Psychiatric Service Dog Society. The regulations differentiating psychiatric service dogs from other service animals are discriminatory if not criminal. Service animals are specifically trained to mitigate a disability; ESA's are not. I am disabled as defined by the ADA and have been diagnosed as having agoraphobia with panic disorder (300.21 DSM-IV; also noted by the AMA as a non-parity, biological illness) and in addition to weekly visits to my LPC, I also take a handful of medication including an SSRI and a Class C narcotic to manage my symptoms. However, medication isn't always effective, especially during severe panic attacks. My psychiatric service dog has been trained to mitigate my disability by performing several physical tasks to prevent and aid in treating my panic attacks as well as preventing them. 

Due to the high dosage of my prescribed SSRI, I am also prone to going into serotonin syndrome; a life threatening  reaction due to having too much serotonin in the body. There is no "warning" to this syndrome and if not treated rapidly, is fatal. My psychiatric service dog has been trained to alert me both physically and verbally when he smells a distinct increase of this chemical; often within an hour or two of what would be the onset of physical symptoms such as convulsions, confusion, tachycardia, hyperventilation, hypothermia, and pupil dilation. The only treatment for serotonin syndrome is benzodiazepine sedation of which I ingest in pill form. For the benzodiazepine to be absorbed by my body and begin to counter-act the excessive amount of serotonin in my body, I would have to ingest this pill 45 minutes prior to the onset of symptoms. As I can not determine myself when or where my body may go into serotonin syndrome, it is critical that my psychiatric service dog accompanies me at all times.

Title: David Ball
Comment:
I agree with nearly anything including this proposed law that helps prevent the continued fraudulent use of animals as service animals regardless of the class they belong to. For people with hidden disabilities it's more of a concern but it also opens the door wider to those who seek to enjoy our rights by lying about their condition. 
The disabled community MUST be willing to give some in order to continue enjoying these hard fought for rights before we lose them due to us allowing people to defraud the systems in our name. Inaction on our part to help the government prevent fraud is the same as condoning it regardless what we say. You must show ID to access many of your rights such as driving, carrying a firearm, drinking, checking out books, cashing checks, etc,  regardless if it's related to disability or not and this should be no different.
This continued divide in the disability community is going to end up hurting us down the road. We need to pull together and support the government in protecting our rights while protecting the rights of businesses including the air travel industry and adhere to our call to be treated "equally" instead of specially.

Title: Lynn Martha Harvey
Comment:
To discriminate against a person who is flying with a Service Animal should be considered in direct conflict with the ADA rules.  It is hard enough to be in a world that sees any type of disablity as a hinderence, whether that disability is easy to see or not visable, without trying to have a normal experience when traveling on "public transportation".  

To say we cannot travel with our service animals restricts our ability to live normally.... Lynn

Title: Claudia W. Burrows
Comment: Please bring the DOT regulations into compliance with ADA by removing the restrictions placed on psychiatric sercvice dogs.  My son is autistic and his service dog is vital to his emotional stability and ability to access the world.  Thank you!

Title: John Franco
Comment:
As a parent of someone who depends on her psychiatric service dog I urge you to reconsider your harsh rule of requiring a letter and 48 hours advance notice.  There is no doubt in my mind that my daughter's
dog is important in keeping her stable and functional.  As is the case for all people I know who are positive contributors to our society, frequent air travel is essential.  The current rule requires expensive and time consuming visits to a doctor that cause an undue hardship and impairs her ability to function as the first class citizen she wants
to be and is entitled to be.  There seems to be an impression that this rule will reduce the number of people who fraudulently board aircraft with their pets masquerading as service dogs.  This suggests the government appears eager to make needy, innocent people suffer for the crimes of others.  Such an attitude is outrageous and contrary to well-established American and Christian principles.  A simple method
for verifying that a person needs to have a service dog of any kind would be to require some documentation like a passport that could be shown at checkin - the passport number could even be supplied when
purchasing a ticket.  Finally, I have to protest the uneven treatment regarding service dogs of all kinds.  As far as I can see, regulations should be uniform for all types of service dogs.  Maybe the passport
should be used for all of them.

Title: Tina Elliott
Comment:
I do not support the desciminatory issue of treating Psychiatric service animals any different than other service animal.  To segregate those with such invisable disabilities, such as psychiatric illnesses, that would greatly impact those with such disabilities in using their service animals is purely wrong.
Service animals helps those with a wide range of disablilities in mantaining a more fullfilling life.  These animals are highly trained in order to help their disabled handlers in a variety of ways that can be difficult to ponder etc. due to the fact that each disabled individual has thier own individual needs unlike any other person who may even have the same disorder as an example.  Service animals are not like emotional support animals (ESA's have no paticular training and are just pets. Also concluding that service animals are trained a variety of ways etc. thus making such a requirement to training documentation also discriminatory) and should not be treated as such...to do so is extremely disciminatory to say the least.  I personally have many loved ones who live far away and to have to deal with taking a plane etc. if someone were sick or may have passed without my service animal would be extremely difficult to impossible.  Its like telling someone who cant walk they can not have their wheelchair with them to get around because someone doesnt like wheelchairs etc.  A service animal is a tool used by any legally disabled individual that can benefit.... It is NOT a pet. 

I highly recommend you take all objections to these discriminatory changes with great care.  I know PSDS has made great efforts in trying to educate on this issue and I am also in full support of what they are also trying to achieve.

So please dont throw us (those with a variety of invisable disabilities) into the trash and discriminate any disabled people they may need the use of a service animal!!!

Thank you for listening.

Title: Melanie Jannery
Comment:
I am now commenting in reference to this paragraph" "In order to assist the Department in deciding which course to 
follow, we are, in this document, seeking comment on the issues PSDS raises in its petition. We note that taking action at this time to change the regulatory provisions in question would constitute a substantive amendment requiring us to issue a notice of proposed rulemaking for public comment. Because PSDS waited as long as it did to file its petition, the Department did not have time to take action before the May 13, 2009 effective date for the revised Part 382. Nor does the Department believe that immediate action to change the final rule would be prudent prior to an opportunity to review comments on issues concerning which a wide variety of parties may have an interest in."

Today marks DAY 201 since the airlines have legally been allowed to discriminate against me and others who use service animals for mental health disabilities.  The petition states that PSDS waited so long...the Department didn't have time to take action...The Department could have delayed the ruling.

Instead of delaying the ruling, they put it into effect.  I have friends who will no longer fly because of the requirements of this ruling.  Their independence has been taken away!

If the Department truly feels that people are faking service animals, please consider posting the consequence of doing this in the ruling instead of singling out one class of disabled people.  Such consequence could be a fine or possible imprisonment.  {THINK...beaches with signs of a dollar amount for littering always seem cleaner for some reason}...Have it listed in the rules.  This consequence will then be listed on all the airline websites instead of a set of rules that takes away what we have gained in all of our progress for equal access to all people no matter what their disability!

Title: Alicia Smith
Comment:
Are we going to ask veterans and others, suffering with PTSD or other mental illness, to have to disclose their illness and give advanced notice to travel by air with their Service Dog that allows them to function more fully in society?  The presence of this animal can allow the person to take less medication, need fewer visits to the doctor and be as fully functional as possible.  A Service Dog is a Service Dog.  These are well-behaved dogs that have received obedience and advanced training in an effort to mitigate an individual's life limiting disability.  

Emotional Support Animals (ESA's) are pets that people use for emotional support.  There is no training needed for an animal to be considered as an ESA because they are pets, not service animals.  Lumping these two categories of support together makes no sense.

The new rules single out persons using psychiatric service animals and establish separate policies for them to fly.  Mental illness is the same as any other physical illness and should be treated the same as heart disease or diabetes. .

Yet, you are requiring those living with a mental illness to book an appointment with their healthcare provider well enough in advance of travel (4-6 weeks) so that the provider has time to produce the letter.  They must also pay a doctor’s office co-pay if they have insurance (approximately $30), or pay out of pocket (minimally $150).  The letter must be given to the airlines with 48 hours advance notice. 

In contrast, persons with any other type of disability may bring their service animal on board without any documentation, advance notice, or extra expense. Again, this is discrimination on the basis of disability in air travel, which is expressly forbidden by the ACAA.

Please reconsider these rulings.  Mental health consumers are making their voices heard on many issues including Mental Health Parity legislation, which treats mental illness, the same as physical illness.  

Thank you.

Title: Candy
Comment:
We as Americans need to think back in history to other forms of discrimination and ask ourselves have we really learned from our mistakes as a society.

We like to think that we have advanced to the level of not discriminating against others based on anything other than the specific persons choices and actions rather than race, gender, disability etc. This shows we have not advanced as far as a society as we would like to think. Discrimination against any group as a whole, regardless of how we define the group is wrong. 

We as adults should consider whether we are acting in our own lives the way we teach our children, or do we just talk the talk.

Title: Elaine Jordan
Comment:
i think that making people with mental disabilities show a detailed note for their service dogs is very discrimintory towards mental illness.
i also feel that it should be clear that pyschiatric service dogs and emotional support animals are different and it is readily apparent by observation

Title: Anonymous
Comment:
The rules should stay as-is.  Allowing the airlines to require 48 hours notice is not a problem, as it is not a requirement so the airlines are free to waive the rule or the amount of time for last-minute bookings.  Many passengers with service animals of other types (guide, mobility, hearing, etc.) always notify the airline in advance so they can be assigned to the seat that works best for them (either bulkhead or another seat) and have it noted not to move them.

Many PSDS supporters are confused by the ACAA regulations because PSDS promoted a statement that was in error in regards to the regulations.  The supporters often quote the statement as all airlines are required to require documentation and are required to require the 48-hour notice with there being no regards to last-minute flight bookings (as in ESA/PSA owners wouldn't be able to get on a plane if they bought a ticket less than 48 hours in advance of the flight).  So, I do think the DOT needs to release a statement to clarify the regulations, but the regulations themselves are good, helpful, and should be kept.

As for the confidentiality of the doctor's letter, in my experience (when I had an ESA), the airline does not keep copies of the letters on file or anywhere else.  They look over the letter handed to them by the passenger to see that it fits their requirements and then they hand it back to the passenger.  Therefore, there is no need to worry about the information getting into the wrong hands and there is no need to set up a system for such letters.

Title: Alice Anonymous
Comment:
As a US citizen who suffers from a disabling mental illness, I am very concerned about the blatant discrimination demonstrated by the new revisions to the Air Carrier Access Act (ACAA), effective since May 13, 2009.

Under these new regulations, as a PSD handler I am required to check in 1 hour prior to the ‘general public’, provide 48-hour advance warning that my dog will be accompanying me, as well as documentation proving my illness.  This rule does not apply to handlers of non-Psychiatric Service Dogs.  

The Department of Transportation (DOT)  has claimed that “The entire purpose of the ACAA, and the Department’s rules implementing it, are to ensure nondiscriminatory air travel opportunities are available to people with disabilities.”  Yet, the ACAA has now drawn a line between the psychiatrically disabled, and the rest of the disabled community by requiring additional documentation.  Yes, this is discrimination.

The DOT has proposed that this is because PSDs have a higher prevalence of ‘fakers’… yet there is no data to support this.  Truly, for a determined person it would be just as easy to fake a mobility assistance dog, or a medical alert dog for seizures, diabetes, or even heart disease.  This ‘reason’ is nullified.

Psychiatric Service Dogs in-Training undergo intense and comprehensive training in order to mitigate the handler’s disability through either ‘tasks’ or ‘work’.   This training must be completed before they are graduated to full Service Dog (SD) status, just as all other forms of SDs do.  Emotional Support Animals (ESAs), on the other hand, are not subject to the same rigorous training.  They also do not ‘mitigate a disability’.  They are pets.  Their presence is for emotional support only, and is not directly medically related.

This concludes Part 1 of 3

Title: Alice Anonymous
Comment:
The DOT has stated that “Carriers can properly apply the same policies to ‘psychiatric service animals’ as they do for emotional support animals.”  Why is this?  There is a vast difference between the two.  ESAs are pets, and PSDs are just that – Service Dogs.  My dog and I, as a Psychiatric Service Dog team, deserve to be treated as any other SD team.

I am in the process of training a Psychiatric Service Dog (PSD) for myself, in hopes that it will allow me more freedom, and the ability to do things I am incapable of right now.  Unfortunately, the new regulations to the ACAA have threatened to take away some of this freedom.

Not only are these new regulations unlawful on multiple counts, but they are also amoral!  Is it fair to ask me to provide proof of my disability just because I have a PSD?  Is it fair to force me to reveal something so personal, just so I can fly with my SD?  Is it fair for the airlines to demand paperwork, just so I can hold on to what small chance at a normal life I do have?  No, I think not.  In fact, I think it’s asinine that the airlines feel they have the right to such confidential information.

For the readers out there with MI:  TRIGGER WARNING

I am an 18 year old college student.  I am a survivor of sexual abuse.  I am formally diagnosed with Depression, Bipolar II Disorder, and Post Traumatic Stress Disorder.  But this is not how I want the world to see me.  In the years I have been pursuing recovery, I have grown into a much stronger young woman.  I wish for the world to see me as such.  Though you may not see my disability, and I do not make it apparent, it is there nonetheless.  I do not need this type of discrimination and ostracization as yet another reason to feel alienated by society.  

This concludes Part 2 of 3

Title: Alice Anonymous
Comment:
Throughout the hardships I’ve lived through the past few years, I am trying my best to live a ‘normal’ life.  I have resigned to the fact that I will never have a chance to experience many of the things other young women my age will.  I will never get to party in college, or go out to bars with friends.  I will never have a ‘fling’ with a guy.  I’ll never be able to walk into a room full of people I don’t know, and simply talk and make acquaintances.  I will never be extroverted, exuberant, uninhibited…

Suffice to say, my PTSD affects almost every aspect of my life. I’d rather not tell people I am disabled by PTSD.  I would like to be able to enjoy life with my SD with some sort of anonymity… Please don’t be the one to take this away from me.

This concludes Part 3 of 3

Title: Chanda Lee Hagen
Comment:
This public comment is in strong opposition of the proposed rule entitled: 'Nondiscrimination on the Basis of Disability in Air Travel'. This is pure discrimination against people with mental illness.
 
This rule proposal is against everything this country stands for. People of this country worked long and hard to protect those with disabilities. This rule destroys that work.
 
* This rule discriminates against an entire class of people with disabilities
 
* Fraudulent activity is not a valid reason to discriminate against people with mental illness who use service animals
 
* Please note that psychiatric service dogs are no more susceptible to fraudulent activities than any other type of service animal. Any type Service Animal can be faked. Most people probably would not even WANT to identify themselves as mentally ill if there is another disability that they could choose from to fake a Service Dog. 

It seems to me that this rule is being set up for other reasons than what has been stated. A way to select out 'scary' people with mental illness.
 
Please abandon this misleading and discriminatory rule proposal.  Even if it stays a rule, can you imagine it will stand up to even the simplest Constitutional, ADA-based  and/or judicial challenge? People in the mental health community WILL stand up for themselves.
 
To save time and money that could be used on rulings that actually protect the disabled, I suggest you abandon this confusing and misleading legislation. Mentally ill people need protection, not discrimination. 
 
Isn't that the most basic job of government and this country?

Title: Denise Wetzler
Comment: The title of these rules: 'Nondiscrimination on the Basis of Disability in Air Travel' Is an oxymoron as it pertains to one class of persons with a disability: those who use Psychiatric Service Dogs (PSD). PSD users have been singled out with an undue burden in order to fly. The rationale given is that there is a significant amount of 'faking' in this category of service dog. Seizure and diabetic alert service dogs, and Hearing dogs for the Deaf can be faked just as easily, but they are not being singled out. Why are all service dog users not required to submit documentation of their disability by their medical provider with an ICD-9 code in the letter, and required to notify the airline 48 hours in advance of flying? Yet this is what PSD users are required to do. If a person who is blind was required to do this, an outcry would occur and the regulation would be immediately quashed, due to their enormous lobbying base. The documentation requirement is an undue burden: a letter with a DSM-IV diagnosis signed by a psychiatrist to be submitted to the airline before we are permitted to fly and 48 hours advance notice to the airline as well. Psychiatrists are booked months in advance, a copay is incurred and a charge upwards of $50 is normally charged for any paperwork. It is a financial burden not faced by other service dog users. HIPPA regulations make it illegal to intrude upon an individual's medical history; this regulation breaks that law. The ADA prohibits discrimination against persons with disabilities, yet these rules discriminate against one singled-out class. PSD users are painfully aware of the stigma still attached to persons with a mental illness and these rules perpetuate that stigma. Because of this stigma, we hold our dogs to a higher standard; they are better trained and more well behaved than many 'program' dogs. I urge you to stop discrimination against PSD users via these Rules. It is unfair and an undue burden they should not be forced to bear.

Title: Muriel Jannery
Comment:
In response to the Department of Transportation’s request for comments on the recent changes to the ACAA regarding people with disabilities using Psychiatric Service Animals during air travel, I suggest that discrimination on the basis of one’s disability sets a double standard.

Five years ago my daughter, who lives in Vermont, had made arrangements to fly to Florida to visit her dad and me.  In the wee hours of the morning that she was scheduled to fly out of Vermont, we received a frantic call from her in which she stated that she was too anxious about the trip to come.

I am happy to say that following that incident, she acquired a dog who first became her Emotional Support Animal who she then trained to be her Psychiatric Service Animal.  It is truly beautiful to see how he is tuned in to her needs and how he is able to help her mitigate her anxiety to the point that she and her PSA now fly to visit us on a regular basis in Florida.

With the new regulations, however, additional stress and expense is placed on people, like my daughter, who use a Psychiatric Service Animal in every aspect of their daily life.

Discrimination on the basis of one’s disability whether visible or invisible is, in this mother’s opinion ludicrous and unconscionable.

Title: Mary L. Redding
Comment: you have got to be kidding many of us can not travel without our asssistant animals even going to the rest rooms on airlines are difficult with out our cannine assitance dogs to halp us

Title: Anonymous
Comment:
The ACAA laws should stand as they currently are. While the PSDS organization would like to have you think, "DOT does not have adequate evidence that there is a problem with people trying to sneak pets aboard aircraft, so as to justify imposing the procedural requirements on PSA users," that is simply not true. There is rampant abuse of the ACAA laws by both pet and show dog owners. Dog show people who do this often brag about using this law to get their show dogs on planes and they teach others how to do it, as well. Pet owners who do this have been found out many times by both the public and service dog users when they admit what they did, brag about what they did, or give a wink-wink about their little Fluffy being a service dog.

The problem with differentiating psychiatric service animals from emotional support animals like the PSDS promotes is that a good number of the "PSAs" are really ESAs yet illegally passed off as PSAs for various reasons. In order for a dog to be a PSA, it must have been trained to do tasks or trained to do work (a series of tasks) which directly mitigates the person's disabilities (a dog that only retrieves items is not a service dog for somebody who is not disabled in getting those items). Presence of the dog, the dog behaving on a leash, looking at the dog, being with the dog, hugging/kissing the dog, petting the dog, etc. are not anything a dog is trained to do and also are not tasks/work. Those animals are emotional support animals.

Emotional support is not something a dog, other being, or object gives or does. It is a willful act inside a human's body. Science has proven that a human gets the same emotional support from inanimate objects as they do from dogs and other living beings. A young child's "security blanket" is another example.

To allow an airline to require a doc's letter for proof is good. There is no harm in the advanced notice allowance even though some percieve such.

Title: Anonymous
Comment:
While this ruling does not affect me personally I think it is reprehensible that any government, let alone one of a first first world country, can think it is ok to discriminate against an entire class of disabled people. Its a step back in the fight for equality and stinks of the ‘lock them away in a lunatic asylum’ mentality.  While that may not have been the intent of the ruling; it is the effect regardless. 

I agree in whole with The Psychiatric Service Dog Society's submission. They have spelled out all the reasons this ruling is discriminatory and unacceptable while also providing some non-discriminatory solutions to replace the current ruling.  

The current ruling is also completely ineffective. People without disabilities wishing to misrepresent their pets can fake other types of service animals such as guide, hearing, medical alert, mobility or seizure response and not be required to provide any evidence beyond credible verbal assurance. 

While I do support the requirements for travelling with a Emotional Support Animal - I think it needs to be made very clear that psychiatric service dogs are NOT emotional support animals. Service dogs - for any disability, psychiatric or otherwise, undergo many hours of intense training. They are appropriately trained for public access in addition to the work and/or tasks that mitigate the handers disability. ESA's require no training of any nature and nor do they provide a specific function in the same way a service dog does.

I do not believe there should be any distinctions between service dogs. All service dogs, regardless of the type of service they provide, are treated equally under the Americans with Disabilities Act - Airlines should not be able to segregate service dogs in to different classes with differing requirements for travel.

Title: Joyce Grad
Comment:
I was greatly assisted by the legal system in obtaining the usage of my psychiatric service dog in a Fair Housing Case.  My current dog, Angel, performs tasks that assist me in daily living and devoid of these tasls I would not be able to handle the daily stressors that are in my life.

Asking for documentation for only PSD's not seizure, diabetes, etc. dogs is a personal affront to those of us who deal with emotional disorders on a daily basis.  

Joyce Grad RN - Angel PSD

Title: Daniel Scott Pitman
Comment: As a Partners in Policy Making Graduate in Indiana in 2009, I am strongly against the regulations because of ADA laws. I would wish to see that the ADA laws be adheard to. Thank you very much.

Title: Susan E.
Comment:
Hello. 
I have a mental ilness and recently started working with a psychiatric service animal  (PSD). I don't understand why there is an issue separating mental disabilities from physical disabilities. Mental disabilities are, afterall, physiological in basis- neurochemistry - which is PHYSICAL- therefore a PHYSICAL disability. The only real difference is that we are hit with STIGMA. 

I don't understand why the DOT wants to differentiate between SDs and PSDs. You don't want a blind person to walk into walls in the plane, so a SD helps them. Similarly, you don't want a person with an MI (mental illness) to "freak out" while on a plane, so a dog helps them.

Personally, I have Bipolar, ADD and some PTSD. I am not happy to have these problems. In fact, I am quite UNLUCKY to have these horrible problems, to have been beaten badly many many times by an abuser, to have survived the burning wreckage of a plane crash - and then to develop an MI over the whole thing and have it nearly stop me completely in my tracks. I have a life to live! I have a family!

So when I discovered a dog, a dog trained to help me with specific tasks to help me with MY illness, that was a gift! A GIFT to me. I think it was a Godsend to receive this gift, something that could in any way help mitigate my symptoms, along with traditional medications and regular doctor visits.

Now, to be segregated by type of illness, c'mon. It's NOT AMERICAN, is it? To discriminate in this way? Are you really going to do this?

Mu uncle is going to die soon, and I will need to fly to go to his funeral. Maybe even I could catch a last day or two of his life. How am I going to do that if I am required to make plane travel arrangements 48 hrs in advance? Can you tell me that? What about War Veterans who are aided with PSDs. Are you going to deny them their PSD?

Please reconsider this measure.
Sincerely,
Susan E.

Title: M.
Comment:
I am appalled that a rule entitled "Nondiscrimination on the Basis of Disability in Air Travel" is being used specifically to discriminate against a particular category of disabled persons, namely those who are mentally disabled.  In an age where the ADA was recently amended to be more inclusive and recognize the broad range of disabilities that can be ameliorated through the use of a service dog, the ACAA takes a profound step backwards with the adoption of this rule.

Such stringent "proof" as this rule requires of the mentally disabled is not required of others using service dogs, and only serves to further ostracize those in the mental health community. 

Furthermore, the categorical lumping of PSDs and ESAs serves to reflect ignorance on the subject matter, and seems to argue that the two should be addressed equally, when they are anything but equal in the eyes of the law.  PSDs undergo the same degree of rigorous training (yes, often by their own handlers) that other types of so-called "physical-disability" service dogs do.  If the airline industry wishes to permit ESAs, it is their prerogative to do so.  However, there is a profound distinction between the training, temperament, and legal access rights of PSDs vs ESAs. 

I can understand the frustration of those in the industry who must deal with those individuals falsely claiming their pet to be a service animal.  However, the burden rests on the airlines to deal with such instances of fraud.  It is unreasonable and discriminatory to shift this burden only to those traveling with PSDs.  Their disabilities are as real as those with with more visible medical issues, and they likely wish to keep their conditions just as private.  

The current rules protect neither the airlines, passengers, nor those who are mentally disabled.  

If your intention with this rule was to truly be "nondiscriminatory," then remove the restrictions and requirements that only apply to those traveling with PSDs.

Title: J.
Comment:
I am pretty upset with this rule, which requires those who use PSDs to jump through proof and notification "hoops" before they can fly with their dogs.

My wife has suffered from profound anxiety for many years, and has been unable to fly due to the debilitating panic attacks that ensued from the time she would book her flight.

With the recent addition of a psychiatric service dog to our family, I was thrilled with the idea that we may be able to again enjoy the benefits of air travel.  However, after learning that she would be required to reveal her mental disability to the airlines, 48 hours beforehand and with a doctor's note (permission slip?!), she became quite disheartened.

Why should she have to jump through such hoops when others bringing service dogs on airplanes are not asked to do the same?  With this rule, you are singling out people with mental disabilities for undue attention and scrutiny- which is not only counter to the very point of the ADA, but also violates HIPPA.  My wife's MEDICAL condition is her own business, and quite frankly, she has enough to deal with without having to 'prove' that her PSD is a legitimate service dog by way of revealing her private business.

Repeal this rule.  It only serves to illustrate your own ignorance of how vitally important PSDs are to their handler's quality of life.

Title: Anonymous
Comment: To use a  Service animal, you have to be disabled.  What your disability is should in no way be discriminated against.  The new rules do just that.  I am firmly against this possible change.

Title: Anonymous
Comment: These proposed changes discriminate against an entire class of people with disabilities. Psychiatric disabilities can affect anyone, anywhere, from any background. The recognition of this vulnerability, inherent in us all, behooves all involved in the creation and enforcement of disability and service animal law to act based on both accurate information and compassion. The proposed changes do not reflect either of the above. Instead, they will simply cause further stigma to be perpetrated on a group of people who are already vulnerable.

Title: VG Wright
Comment:
The proposed changes are discriminatory. They single out an entire class of people with disabilities and discriminate against them. The possible abuse of the emotional support animal category is not a valid reason to discriminate against people with psychiatric service animals; they ARE service animals. A service dog is a service dog, why would you create a distinction when the ADA specifically includes all service animals.  
        Emotional support animals are pets, not service animals.  They do not qualify in the same category. If you are concerned with the possible abuse of emotional support animals, address that specific issue. Emotional support dog is not the same thing as a Service Dog. 
       There is no data regarding fraudulent use of psychiatric service animals. This is evident when you did not report the data. 
       No one would ask a blind person to go to the doctor and get a letter stating that they are "blind enough" to have a service dog, and make them alert the airlines 48 hours in advance before they fly. No one would ask a disabled person with diabetes or seizures to prove that they are disabled with a medical note and a 48 hour notice. The change would only discriminate against psychiatric service animals. Yet, the psychiatric animals are no more susceptible to fraudulent behavior than any other type of service animal.
      The Federal Government of the United States clearly identifies the rules and regulations that apply to disabled individuals with the ADA document. Why would you make laws against your own Federal Governmental Regulations? 
      All people with disabilities are treated equally. All disabled individuals with Service Dogs should also be treated equally. Emotional support animals are NOT service animals.

Title: Linden Lovvik
Comment:
ACAA regulations must be fair and equal to all disabled persons who work with service dogs.  Do not single out people partnered with psychiatric service dogs.  

It is discrimination to allow airlines to require medical documentation from a psychiatric service dog handler to prove a psychiatric disability for that person to be allowed to take his or her place among the other passengers.  To require this medical documentation 48 hours in advance of the flight makes the discrimination even more onerous.   

It is abhorrent for non-medical personnel to have access to a person's medical information.  There are no provisions stating which airline staff will have lawful access to this private information, nor how long the documentation will be kept, where it will be stored and no assurances that it will be properly disposed of.

The issue seems to be that the DOT does not recognize a difference between a psychiatric service dog (PSD) and an emotional support animal (ESA).  PSDs are trained animals who work for their handlers to mitigate effects of disability.  Just like all other service dogs, PSDs are specifically trained to navigate calmly and politely within all places accessible to the public.  This requires advanced obedience, as well as extensive exposure and training to function properly in public places.  

ESAs are pets which are considered therapeutically necessary for the disabled person.  They are valuable in their own right, but they are not service animals.

The ACAA document states these new regulations are intended to eliminate fraud perpetrated by people bringing their pets into the cabin as PSDs or ESAs.  Discriminating against service dog handlers who have psychiatric disabilities will not accomplish this goal.  People who are intent on deceit will simply claim that their pet is a seizure alert service dog or diabetes alert service dog.  

Preventing fraud by discriminating against an entire group within the disabled community is not acceptable.

Title: Shawna Clark
Comment:
This legislation discriminates against people with mental disabilities on the basis that our disabilities are not visible.  As a high functioning person with bipolar disorder, I find it hard enough to convince potential employers of the necessity of my Service Dog; I am outraged that the DOT would take it upon itself to target psychiatric Service Dogs in order to identify (before transporting) those who have any sort of mental illness.  

The new rules ask us to do something that is not required of any other single person with a disability: not people with visual impairments or hearing impairments Guide or Hearing dogs – not even diabetics or epileptics who use Medical Alert or Response Service Dogs.

Under the new rules, persons with mental illnesses would have to make an appointment with their doctor well before their travel date, thus incurring a co-pay or visit charge as well as (in some cases) a cost to produce the letter the DOT is requiring.  Many people with disabilities (mentally or otherwise) live within a fixed income and this could produce a hardship not imposed upon any other disabled group.  

When a person with paraplegia arrives at an airport terminal, no one questions their right to have a Service Dog.  When I arrive with mine, people immediately ask the invasive question: “What’s wrong with you?”  My medical records are protected by HIPPA, as are every American citizen’s.  I don’t feel I should have to share my diagnoses, or even the fact that I am being treated for a disabling mental illness, with an airline before I fly.  This is discrimination on the basis of disability in air travel, which is expressly forbidden by the Air Carriers Access Act (ACAA).

I understand the use of psychiatric service dogs is abused.  However, this does not give cause to single us out for identification on mass transportation.  Any rule can be abused; how hard is it to obtain crutches or a wheelchair for someone with perfectly functioning limbs in order to reap benefits intended for people that have a physical disability?  The animals that are branded “service dogs” can be ill-behaved whether they are used for physical OR mental illnesses.  Regarding this issue, training is paramount.  

Among those who are physically disabled, we who use Service Dogs for mental illness are already singled out and disparaged for our use of them.  It is hard enough to be castigated by other people who are disabled (albeit physical versus mental); must we also live being pariahs when trying to travel? 

The Mental Health Parity (MHPA) legislation is only our community’s first step in obtaining equality with physically disabled persons.  It is a constant struggle to obtain and preserve the parity to which we are constitutionally entitled. I ask that you help us advance this purpose by reconsidering the recent rulings.

Title: Denise Wetzler
Comment:
The changes in the rules: Nondiscrimination on the Basis of Disability in Air Travel are unfair:
1) These changes discriminate against an entire class of people with disabilities.
2) There is no data regarding fraudulent use of psychiatric service animals.
3) Abuse of the emotional support animal category is not a valid reason to discriminate against people with psychiatric service animals- emotional support animals are pets and psychiatric service animals are not
4) Psychiatric service animals are no more susceptible to fraudulent behavior than any other type of service animal.
5) The rules place an undue burden on one class of people with disabilities that other classes do not have to bear.
6) The rules violate HIPPA provisions protecting private health information, giving airline personnel access to protected health information.

Title: Anonymous
Comment: Nondiscrimination on the Basis of Disability in Air Travel lumps together two things that are actually separate: Emotional Support Animals (ESA) and Psychiatric Service Dogs (PSD). An ESA is a pet with no formal training as a Service Animal but taught to behave in public. It is not trained to perform tasks nor to do work. A PSD is trained to perform tasks and do work, as well as trained to behave appropriately in public. It is a misnomer to lump the two together. A PSD is a Service Animal just like a guide dog for a person who is blind, or a Hearing Dog for a person who is Deaf or Hard of Hearing. All these categories of Service Animals are trained to perform tasks or do work, depending on the needs of the owner/handler. Please recognize the difference between an ESA and a Service Animal, which includes a PSD. Requiring an ESA owner to provide documentation is appropriate; requiring a PSD owner/handler to do the same is not. If Service Animals for persons with other types of disabilities are not required to submit documentation of their disability, then neither should this type of undue burden be place upon PSD owner/handlers. It is unfair to categorically discriminate against one type of Service Animal because: a) confusion exists between ESA and PSD; b) there is a suspicion of abuse of the ESA category; and c) there is no documented abuse of the PSD category. To sanction discrimination against an individual that uses a PSD based on undocumented abuse of the PSD category and suspicion of abuse of the ESA category is unfair and inappropriate, not to mention illegal.The Americans With Disabilities Act includes protection for PSD users; these Rules are the only place where discrimination occurs. Please rectify this unwarranted discrimination.

Title: Anonymous
Comment:
Please do not make this unfair change.  I do not believe we should discriminate against psychiatric service animals in air travel.  I agree with the Psychiatric Service Dog Society's position.

1) These changes discriminate against an entire class of people with disabilities 

2) Potential fraudulent activity is not a valid reason to discriminate against people with psychiatric service animals

3) Psychiatric service dogs are no more susceptible to fraudulent activities than any other type of service animal
Thank you.

Title: Anonymous
Comment:
This ruling on PSA will be harmful for those that have these dogs for a legitmate illness.  Denying access to someone's service dog or requiring documentation above and beyond those with guide dogs or other service dogs is discriminatory.  These ESA and PSA are service dogs that do provide a service just as real and legitimate as other types of dogs.
Also there is nothing in the regulation that guarentees the airline will be protective of private medical information that is protected under HIPPA law.  How will the airlines be required to comply with HIPPA regulations reguarding these PSA's and ESA's?  This regulation is putting the airlines at risk of violating someone's medical privacy rights and at risk of law suits and federal action reguarding privacy breaches.

Title: Darrell R. Hudson
Comment: The airlines do not need to know the reason why a person has need for a service dog, as it is a private medical matter and is none of their business.  A service animal is a service animal regardless of reason for the need.

Title: Linden Lovvik
Comment:
I am interested in learning how flying will be any safer if the regulations remain in effect.

How will requiring people with PSDs to expose their medical information to non-medical personnel make flying safer?

If you believe that service animals in the cabin are a potential danger to passengers, I'd expect you would want all SD handlers to be cleared for flight.

Title: Mary Lafia
Comment: Psychiatric Service Dogs have to mitigate a disability as do all service dogs.  I see no reason why psychiatric disabilities should be singled out for different rules than those with any other disability.  They use their dogs to be able to travel the same as people with other disabilites.  Their disabilities are invisible but so are many other disabilities.  Their dogs are trained to high standards and they work as a team in order to enjoy the same benefits other people take for granted.  To require a different standard for one class of people is unfair and discriminatory.

Title: Anonymous
Comment: It seems you've thought of another way to humiliate and further stigmatize mental illness.   Either require documentation from everyone with a support animal or don't. Singling out ONE group of many is obvious discrimination and a needless invasion of their privacy.

Title: Bradley W. Morris
Comment:
I am responding to a 2-point Anonymous post from 11/30 (Document ID:  DOT-OST-2009-0093-0072), partly quoted here:  (1) "The rules should stay as-is. Allowing the airlines to require 48 hours notice is not a problem, as it is not a requirement so the airlines are free to waive the rule or the amount of time for last-minute bookings." /____/
This point is analogous to saying that merely allowing people to own slaves is unproblematic, since no one's required to, so people could not own slaves as they see fit.  Clearly, allowing an injustice, even if that injustice isn't required, is still an injustice.  Allowing discrimination against persons with specific kinds of disabilities, in addition making it seem like standard protocol to, and somehow relying on the good faith of every airline employee not to discriminate--well, this is ill-considered and naive in the most harmful way. /____/
(2) "As for the confidentiality of the doctor's letter, in my experience (when I had an ESA), the airline does not keep copies of the letters on file or anywhere else. They look over the letter handed to them by the passenger to see that it fits their requirements and then they hand it back to the passenger. Therefore, there is no need to worry about the information getting into the wrong hands and there is no need to set up a system for such letters. " /____/
This sentiment is equally naive, and is analogous to thinking that since you've never been the victim of identity theft, there's no need for a system to protect anyone from identity theft.  Unlike the healthcare industry, which has explicit standards for handling personal health information (via HIPAA), there are no clear standards for airline personnel.  An intelligent system is designed to prevent mishaps, not assume they'll never happen, but if they do, provide an ad hoc patch.  Allowing airlines to require documentation and notice is wrong, at least for service animals, but if it happens, it should at least be done right.

Title: Laurie E. Werbner
Comment:
I believe it is wrong for the Department of Transportation to discriminate against an entire group of people with disabilities, i.e., those who rely on psychiatric service dogs to assist with mental health disabilities. Changes to the DOT rules are not warranted given the lack of evidence on fraudulent usage of service animals or emotional support animals.  This is not a valid reason for discrimination against psychiatric service animal users. If written documentation is not required for non-psychiatric service animals, it should not be required for psychiatric service animals. Not requesting the identical documentation from all other people with disabilities discriminates against a single population of people who use service dogs to assist with their disabilities. 
There are no data to prove that Psychiatric Service Animals are ‘faked’ more than other types of service animal. This false claim by the DOT has been made simply because a psychiatric service dog handler’s disability is invisible. To assume this with no data discriminates against an entire population of disabled people, i.e., individuals with mental illnesses, including military veterans who have come home suffering from PTSD, one of many serious (though invisible) psychiatric diagnoses for which psychiatric service dogs have provided enormous undeniable assistance. The creators of the ACAA wisely forbade discrimination against some individuals with a clause addressing nondiscrimination on the basis of disability. If documentation, 48 hours notice, special certificates, doctor's notes, letter to the airline, etc. is not required for all people who rely on service dogs, people with PSDs should not be forced to meet special requirements. Requiring a person to reveal the nature of her disability is a potential legal violation of medical privacy (see HIPPA), trespasses on personal privacy. There is no adequate justification here for singling out & discriminating against one class of people with disabilities.

Title: Karen E. Alexander
Comment:
This law is in direct violation of the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA).  I, as a disabled person using a service dog, should NOT be required to do any of the procedures this law is requiring me to do before traveling on a plane.  Please change this law to be in comliance with the ADA.

Karen Alexander 
PTSD Veteran USAF

Title: Linda Maxine Corbridge
Comment:
I believe that the changes for the mentally ill should not be discriminated against. The potential fraudulent activity is not a valid reason to discriminate against people with psychiatric service animals and the the Psychiatic service dogs are no more susceptible to fraudulent activities than any other service animal. This is not right. I am a mother of a young woman in this kind of situation and she is unable to do without her service dogs. Please do not pass this bill. 
                            Thank you, Mrs. Corbridge

Title: Anonymous
Comment: It seems to me that this requirement is overly broad as well as discriminatory.  If you are concerned about people (anyone) passing off a pet as a service animal, why not require some sort of ID or letter (including photo) for the service animal, to be obtained once, which simply identifies the pet as a service animal?  This should, of course, be applied to all service animals.  It would not violate privacy the way that requiring medical information would.

Title: Lorre Leon Mendelson
Comment:
I find this law to be discriminatory against people with psychiatric diagnoses and would like it changed immediately so that no one with a disability is required to provide documentation for their service animal or disability. Some of us don’t believe our disability is a medical issue. 

I believe this law is not reflective of our values in 2009, of tolerance, acceptance and equal rights. I have a service dog who assists me with Depression, PTSD and OCD. I unexpectedly had to fly to a funeral in CA from TN in July 2009.  In a very short period of time, in order to comply with the law, I had my psychiatrist write a letter as required by law. She was reticent and it cost me $25 for her to write this. I also had to call 48 hours in advance and talk with a stranger about my having mental illness and bringing my service dog. This must be in violation of HIPPA. It was an humiliating experience. 

I urge you to dispose of this law and help end discrimination and prejudice against people with psychiatric diagnoses and all disabilities. Thank you, Lorre Leon Mendelson

Title: Valerie Stocking
Comment:
To Whom It May Concern,

I am writing to request the repeal of 14 CFR 382 (Nondiscrimination on the basis of Disability in Air Travel).

As a mental health consumer with a trained Psychiatric Service Dog, I fly 1-2 times a year.  I find the process of pre-boarding stressful enough as it is.  let alone if I have to show a letter revealing to a non-medical professional that I have a mental illness.  This type of disclosure should not have to happen.  Or, if it does, then all passengers flying with service dogs should be required to present such documentation before they board the plane.

The DoT stated that this documentation for those with mental illness will prevent others with pets from claiming that they are emotional support dogs or psychiatric service dogs.  This may be true, but that won't stop these people.  They will merely change tactics, and state that their pet is a seizure alert dog, or a diabetes alert dog, or come on board with a cane feigning mobility issues.  I actually know of two people who planned to feign blindness, wear their sunglasses in the cabin, and state that their dogs were guide dogs!

The DoT has claimed that this is a serious problem, and that there are many examples of those with pets claiming a psychiatric disability boarding planes.  Why, then, do they have no documentation of these claims?  Who is keeping track of all this?  So far, no evidence has been presented.  

I for one resent this discrimination.  Why should I be subjected to screening that others with service dogs are not?
This regulation undermines the ADA, and is discriminates against a group of people who are already marginalized by society.

Please rescind 14CFR 382.

Thank you for your attention.

Sincerely,

Valerie Stocking

Title: Michele L. Mellema
Comment:
Part 2 of 3
Per ACAA definitions: "Service Animal
Any animal that is individually trained or able to provide assistance to a qualified person with a disability; or any animal shown by documentation to be necessary for the emotional well being of a passenger."
Note the first clause of that phrase.  A PSD does much more than help with a persons emotional well being.  They don't just sit there and look cute.  They are by definition trained to mitigate their partner's disability.  

Some PSD are even able to do some of their work in flight.  Many can alert their handler to an oncoming panic attack, allowing the partner to begin relaxation techniques or take necessary rescue medications just for one example.  This happens much earlier than the handler would normally notice by themself, which can allow the chance to avoid a scene in flight.  In the airport, they can help mitigate the effects of some medications that are often taken pre-flight that have side effects such as dizziness.  Some PSD are trained in balance and guide work to assist their partners in safely moving around in crowds.
A sample IAADP task that could transfer to an in flight environment: "Dog is trained to vigorously lick someone’s face on command to bring his partner to full awareness, just as seizure response dogs can be trained to do when their partner is extremely groggy after a grand mal, which shortens the recovery time.  This unpleasant tactile stimulation also can divert the partner’s attention from something that triggers tears or other inappropriate emotional reactions in school or a workplace."
Most service animals just hang out for the ride, a PSD can feasibly be actively on duty for the flight.

Title: Michele L. Mellema
Comment:
Part 1 of 3 
I agree with the PSDS's opinion on the issue of extra restrictions being placed on only PSD and not other types of service animals.  
A PSD has had extensive training in how to behave in public and in tasks or work that mitigate their handler's disability.  They are not pets, but they are pieces of medical equipment, just like a service dog trained to help with any other type of disability such as blindness, deafness, or mobility impairments.

An ESA is a pet that has been given legal status and access to non pets housing under the Fair Housing Act, and to airplanes by the ACAA.  They do not have to have any special training.  

Requiring one class of disability to get documentation that is not required of other people with disabilities or other passengers is discrimination.  (I'm not even going into the associated costs etc. which have been brought up numerous other times.) Some doctors will not write notes as not all doctors are familiar with the possibility that a dog can be trained to help a person with a mental disability as they are a relatively new concept.  In addition to the PSDS, the IAADP (International Association of Service Dog Partners) and ADI (Assistance Dogs International) which are both long standing entities in the SD world recognize a PSD as a legitimate type of service dog.  The US government (DOD/VA) is funding a study of service dogs for PTSD for returning war veterans.  Is the DOT honestly going to tell disabled war veterans that they have to go through extra red tape to catch a flight because their disability is mental instead of physical? 

I would also like to add that of all the possible things to choose to fake a SD for, I would think that mental illness would be someone's last choice.  There's a lot of stigma involved with mental illness, as proven here by the acts of the DOT.  Diabetes, seizures, and many other invisible disabilities do not have near the stigma involved.

Title: Michele L. Mellema
Comment:
Part 3 of 3
I propose allowing all service animals the same "credible verbal/visual assurance" and actually levying a heavy fine and/or jail time for people that are not disabled and lie about taking their untrained pets and show dogs (for a previously listed example) with them as a service animal.  A person caught faking could be blacklisted from flying for a predetermined amount of time such as 3-5 years along with a heavy fine.  Make it so that doing it twice results in mandatory jail time, even stiffer fines, permanent no flight status, and permanent removal of the animal from their possession.  Make it a very unattractive option to be caught flying without a disability and claiming your dog is a service animal or even with a disability claiming your untrained animal as a service animal.

A person with a disability isn't always going to be carrying documentation stating they are disabled (see also title 3 of the ADA, the Business Brief, and FAQ from the ADA), however they would likely be able to back it up after the trip has been completed and they are back home.  Someone faking wouldn't have the same luxury.  Find a way to flag the person if it really is that bad in an individual situation and afford the person a reasonable opportunity to either clear up their disabled status or if in question the dog is indeed a trained service dog for their disability upon return home and if they can't provide reasonable proof (such as a training journal or if trained by a school or private trainer documentation from them stating the dog has been trained) then begin prosecution.

Title: Patricia Joan Thayer
Comment: I am very disappointed to learn that the DOT may begin to single out the mentally ill for proof that their dog is a service dog and required by a doctor.  Are you going to do the same to the blind with a seeing eye dog? Of course not! Sigleling out one group of disabled people for even further discrimination is reprehensible.  I used to fly, but if my dog would be treated like baggage, I would never fly again. I'd donate my several tickets worth of frequent flyer miles to a charity and just plan to never fly the unfriendly skies.

Title: Debbie Bader
Comment:
These rules are hardly "nondiscriminatory".  Why are you singling out people with psychiatric disabilities?   No other service dog teams are being asked to provide any kind of "proof" that they have "real" service dogs.
 
I thought we were actually at a point where society was working past the stigma associated with mental illness.  Sadly, it seems the DOT is way behind the times.

ESA's are another matter entirely.  They are not legally recognized as SERVICE DOGS, nor do they (or should they) be put into the same category as PSDs.
 
Repeal this rule.  Psychiatric SERVICE DOGS handlers should NOT have a separate set of requirements than those using other types of SERVICE DOGS.

Title: Steve Bader
Comment:
These rules only serve to make life more difficult for those who already find their days challenging enough.  Even though you cannot see it, these people fight their own inner battles every day - and I'm proud of them for moving forward in their lives with the use of trained service dogs.
 
What I am NOT proud of is how our government (this time, the DOT) continues to find ways to segregate such people - who are just trying to find a way to peacefully live their lives.  If a trained service dog helps them to function better in this world - more power to them!  Your rules, which force them to "out" themselves to airline staff just to take a trip with their dogs are not only insensitive, but also violate their right to privacy, HIPPA, and the ADA.
 
Take this so called "nondiscriminatory" rule back, and stop giving the mentally ill such a hard time.  They have enough to deal with already without some bureaucrat telling them they need a note from their doctor and 48 hours notice to fly with their service dogs.  You don't ask this of any other service dog handlers, it's not right to ask it of the mentally disabled either.

Title: C.V.
Comment:
Please insure that individuals with psychiatric disabilities and/or physical disabilities that require a service dog are not discriminated against in public transportation. Please insure, especially, that American military veterans with these disabilities are not discriminated against.
I am a Vietnam combat veteran. However, I do not have any physical nor mental disability.
Thank you.

Title: Anonymous
Comment:
If a service dog, no matter what kind, has the proper identification, and is wearing a vest that identifies the service dog as such, it must not matter what disability the person has. If the dog does not have proper ID, a vest, then they are not truly a service dog. 
The identification might even contain a picture to it is clear that this is the actual animal that is a service dog.
Service dogs are vital to people with many disabilities. They musts be allowed in hospitals and other locations. If someone can't show the identification, then the dog does not have proper training to be a service dog.
My daughter is blind and has a guide dog. She carries documents that state such, he wears his harness, he is cared for in specific ways that guard against fleas and other things. She does not have to show a letter from a doctor stating she needs hime, so people with mental illness or other disorders that are not visible, should have the same guidelines.
Any other way of treating people with mental illness who have service dogs would be discrimination.

Title: Julie Ryle
Comment:
Requiring seperate conditions for service dog handlers with psychiatric disabilities is discrimination.  Someone who uses a psychiatric service dog is disabled just as is someone who uses a seeing eye dog, mobility assistance dog, seizure alert dog, etc.  The ADA states that service dogs do not have to be certified, vested, or have proof of their handler's disability.

Emotional Support Animals are NOT service animals, they are not trained to perform tasks/work, and are simply snuggly feel good pets.  It is reasonable for the airlines to require additional documentation for them to be brought aboard a plane.  

Additionally, there is no credible evidence of fraudulant use of service dogs whose handlers have "invisible" disabililties. 

Having a Psychiatric Service Dog allows people with a disabling mental illness to more successfully live life.  Discriminating against such service dog handlers is wrong, and should not be tolerated.

Require documentation for Emotional Support Animals, but leave true Service Dogs alone - do not segregate Psychiatric Service Dog Teams from other service dog teams by requiring additional documentation and early notification.

Title: Nancy L. Young
Comment: Without even uttering the word discrimination, I don't understand why the powers that be don't "get it". If a person is qualified for a service dog in any capacity, particularly someone with a mental illness or needing emotional support, then they need their dogs on a plane, on a trip and in new and different situations like these. Service dogs are incredibly well trained and are not a problem in any place they go to. If having their service dog," they" meaning people with emotional issues and mental health issues (which are quite intertwined), is a calming and much needed effect on a plane with people who are unknown to the dog's owner, how can anyone not see the benefits to everyone on the plane? If someone with a mental illness and an amputation brought a service dog on a plane and had a letter proving this was "legal" due to an amputation and trouble being mobile, nobody would think twice about it The mental illness would be unknown to the airlines and the amputation would be acceptable, but to the dog's owner, it would be incredibly important to have the dog along because of whatever the trip could cause without the dog's support. I thought people were becoming more informed and accepting of mental illness, but I am wrong. Unless it is you or someone in your family, let's keep it locked up in the closet? I think that whomever is responsible for this major error needs to be educated.

Title: Jerold Towber
Comment:
Your "seperate but" equal policy creating extra administrative hurdles for people with disabilities is reprehensible.

It is also unconstitutiional and violative of Title VII and Section 504, etc.

I am a lawu yer with a service dog and a mental disability.

You will not get away with this.

Thank You.

Jerold Towber,Esq.

Title: Lisa Waldman
Comment:
These rules demand written documentation, such as a note from a mental health professional testifying to the need for the animal to accompany the passenger, 48 hours in advance for both psychiatric service animals and emotional support animals to be allowed on an aircraft. This is not required for service animals of people with disabilities that are not psychiatric in nature.
 
So you are discriminating against people with psych disabilities versus physical ones. Isn't that illegal somhow. Doesn't the DOT have more important things to do with it's time like help make sure planes are safe, pilots are not intoxicated, etc. The stigma associated with psychiatric disabilities is enough by itself, DOT does not need to add to that.

Title: Tricia Marie Morrissette
Comment: I belive that if a person has a service animal that they should be allowed to bring that animal onto an airplane without having to provide 48 hour notice, or show all kinds of documentation. A phychiatric disability is still a disability, no madder how you look at it. I believe that is is discrimination to tell someone that they can not take their service animal onto a plane because the animal is for a phychiatric  disability.

Title: Cheryl Lichak
Comment: Why do people with mental illness have to keep fighting these stupid government regulations. People with mental disabilities are DISABLED and deserve the same respect as people with other disabilities. A service dog is a service dog wheteher it is helping a physically challenged person or a mentally challenged person. When are you people going to get it right!

Title: Eileen Raizen
Comment: See attached file.

Title: Dustan Anne Kessel
Comment:
Concerning the regulations to be imposed upon owners of psychiatric service dogs by the DOT, I am appalled.  I am a veteran of the United States Navy and I have a younger brother with autism who may one day need and friends who rely upon their psychiatric service dogs.

It is inappropriate to have airline employees asking psychiatric dog owners for PROOF their need for their dog or reason for bringing their dog and then asking for a doctor's note for travelling with your dog. 

This law is being put into place for the airlines to avoid confusing people without disabilities traveling with dog who abuse the emotional support animal rule.  Shame on those who abuse the rule and shame on the DOT for imposing a regulation that separates one type of disability from others in order to imposes a higher standard of proof by showing medical documentation to travel with their service dog.

Can we license/certifiy dogs as opposed to labeling people?

If a dog is certified as a service dog, shouldn't we be asking for the dog's credentials, not identifying the disability of the person using the dog.

Title: Anonymous
Comment: My emotional support dog provides me with a sense of safety, helping me step out in the world and be among people. As written, DOT’s proposed rule fosters an already painful shame for being chronically, although invisibly, mentally ill. The rule would characterize me as a presumed liar and someone intending to abuse the system. By requiring me to acquire a mental health professional to attest to the veracity of my illness and need for my emotional support dog, I am transformed from a respected paying passenger to a certified mentally ill person whose dignity and privacy can be dismissed. DOT assumes that because my disability might not be apparent, I should be required to disprove the presumption that I am abusing the transportation system. I ask that DOT not make me submit to humiliating requirements that would first identify me as someone with a mental illness and second renders me undeserving of the respect, compassion and trust bestowed upon other passengers.

Title: Dwayne L. Gillispie
Comment:
It has come to our attention that under the new Rules that persons with invisible disabilities will be subjected to a higher level of scrutiny than those persons with visible disabilities in the right to be accompanied by a Service Animal in Public Transportation.

With the new requirements of producing medical proof of the disability and the need to be accompanied 48 hours in advance of the flight would prevent an emergency flight by a person with such a disability.

Equate the Service dog to the need for a person to take tranquilizers or sedatives. Or even a person suffering from a heart condition. Should those persons be required to be drug free and not have medication available on the flight? 

The right of a person to be accompanied by a service animal must be applied equally and can not be restricted to just the visible disability. That right to be accompanied by a service animal must be applied equally to all persons with a disability. Failure to provide equal treatment results in a discrimination and will result in much litigation in the Courts.

I would urge the Department of Transportation to restrict their rules to that which provides equal treatment under the law. To deviate from that equal treatment would be discrimination without a question.

Thank you,
Dwayne L. Gillispie
American Legal Foundation of Florida
alf.law.officelive.com

Title: Anonymous
Comment: I sincerely feel that service animals for psychiatric illnesses in air travel are a considerable asset to society.  They help to calm their owners down.
