People with psychiatric illnesses have had enough of their freedom removed as it is in our country.  At least give them a chance to travel using their helpful companions to make it possible.  Have mercy on them.

Title: Robert Leroy Hanafin
Comment: As a member of the Editorial Board or a national Veterans and Military Families News Network, I concur with views of the Association for Airline Passenger Rights (AAPR). What may concern America’s Veterans returning from the wars in Iraq and Afghanistan diagnosed with PTSD or other invisible wounds of war is that DOT's new rules [Sections J82.1J 7(e) & 382.27(c)(8)] violate the legislative intent of the law (49 U.S.C. 41705), which provides that no air carrier may discriminate against any otherwise qualified individual with a disability, by reason of such disability, in the provision of air transportation. I believe that the revised regulations governing Psychiatric Service Animals unfairly discriminates against people with psychiatric disabilities. Most psychiatric disabilities, including Post Traumatic Stress Disorder (PTSD), are by nature a hidden disability, unlike more apparent physical disabilities that can be seen with the naked eye. The requirements spelled out in Section 382.117(e) are discriminatory for people with hidden disabilities versus people with physical disabilities, thereby treating one class of disabled passengers differently than other classes of disabled passengers, as well as their nondisabled counterparts. The requirement also imposes on passengers with psychiatric disabilities new time restrictions, added expenses and potentially embarrassing situations with airport and airline staff that forces them to reveal the nature of their hidden disability - which also raises significant privacy concerns. The DOT requirements should also have input from the various airlines that have to implement these rules, because the end result will most certainly be legal litigation aimed at the Airline Industry and DOT. Furthermore, since no data exists to document that a problem exists whereby passengers without disabilities are trying to "pass off pets as service animals, DOT's requirement is punishing the very passengers that it is intended to protect under the law. It appears that the more prudent approach would involve DOT working with input from the airlines - and advocacy groups - on data collection to ascertain whether widespread misuse and violations of the protections by non-disabled passengers exists before imposing an added barrier to passengers needing Psychiatric Service Animals.

Title: Anonymous
Comment:
The rules associated with bringing a psychiatric guide dog on an airplane are unfair, discriminatory and humiliating to people with this type of disability. Requiring them to have to meet standards above and beyond those for individuals with other types of working animals will discourage them from travelling by air. It will lead to increased scrutiny and anxiety for those who need a specialized psychiatric therapy dog to fly and can make the symptoms of their disability worse.  Is this the intent of the rules? 
DOT should begin a new rulemaking process in this practice.

Title: Joe Fitzgerald
Comment:
Respectfully, it appears discriminatory to require individuals with a "psychiatric disability" to open up their medical status to airline personnel.

Why shouldn't this rule expand to include a requirement that  individuals seeking to eat in a restaurant with their service animal will need to submit documentation a day in advance of their reservation?

It seems that airline personnel can easily determine if a claimant has an animal that is not able to comply with the behavioral boundaries expected of a qualified service animal.

I believe it IS reasonable for customers to provide documentation that their service animal has been "certified" by an organization, as well as their physician.

But to require an additional set of "hoops" for those who are legitimately disabled, is a set-back.

One additional note:  To ask those veterans who now utilize service animals for their PTSD diagnosis, to go through the additional humiliation of discussing why their animal is accompanying them, only re-introduces the pain and terror that brought on the condition in the first place.

For the record, I am an individual with a "physical" disability that has been certified by vocational rehabilitation.  I have not, nor do I intend, to seek any financial benefit.  My own service animal is certified and has flown without difficulty on a number of occassions.

I have, however, been the victim of job discrimination that could not be protected because I was considered a "contractor."

In conclusion:  Are there people who violate the spirit and intent of the A.D.A. in order to travel with their animals?  Undoubtedly, yes.

But I submit that any airline can easily determine of that animal's behavior is inappropriate to travel, and handle such cases on an individual basis.

Thank you for the opportunity to respond.  Don't hesitate to contact me if I can provide further input.

Title: Molly P. Hauck
Comment:
On May 13, 2009, the Department of Transportation's (DOT) Air Carrier Access Act revised regulations went into effect. These rules for the first time applied U.S. nondiscrimination provisions on foreign air carriers with flights that originate in the U.S.

However, another provision of the regulations requires a uniquely high level of documentation from individuals who seek to board aircraft with psychiatric service animals or emotional support dogs.

These rules demand written documentation, such as a note from a mental health professional testifying to the need for the animal to accompany the passenger, 48 hours in advance for both psychiatric service animals and emotional support animals to be allowed on an aircraft. This is not required for service animals of people with disabilities that are not psychiatric in nature.
 
Seeing the regulations as discriminatory to people with mental illnesses, the Psychiatric Service Dog Society attempted to stop the rule a few months before it went into effect, but wa

Title: B. L.
Comment: If documents  will not be required, people will abuse the privilege and will  bring their pets even if they don't really need it for their mental health. THis will cause chaos and great discomfort to other people.

Title: Melissa Szumlinski
Comment: I agree with Psychiatric Service Dog Society.   100%.  Please consider the ramifications of discrimination based on disability.

Title: Carol Lang
Comment: I support the idea of service animals on planes if they are caged and the owner buys them a seat on the plane where they place the cage.

Title: Nicole Glasser
Comment: If someone is blind should they be required to get a letter from their doctor confirming they are blind and require a service dog to be with them at all times? I mean, they could be pretending right?  And what about people who need their dog to alert them that a seizure is coming on, I mean they could be making it up too right?  I mean, they may just look like any other person.  Seems a little offensive doesn't it? Yet this appears to be the thinking with a mental health condition.

Title: Ann Crownover
Comment: Being a parent of a child diagnosed with Bipolar Disorder, I feel this is a highly discriminatory law.  As diabetics, blind indiviuals, etc., are not required to present written documentation at least 48 hours prior to their flight, why should individuals with a mentall illness have to do this?  This may present a problem for a person who wants to travel, if they may not be able to access their psychiatrist prior to their flight.  I also personally know people who have emotional support dogs, and know how well-trained and well-behaved these dogs are.  This law must be done away with in order for people with mental illness to have the same rights as people with "non-psychiatric" disorders.

Title: Caroline Fisher
Comment:
People with mental illness face significant stigma and discrimination.  As a psychiatrist, I see every day the effects of discriminatory rules made in the mistaken belief that mental illness is not "real,"  not biological, not legitimate and somehow not deserving of the consideration of society even as mental illness has been determined by the World Health Organization to be one of the leading causes of morbidity across the world.  I urge you to end this discriminatory regulation.  Treat people with mental illness with the same respect as those with  any illness.  
Although I travel extensively, I almost never see a service dog of any kind.  Will allowing people to travel with their psychiatric service dogs without disclosing their private medical information really be such a threat to public safety that it justifies the shame and humiliation of these regulations?  I cannot see how it would.

Title: Yvonne Barash
Comment:
Please reconsider the requirement of extra documentation and 48 hours prior notice for allowing mental health service animals to accompany passengers on air travel.  This cumbersome paperwork is not required for service animals used by the those with other disabilities, and I am concerned that it adds to the stigma of mental health issues.

Thank you.

Sincerely,

Yvonne Barash R.N.  B.S.N.

Title: Carol S. Hall
Comment: Requiring additional restrictions on those with psychiatric sevice animals is discriminatory and stigmatizing.  People with psychiatric service animals should be subjected to the same rules as other service dogs.

Title: Marge
Comment: I suffer from depression, PTSD and have physical limitations.  I am on disability and live in a LOT of pain.  To look at me, you'd never know.  Every day I have to apply all my strength, mentally and physically to be able to leave the house.  I am ashamed when I stay housebound.  I live alone and have no family; at least I have two rescue kitties.  I dream of going places and maybe someday I will have a service dog to help me live life.  That 48hr notice is abusive.  Just the pressure of that would probably cause me to cancel trip.

Title: Deborah Anne Kinmonth
Comment: A service dog is a service dog, period! No matter what service they are performing it is necessary. The idea that mentally impaired people should have to go through more hoops than other disabled people is reprehensible, and discriminatory. Any service dog, by definition, flies - regardless of their owner's impairment. A service dog would not be given to a person who did not have a need for it.

Title: Denise Wetzler
Comment: Please stop discriminating against individuals with a mental illness that also choose to use a service dog. Any type of service dog can be faked if one so chooses. My service dog allows me to function in society. I am no more likely to cause a problem on a plane than the person seated next to me because I have a mental illness. With my service dog I am far less likely to cause a problem on the plane than the person seated next to me. My service dog is trained to mitigate a disability, not keep me company. My disability is covered under the ADA just like an individual who is blind, Deaf, or has seizures; so is my right to use a service dog to assist me. Do not force an undue burden upon psychiatric service dog users that other individuals with disabilities are not forced to bear. Do not continue to stigmagize an entire population because of the ignorance and bigotry of others. We are unfairly stigmatized in our daily lives, please do not add to this injustice in order to allow us to fly with our service dogs. If you are concerned about 'fake' service dogs, then make the requirements across the board to be fair. HIPPA protects my medical information; you are forcing individuals with mental illnesses to disclose what is protected by law. I do not trust untrained airline personnel to keep my medical information private, and it is none of their business, just as it is none of their business if a person is diabetic or has seizures, or is blind or Deaf, or mobility impaired. If you want a class action lawsuit, then keep the rules as they are. If you want to truly NOT discriminate on the basis of disability in air travel, then please change these rules and eliminate the undue burden now placed on those using psychiatric service dogs. Enough is enough. Thank you.

Title: Rebecca Sue Jones
Comment:
Regardless of the outcome of the discussion on this topic, the title of the document should be changed. Technically, grammatically, this means: A person cannot be discriminated against on the basis of their ability (or disability) TO TRAVEL THROUGH THE AIR (ie, if they are incapable of flight without an airplane, for example).  The proper title should be "Nondiscrimination on the Basis of Use of Psychiatric Service Animals" (which could also be misconstrued--are the service animals themselves mentally ill?--but I believe it is the formal, legal title for those animals.)

Thanks.

Rebecca Jones

Title: Stephanie Lynn McCown
Comment: I agree with the recommendaitons of the Psychiatric Service Dog Society's comments.

Title: Amber J. Whelan
Comment: Please don't take away one more thing from the people who were born without the everyday luxuries of those without disabilities, be they physical or mental.  Service / Therapy / and Companion dogs all play an equally important role in the lives of those who need to utilize them.  Even if you can't sympathize, please have empathy.

Title: Handi-Dogs, Inc.
Comment:
Handi-Dogs, Inc. teaches individuals with disabilities covered under the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA) to train their own assistance dog. The Federal Register that came out in October 2008 somewhat clarified the distinction between a companion dog and a service dog. Under the ADA a service animal must be "trained". In additions, the Americans with Disabilities Amendment Act recognizes that individuals with mental and emotional disorders have rights under the ADA. This recognition is long overdue.

Handi-Dogs supports the Psychiatric Service Dog Society's position that individuals experiencing mental and emotional disorders who have "trained" service dogs should not be singled out by the airlines, or any other industry, by being required to provide 48 hours notice before flying with their dog. Individuals experiencing such disorders have the right to parity under the law.

Title: Adelbert Vincent Acey
Comment: It is inconceivablel that a mentally disabled person who has an emptional service dog is not allowed the same care as those with recognized disabilitys. I strongly reccomend that this regulation be thrown out and that mentally disturbed people can and will have the right to have their emotional service dog with them

Title: Anonymous
Comment: I am writing to oppose the document. It is extremely discriminatory, and will cause undue hardship for those citizens who depend on their Psychiatric Service Dogs to lead a more normal life. This country is founded on equality for all, but this new regulation limits the freedom to travel for a significant segment of our population.

Title: Eric Oscar Jackson-Rivera
Comment: Different rules are not necessary. This also suggests a violation of the privacy of persons living with mental diversities and disabilities.

Title: Nebraska Advocacy Services, Inc.
Comment:
DEPARTMENT OF TRANSPORTATION

Office of Secretary

14 CFR Part 382

Docket-OST-2009-0093

Nondiscrimination on the Basis of Disability in Air Travel


Submitter Information

Name:	Ronald J DeMers, Case Advocate
Agency:	Nebraska Advocacy Services, Inc.
		The Center for Disability Rights, Law and Advocacy


General Comment

In 1990, the U.S. Department of Transportation (DOT) promulgated the official regulations implementing the Air Carrier Access Act (ACAA).  As guidance for these regulations, the DOT used the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA) service animal guide issued by the Department of Justice (DOJ) in July 1996.  The purpose of the DOJ and ADA was and still is to promote equal access and inclusion to all individuals with disabilities.  Part 382 references the ADA and the Americans with Disabilities Act Accessibility Guidelines (ADAAG) for such concepts as “equivalent facilitation” of service animals.  It is quite clear that the meaning of the ADA and ADAAG as issued by the DOJ is quite prevalent in these regulations.  However, under the Final Rule, published on May 13, 2009, there is an extreme deviation from the meaning or intent of the ADA, the ADAAG, the DOJ or the Americans with Disabilities Amendment Act (ADAA) .  At no time in the previous documents mentioned has it ever been considered, intended or acceptable to discriminate against a disability group, solely on the “fear” that someone may attempt to take advantage of the situation.  This “fear” is the same fear that has bred discrimination and continues to breed discrimination to this very day.  Discrimination will never be eliminated until such fears can be eliminated.   The outward appearance of combining a group of individuals with a disability who use qualified service animals and a group of individuals with a disability who do not have qualified service animals is simply to make it easier to discriminate against the group of individuals with a disability who use qualified service animals simply because of unwarranted and unjustified “fears” of some action that “may” occur in the future.  It is pointed out that the DOT has found individuals in both groups attempting to abuse this rule.  However, it is very difficult to believe that in the grand scope of all airline travels, that this is a major problem as much as some “isolated” incidents that have occurred in the past.  Of all of the major issues that face our airlines today, this has the appearance of being a minimal issue.  

The new provision “refines DOT’s previous definition of service animal by making it clear that animals that assist persons with disabilities by providing emotional support qualify as service animals and ensuring that, in situations concerning emotional support animals and psychiatric service animals, the authority of airline personnel to require documentation of the individual’s disability and that the passenger needs the emotional support or psychiatric service animal as an accommodation for air travel and/or for activity at the destination of the passenger traveling with the animal is understood”.  This serves to make it a “separate subgroup of a disability group”.   Although it is mentioned that many people use different terms for their service animals, typically describing the service the animal provides to the individual, i.e., seizure alert, hearing, signal, and psychiatric, etc., these are all qualified as service animals and fall under the protections of the ADA and the DOJ.  

There is mention of having a wide variety of service animals for individuals, i.e., cat, monkey, etc.,  however there is no mention of the fact that under the DOJ’s proposed regulations, service animals must be domesticated animals, i.e., no reptiles (lizards), no primates (monkeys), or other livestock (miniature horses).  These are the types of animals used as examples when the DOT created the new ACAA Rule 382 provisions.  Obviously, these animals would make it difficult to distinguish between pets and service animals.  However, with the removal of these types of animals from this argument, the only reasoning left to discriminate against individuals with service animals, regardless of the services provided, is for convenience of airline personnel, as “clear guidelines are needed to assist airline personnel...” in identifying service animals.  

As pointed out in the Guidance for Service Animals created by the DOT, training is, in most situations, the key.  However, the definition of service animal also includes an animal that has been shown to have the innate ability to assist a person with a disability.  Some animals that can provide functions for individuals independent of training are still considered service animals.  In determining if an animal is a service animal, the ACAA indicates that the airline personnel may 1) Obtain credible verbal assurance; 2) Look for physical indicators; 3) Request documentation of service animals other than emotional support or psychiatric service animals; 4) Require documentation for emotional support animals and psychiatric service animals; and 5) Observe the behavior of the animal.  The DOJ indicates that if a person is unclear if an animal is a service animal, he or she may ask only “what service does the animal perform?”  Inquiry into training is inappropriate as was just indicated, not all animals require specific training to perform functions for individuals.  Again, asking how an animal performs these tasks is inappropriate, as it goes beyond what is acceptable under the ADA and DOJ.  It should be understood that there must be some training for the animal, being obedience at a minimum, to ensure that the animal will not lunge, bark, growl, etc., which may disqualify the animal as a service animal, due to aggressiveness.  

It is inappropriate to place such differing disability groups, i.e., psychiatric service animal users versus emotional support animal users, into one “lump” group for individuals with psychiatric disabilities.  The stigma of having a mental illness or psychiatric disability is something that is very hard for an individual to overcome.  Now add the separation from the rest of society because the an individual with a disability has an avenue that will provide relief for psychiatric symptomology (psychiatric service animal), but has to identify their disability and provide documentation, which is not required under the ADA and DOJ, and make 48 hour advance notification of intent to fly with your service animal will only serve to increase the  stigmatization of an already over- stigmatized disability.

I urge you to revoke the rules that require documentation and advance notice of travel for users of psychiatric service animals, and instead follow the guidance of the ADA, DOJ, ADAA, and the ADAAG.

Title: Anonymous
Comment: It’s imperative not to create yet another discrimination within anti-discrimination regulations! After great effort to establish the ACAA rules, applying an altogether different set of requirements to people with mental disabilities than to people with with physical disabilities, the ACAA rules creates an inexcusable discrimination against the mentally ill!

Title: Anonymous
Comment: It’s imperative not to create discrimination within anti-discrimination regulations! After great effort to establish the ACAA rules, applying an altogether different set of requirements to people with mental disabilities than people with to people with physical disabilities, the ACAA rules creates an inexcusable discrimination against the mentally ill!

Title: Anonymous
Comment: I am not in favor of these regulations as they discriminate against an entire class of people with disabilities.

Title: Dorothea Ann Bawks
Comment: The amendments to the ADA now include people with psychiatric disabilities. It is no longer legal to use non equitable, discriminatory practices,policies and procedures toward people with psychiatric disabilities. Period!

Title: Susan Connor DVM
Comment: see attached letter for comments

Title: Jamelia Saied
Comment: Psychiatric service animals should be governed by the same rules that apply to other service/assistance/companion animals.  They should not be subjected to additional restrictions or documentation than other service animals.  This can create an unnecessary and burdensome situation for a consumer.  For example, tomorrow I am traveling from my home in Anchorage, AK to Seattle, WA for cancer treatment.  It was not until yesterday that I found someone to care for my registered service dog while I am gone.  I also did not find out about the rule change until yesterday.  My psychiatrist is out-of-town and I would have been forced to cancel my trip, at a high cost, if I had to take my dog with me because I could not comply with these new regulations.

Title: Joyce Grad
Comment:
Since earlier this year the DOT has demanded all persons whom utilize a psychiatric service dog to carry a note from their psychologist and have 48 hrs. between booking and boarding. I believe this to be unconscionable not only for the civilians who use these trained dogs but for our military with PSTD for whom these task trained dogs have broadened life and made life much easier. Several years ago I was denied the usage of a small service dog in a coop, which became Grad V. Royalwood  in the Federal Court System and with the help of MPAS and the DOJ I won the suit. It states in the story that I am bipolar, which while that is true, I am bipolar 2 the lesser of two degrees. The problem which significantly impacts my life is my PTSD.


Unfortunately there are many who do not wish to recognize this vital service dog. It is so important that we get this policy changed. Let's end the discrimination of PSD's now both with the DOT and IRS. IRS only allows medical deductions for those service dogs for individuals with physical problems: guide, seizure, deaf, etc.... The opposition states that fraud will be perpetrated is devoid of these facts. There is no other service dog including those with invisible disabilities, that is required to have documentation from the treating doctor in this case the psychiatrist and a 48 hr time lag from purchase to boarding.

 I am almost 60 and remember how badly we treated our Vets in Nam. Do not let this war continue devoid of the help that a PSD can give a veteran with severe PTSD.

An ESA is NOT the SAME as a PSD, and should need verification. However, to blanket the entire psychiatric community with these penalties when they are not addressed to other invisible disabilities is abhorrent.   PSD's are task trained dogs just as service dogss are trained for persons with physical disabilities.  

Personally speaking, my dog also serves me in mobility.  I see NO reason there should be a (2) service dog allowance.

Joyce Grad RN

Title: Debbie Evans
Comment:
Please, allow service dogs to be allowed,we are so dependent upon them.

Thank you,

Debbie E

Title: Kim Keever
Comment: I think that this is discriminatory make someone with a service dog for a mental illnes submit paperwork documenting their condition....A service dog is a service dog and should be treated as such whether or not for physical or for mental illness

Title: Lillyth Denaghy Keogh
Comment:
A service dog is a service dog is a service dog.  Regardless of disability, you NEED to allow ALL service animals with their owners.

I, for one, an severely allergic to animals, and will pitch a fit when someone enters a place with their animal.  HOWEVER, I recognize the necessity for service animals, and, in the past, have even allowed them in my place of business, despite the fact they make me ill.

You simply CANNOT discriminate against service animals.  To do so is to discriminate against their disabled owners.

Title: Shelby Nordhagen
Comment: I agree with the Psychiatric Service Dog Society's position.

Title: Lei Ellingson
Organization Name: The Carter Center Mental Health Program
Comment:
December 14, 2009
Office of the Secretary, DOT
OST–2009–0093:  

The Department of Transportation’s new regulations regarding the use of psychiatric service animals are a form of blatant discrimination against people with mental illnesses.  Individuals with other disabilities or disorders are not required to provide documentation or make public their illness. It is unfair and shameful to call out one disability. If these new rules are to be imposed on the use of PSAs, they ought to be imposed on everyone in need of a service animal.

Title: Candace L. True
Comment: A service dog is a service dog. The services they are performing are necessary and allow people with any disability - mental or physical to live useful, fulfilling lives that would otherwise be limited without the animal. Persons with a mental illness who are able to contribute to society and live fulfilling lives because of a service animal should not be treated any different than a person with any other type of disability.  Any service dog, by definition, flies - regardless of their owner's impairment. A service dog would not be used by a person who did not have a need for it.

Title: Michelle Renee Whitlock
Comment: This is not required for non-psychiatric problems and is unfair.  This is clearly discrimination against people w/mental illnesses.

Title: Joel Wier
Submitter Representative: Joe Wilson, Lindsey Graham, Jim DeMint
Comment: Service dogs have gained uniform acceptance in our society. Arbitraily enacting more stringent requirements on the service dogs of citizens who have a mental illness is discrimination and is extrememly stigmatizing. This seems arbitrary and capricious. Many of the people using mental illness service dogs are veterans. These veterans have perserved our freedoms. This proposed rule should not be implemented.

Title: Roger Cram
Comment:
Why is this necessary?
U.S. Department of Transportation would require owners of psychiatric service dogs to provide documentation from a licensed mental health professional at least 48 hours in advance of a flight that he or she has a mental or emotional disability and needs a psychiatric service animal as an accommodation for air travel.

Title: Kim Marie Campbell
Comment: I would like to sincerely recommend that the USA DOT will reconsider the recently implemented Draconian rule that those peoples' with a disability relating to Mental Health Illness using a TRAINED Service Dog/Animal to alliviate a life limiting aspect of thier illness, must provide a letter on the letterhead of their relevant Health Professional provider at least 48 hours before their flight leaves.  That  hose with Mental Illness's should be ALLOWED TO TRAVEL/FLY WITHOUT having to produce a letter on the letterhead of their relevent Health provider defining the users DSM-IV diagnosis is paramount.!  This is currently only asked of those with Mental Illness, no other class/type/severity of any disability is required to supply any PROOF of their disability, or justification of their use of their Service Dog/Animal.  This is blatent severe, and unjustified discrimiation.

Title: Sue Abderholden
Comment: We agree with the comments that have been submitted by the National Alliance on Mental Illness, our national office.  It is burdensome to require a person to obtain a letter 48 hours prior to a flight.  There is a shortage of mental health professionals and so once a person has been certified as needing or being able to benefit from a psychiatric service animal that should be good for a year or more.

Title: Deborah Lyne Berzins
Comment:
Have we learned nothing from all the civil rights movements?  ANY type of discrimination is wrong.  Asking for different documentation for PWDs who have mental illness is moving backwards, not into the future.

Give PWDs a break.  We have enough hoops to jump through without having to deal with even more paperwork just to travel from point A to point B

Title: Frank Mancuso
Comment:
Please remove the restrictions.
Psychiatric animals are not pets. You don't get the animal unless you need it and you don't keep it unless you keep psychiatrist appointments and stay on your meds.
Currently my daughter is in the process of being evaluated for a dog. She is flying more often on her job and the thinking is that a dog would help with her anxieties. Thank You

Title: Candice M.
Comment:
As a SD user, I find these new regulations requiring only PSD users to jump through extra hoops because of the possibility of fakers is discriminatory in and of itself.  ESA users, sure, make them do the 48 hr notice and drs note, etc.  This pet/animal has only access rights given them by the DOT in the first place.  ESAs can be used for people with severe non-disabling illnesses, have no access rights at a supermarket or other public places.  PSDs however, are for people with life limiting disabilities, have access rights through the ADA and shouldn't be given discriminatory treatment because of the possibility of a faker.  IF every type of SD needed these requirements, than it would suck, but it would just be what you had to do when flying with your SD.  This law, written as it is is very discriminatory and should have not gotten passed as it is.  Another thought, whats to stop someone who uses a PSD to change their verbiage at airports and say, yes this is my Medical Alert/Response SD.  Then they wouldn't need to jump through these hoops and they wouldn't be lying at all, it is still the truth as many many PSDs also do medical alert or response as a task/work for there handlers.  As to the question that was posed as to how a PSD works for its handler, I know of a PSD who alerts before her handler dissociates/blacks out due to severe DID (dissociative identity disorder), also before using a SD she used to injure herself many times a day, her SD uses tactile stimulation to keep her handler focused and SD body placement to make it physically impossible for the handler to harm herself.  People, objects, and other techniques had been tried in the past, all to no avail.  These are just 2 of over 30 tasks that this SD does to help her handler fly, drive, shop and basically live a more 'normal' life.
Please change this discriminatory ruling.  It is hard enough for a SD user to go through life w/ a SD. Why create one more barrier for our disabled citizens?

Title: Harold Gue
Comment:
An example of a tragic scenario that will eventually develop due to this regulation.

The Department of Defense and Department of Veterans Affairs are now making use of psychiatric service dogs in the treatment of PTSD (Post Traumatic Stress Disorder). 

A decorated combat veteran, being treated for PTSD with the help of a psychiatric service dog, is denied permission to fly to visit a dying family member because of their service dog. This veteran decides to leave the dog behind due to the time constraints. Later, this same veteran suffers a serious episode that endangers their life or the life of someone else. 

This story is most likely to make the news on some show such as 60 Minutes or 20/20. It will probably make the news around the same time some other unfortunate incident occurs because someone decided to "sneak" their dog onto a flight by pretending is a service dog for those suffering from some other "invisible" condition that is not psychiatric in nature. 

People will start asking who setup the rules so that they are ineffective and life threatening at the same time. 

Other people making use of service dogs are not required to meet this new rule, only those afflicted with psychiatric disorders such as depression or bipolar syndrome? Why would this rule only apply to those people and not others such as someone making use of a service dog for someone suffering from epileptic seizures or diabetes? Are psychiatric service dogs more susceptible to fraudulent behavior than other types of service dogs? 

How does this regulation stop potential fraud? Is someone who would be willing to commit this type of fraud going to be deterred because they cannot feign being crazy? These same hucksters will suddenly be stopped because everyone knows that crazy people are okay, but you don't want anyone to think you're diabetic or epileptic or blind or deaf or whatever other conditions may apply?

This rule is completely ineffective and a major hindrance in the lives of many people. Some of these may be potentially life threatening in nature. It discriminates against an entire group of people; it discriminates against those suffering from psychiatric disorders. 

If it does not violate the actual words of The American With Disabilities Act, it surely violates the principles upon which the law was originally created. 

This will definitely lead to lawsuits. Lawsuits that are going to cost the government lots of money to fight. These are also lawsuits that will, in all probability, will be lost by the government. 

Finally, why was this regulation originally created? 

The reasoning that it is to prevent fraud and abuse does not make sense. What is to prevent the same huckster from not claiming some other disability. This rule applied to all service dogs would at least make sense from this perspective. 

Was it originally meant to apply to all service dogs, but the bureaucracy felt it couldn't counter all the lawsuits that would be generated if applied in this manner? 

Was it made because someone confused “emotional support dogs” with “psychiatric service dogs”? All pets are “emotional support dogs”. A service dog is something altogether different. It is an understandable confusion, but now would be a good time to learn the differences.

Title: Anonymous
Comment: Then shall he answer them, saying, "Verily I say unto you, Inasmuch as ye did it not to one of the least of these, ye did it not to me".

Title: Dwayne Earle King
Comment: The requirement for medical certification of for mental health service dogs before commercial flights sounds like an excellent idea.

Title: Edie F. Pierce-Thomas
Comment:
My concern about psychiriatic comfort pets in travel is that some people have cats as their comfort pet and while I personnally am a cat lover, there are more poeple who are allergic to cats then there seems to be people allergic to dogs and so if a cat is allowed with the passengers on air travel or trains or ships, etc. others who are allergic could easily suffer in the closed space.  I have known many peole with cat allergies and it can effect them very quickly and very severely.  What would be done for those people?  Would, for example, the airline contact all the other passengers to tell the, that a cat (or any other animial for that matter) will be on board and they can change flights and then who will cover the cost of changing the flight?  

My experience also has been that work animals are trained and certified - i.e. seeing eye dogs, while psychiatric animcals are not and that can be a huge difference.  Some work dogs you don't even realize they are there, while with an untrained comfort animal, that it unlikely.

Thank you for considering this angle as well.

Title: Qantas Airways Limited
Comment: The attached document is the response provided by Qantas Airways Limited (ABN 33 069 720 243) in relation to the Petiiton made by the Psychiatric Service Dog Society (Docket No OST - 2009 - 0093).

Title: Faith E. Degnan
Comment: I agree with the Psychiatric Service Dog Society

Title: Melanie A. Foxcroft
Comment:
This is the THIRD time I have attempted to submit comments on this web site, the first two attempts were simply turned away for so-called "technical" reasons, with no method to correct whatever it was, please correct this immediately, dumping legitimate public comments is a travesty!!
Here are my comments:
The additional levels of requirements for travel with a companion animal for people with a disability of mental illness who need a companion animal as an accommodation are outrageous.  Institutionalizing discrimination for one type of disability compared to another (say, blindness) is highl discriminatory.  The same requirements must apply to all disabiities.

Title: Liz Rosenberg
Comment: My feeling is that if you have a service dog, the reason behind it is between you and your doctor.  Requiring people to provide a letter disclosing someone’s disability should be illegal.  It’s discrimination to do this for one group and not the others.  It’s wrong to require someone to give a 48-hour notice to fly to be accommodated with their service dog.  I bring a bag of pills every time I fly.  What are they going to require next…me to have to give a 48-hour notice before flying with my meds?  We need to be consistent up there like with the ADA down here.

Title: Denise Wetzler
Comment:
The rules confuse Emotional Support Animals (ESA) with Psychiatric Service Dogs (PSD). An ESA is nothing more than a pet, and documentation can and should be required for an ESA to travel in the cabin. A PSD is a highly trained Service Dog, trained to mitigate a disability, just like a guide dog for a person who is blind, or a hearing dog for someone who is Deaf or Hard of Hearing, or someone with a mobility impairment who uses a Service Animal, or someone who has seizures or diabetes. A PSD should be treated like any other category of Service Animal and not be subject to the undue burden currently placed on its user. 
The current rules and the 'suggestion' that a PSD can be faked in order to have one's pet travel in the cabin is promulgated by a population of Service Animal users who do not believe that a PSD is a legitimate Service Animal. Please do not allow the bigotry and prejudice of this group to cause one group of Service Animal users an undue burden, and to perpetuate the stigma that a person with a mental illness must face in everyday life. A person with a mental illness is no different than someone with diabetes, or heart disease, or epilepsy. The disability may be invisible, but it is there. A Service Animal will mitigate the disability of the individual that works with it, regardless of the type of disability. Please do not continue to discriminate against an individual that chooses to use a PSD in order to lead a more normal life. Allow them the rights accorded other Service Animal users when they choose to fly. Please, truly do not discriminate on the basis of disability in air travel.

Title: Greg N. Zima
Comment:
Having read the regulations, I truly believe this is discrimination.  It would discriminate against those with psychiatric disabilities.  Psychiatric dogs are used by Veterans with PTSD, autistic children, and those struggling with mood disorders. Besides blatant bias and disregard for someone's private life there are other questions that need to be answered.  How will the information be protected?  Are the airlines and DOT ready to handle that VERY private information?  Will they be liable if that information is leaked? Why are we putting the onus on people struggling with disabilities?  The responsibility should be on how dogs are registered.  If I did have a registered psychiatric dog, who in the airlines should have a right to question my doctor?

If a dog is registered as a Service Dog it is a Service Dog- period.  If there is a problem with how dogs are registered, then solve the problem there, not with DOT.  This is a case of 'mental profiling'.  Let's take a realistic view: we do not allow for racial or religious profiling, yet we can show data on terrorist attacks and crime rates based on both.  I don't see any data based on the abuse of a service animal (only the anticipation thereof).  If we are questioning the validity of a service dog, should we also question the validity of prescriptions by doctors?  There is so much flawed thinking in this regulation I hope the ACLU and the ADA comes on board.  I suspect this will end up in a lawsuit based on the obvious discrimination.  How do you prove someone with epilepsy really has what they say?  Should they show a 'doctor's note'? And when did DOT and the airlines become the disability police? In our American system we do not (and should not) infringe on the rights of those with legitimate disabilities to stop some from abusing the system.

Someone please contact me and explain how this does not discriminate against someone who served our country and now has a psychiatric disability.

Title: Rebecca Greeley
Comment: If all service dogs have to be registered with the State, why should some people with service dogs have obtain a doctor's note and paper submission with personal information to the airline 48 hours before a flight?? Why are the mentally ill being discriminated against? Why should the Department of Transportation be privy to my personal information if I require the use of s service dog? There are CERTAIN disabilities that require service dogs, and are allowed to have their dogs with them, with proof of a service dog certification, but not all disabilities are being treated the same? If a psychiatric patient has a service dog that is part of their coping, why should that service dog and the person supported by the dog, be treated any differently than a partially blind person or an epileptic? The onus should be put on the certification of the service dog BEFORE the patient travels with the service dog. The onus should NOT be on the psychiatric patient.  This adds a tremendous amount of stress to people who are already under mental stress, either from mental illness or post-traumatic stress syndrome.

Title: Alix Beaumont
Comment: I am twenty one years old and have a psychiatric service dog.  I receive a lot of discrimination because of my working dog, but I literally cannot leave my house without him on the best of days.  On the rare occasion I decide to venture out without him, I cannot handle myself.  I could lash out irrationally at people or decide to kill myself.  He tells me when my moods are going to change drastically for no reason and can help me keep my cool until I can get to my medication.  He really keeps me and everyone around me safe. I also am on the autism scale and it helps me come out of my shell when people start a conversation with something I really love...being as one is politics...the more appropriate thing is my dog. I've been learning to live alone, without my mom, but I fly a lot of places to visit my mom who works all over the country as a travel nurse...specializing in heart transplants. It would make things so much easier if I didn't have to worry about discrimination like I do everywhere else.  My dog and I have a codependent relationship and not allowing my service animal to fly with me is like telling me I cannot have my medication.

Title: Seth Langilotti
Comment:
To pass these changes would discriminate against a huge class of people with disabilities, and it is very unfair. 

My psychiatric service dog alerts to my anxiety before it reaches the point of "no return" so to speak. This allows me to medicate myself and come back down from the panic attack before it reaches the point where I would need medical assistance, due to hyperventilation and oxygen deprivation. She also has tasks such as grounding me during a panic attack, providing a physical barrier to assist in lowering triggers, guiding me to the exit of buildings and locating not only my car but my parents and alerting me to people calling my name while in a disoriented state. She will also learn to retrieve medication, bark for help, alert to people calling my name, and prevent me from wandering into the street when in a disoriented state. 

My service dog is just as legitimate as any other service animal, and it is discriminatory to require documentation for some and not others. It would be a better option to require documentation ONLY for emotional support animals, i.e. those that do not have special training and perform tasks to mitigate their handler's disability, or for ALL service animals, as opposed to just some. People with mental illness are already a stigmatized, discriminated against group and this will only reinforce that.

Title: Rebecca Wilkinson
Comment:
To Whom it May Concern,
I would like to see psychiatric service dogs have the same rights as other service dogs in not having to have special documentation to fly. I have a service dog and while he is not for a psychiatric disability, I know of people who with help from their dogs are able to live independently and work in society. 

A well trained service dog is easy to tell apart from someone who is just trying to get their pet on the plane. Service dogs are very highly trained animals and they do not solicit attention, bark (unless they have been trained to do so to get help) beg for food, eliminate inappropriately, cause harm to anyone or otherwise act in any way out of control. They are also well groomed and kept healthy for a long working life.

These psychiatric service dogs have been trained to act on the person's behalf when they need them, and often times the person doesn't know when that will be. They have specific tasks just like any other real service dog. Please keep the rules equal for all service dogs and their handlers. Thank you for your consideration.

Title: Becky Barnes
Comment:
Guide Dog Users, Inc. (GDUI) thanks the Department of Transportation for the opportunity to comment on requirements for air travel for passengers who wish to fly with emotional support and service animals. GDUI supports the department’s separate categories for emotional and service animals and is in favor of maintaining and strengthening this important distinction. Individuals with psychiatric disabilities partnered with specially trained service dogs should not be treated as a separate class from individuals with physical disabilities. 

Guide Dog Users, Inc. (GDUI) thanks the Department of Transportation for the opportunity to comment on requirements for air travel for passengers who wish to fly with emotional support and service animals. GDUI supports the department’s separate categories for emotional and service animals and is in favor of maintaining and strengthening this important distinction. Individuals with psychiatric disabilities partnered with specially trained service dogs should not be treated as a separate class from individuals with physical disabilities. 

Guide Dog Users, Inc. (GDUI) thanks the Department of Transportation for the opportunity to comment on requirements for air travel for passengers who wish to fly with emotional support and service animals. GDUI supports the department’s separate categories for emotional and service animals and is in favor of maintaining and strengthening this important distinction. Individuals with psychiatric disabilities partnered with specially trained service dogs should not be treated as a separate class from individuals with physical disabilities.

Title: Barbara Pilvin
Comment: All service dogs, including psychiatric service dogs, must be and are highly trained; so are their handlers/owners.  I don't have such an animal, but I have seen them in action.  They all provide an invaluable service and their use should under no circumstances be subject to any discriminatory regulation.  If the dogs behave appropriately and help their owners, great; if not, then proper measures should be taken...but discriminating against people on the basis of the disability for which they have the dogs is unconscionable and must be prohibited.

Title: Jerri Lynne Adams
Comment: I agree with the Psychiatric Service Dog Society's position

Title: Barbara Lynn Ramich
Comment: I just found out about this discriminary practice.  People with mental disabilities already have a disadvantage because of discrimation.  Now they have to announce to the world that they have a service dog because they are bi-polar, etc.  This is so unfair to these people.  I would really like to see this practice stopped.

Title: Anonymous
Comment: Please see attachment

Title: Anonymous
Comment:
I agree with the Psychiatric Service Dog Society's position on this issue. It is blatantly discriminatory to ask for additional documentation from any particular subset of Service Dog handlers.

I am well aware that there are people fraudulently passing their dogs off as Service Dogs in order to gain access to places where pets aren't welcome. This policy will NOT eliminate this problem. It will simply cause them to change their stories from suffering with one invisible disability to another.

Psychiatric Service Dog handler

Title: Shannon Chapman
Comment: I do not agree with this action, this is how these people with mental disorders function on a daily basis. I do hope that you will re think this and not allow this to happen

Title: Linda M. Norris
Comment: It is very important to treat and help anyone with any kind of a disability. I have seen such remarkble recovery when animals ae abailable to help somene with a dsability be it something we can see or something invisible.

Title: Anonymous
Comment:
I am one of the many people that have an invisible illness. If you didn't see my cane or watch me walk when my balance is acting up you would not know. But it is very real it is an MS type illness and no at this moment I do not look sick(how ever that looks). My service dog goes everywhere with me and you would never understand how rude people are until you have walked in my shoes ! My dog wears a vest stating he is a service dog he is very well trained and does not cause any problems . Unless you count all the people who want to pet him . That right there poses a problem for me , I need him to stay focused on me at all times , kinda hard to do with people running up to pet the pretty dog ! I have been asked many times what the dog does for me and why do I need him. Well I don't believe they need to know all about my illness its none of there business's . I don't ask them whats wrong with them , all tho I really would like to !
Please don't make our life any harder than it already is ! The only thing this change would do is hurt those of us who are really disabled and have trained service dogs(self trained or professionally trained) The fakers will always be around and we just have to be able to see that they are the fakers ie...Dog acts up , person can't control the dog ect.. 
Please do do us more harm than good !
Thank You

Title: Kathy Davies
Comment:
I object to the discrimination against those peoples with mental health
illness/psychiatric disorders using Service Dogs, having to supply letters
from their Medical Health Providers, stating they are being treated for an
illness covered by the DSM-IV, a min of 48 hours before their flights. I
ask that the DOT remove such a discriminatory ruling, and treat all Service
Dogs/Animals equally.

Title: Sharon Anne Robertson
Comment:
"I object to the discrimination against those peoples with mental health illness/psychiatric disorders using Service Dogs, having to supply letters from their Medical Health Providers, stating they are being treated for an illness covered by the DSM-IV, a min of 48 hours before their flights. I ask that the DOT remove such a discriminatory ruling, and treat all Service Dogs/Animals equally."

Mental illness is a disease like any other physical impairment.  Do you ask a blind person for proof he's blind?

I am appalled !

Title: National Alliance on Mental Illness (NAMI)
Comment:
The attached file contains the comments
of the National Alliance on Mental Illness (NAMI)
 to the request of the U.S. Department of 
Transportation (DOT) for comments on the recent 
changes to the Air Carrier Access Act (ACAA)
regarding the use of psychiatric service
animals.  NAMI believes that these changes 
discriminate against people living with mental 
illnesses who use psychiatric service animals and 
urges the DOT to return to a standard that
is fair and non-discriminatory.

Title: Eliza M. Hirst
Comment: The DOT's strict requirements for psychiatric and emotional support animals are discriminatory. There should be no distinction between physical disabilities and mental/emotional disabilities with regard to the documentation and requirements for air travel.  The DOT should not require different or additional documentation if it is not required for other service animals.  The end result for the person with disabilities is the same: an accommodation to travel. Disclosure of the underlying basis for a service animal travel request is not necessary, so long as the individual can demonstrate the animal directly assists with a disability. Forcing individuals with mental illness to supply verification of a DSM diagnosis perpetuates the stigma of mental illness and hinders equal access and accommodation.

Title: Erin S. Misukonis
Comment:
I object to the discrimination against those peoples with mental health illness/psychiatric disorders using Service Dogs, having to supply letters from their Medical Health Providers, stating they are being treated for an illness covered by the DSM-IV, a min of 48 hours before their flights.  I 
ask that the DOT remove such a discriminatory ruling, and treat all Service 
Dogs/Animals equally.

Title: Sherri Johnson
Comment:
I object to the discrimination against those peoples with mental health
illness/psychiatric disorders using Service Dogs, having to supply letters
from their Medical Health Providers, stating they are being treated for an
illness covered by the DSM-IV, a min of 48 hours before their flights.  I
ask that the DOT remove such a discriminatory ruling, and treat all Service
Dogs/Animals equally

Title: Loretta McDonald
Comment:
Why would the government choose to discriminate against people with mental illness/psychiatric in regards to using service dogs? The US federal law protecting those discriminated against includes those with mental disorders/illness. Many state laws do, too. Why would those people now be the target of discrimination? 

I am disappointed to learn of this unfair treatment. I implore you to correct this mistake and draconian law.

This is an outrage.

Title: Tonja Peterson-Wendt
Comment:
It would be my hope that the consideration of such requirements would fall under the HIPPA laws and would be unsuitable for disclosure.
It is none of my business why you would need to bring a wheelchair or a cane on board a plane. It is also none of my business why you are over weight, diabetic, or why you have open sores on your skin.  
As I live in the state of Nebraska where dogs as well as any other animal are considered property, that would mean that they are indeed no different than a wheelchair or a cane or a pair of glasses, braces on a person's legs, or an oxygen cart.  
Being asked to tell others of the reason for medical devices, including the exact reason you have a service dog is an invasion of privacy, may compromise your security, and gives people a reason why they can single you out.  
I do agree that some people are abusing the system. I have heard about that. However, if something is to be done about this it shouldn't come at the expense of those that are hurting. The amount of money I get in Social Security does not cover my medical expenses, let alone my living expenses already. Having to ask my Dr. to fill out a lengthy form or a form that displays my disability for all to see or have access to if they would even like to be nosey is wrong. The costs to obtain the mentioned documents in time and money are prohibitive.
While I do not like to disclose what tasks my dog is trained to do, I am currently able to do so in a manner that gives enough information without actually sharing at is exactly wrong with me. A diabetic, may choose to wear a bracelet or necklace, but may always be carrying needles. Needles are a dangerous object, they are also something that is medically needed for their safety and well being. They are not asked to disclose their reason's for carrying needles on board, have a Dr's note and certified beyond a doubt that they are diabetic. They just show up with their needles and medications. It is that simple.

Title: Heather L. Vallance
Comment:
I also have Manic/depression disorder so I stronly object to the discrimination against those peoples with mental health
illness/psychiatric disorders using Service Dogs, having to supply letters
from their Medical Health Providers, stating they are being treated for an
illness covered by the DSM-IV, a min of 48 hours before their flights. I
ask that the DOT remove such a discriminatory ruling, and treat all Service
Dogs/Animals equally."

Title: Michael Russell
Comment:
My girlfriend has a psychiatric service dog that has changed both our lives for the better. I do not understand the rationale behind the DOT's changes to require a letter stating your disability and 48hrs notice. 

This is not required from any other kind of Service Animal. It is unfair, unnecessary and undermines the whole concept of having a Service Dog, which is to be able to live and function in the world like everyone else without discrimination.

How is having to call ahead, have a Dr's note and basically making yourself stand out, being and equal to the rest of society?

I sincerely hope the DOT will listen to the PSDS comments and reverse their decision.

Title: Anonymous
Comment: I agree with the PSDS view to stop discrimination against people with mental illness using PSD's. It is unfair and unjust.

Title: Michelle Sidnie Ryan
Comment:
This is an issue that is very important to me. The decision that is made will affect all of us with psychiatric service animals for years to come. I understand that the airlines think they are curbing misuse of animals and allowing people without a legitimate need to take “fake” service dogs on airplanes.

The problem is you are targeting a class of people with mental illness instead of targeting everyone with an invisible disability. Therefore it is only rational that it has nothing to do with people faking service dogs and everything to do with people with mental illness.

Service Dogs are dogs that are individually trained to help someone with a disability, period. There does not need to be different classifications in order to board an airplane.   We all need to be treated equally.  Our dogs are our lifelines and help us all in unique ways specific to our disabilities but they all are doing a job.

To single out people with mental illness is not only prejudiced but is also saying we are of lower, not trustworthy status. I do not see any requirements for other invisible disabilities such as people with epilepsy, diabetes, hearing loss, cardiac problems etc.

It is a hardship and a burden to come up with the required documentation asked for by the DOT. It is humiliating to have to disclose something as personal as our mental health issues with complete strangers in order to do the exact same thing as the person with a non psychiatric service dog standing right next to me. 

I know the DOT is smart enough to see the error of their decision and to rectify this and treat all persons with service dogs equally and fairly. Thank you for giving us an opportunity to express our opinions and to allow you to return the policy as it was where no one is singled out and traveling can be an enjoyable experience with our trained and faithful service dogs instead of something dreaded and to be avoided.

Title: Michelle Phillips
Comment: I am writing this because I feel that a service dog, no matter what the reason for having one is, should have to same rights as all service dogs.  It does not matter if the person whom is using it, is using it due to blindness, seizure detecting, or psychiatric reasons.  They are trained service animals and without them, a persons life may be impaired.  Please allow all service animals the same rights.  Thank you!

Title: Anonymous
Comment:
"I object to the discrimination against those peoples with mental health
illness/psychiatric disorders using Service Dogs, having to supply letters
from their Medical Health Providers, stating they are being treated for an
illness covered by the DSM-IV, a min of 48 hours before their flights. I
ask that the DOT remove such a discriminatory ruling, and treat all Service
Dogs/Animals equally."

Title: Jim Mikkelsen
Comment:
This new rule specifically discriminates against people with mental illness utilizing Service Dogs.

There is no evidence that one type of Service Dog is faked more than any other.

There is a huge difference between Emotional Support Animals and Psychiatric Service Dogs. Don't confuse the two.

Psychiatric Service Dogs are just like all other Service Dogs and should be treated as such.

Title: Claire Martine Paulson
Comment:
I object to the discrimination against those peoples with mental health illness/psychiatric disorders using Service Dogs, having to supply letters from their Medical Health Providers, stating they are being treated for an illness covered by the DSM-IV, a min of 48 hours before their flights. I ask that the DOT remove such a discriminatory ruling, and treat all Service
Dogs/Animals equally. 
It is not easy to just go out and get a service dog, the people who have them NEED THEM! They are a lifeline, the are support they are a link to the outside world.

Title: Donald Charles Martin
Comment:
Dear Sirs,

I am a retired professor from the University of Washington. One of my appointmaens was in the Department of Psychiatry and Behavioral Sciences. 

I can only conclude that the proposed rule change on psychiatric service dogs is based on ignorance and is simply discrimination against mental illness.

Yours Truly

Dr. Donald C. Martin

Title: Diana Mikkelsen
Comment:
This new rule is unethical and discriminatory.

There is no reason to discriminate against people with mental illness using Service Dogs. They should be treated just like everybody else. This new rule creates a huge barrier to access.

There is no need to punish the mentally ill just because some people are trying to fake Service Dogs. There is no evidence that only Psychiatric Service Dogs are the only ones being faked.

People with disabilities and people who use Service Dogs should be treated just like the rest of us. They should be allowed access to planes without inconvenient and unattainable demands you have placed on them.

Title: Association of Asia Pacific Airlines
Submitter Representative: Mr. Steve Martin & Mr. Howard Mann
Comment: Please find attached the comments of the Association of Asia Pacific Airlines (AAPA) in response to the request for comments on the petition made by the Psychiatric Service Dog Society (Docket No: OST-2009-0093).

Title: Eva Lundahl Philpot
Comment: It is outrageous that the government will be discriminating against mental disability patients and require proof from a doctor before letting them travel with their service animals. Discriminating against any minority is is bad, but especially so with mental handicaps. These people have enough problems to worry about and being treated like second class citizens is unfair, appalling, and completely unacceptable. Please reconsider this ruling once more and treat everyone equally in this country. Mental handicpas are serious illnesses that should not be aggrevated by requiring public proof. Thank you. Eva Philpot, Renton, WA

Title: Elizabeth A. Bulla
Comment: If it were after hours there is no way the airline would be able to verify those "documents" are legitimate. These poor people have likely lived horrible lives with only the love of these animals to help them cope. If someone has a mental illness they certainly shouldn't be discriminated against by strangers to satisfy some sadistic legislators who have nothing better to do than come up with more "rules" to embarrass and single out the already mistreated members of our society who get a small concession to make their lives easier. There can not possibly be that many people out there thinking up ways to get their little dog on a flight with them when its just as easy to put them under the plane where there are climate controlled compartments. People with pets do not fly with airlines that do not accommodate their pets anyhow. Either I pay more to fly with an airline that has the facilities I want or I drive. perhaps you could change the rule to say that all assistant animals regardless of type should have some kind of documentation on them in case they are asked- that way their private medical information Never even has the chance to be used inappropriately since the airlines don't get involved. Make it a "passport" that a patient goes to get once with forms they have filled out by the doctor and then its good for 5 or 10 years. They then have to renew it. You could just add it into any secretary of state office. The patients get to retain their dignity and the airlines get to make sure no one is abusing the system and no one else even has to know what the condition is. That way they only have to have this one thing and they just keep it around for travel. Like a license for a companion animal to fly. The secretary of state office would verify the info and there could be either a nominal fee just to cover costs or perhaps for low income people they could provide proof of other state benefits to get the fee waived. I have run out of room but would love to expand this.

Title: Jennie Lynn Zimmer
Comment: I am a member of the Psychiatric Service Dog Society and I agree with their position on this issue of the changes to ACAA.

I support the Psychiatric Service Dog Society's position.

Title: Genenne Nettleton
Comment: I agree with psds please dont discriminate aganst Psychictric Service Dogs and there handlers.

Title: Philip Barry Kirschner
Comment:
In essence the Guild Dog users cares nothing for the psychatric populations and in fact has a historial record of bias and discrimination based upon fears and stereotypes.  We also agree that PSD's trained to mitigate such a provide medication reminders, and trained to brake certain behaviors are service dogs, and should not be subjected to the same ESA regulations. However, even ESA's should not be discriminated against nor should they be required to be forced to provide documentation stating disability, illness or DSM codes. 

There is a double standard. Let's face it, the real reason for wanting ESA's/psd is to force a standard and control training and push training schools and this control the industry. I suspect the airlines have another motive. To put air marshals on fligths where persons with PTSD are flying. The guilde dog community has always opposed the PSD's and now that we have returning vets from millitary service like myself who need PSD"s  they are supporting it, because of the dollars available from the VA and volunteer donors who support vet causes. To me, the guide dog community is disengenious at least, and intelectually dishonest at best.

Title: Anonymous
Comment: I do not think it is right that people with service dogs for psychiatric conditions are being treated differently from people who use service dogs for other conditions. All service dogs should be treated the same.

Title: Brenda G. Running
Comment: I agree with the Psychiatric Service Dog Society on this important issue of discrimination.

Title: Joanne Page O'Neill
Comment:
The request for a letter stating the persons mental diagnosis requiring the person using a service animal for emotional support discriminates against an entire class of people with disabilities.  There is no real data regarding fraudulent service animals abuse of the emotional support animal category is not a valid reason to discriminate against people with psychiatric service animals, and that psychiatric service dogs are no more susceptible to fraudulent activities than any other type of service animal.  This is already a class of people that suffers from more discrimination than almost any other disability.

Additionally, it is important to note that Emotional Support Animals are a class of pet that has been granted status by the DOT, they are not the same as psychiatric service animals which are not pets. Therefore it is acceptable legally to require different documentation for these different classes of animals. PSDS proposes two possibilities for documentation requirements:
No documentation required for service animals, documentation required for emotional support animals.

Thank you for your attention to this issue.

Title: Erin Abplanalp
Comment: I  AGREE WITH THE PSYCHIATRIC SERVICE  DOG SOCIETY !!!!!  PLEASE DO NOT DISCRIMINATE AGAINST OWNERS OF PSYCHIATRIC SERVICE DOGS THEIR NEEDS ARE JUST AS IMPORTANT!!! THANK YOU !!!!!

Title: Craig Thomas Abplanalp
Comment:
I agree with the Psychiatric Service Dog Society. Dogs trained and used for this purpose should be permitted to assist their owners. These individuals cannot perform day to day activities without the assistance of these highly trained animals. 

We have bigger things in this world to worry about than making psychiatrically challenged individuals suffer further. 

Sincerely,
Craig Abplanalp

Title: Jennifer Page O'Neill
Comment: I am a person living with several disabilities and recently became aware of this proposed rule which discriminates against people who use service dogs for psychiatric reasons.  My service dog not only helps me with my depression but also with my anxiety disorder.  Mayzie (my border collie) is always at my side no matter where we go.  We recently took a trip to Texas for a conference and she was allowed to sit at my feet on the flight to and from the conference.  She is just like any other service dog in that if we are in public she is "working".  Without being able to take my Mayzie with me, I fear that my ability to get out of my house every day and even cope with everyday situations would be severely diminished.  I am very concerned about this proposal and I DO AGREE WITH THE PSYCHIATRIC SERVICE DOG SOCIETY.  Please consider the people who would be affected by this rule and give serious thought to the degree that these animals help people like me.  It would be devastating if this rule was passed.  Not only for me but for thousands of people like me.  Please help me by not allowing this rule to pass.  Thank you.

Title: Linda Haven
Comment:
I  strongly object to the discrimination against those peoples with mental health illness/psychiatric disorders using Service Dogs, having to supply letters from their Medical Health Providers, stating they are being treated for an illness covered by the DSM-IV, a min of 48 hours before their flights. 
I ask that the DOT remove such a discriminatory ruling, and treat all Service Dogs/Animals equally.
Anyone with a SD should be allowed to use this service- without "justification to the Airlines", as they have already been screened thoroughly, before being given a SD.

Title: Betty Jane Weaver
Comment:
As the mother of a child with a disability I am appalled to read the proposed changes which will discriminate against a large sector of our society.  To be required to submit 'proof' of any disability 48 hrs prior to being allowed to fly with your service dog is abhorrent!  The disabled are often on a limited income and do not have the means to get such 'proof' but more distasteful to me is having to provide strangers with documentation of the very personal and private condition that they are suffering from. Let's not forget the 48 hour part - so if a family member becomes gravely ill and requires someone to leave immediately you are removing the ability to be there perhaps for the last moments with them?  The option of traveling immediately without the service dog is NOT a viable option for most that use them.  
Please reconsider these changes based on common sense and compassion.

Title: California Association of Social Rehabilitation Agencies (CASRA)
Organization Name: California Association of Social Rehabilitation Agencies (CASRA)
Comment: Please see the attached PDF for our comments on the Air Carrier Access Act revised regulations. Thank you.

Title: Susan Bakalev Marshall, LCPC, ATR-BC
Comment:
I am a Licensed Clinical Professional Counselor in the state of Maine.  One of my clients has a Psychiatric Service Dog (PSA), who accompanies her in public and offers assistance to alleviate anxiety and depressive and panic attacks symptoms. It is my understanding that she received a prescription from a psychiatrist for her service dog.

My client brings her PSA to therapy sessions. The dog is well trained and I have been told by this client and observed how her psychiatric service dog alerts her when she is dissociating.

There appears to be confusion at the very least and certainly discrimination with this new Air Carrier Act requiring differential treatment of passengers using PSA’s as opposed to those using other types of service animals. I support that the 48-hour notice to the airlines not be required of people with psychiatric diagnoses, who use psychiatric Service dogs for these reasons:

1) These changes discriminate against an entire class of people with
disabilities.
2) There is no data regarding fraudulent use of psychiatric service animals.
3) Abuse of the Emotional Support Animals (ESA) category is not a valid reason to discriminate against people with PSAs
4) PSAs are no more likely to be subject to fraudulent behavior than any other type of service animal.

ESAs are pets that have been granted status by the DOT. They are not service animals.  The Psychiatric Service Dog Society (PSDS) proposes no documentation be required for any service animal.

Documentation may be required for ESAs or they may be eliminated from in-cabin air travel.

In summary, I support the Psychiatric Service Dog Society’s position in opposition to the ruling that indicates anyone flying with a Psychiatric service dog make their reservations 48 hours in advance, provide complete diagnoses from a Psychiatrist, and a letter stating that the person is OK to fly. This is discrimination- as no other Service Animal users are asked to do this nor or other passengers.

Thank you. 

Susan Bakaley Marshall, LCPC, ATR-BC

Title: Janice Sugden
Comment:
"I object to the discrimination against those peoples with mental health
illness/psychiatric disorders using Service Dogs, having to supply letters
from their Medical Health Providers, stating they are being treated for an
illness covered by the DSM-IV, a min of 48 hours before their flights.  I
