Title: Dana Nelson
Comment:
Hello,

I would like to comment on the discrimination that is put on to those who require psychiatiric service dogs.  I believe that it is a travesty to make those with invisible disabilities jump through so much hurdles in order to use airlines. 

 I have not seen any data that supports the claim that there are those who falsely state pets as service animals.  

I have a service dog that allows me to be a productive member of society and gives me the freedom that I used to have.


I hope that this severe discrimination can be resolved quickly and to what the Psychiatric Service Dog Society has suggested.

I appreciate being allowed the opportunity to voice my opinion.

~Dana Nelson

Title: Susan J. Grill
Comment:
I thought the federal government recently decreed that mental illness is a medical condition and covered under medicare and so on. If it's happening in your brain, it's medical. A psychiatric support dog is trained to do all sorts of things to benefit people who are disabled by mental illness.

Imagine having agoraphobia. It's medical, look it up. Imagine not being able to leave your house because you might have a random panic attack anywhere. Now imagine a trained dog that can sense panic attacks before they happen and bring you the correct medicine, can lead you out of a crowd during a panic attack, can find the nearest exit from a scary building.... Psychiatric service dogs have actually been known to assist people so much their disability is mitigated--to the point that the person can go back to work and pay taxes and contribute to the gross national product. You want to say these dogs are any different from one who alerts to seizures?

Wait, seizures are in the brain too. Are people "imagining" them? Are you going to limit seizure alert dogs next?

Quit being so embarrassingly ignorant and allow psychiatric support dogs the coverage of a law that was designed to protect ALL disabled people, not just people you happen to feel sorry for, like blind people, and not the ones with stigma, like mentally ill ones. Educated people across the world are wincing at this proposed restriction because of the bigotry involved. Don't you know better?

Comment:
While I realize that there are occasional misuses of the system allowingthe legal right to travel with Service Dogs, the vast majority that need the service do not.
   I do not understand why those with any kind of Mental illness must provide proof so often, with updates. Yes, security is an issue but it is for all travellers and I certainly

Whenever I have travelled with Service Dogs in their training, I have never been asked for proof of what the medical need is, I just have to have their paperwork saying the dog is providing a needed job. Medical information on any individual is private info and always has been.

Pam Legault, R.N.

Title: Charles E. Fahlgren
Comment:
The US Constitution guarantees equal treatment of all those with disabilities.  The restrictions being placed on those with mental difficulties using service dogs is based on paranoia and opinion, not on equality.  While a visually or auditory impaired person can readily be identified, those with mental difficulties cannot.  The regulations, as established at present, place those with mental difficulties into an impossible situation.  Perhaps the DOT should just require them to wear a sign in 100 font on their chest declaring their situation!
Bring back equal treatment, which is what America claims to be all about.  Tell Homeland Security to tone it down and have some compassion.

As a user of a Service Dog for an 'invisible' physical disability, I object to the discrimination against those peoples with mental health illness/psychiatric disorders using Service Dogs, having to supply letters from their Medical Health Providers, stating they are being treated for a an illness covered by the DSM-IV a min of 48 hours before their flights. I ask that the DOT remove such a discriminatory ruling, and treat all Service 
Dogs/Animals equally.

Not all doctors understand or appreciate the use of Service Dogs.  That in itself can cause difficulty for a person if their doctor is not up to date on Service Dogs and their assistance.  Having to see a doctor to have the letter composed costs the patient additional money and ties up the doctor unnecessarily.  

Family and work emergencies can come up, necessitating travel plans that may make 48 hours unreasonable.  The ADA has a reasonable ruling.  It states that disabled with a Service Dog may be asked if they are disabled, asked if the dog is a Service Dog, asked what tasks it performs to mitigate the disability.  I believe that should be sufficient for the Airline Carriers as well.  For so very many reasons, I ask that this ruling be discarded and the discriminatiion ended.  Thank you for 'listening' to my views.

Title: Michele Enenstein
Comment: As a service dog advocate and a disabled person using a service dog, I find it horrifying that the ACAA is discriminating against a group of people due to the nature of their disability. People who are disabled by mental illness have the same rights to service dog usage as any other group of disabled people. The rules for all service animals (Emotional Support Animals are NOT service animals) should be the same. Targeting one group of service animals users is discrimination and completely unacceptable!

I ask that the DOT remove such a discriminatory ruling, and treat all Service Dogs/Animals equally.

Title: Dee Wheat
Comment:
It's a sad day when we are forced to "prove" our disabilities because the non-disabled, who are the first to park in handicapped parking and use the power chairs provided by stores have now found a way to further rub our noses in the mud by saying that their pet is a service animal and thus must ride with them. Frankly, I would not put one of my pets in an unpressurized, unheated airplane cargo hold for any reason. Because of that, I travel exclusively by private vehicle. If I were forced to fly, I would kennel my pets rather than ship them. 

This is yet another place where common decency and respect for the law SHOULD prevail but they obviously do not because if they did there would not be a problem.

However, I cannot excuse penalizing the disabled simply because some non-disabled people choose to ignore the constraints of simple personal honesty and responsibility. The law is clear. If an animal serves a specific purpose for its disabled owner, then it is by default a service animal and there is no corroborating documentation required. If people choose to disobey the law and falsely represent their pets as service animals, then the natural course of things will inevitably intervene in their lives in regards to punishment for their transgression. Do NOT punish the disabled in order to dissuade the non-disabled from breaking the law. We in the disability haul along more than enough excess baggage in our lives. An additional doctor visit to get a letter written confirming that there is a legitimate need for a service animal is both ciostly and punitive. At the very least, if the airlines require documentation it should never leave the hands of the service animal's owner, and the airline should be required to pay for the visitto the doctor's office, for any charge for writing the letter, and any transportation costs incurred as well as compensating the disabled person for their time spent in getting the requested documentation.

Title: Page Simon
Comment:
Persons with disabilities who use Service Dogs are being seriously discriminated against by not being able to travel with them in emergency situations but being made to wait 48 hours. They are also being asked to submit personal information to people who are not cleared to handle it or required to keep it private. Yearly updated letters are also cumbersome and a burden. 

Suggestion: Let persons who need service dogs get a secure photo-ID card, like a driver's license, that lets them board with their dogs. It could expire every 3 year and need to be renewed, just like a driver's license. It would not reveal the nature of the need and could be used like a passport or license when boarding a plane.

Title: Jay Bangle
Comment: I object to the discrimination against those peoples with mental health illness/psychiatric disorders using Service Dogs, having to supply letters from their Medical Health Providers, stating they are being treated for an illness covered by the DSM-IV, a min of 48 hours before their flights. I ask that the DOT remove such a discriminatory ruling, and treat all Service Dogs/Animals equally.

illness covered by the DSM-IV, a min of 48 hours before their flights.  I

Title: Service Dog Owner from CA
Comment:
I completely agree with the things brought up by Psychiatric Service Dog Society. These new restrictions on Psychiatric Service Dogs is discriminatory and uncalled for. There has been no real evidence to support discriminating against people for their disability. 
 
Psychiatric disabilities effect your physical body just as much as any other disability might. For instance, when I am in a depressive state all my joints ache, get stiff, and lock up or collapse under me for no reason. This can be very dangerous if I were crossing the street or train tracks by my house or walking with my children or going up or down stairs. My service dog is trained to brace me just like for someone with a physical disability. However, the reason for this task is totally psychiatric. 

On the opposite end of the spectrum when I am in a manic state I get major PTSD flashbacks and have run into traffic many times because I thought I was being chased and nearly got run over by a car. My dog is trained to block me from walking into traffic similarly to how a guide dog is trained to do the same thing. 

These are just a couple of examples. My service dog is trained to provide me with 12 different tasks as well as different types of work such as deep pressure stimulus, tactile stimulus, and others. My dog has as much training as any other kind of service dog. Psychiatric service dogs are held to a high standard and we all strive to make our dogs as invisible as possible. 

By requiring these handlers who use psychiatric service dogs to provide 48 hour notice and a doctors letter, you are going to be effecting many people such as soldiers coming home from war with PTSD, and abuse victims. My conditions are 90% hereditary. If my mother knew about Psychiatric Service Dogs, she might still be alive today. She died from Bipolar three years ago in a very violent death. I did not ask to be given these conditions, but now I am being punished for it. What if I need to go to a funeral?

Title: Veronica C.
Comment: Your proposed discriminatory policy is outrageous. All Service Dogs should be and ARE considered equal in Federal Regulations. There is a clear distinction between Emotional Support Animals and Service Animals; ESAs are NOT trained for service, they are there to cuddle and hold for emotional support. Would you consider applying the same policy to the blind? Of course not! This proposed policy shows a lack of clear thinking, is not in line with Federal Regulations, and is discriminatory.

Title: Joel Von Penner
Comment: I am a spouse of a psychiatric service dog handler and this affects me greatly as this makes even short plane trips impossible. This would have been disasterous if there was a death in the family and we had to fly out of state on short notice. I am fully in support the PSDS stand on this

Shirley Hendel

Title: Karen J. Schiller
Comment: The current and recent DOT ruling is unfair discrimination, and should be stopped!

Title: Anonymous
Comment:
This regulation is clearly meant to discriminate against people with mental illnesses.  If it were truly to keep people from falsely claiming that their pets are service animals, it would be a requirement for all service animals.  With this regulation in place, all someone has to do, to fake a service animal, is claim to have any other disability.  Since many disabilities are invisible, to a casual observer, when the individual is not having an episode, they will probably get away with it.  Some examples of disabilities, that service dogs are commonly used for, and do not require a doctor's note, according to this regulation are diabetes, epilepsy, allergies, and asthma.  A non-disabled person need only claim one of these disabilities, no proof is needed.  Mobility, blindness, and deafness, can also be faked, without too much difficulty.

This regulation has no other purpose than to send the message that the mentally ill are second class citizens.  It does this by violating their rights to travel freely from State to State, and violating their right to privacy.  The regulation will do irreparable harm to any law biding citizen, that requires a service animal.  If they need to travel for work, at a moment's notice, the are not allowed.  If they wish to be by the side of a dying loved one, they can't.  There is also no provision, or restriction on how this information is kept by the airlines, or who has access to it.  There is nothing to protect someone's prospective employer, or landlord from being able to access this information.  With the stigma that mental illness has, in spite of the fact that it, in many cases, does not affect their ability to do their job, or be a good tenant, they would most likely not be discriminated against, by the prospective employer, or landlord.

Title: Eldora Ann Fessenden
Comment:
I believe that all owners of service dogs and their dogs should be treated the same
If ID or letters are mandatory, then it should be across the board
to make those with mental problems that use a service dog display their infirmaties when other people using service dogs are not seperated out is discriminatory
Just as someone with a 'handicapped' placard on their car may have a heart condition or emphesema is not notably 'handicapped' but can still use a handicapped parking spot (not just someone with their leg in a cast) so people with less obvious limitations should be able to use service dogs when travelling without being singled out
Sincerely
Ann Fessenden

Title: Alicia Klenk

Title: Gerd Brunner
Comment:
[This is a series of comments. Here is Part I]

To the Office of the Secretary,
 I write in strong support of the Psychiatric Service Dog Society (PSDS) petition: 
 "Nondiscrimination on the Basis of Disability in Air Travel". 
The current provision of the Department of Transportation’s Air Carrier Access Act (ACAA) regulation (14 CFR Part 382) seriously concerns me with respect to the unequal treatment of persons suffering from a disability. As a biomedical research, working in the largest medical center of the country, it strongly concerns me that a clearly vulnerable group of individuals is  coerced into providing proof of their health status to unqualified personnel in a public space. The current provision is in clear violation of several laws regulating handling and storage of health data,  patient confidentiality (such as who has access to data) and others. I strongly doubt that airline personnel obtained  adequate training for this task. Also, the current provision does not outline what the airlines are doing with the letters. Are they stored, who has access and so on. The Health Insurance Portability and Accountability Act (HIPAA) has clear rules as to how, who and where and for how long patient data can be stored. Airlines are clearly not equipped to store and/or access health care data.
The current provision discriminates specifically against one group of disability, namely persons suffering from mental disability such a post traumatic stress disorder (PTSD), or generalized anxiety disorder among many others. 

[please continue reading Part II]

Title: Susan Kenny-Welch
Comment: The discrimination against those peoples with mental health illness/psychiatric disorders using Service Dogs is wrong.  To have  to supply letters from their Medical Health Providers, stating they are being treated for an illness covered by the DSM-IV, a min of 48 hours before their flights severely limits their ability to fly should a family emergency occur..  I ask that the DOT remove such a discriminatory ruling, and treat all Service Dogs/Animals equally."

Title: Gerd Brunner
Comment:
[This is a series of comments. Here is Part II]

From a constitutional point of view every individual should be treated equally by the ACAA. However, why is the group of persons suffering from mental disabilities singled out in  provision 14 CFR Part 382? The current provision does not require advanced notice and/or a  Doctor signed letter from persons suffering from physical disabilities such as a person in a wheel chair. Not that the current provision discriminates against a single group of individuals, it also makes life much harder for a group of Americans who are already disadvantaged such as war veterans suffering from PTSD and many others. 
In general, the access to public locations is regulated by the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA). However, only air-traffic is exempted from the ADA and is regulated by the ACAA. It is concerning as to why airlines need own regulations. However, this point is not part of the current debate, although it is indicative of the special treatment of the airline industry.  
Moreover, it is alarming that the current provision does not distinguish between psychiatric service animals  and emotional support animals. Psychiatric service animals, such as psychiatric service dogs, undergo specific and complex  training that most often is accompanied by a certification process of the animal. Conversely, emotional support animals are just regular pets without advanced training. Moreover, psychiatric service animals  fall under service animals as regulated by and outlined in the ADA. From the ADA point of view there is no distinction between  psychiatric service animals and emotional support animals. If the ACAA had adopted the essence of the ADA, then there would not be any debate necessary. 


[please continue reading Part III]

Title: Comment on FR Doc # E9-21351
Comment: I support the Psychiatric Service Dog Society's position regarding this issue. Please repeal these oppressive rules and treat handlers of psychiatric service dogs with the respect any other airline passenger is shown.

Title: Gerd Brunner
Comment:
[This is a series of comments. Here is Part III]


Scientifically speaking there is also no reason to treat psychiatric service animals and emotional support animals alike. For instance, psychiatric service dogs, a subgroup of psychiatric service animals, have been subject of various scientific publications [1-3]. On the other hand emotional support animals have not.
 The argument in the current provision as to why documentation is needed for mentally disabled individuals  is  superficial, discriminatory and lack's any scientific basis. 

 In conclusion, the current provision does discriminate against one group of individuals and need to be changed as it is clearly unconstitutional.

References:
[1] Dr. E. L. Altschuler, Pet-Facilitated Therapy for Posttraumatic Stress Disorder Annals of Clinical Psychiatry, Volume 11, Number 1, March 1999 , pages 29-30(2).
 [2] Dr. Lisa Bryden, Therapeutic help from man's best friend  CMAJ • February 26, 2008; 178 (5).
 [3] Drs. Martin F, Farnum J. (College of Veterinary Medicine, Washington State University, USA) Animal-assisted therapy for children with pervasive developmental disorders. West J Nurs Res. 2002 Oct;24(6):657-70.

Sincerely,
 Gerd Brunner, Ph.D.

Title: Ron Honberg
Comment: The attached file contains NAMI's comments about the changes in the rules concerning the use of psychiatric service animals under the Air Carriers Access Act.

Title: Nikki Littleton
Comment: I am writing to request that you change this discriminatory law.  Under the ADA, a service dog is a dog that is individually trained to mitigate the disability of it's disabled handler.  That is any disability!  A service dog is guaranteed public access rights and is highly trained to behave appropriately in public.  ALL service dogs are equal under the ADA.  An emotional support animal is NOT individually trained to mitigate a disability, does not have public access training and is not recognized by the ADA.  A psychiatric service dog is a fully trained service dog and as many are owner trained, they are usually better trained than service dogs that help with other types of disabilities because the handler is very aware of their behavior.  To lump a fully trained service dog that is trained to mitigate the disability of it's handler in the same category as an untrained pet that a person is allowed to bring on the plane as an emotional support animal does not make any sense.  There is no comparison.  A service dog is a service dog, period!  Whether it is for someone who is visually impaired, hearing impaired, mobility impaired, for seizures, diabetes, autism, or a psychiatric condition, it is still a service dog.  The DOT claim that people are "faking" psychiatric service dogs not other types of service dogs is baseless.  Do you have any hard proof that this is happening?  I have heard of people putting on dark glasses and pretending to be blind to get their dog allowed on the plane as a service dog.  Honestly, if you were going to fake a disability to claim your dog was a service dog, would you fake a mental illness and tell airline personnel that you were mentally ill?  Especially in the world of post 9/11?  It would be so much safer to pretend you were epileptic or diabetic.  Please change this law so that all people with disabilities who utilize service dogs to mitigate their disabilities and try to live their lives in the best way possible are treated the same.

Title: Mary I. Thiessen
Comment:
I do not agree with the discrimination against those who have mental health illnesses or psychiatric disorders using Service Dogs that requires them to supply letters a minimum of 48 hours before their flights from their Medical Health Providers stating that they are being treated for an illness covered by the DSM-IV.
What if there is a family emergency?  Why discriminate?  Other Service Dog users do not need such a letter, which is shared with strangers, and is costly to obtain.  Doctors do not give out these letters for free.
I ask that the DOT remove such a discriminatory ruling, and treat all Service Dogs/Animals equally.

Title: Nikki Littleton
Comment: I am one of the people that you are discriminating against with the current regulation. I was sexually abused at the age of 8 and several times after that. Because of this, 33 years later, I still suffer from Post Traumatic Stress Disorder. I have panic attacks, hypervigilance, irrational thougts and fears, etc. I am also the mother of a child with Asperger's Syndrome, a wife of 21 years, have been a working, contributing taxpayer since I was old enough, am a straight A college student, do volunteer work, etc. I am not crazy. My mental illness does not define who I am. Most people who meet me have no idea that I have a mental illness. I also have a mobility impairment and am a type 2 diabetic.  I have an owner trained service dog. He is trained to mitigate my diabetes and my mobility impairment as well as my PTSD. The most important of his jobs is to mitigate my PTSD.  Without him I could not do things that others take for granted. Even going into a public restroom alone is horrifying. What if there is someone hiding in a stall waiting to attack me? Standing at a counter, like at the bank or the airport, what is someone sneaks up behind me?  Teddy is trained to alert me to the presence of other people, and he is trained to stay between me and other people or the doorway. In a situation like the bank line, he is trained to lay behind me. Without my service dog, I would not be able to go out alone, especially at night.  A service dog is a service dog under the ADA and the Rehab Act. The ACAA is the only federal law that does not recognize a service dog for a mental illness as equal to a service dog for any other disability.  That is just wrong. The 48 hour notice and doctor's letter required only for those with a service dog for a mental illness is unfair and discriminatory. It is an example of the stigma against people with mental illness and is a huge step backwards for the United States. Please change this rule immediately so that it is not discriminatory.Thank you

Title: Maria T. Belrose
Comment:
I feel that requiring people with mental health issues, that use service dogs, to submit letters from their health providers 48hrs before a fllight is wrong.  

No other persons that use service dogs are required to submit these letters.

This practice is discriminatory and should be stopped.


Thank you for your time,  

Maria Belrose

Title: Katarzyna Mikurda
Comment:
I support the petition of the Psychiatric Service Dog Society. 
In my opinion singling out one group of Service Dog handlers is highly discriminating. 
In the light of the modern scientific research drawing a line between "mental" and " physical" illness - disability - is not appropriate anymore, the roots of mental illness are physiological (changes in function of the brain) and so are the symptoms. There is no logical reason to draw a line between service dogs assisting a person during seizures and flashbacks or panic attacks (both manifesting themselves as host debilitating physical symptoms).
The Department seeks for examples on how service dogs for people with mental health disabilities differ from emotional support animals. Service Animals are trained to perform specific work or tasks mitigating handlers' disability. A good examples are dogs alerting and/or assisting during panic attacks (a common symptom of, for example, the Post Traumatic Stress Disorder). Their function is no different than that of SDs assisting people during seizures or low/high blood sugar episodes. Panic attacks, as many other debilitating symptoms of mental illness, can occur anytime, including a flight or time at the destination.
I would like to comment on the ADA analogy. The Department believes that air travel differs substantially from other places of public accommodation. This is not necessary the case. Cruise ship and train travel are both governed by ADA and also involve people confined in a space for prolonged time intervals. 

To conclude: I support the solution number 4: documentation and advance notice should be eliminated for all types of SERVICE ANIMALS. As ESAs are NOT RECOGNIZED as service animals (in the community involved, the society in general and the ADA) the rules should remain unchanged in their case. This is the only solution that will help to avoid the confusion and discrimination.

Title: Kathleen M. Sauviac
Comment: I am writing to support a stronger policy regarding requirements to bring a service dog onboard any public transit including air travel. I am in a wheelchair and on a ventilator. As such, my disability is apparent. While there are those with invisible disabilities who would argue about HIPPA laws or their privacy, there should also be the burden of proof as to not only their disability and the tasks their dogs perform to mitigate their disability. The problem with "prescribed pets" or emotional support dogs has become rampant as well as abuse by the general public who simply wishes to travel with their pet and/or avoid fees.  My service dog was trained by a nationally known organization. She is quite valuable monetarily due to the training she has had, as well as being invaluable to me. I run the risk quite often of her being exposed to untrained pets who are in public being misrepresented as service dogs. She has been lunged at, snapped at, and nearly bitten twice in public by these dogs who were wearing vests that were purchased online. If she had been harmed, I would have held the company liable for her injuries. I would think the airlines would also want to avoid potential lawsuits to other passengers who could potentially be harmed and also to stop the fraud committed by far too many people today. Thank you for your attention to my comment.

The dog needs to have something from the doctor stating that the dog is a service dog for the disabled.  Again under the law the disabled person must state 3 things the dog does for him/her.

Title: Barbara Petzko

Why would anyone consider depriving an ill person of therapy at any time?

Please allow service dogs on planes regardless of the owner's diagnosis. Service is service. Period!

Thank you for your consideration.

Sincerely,
Barbara Petzko

Title: Elizabeth Shea J. D.
Comment:
1. I support  the appeal of sections 382.117(e)  and  382.27(c)(8)  of the May 2008 Final Rule of the ACA Act which  places advance notification and documentation standards on the users of PSD but do not support such an appeal in referene to ESAs/comfort animals.
2. The above sections clearly violate existing Federal law and standards by discriminating against handlers with PSD. With reference to PSD and  PSD's only, I suggest the elimination of the Advance Notification and Documentation requirements for handlers of psychiatric service animals.
3. I share the department's concern re fraud and abuse of service dog access since such abuse could impact on access policies and availability.  However the department has shown neither empirical or ancedotal evidence that abuse exists and is of such a magnitude it would require such ononerous limitation on the rights of the disabled.  I  realize that air travel does bring with it additional concerns of safety and in these days security that is not usually presented in access issues. Still there should be at a minimum a showing of substantial, substantive evidence that unusual restrictions are necessary and would accomplish the desired result.
DOT has not shown the need for the discrimination they have put in place or the need for Fraud detection they are requesting and until they do so there is no rationale for developing these policies.  I join in the recommendation that DOT do a five year study on the issue of the existence and frequency of fraud and abuse related to service dog access. DOT could require the airlines to collect statistics about   ( 1 ) the number of assistance dogs traveling and ( 2 ) what percentage presented problems and ( 3 )what percentage was documented as fraud or (4 ) attempted fraud or ( 5 ) suspected fraud. Title: Nikki Littleton
Comment:
I continue to ask why the question is whether the airlines can distinguish between ESA/PSD. The ADA of 1990 clearly states the definition of a service dog and makes it clear that a service dog is individually trained to mitigate a disability, INCLUDING A PSYCHIATRIC DISABLITY! A PSD is legally protected and has been trained and is allowed public access. A PSD is a service dog, just like a seeing-eye dog, a hearing dog, a seizure alert dog or a mobility dog. A PSD is highly trained both to mitigate the disability of the handler and to behave in public. If you ask the handler of a seeing eye dog, hearing dog, mobility dog or any other type of service dog, they will also tell you that their dog provides many therapeutic functions that are also performed by PSD, ESA and pets.  I have a friend with a seeing-eye dog and he will tell you the that the dog is his best friend, that he calms him, makes hiim feel better, etc.  It is the very nature of the human/animal bond.  That is not the ONLY thing a PSD provides, as ATA has given examples of in their comment.
An ESA is an untrained pet that a passenger feels they need and gets a doctors note to be allowed to bring on the plane. I
Another clea?distinction between the two, putting it in plain terms. PSD and all other SD have full access to all areas of the airport covered by the ADA.  ESA do not. Therefore, ESA would have to follow the rules for pets everywhere except on the airplane and the other areas governed by DOT, not ADA. In these comments, the ATA clearly states that there is a problem with people faking other disabilities too, yet the DOT has claimed that one of the reasons it has implemented this discriminatory rule is because people fake PSD and not other types of SD. PSD are SERVICE DOGS, just like Guide Dogs, hearing dogs, Autism dogs, Medical alert/response dogs, mobility dogs and all other types of service dogs.  

If the DOT wants help in distinguishing between ESA/PSD, look at the ADA or Delta Society or HUD.

Title: Ron Greggs
Comment: AMU-Business 311 Law & Ethics (Assignmen 8) attached.

Title: Ian Ford
Comment:
To the Office of the Secretary of Transportation
Re: docket number [OST-2009-0115]

The TIGER funds sound like an ideal opportunity to start rebuilding the national
transport grid using lightweight guideway and US-produced components. 

I hope the requirement for rapid job creation doesn't rule out R&D and pilot
projects altogether. My fear is that in the name of job "creation" we will spend
money just to pay people to do something. 100 M$/year "creates" 20,000 jobs
instantly even if it is used to build monoliths in the desert, but of course
those jobs don't outlast the grant. So the emphasis ought to be on lasting jobs,
which could be a conflicting requirement with the requirement of rapidly created
jobs.

Since there is apparently no anti-waste criterion in the funding, it looks like
expensive urban rail projects would qualify, even if they can only be justified
on questionable arguments like TOD creation and quality of life. At the same
time, advanced transit projects using lightweight guideways such as PRT might
not qualify because of the lead time required to complete a pilor project,
safety certification, and so on. If the advanced system is many times more
economically efficient (which needs to be part of the analysis), then the
criteria should lean in their favor.

Title: Sherry Bohnert Earley
Comment:
Please clarify in paragraph entitled "State and Local Planning" if the project MUST 
be in relevant State and metropolitan planning documents prior to award or will 
projects that are not in the relevant documents still be considered.  There are 
extenuating circumstances in our region (Hampton Roads Virginia) that prohibited 
some recent projects from being included in the metropolitan area's long range 
plan and the state's transportation improvement plan.  I would like to recommend 
that inclusion in these plans not be a consideration in determining if a project is 
ready to go.

Title: Jennifer Strehler
Comment:
We have a project that formally requested to be added to the Colorado STIP 
(January 2009) but is not yet in there because CDOT refuses to add a project into 
the STIP until AFTER it has received state or federal funding award. This seems to 
conflict with the draft TIGER federal requirements on p. 23231 which essentially 
say that the project should already be listed in the state's STIP/TIP (e.g., listed on 
http://testimony.ost.dot.gov/ARRAcerts/) or that the applicant needs to submit "a 
certification from the appropriate agency that the project will be included in the 
relevant planning document prior to award of a TIGER Discretionary Grant."  
I bring this to FTA's attention so that our TIGER application is not 
incorrectly "graded down" because of what appears to be the circularity in the 
state vs. federal rules/procedures.  CDOT ranked our project highly in terms of 
importance for funding and they have provided written communication saying they 
will add my project into the STIP quickly, after we receive any federal funding 
award notices. To accomodate our situation and others in Colorado, the Town of 
Avon requests that the final TIGER rules are changed to allow the project to either 
already be in the STIP or e.g., "...be able to be added to the state STIP or other 
relevant planning document within 30 days of receipt of award".  (This was how the 
TIGGER grant program handled this problem.)

Title: Francis Ratcliffe Pickering
Government Agency: The Central Connecticut Regional Planning Agency (CCRPA)
Comment:
Dear Sir or Madam,
The Central Connecticut Regional Planning Agency (CCRPA), the designated 
Metropolitan Planning Organization (MPO) for central Connecticut, would like to 
comment on Docket No. OST-2009-0115, "TIGER Discretionary Grants."

CCRPA is concerned that the definition of "Eligible Applicants" under this and 
other ARRA programs (including High-Speed Rail/Intercity Passenger Rail) is too 
narrow. In particular, the list of "Eligible Applicants" proposed leaves out 
Metropolitan Planning Organizations. This omission is a problem. MPOs play a 
pivotal role in transportation, and not just in planning. Many MPOs have developed 
the capacity to and actively implement projects. MPOs' regional, multimodal 
perspective makes them the ideal parties to carry out the plans they developed.

Omitting MPOs from the Eligible Applicants creates an unnecessary disconnect 
between project planning and project implementation and reduces the likelihood 
that regional transportation projects are executed in a manner that is both swift 
and true-to-plan. Omitting MPOs will also unnecessarily limit the parties who can 
apply to the Tiger Discretionary Grants program, as well as the number of projects 
that would be eligible under the program. If intent of the program is to stimulate the 
economy, such constraints may be counterproductive. Many MPOs have lists of 
sound, shovel-ready projects they are eager to implement. All that lacks is funding.

For these reasons, CCRPA would like to ask that MPOs be expressly included in 
the list of Eligible Applicants for the TIGER Discretionary Grants as well as other 
similar programs. The federal government provides MPOs with funding to develop 
regional plans and projects; if it would like to see those plans and projects made a 
reality in the most efficient and expeditious manner possible, it would make sense 
to allow them to apply to the TIGER Discretionary Grant program.

Thank you for your consideration.

Sincerely,

Francis R. Pickering
Regional Planner, Central Connecticut Regional Planning Agency

Title: Richard Gerard Pieper
Comment:
Office of the Secretary of Transportation
Docket #OST-2009-0115



The County of Camden would be interested in pursuing the TIGER grants for 
improvements to our transportation system.  We are a very large county in 
southwest Missouri whose biggest industry is tourism.  Because of the economic 
crisis that the country is in we have had to make budget cuts as have many 
agencies over the last 1-1/2 years.

Because of these budget cuts our transportation infrastructure has suffered.  The 
roads that we have paved are beginning to fall apart and the remaining roads we 
have are gravel and in need of upgrading.

We are requesting assistance in obtaining help for our ailing infrastructure.  I will 
send in an application submittal by the required deadline.

Thank You for your assistance.

Rich Pieper
Road & Bridge Administrator

We would like to improve our asphalt roads to a higher standard and our heavily 
traveled gravel roads upgraded with a hard surfacing.  We would not be able to do 
all of this work with our crews so we would have to obtain bids from contractors to 
perform the majority of this work, which would put more people to work in our area.

Title: Dan Keith Cleavenger
Comment:
Dear Mr. Secretary:

Thank you for the opportunity to comment on the criteria for the TIGER 
Discretionary Grant program.  The City of Mesa is very interested in the TIGER 
program and the opportunity to work with the Federal government to promote 
investment in regionally significant infrastructure projects that will provide for long-
term benefits, create jobs and revitalize the economy.

After careful review, the City suggests that consideration be given to placing 
greater emphasis on connecting transportation modes to regionally significant 
public facilities.  Connecting modes such as freeway corridors to link directly to 
other modes such as airports that provide commercial passenger and cargo 
service will greatly facilitate the development of regional employment centers.

In our view, seamless multimodal transportation networks provide a platform for 
business development and job creation.  Such interconnectivity between modes 
provides businesses with superior speed and agility and the most efficient supply 
chain management to better distribute their products.  This will serve as a magnet 
for the growing number of companies that are dependent on time-critical, high-
value manufacturing and perishable distribution.

Once again, the City of Mesa greatly appreciates the opportunity to comment on 
the TIGER Discretionary Grant criteria and we look forward to working with you on 
this exciting program.

Sincerely,

Dan Cleavenger
Transportation Director

Title: Houston-Galveston Area Council
Comment:
This funding clearly is not intended to fund project studies, and focuses upon current projects that 
are ready for a near-term start date.  While this addresses the urgency of stimulating job 
development, it limits the exploration of innovative transportation strategies and projects.   In fact 
most projects that would meet the guidelines listed in the federal notice (near-term start date, NEPA 
compliant within 30 or 60 days, funding structure in place) may have political and financial support in 
place and be less likely to have a powerful and urgent need for these funds.  In order to meaningfully 
meet project selection criteria, the readiness of the project in the planning process needs to be 
more lenient.

Title: City of Charleston
Comment:
Our comments are included in the attached file.  thank you for your attention and 
we look forward to your response.

Title: Rodger D. Rochelle
Comment:
To:  Office of the Secretary of Transportation
Docket # OST-2009-0115

The North Carolina Department of Transportation respectfully submits the following 
comments on ths subject Docket:

1.  The Summary of the Rule states that " … the Department may award funds 
based on the initial applications without publishing a supplemental notice."  The 
Rule also states that the supplemental notice, if necessary, will be published on or 
before June 17, 2009.  The combination of these statements implies that awards 
may be granted prior to June 17, 2009.  In such case, applicants may be applying 
based on this Rule, not knowing whether the application requirements or selection 
criteria will be modified through a supplemental notice.

We respectfully request that clarification be made as to whether applications will 
be accepted prior to June 17, 2009.  Perhaps the Rule could expressly state the 
date beyond which applications may be submitted.

2.  The Summary of the Rule states that " … the Department may award funds 
based on the initial applications without publishing a supplemental notice."  The 
Rule also states that the supplemental notice, if necessary, will be published on or 
before June 17, 2009.   The combination of these statements implies that awards 
may be granted prior to June 17, 2009.  Continuing, the Summary states that "… 
the Department will evaluate all applications and announce the projects that have 
been selected to receive Grant Funds as soon as possible after the Application 
Deadline, but no later than February 17, 2010."  Since the Application Deadline is 
clearly September 15, 2009, please clarify if awards may be made before the 
Application Deadline.

3.  The Rule clearly expresses the desire to award funds to projects with national 
or regional significance and benefit.  It is likely that those projects with the 
greatest national or regional significance will be large.  These larger projects will 
also be the most challenging to complete prior to February 2012.

As such, we respectfully request that the Application Deadline be advanced,  
perhaps to August 1, 2009, to provide additional time to deliver these large 
nationally or regionally significant projects prior to February 2012.

4.  The Rule requires a "well-developed analysis of expected benefits and costs 
…".  The Rule also requests comments on the methodology for such an analysis 
and further states that, after the comment period, the "DOT will publish more 
detailed guidance on the analysis required…"

We request clarification as to whether an application submitted prior to the 
issuance of this further guidance can be amended to reflect the requirements of 
any further guidance.

5.  The Rule states that if the current solicitation does not result in the award and 
obligation of all available funds, that a subsequent solicitation may be proffered.  

In the event that funds are awarded to an applicant to a lesser amount than 
requested, please clarify as to whether the successful applicant can respond to 
any future solicitation for the purpose of acquiring additional TIGER funds for the 
same project partially funded previously.

Title: Livable Communities Coalition
Comment:
As executive director of the Livable Communities Coalition in Atlanta, Georgia,
I submit the attached comments on the proposed TIGER grants.

Title: City of Boise, Idaho and Capital City Development Corp.
Comment:
May 29, 2009

Office of the Secretary of Transportation
U. S. Department of Transportation
1200 New Jersey Avenue, SE
Docket Operations, M-30, Room W12-140
Washington, DC   20590

Docket Number OST-2009-0115

The City of Boise, Idaho, and Capital City Development Corp. (CCDC), Boise's 
redevelopment agency, intend to apply for a TIGER Discretionary Grant (Docket 
No. OST-2009-0115) to provide gap financing for the Downtown Boise Streetcar 
project currently in development. The city and CCDC offer the following comments 
on the Interim NOFA:

1. At least $300 million in the TIGER Discretionary Grant program should be 
dedicated uniquely for "ready-to-go" streetcar projects. Streetcars are a low cost 
transportation alternative which help address concerns about greenhouse gas 
emissions and the nation's dependence on foreign oil. They attract economic 
development, promote infill density and provide pedestrian-friendly mixed-use 
neighborhoods. Streetcars inherently capture all of the primary objectives of the 
ARRA and the TIGER program, yet of all forms of surface transportation 
infrastructure streetcars have been chronically unfunded or under-funded at the 
federal level. A set-aside of a significant portion of the TIGER program for 
streetcars would mean that they would not be judged in competition with other 
surface transportation projects.

2. Streetcar projects should not be judged under current New Starts/Small Starts 
rules, which are in direct conflict with the stated TIGER Discretionary Grant 
ranking criteria that emphasize long-term outcomes and job creation/economic 
stimulus. Currently under the Small Starts program, a project must have an overall 
rating of "medium" to be approved for federal funding and, in accordance with the 
language in the SAFETEA LU Technical Corrections Act, the FTA must 
give "comparable but not necessarily equal" weight to all of its criteria (supportive 
land use, economic development) in the evaluation process. An April 2005 Dear 
Colleague letter authored by FTA Administrator Jenna Dorn has unfairly 
discriminated against streetcar projects under the Small Starts program by 
requiring that projects must receive at least a "medium" cost effectiveness rating, 
which trumps the other criteria, before FTA will recommend a streetcar project for 
funding.  DOT should repeal the April 2005 Dear Colleague letter. This would clear 
the way for DOT to fund Small Starts streetcar projects through the TIGER 
process. 

3. The current FTA authority to award grants (in Section 5309 monies) up to $25 
million that are exempt from FTA rules, procedures and process should be 
explicitly invoked for streetcar projects in the TIGER program. Requiring 
compliance with typical FTA rules is too expensive and time consuming for most 
streetcar projects to be competitive in a grant program. Exempting streetcars from 
typical compliance would more closely meet the objectives of the TIGER program. 
The TIGER program should fund "exempt" streetcar projects that are already in 
development and require less than $25 million in federal funding. 

4. Additionally, streetcars that run in existing streets with other vehicular traffic 
should be categorically exempt from NEPA requirements. These streetcars would 
operate in roadways that are already in compliance with environmental 
regulations; streetcars do not add any negative environmental impacts (and in fact 
have been shown to provide certain positive impacts in air quality, resource 
consumption and traffic congestion.) 

Thank you for this opportunity to comment.

Title: Texas Department of Transportation

Title: Thomas S. Oldfield
Comment:
Thomas Oldfield providing comments to DOT’s notice of proposed rulemaking
published 18 May 2009 (74 FedReg. 2326). 
        I have been engaged in nation-wide project development for many years in
this area of operations. My comments reflect that experience and may have some
impact on regional projects currently under development
	Context: The statutory context that underlies the proposed rulemaking is the
American Recovery and Reinvestment Act of 2009 (HR-1) or ARRA (hereinafter,
referenced as). Our comments focus on the enabling the Secretary and the US
Department of Transportation modals to achieve the purposes and intent of the
law; and, our comments distinguish these purposes from the objectives of the
normal Federal budgetary process enacted annually by the Congress. 
	Summary: The underlying purposes of ARRA differ from those of the normal
budgetary process. ARRA is designed to inject immediate funding assistance to
the economy of the United States during a time of urgency. Thus, ARRA
establishes numerous  time limits for Executive Branch action. The DOT proposed
rulemaking is in support of an area of spending to be authorized at the
discretion of the Secretary of Transportation. The Congress identifies the
purposes and intent of the legislation to,
 (1) To preserve and create jobs and promote economic recovery, 
(2) To assist those most impacted by the recession.
(3) To provide investments needed to increase economic efficiency by spurring
technological advances in science and health. 
(4) To invest in transportation, environmental protection, and other
infrastructure that will provide long-term economic benefits. 
(5) To stabilize State and local government budgets, in order to minimize and
avoid reductions in essential services and counterproductive state and local tax
increases. 
	We can assume that the Congress established these principles in priority order
given the objectives of the legislation. Thus, we encourage DOT to re-examine
its proposed rulemaking to reflect these very explicit priorities. We do not
believe that the proposed rules support either the Congress’ short term
objective or the core purposes of the Act. The proposed rulemaking does not
reiterate the ARRA objectives faithfully; and, it injects objectives outside of
the intent of the Congress and inconsistent with statutory dictates:
	The second priority, “To assist those most impacted by the recession” becomes
diminished. Of greater importance under the proposed rulemaking is, “To invest
in transportation infrastructure…” which is not a faithful recitation of the
statute and not the mandated second priority of the legislation. We recommend
that the third priority be restored to second place, as stated in the
legislation and that DOT act accordingly. Further, third and forth priorities
should be re-stated according to the statute, in accord with DOT’s various
mandates. Indeed, the last priority, in the notice of proposed rulemaking is not
even mentioned and, as we shall explain later, has become its first priority:
“To stabilize State and local government budgets.” 
	Given the language of the statute, the Congress has further required that DOT
establish a special context by which these funds will be distributed and
monitored. Thus, we conclude that, given the time sensitivity of delivery, that
the normal DOT regulatory environment may not necessarily apply, absent any
requirement to do so by the Congress. Accordingly, we encourage DOT to
re-examine its proposed rulemaking to eliminate any unnecessary attempt to
re-contextualize its implementation in the past regulatory frameworks that may
not be appropriate or fully consistent with the intent of the Congress and which
may extend the time of delivery or  evaluation of proposals. While the proposed
rulemaking attempts to achieve that objective, it does not fully implement the
intent of the Congress. Accordingly, we have discussed herein a few of what we
believe to be variances for immediate attention and as a framework for revision.
Essentially, we do not believe that ARRA empowers DOT to act outside of the
regulatory environment, but that it is empowered to take exception to past
requirements in light of the purposes that ARRA enunciates.
	Proposed Regulatory Provisions:
I.	Background: Statutory provisions should be reiterated (See, Summary
Provisions, above). The President did NOT sign such a bill into law that takes
exception to provisions enacted by the Congress. Thus, those provisions should
be faithfully reiterated in the context of the proposed rulemaking language.
 Subsidy/Administrative Costs: The language of the act provides that $200m shall
be available “for the purpose of paying the subsidy and administrative costs of
projects eligible for federal credit assistance…” The agency should specify its
findings and if it intends to use these funds as authorized or if the Secretary
has made another determination.
II.	Selection Criteria: Again the Department is in error in its recitation of
the provisions of the act, recast as selection criteria. Long-term outcomes,
while commendable, is not an identified criteria under ARRA. It does not have a
higher criteria than “job creation”. The Department has made a serious error in
judgment by attempting to advance non-statutory criteria as part of its
selection criteria. ARRA is not a long-term solution for the economy. It is an
immediate response to the needs of the population CURRENTLY and adversely
effected. These are “short term” objectives not, “near term” and/or “long-term
objectives.” No explanation which the department might advance is sufficient to
overcome or supplant the intent of the Congress.
a.	Livability, sustainability, safety: criteria for these categories should be
compared to the immediate outcomes expected under ARRA. The impression given is
for long-term results. ARRA is designed for short-term solutions with possible,
but not mandatory long-term results.
b.	BCA: While the BCA approach may be desirable, it should not be holding as a
primary evaluative criterion. Areas and terms of reference such as greenhouse
gasses, water quality, etc. are all long-term consequences. Certainly, any
project identified should do no harm or have an adverse effect on any of these
areas. However, imposing a positive criterion or standard of measure is
unnecessary given the nature and size of these grants. It imposes an unnecessary
burden on applicants without immediate result. If the Department wants to use
this as an internal criterion it is free to do so. The applicant, however,
should not be so obligated.
c.	Project Performance Evaluations: Clearly, these criteria should be of primary
and distinguishing importance. They are primary ARRA objectives.
i.	Job Creation: Any project selected under this ARRA discretionary authority
MUST demonstrate and be liable for job creation. In most cases, infrastructure,
once created will NOT yield sustained employment. Applicants as a mandatory
criterion should be required to clearly demonstrate sustained employment by
short-term project efforts that will not terminate with the completion of the
project. Thus, short-term construction or similar employment, while important is
not a prime ARRA objective.
ii.	Business Assistance: provisions in these areas reiterate old and ineffective
approaches to DBE, SDVOB, and SB program past failures. As in most past DOT
programs, we expect that the DBE, SDVOB, and SB community will continue to be
victimized by prime contractors and ineffective/outdated DOT review, protective,
and compliance procedures. This provision is purely palliative and should be
substantially revised. These protected classes are more negatively impacted than
any other class and should be accorded primary considerations and protections.
iii.	Project Schedule: ARRA funded projects and contractors should enjoy
expedited payment and strictly enforced prompt payment provisions.
iv.	Environmental Approvals: Absent any timely (30 day) agreement among the
numerous Federal and local environmental agencies to agree upon acceptable
solutions, DOT should assume jurisdiction and impose immediate and reasonable
solutions without delay.
v.	Legislative Approvals: Absent any timely (30 day) agreement among
legislative, municipal, and local authorities, DOT should assume jurisdiction
and be empowered to impose immediate and reasonable solutions without delay. DOT
should be empowered to impose any penalties for cost incurred on uncooperative
legislative/municipal/local participants.
vi.	Planning: Absent any timely (30 day) agreement among planning bodies, DOT
should assume jurisdiction and be empowered to impose immediate and reasonable
solutions without delay. DOT should be empowered to impose any penalties for
cost incurred on uncooperative planning participants.
vii.	Financial feasibility: Absent any timely (30 day) agreement among financial
review organizations, DOT should assume jurisdiction and be empowered to impose
immediate and reasonable solutions without delay. In such cases, DOT should make
provisions to demonstrate its competency in such areas or delegate this review
to areas of competency. Concerning financial feasibility, DOT should make
special provisions for bonding exemptions for DBE, SDVOB, and SB participants.
d.	Secondary Selection Criteria:
i.	Innovation: technology innovation is a separate category under ARRA. General
funding applicants should not be required to demonstrate technical innovation
unless this is the primary objective of the respective project. Hence, it should
not be a generalized and binding criterion.
ii.	Innovation Life Cycle: Here DOT provides preference for long-term projects,
which is inconsistent with ARRA. It should be substantially revised or removed.
iii.	Partnerships: Private-Public sector partnerships should be strongly
encouraged to enhance project funding and sustained job growth. This section
merits substantial improvement since it offers a considerable leverage potential
for the Federal grant investment from companion private investment. This section
should include attention to alternative areas of credit enhancement,
entitlement, appraisal, permitting, debt and investment instrument production
under proper supervision by competent financial oversight Federal agencies.
Municipal and State governments should be discouraged from competition with
private sector enterprises and required to engage in partnerships as the primary
mode of program development. With appropriate provisions – not contained herein
– ARRA provisions and funding leverage can be considerably enhanced for every
project, in every state. Moreover, private sector participation can assure
sustained employment beyond the completion of the project specific employment.
This is an area where preference should be given to SB, DBE, and SDVOB businesses.
e.	Program Specific Criteria: A preference for long-term projects and outcomes,
again is present and should be revised or eliminated as inconsistent with ARRA.
Specifically, the TIFIA evaluation scoring needs considerable revision to
reflect compliance with ARRA. For example, criterion (a) has no reference to job
creation! In an environment of limited credit availability, criterion (d) should
be adjusted given specific provisions of the act to the contrary. Criterion (g)
should be a DOT responsibility and not incumbent on the applicant to complete
DOT’s responsibility. Thus the provision should be eliminated. The TIFIA opinion
letter should be at the cost of the government, not the applicant; and, should
be, accordingly so clarified.
III.	Application Content: The $30,000 application is simply outrageous. Under
ARRA, the DOT receives millions to defray administrative expenses. Adding
additional fees is not found in ARRA and should be impermissible. Moreover, this
level of fee has a direct and adverse impact on DBE, SDVOB, and SB applicants.
Structurally, it means that only the largest can apply! This is completely
inconsistent with the problems ARRA attempts to redress. Indeed, DOT, at its own
expense should offer any certified DBE, SDVOB, and SB assistance to prepare a
submission. 
Summary: The DOT proposed rulemaking merits substantial revision. It focuses on
“big government” and “big business”. Moreover, it incorporates substantial and
negative regulatory baggage which have been proven ineffective for many years.
Finally, the proposed regulation imposes a standard that is in exception to the
intent of the Congress. Thus, the notice of proposed rule making is potentially
damaging to the core objectives of the legislation. Hence, I must urge DOT to
withdraw the proposed rules and program until they can be revised to meet
Congressional intent.

Title: Johnnie K. Singleston
Comment:
I support the use of the TIGER grants to fund construction of the Interstate 73 
interchange in Dillon County, SC.  This interchange is an essential part of I-73 and 
will create jobs in an area that is economically distressed.  I-73 runs through 
counties that are often referred to as the 'corridor of shame'.  By investing in I-73, 
jobs will be created, traffic flow will improve and the SCDOT can begin building the 
remaining portions of I-73 to connect it with other roadways already built.

Title: Brad Dean
Comment:
The TIGER grant program will fund important infrastructure projects that deliver 
significant economic benefits to projects of national and regional significance.   
Interstate 73, established as High Priority Corridor #5 in ISTEA, remains an 
uncompleted national priority.  The South Carolina portion of this corridor was named a 
project of national and regional significance in SAFETEA-LU for good reason:  the 
project will reside in 3 counties in northeastern South Carolina where average 
unemployment is more than twice the national average.  This interstate will also extend 
the national interstate system to Myrtle Beach, SC, the nation’s busiest vacation 
destination without interstate access.  

A significant portion of this road has already been built using local tax collections.  The 
State of South Carolina has made a recurring investment to I-73 every year for the past 
five years.  The South Carolina General Assembly has also approved legislation 
authorizing tolls to be collected upon its portion of I-73.  A TIGER grant will allow the 
project to make considerable progress on the ground, creating jobs that are badly 
needed.  Key benefits of I-73 include:
 
 - Job creation, both from construction of the road and surrounding economic 
development, in nearby areas that are economically distressed;
- Improved safety, especially for hurricane evacuations from the South Carolina coast;
- Economic growth of the nation’s busiest vacation destination without interstate 
access.  

With so much state and local funding already invested in this project, the USDOT 
should give serious consideration to funding Interstate 73 in South Carolina through a 
TIGER grant.

Brad Dean

Job creation, both from construction of the road and surrounding economic

Title: Katrina Miles
Comment:
I-73 advocates continue to support completing the proposed interstate as a whole, 
believing completion of this interstate will spur economic activity, create jobs in 
areas with high unemployment rates, boost tourism and save lives.  

Economic Impact
It is estimated that I-73 could create thousands of jobs and draw new industry into 
some of the most economically depressed counties in South Carolina.   I-73 will 
also serve international commerce, as it potentially connects a major port 
(Charleston, SC) to the Canadian border.  Though I-73 does not travel to 
Charleston, discussions are underway to determine whether an inland port could 
be located in/near Marion, SC, enabling the South Carolina ports system to 
become truly intermodal.  If this is completed, I-73 runs in Marion, SC and would 
become a major thoroughfare of port distribution.

Tourism
National trends clearly indicate the need for improved roadways to facilitate future 
growth in the tourism industry.  While the more rural counties look to I-73 as an 
economic tool to draw business and industry, the Grand Strand can expect to 
expound on its product of tourism if the interstate is built, according to Dr. Donald 
Schunk, research economist at Coastal Carolina University.  Myrtle Beach and 
the rest of the Grand Strand in Horry County is the central cog in South Carolina’s 
top industry: tourism.  The area pumps about $15 billion year into the state’s 
economy.  Schunk said I-73 would allow for 100,000 or more visitors a year to 
Horry County’s beaches and estimated the additional visitors would spend $60 
million annually.  About 63 percent of Horry County’s employment is tourism-
related, according to the Myrtle Beach Regional Economic Development Corp.  
  
Safety
During the peak summer season, the Myrtle Beach area of South Carolina hosts 
as many as 500,000 visitors per day.  It is estimated that 94% of those visitors 
drive to the area and 70% of those drive-in visitors come from outside the state, 
traveling on I-95.  When combined with the permanent populations of Horry County 
(238,000) and Georgetown County (103,000) it is apparent that this region has in 
excess of 800,000 people daily.  In the event of a severe tropical storm or a 
hurricane, it will take 2-3 days to evacuate the coastal area.  If a storm were to 
strengthen, speed up and/or change course, 2-3 days may not be available.  Lives 
could be lost, due to the fact that the area is primarily dependent upon one 
evacuation route: Highway 501, a local thoroughfare that is 4-lane and not 
sufficient to evacuate such large numbers of people.

Title: Smart Growth America

Title: Franklin Gordon Daniels
Comment:
The TIGER grant program will fund important infrastructure projects that deliver 
significant economic benefits to projects of national and regional significance.   
Interstate 73, established as High Priority Corridor #5 in ISTEA, remains an 
uncompleted national priority.  The South Carolina portion of this corridor was 
named a project of national and regional significance in SAFETEA-LU for good 
reason:  the project will reside in 3 counties in northeastern South Carolina where 
average unemployment is more than twice the national average.  This interstate 
will also extend the national interstate system to Myrtle Beach, SC, the nation’s 
busiest vacation destination without interstate access.  

A significant portion of this road has already been built using local tax 
collections.  The State of South Carolina has made a recurring investment to I-73 
every year for the past five years.  The South Carolina General Assembly has also 
approved legislation authorizing tolls to be collected upon its portion of I-73.  A 
TIGER grant will allow the project to make considerable progress on the ground, 
creating jobs that are badly needed.  Key benefits of I-73 include:
 

Job creation, both from construction of the road and surrounding economic 
development, in nearby areas that are economically distressed; 
Improved safety, especially for hurricane evacuations from the South Carolina 
coast; 
Economic growth of the nation’s busiest vacation destination without interstate 
access.  

With so much state and local funding already invested in this project, the USDOT 
should give serious consideration to funding Interstate 73 in South Carolina 
through a TIGER grant.

impoverished counties and communities that it passes through. We are ready to 
start construction now.

Title: Wendy Bernstein
Comment:
As a long time resident of Horry County, I believe the I-73 project is critical to the 
continuing growth of the Grand Strand. The TIGER grant program would provide 
the financing necessary to build the Interstate 73 (a High Priority Corridor #5 in 
ISTEA which remains an uncompleted national priority) project. The project will 
reside in 3 counties in northeastern South Carolina where average unemployment 
is more than twice the national average. This interstate will also extend the 
national interstate system to Myrtle Beach, SC, the nation’s busiest vacation 
destination without interstate access.  

 A TIGER grant will allow the project to make considerable progress on the 
ground, creating jobs that are badly needed.  

Major benefits of I-73 include job creation, both from construction of the road and 
surrounding economic development, in nearby areas that are economically 
distressed. Another benefit is improved safety, especially for hurricane 
evacuations from the South Carolina coast, and economic growth of the nation’s 
busiest vacation destination without interstate access.  

A significant portion of this road has already been built using local tax collections, 
and the State of South Carolina has made a recurring investment to I-73 every 
year for the past five years. With so much state and local funding already invested 
in this project, the USDOT should give serious consideration to funding Interstate 
73 in South Carolina through a TIGER grant.

Title: Philip G. Sunderland
Comment:
Dear Sir or Madam:

The Metropolitan Washington Airports Authority would like to comment on Docket 
No. OST-2009-0115, TIGER Discretionary Grants.

1.  Section III.B describes the conditions under which a component of a project 
could be considered.   The Airports Authority recommends tht an engineering and 
design project be an eligible component of a project if it can be demonstrated that 
advancing the engineering and design would create positive economic impacts 
and jobs by advancing the project’s construction. 

2.  The Airports Authority also recommends that the Department consider the 
benefits of the advanced construction of the full project, not just the engineering 
and design phase.

3.  The Airports Authority recommends that transit projects being developed 
without the use of Section 5309 funds (New Starts and Small Starts), still be 
considered eligible transit projects.  

4.  The Metropolitan Washington Airports Authority is a public body created by an 
interstate compact between the District of Columbia and the Commonwealth of 
Virginia.  It wishes to apply for funds even though its project is not in the approved 
State Transportation Improvement Program (STIP) and is not being funded with 
state funds.  Note that the Airports Authority’s Chief Executive Officer, rather than 
the Governor of Virginia, signed the Airports Authority’s Section 1511 certification 
for an application for funds from the American Recovery and Reinvestment Act of 
2009 Public Transportation Capital Investment Grants Program Appropriation and 
Allocations. 

5.  The Airports Authority concurs in the comments of Jennifer Strehler of Avon, 
Colorado, and Sherry Bohnert Earley of Hampton Roads, Virginia, with regard to 
the requirement that the project be in the State Transportation Improvement Plan.

Thank you for the opportunity to comment and for your consideration.

Sincerely yours,
Philip G. Sunderland
General Counsel

Title: American Association of State Highway and Transportation Officials (AASHTO)
Organization Name: American Association of State Highway and Transportation Officials (AASHTO)

Title: David B. Prince
Comment:
I am an attorney in private practice in Los Angeles, California. Project 
development is an area of practice. Thus, I am submitting comments to the DOT 
proposed rules published at its DOCKET # OST-2009-0015.
    The proposed rules raise some general questions that require more careful 
attention on the part of the US Department of Transportation. Clearly, the 
Department is attempting to provide project funding in a manner consistent with the 
intent of the Congress and the express purposes of the Stimulus Act -- American 
Recovery and Reinvestment Act of 2009. It simply did not come out that way; and, 
DOT should re-examine these efforts before finalizing its rules and funding process.
    In general, the proposed rules tries to provide some preferences that have 
always been on DOT's books. They are simply not part of the Recovery Act. The 
Recovery Act or ARRA is designed as a quick fix, not a long-term solution. Long-
term solutions are a part of the normal budgetary process, repeated annually. The 
Recovery Act seeks to put people back to work quickly and stimulate local 
economy. Moreover, in many of the areas of funding, normal processes are waived. 
The DOT provisions of ARRA are no different. Instead, DOT has incorporated its old 
baggage in the guise of fulfilling Congressional intent. Nothing could be further from 
the truth if you read the fine print.
    Here, I am not going to provide a complete laundry list of problems. However, 
key and at the top of the list are the priorities expressed by the Congress and their 
implementation. DOT simply does not repeat and corrupts those priorities in its 
proposed rules! As Congress provided a statutory blue print, so to MUST the DOT 
seek to implement the will of the Congress. That's simply how the Constitution 
works.
    There are a few "wool over the eyes" attempts in the homage to the DBE -- 
Disadvantaged Business Enterprise -- program. Knowing that the program has 
serious flaws, DOT simply repeats, rather than improves the approach. Keep in 
mind that the ARRA is focused on small business. The DBE program, however, 
counts small businesses as victimized by large construction firms. This isn't any 
surprise. Incorporating a reference to such a flawed program without any 
improvement is, at best, ingenuous.
    During these times, when recovery efforts need to be focused on short-term 
results, DOT opts for long-term effects, broad consequences, policy mumbo jumbo, 
etc. We need to put workers back to work and offer small business opportunity. 
These rules do not accomplish that objective of the act even in this small, 
discretionary program.
    Finally, partnership programs should be strongly encouraged. They hold the 
promise of leverage for our tax payer dollars and sustained growth. This area needs 
very considerable redrafting.
    Thus, I do not believe that DOT has operated in the best interest of the public, 
the government, or the will of the Congress. Rather, it has created a program that 
was not intended by the Congress which will inevitably reward the "old guard" of 
large business and competitive local governments.
    I recommend that DOT personnel, first re-read the Constitutionl; and, second, 
revise this document so that it serves the will of those who the public elected and 
are empowered to express the will of the people.

Title: Santa Barbara County Association of Governments
Organization Name: Santa Barbara County Association of Governments
Comment:
The Santa Barbara County Association of Governments (SBCAG) is the MPO for Santa
Barbara County, California.  We have reviewed the Draft Guidance for the Grants
for ‘Transportation Investment Generating Economic Recovery’ (TIGER) Program
released on May 18, 2009.  SBCAG would like to submit the attached comment letter.

Title: William Golden
Comment:
Interstate 73, established as High Priority Corridor #5 in ISTEA, remains an 
uncompleted national priority.  The South Carolina portion of this corridor was 
named a project of national and regional significance in SAFETEA-LU for good 
reason:  the project will reside in 3 counties in northeastern South Carolina where 
average unemployment is more than twice the national average.  This project will 
bring over 7,000 jobs during the construction phase, and will ultimately provide 
much needed new industry and higher paying jobs upon completion.

This interstate will also extend the national interstate system to Myrtle Beach, 
SC, the nation?s busiest vacation destination without interstate access, providing 
additional jobs for local residents. 

In addition, this project will alleviate congestion on over taxed roadways.  
Currently, sufficient roadways do not exist to provide for a timely evacuation of 
the area in the event of a hurricane.

A significant portion of this road has already been built using local tax 
collections.  The State of South Carolina has made a recurring investment to I-73 
every year for the past five years.  The South Carolina General Assembly has also 
approved legislation authorizing tolls to be collected upon its portion of I-73.  A 
TIGER grant will allow the project to make considerable progress on the ground, 
creating jobs that are badly needed, while providing for economic growth in the 
future.

Given the signifigant state and local funding already invested in this project, plus 
the considerable economic and safety benefits for the region, funding I73 merits 
serious consideration through a TIGER Grant.

Title: Stephen Dilts
Comment:
June 1, 2009


The Honorable Ray LaHood
Secretary
US Department of Transportation
1200 New Jersey Avenue, SE
Washington, DC 20590

Re: Docket No. OST-2009-0115

Dear Secretary LaHood: 

The New Jersey Department of Transportation submits the following comments 
regarding the project selection criteria and guidance for awarding TIGER 
Discretionary Grants.

The Federal Railroad Administration (FRA) should be the lead for the freight rail 
projects that the U.S. Department of Transportation selects.  The FRA has 
established policies and procedures geared to deliver freight rail projects.  Utilizing 
the FRA will make the delivery of the freight rail projects more efficient.

To insure the right balance of worthwhile projects, covering a range of modes, 
priority should not be limited to those completed by February 17, 2012; instead 
priority should include those projects that can be substantially completed by that 
date.  Giving priority to projects completed by February 17, 2012 risks jeopardizing 
otherwise significant and worthwhile projects that will be substantially completed 
by that date.

Thank you for your consideration and the opportunity to comment.

Sincerely, 


Stephen Dilts
Commissioner, New Jersey Department of Transportation
