Title: California Department of Transportation
Comment:
California Department of Transportation Comments on Docket OST-2009-0115


June 1, 2009




Office of the Secretary of Transportation
Docket Number) OST-2009-0115
US Department of Transportation
1200 New Jersey Avenue, SE
Docket Operations, M-30
Room W12-140
Washington, DC 20590

Reference: Docket Number OST-2009-0115

The California Department of Transportation (Caltrans) offers the following 
comments in response to the May 18, 2009, United States Department of 
Transportation (US DOT) Interim Notice of Funding Availability for Supplemental 
Discretionary Grants for Capital Investments in Surface Transportation 
Infrastructure Under the American Recovery and Reinvestment Act and Request 
for Comments on Grant Criteria:

General Comments:

In general, Caltrans is supportive of US DOT in its efforts to ensure that the 
Transportation Investments Generating Economic Recovery (TIGER) program can 
have a lasting effect on increasing national competitiveness and improving the 
economy, especially through advancing projects that improve freight mobility. 

In discussion with its State and National partners, we note that there has been a 
general theme of response that the proposed grant criteria are vague and exceed 
existing requirements for similar programs under United States Code Titles 23 and 
49.  We concur with this theme especially as expressed in terms of lack of 
specificity for calculating direct and indirect job creation and how US DOT will 
weight long-term outcomes.  

We concur with the formal comments on this docket provided by the American 
Association of State Highway and Transportation Officials.  In addition, some of 
our partners have noted and we agree that the proposed criteria should give 
greater priority to projects that leverage local, state, and private sector funding, 
and/or can be delivered rapidly.  

The purposes of the TIGER program is similar to the existing Projects of National 
and Regional Significance Program (PNRS), and most of the proposed eligible 
projects fall within the scope of existing state and metropolitan planning and 
program requirements.  In the case of the PNRS, US DOT has already published 
final regulations that established a more flexible application and selection process 
that is sufficient to allow competitive selection for the same types of projects that 
are eligible for funding under the TIGER program.  For the most part, these 
existing regulations focus on project viability in terms of its completion of existing 
planning, programming, and financial requirements.  Using them as the basis for 
the TIGER program criteria would expedite the selection process and reduce the 
complexity of the proposed application process.

Cost Benefit Analysis Requirements:

The proposed grant criteria require applicants to estimate a project’s expected 
benefits in the five long-term outcomes.   Cost benefit analyses are an effective 
way to determine the relative value of individual proposals, especially in highly 
competitive programs.  However, as proposed, the proposed requirements exceed 
the limitations of these types of analyses, especially when applied to vaguely 
described primary selection criteria for the Livability, Sustainability, and 
Competitiveness Long-Term Outcomes.  If US DOT is to retain these criteria and 
process, then it should either be more specific in defining criteria, or specify that 
in the above-mentioned cases, a qualitative description would suffice.

Certification Requirements:

The requirements are very clear in specifying who is responsible for providing 
Section 1511 certifications for projects that are included in the Statewide 
Transportation Improvement Program (STIP).   It would be beneficial for this 
section to clearly identify who is responsible for projects that are not included in 
the STIP, especially if they funded from sources other than those under State or 
Local control.

Sincerely, 



KEN DE CRESCENZO
Federal Liaison

Title: Donald C. Witty
Comment:
I support the use of TIGER grants to fund major infrastructure projects and 
encourage the USDOT to consider a grant to help further progress of Interstate 73 
in South Carolina.  I-73 will create jobs in our region, where unemployment is as 
high as 18%.  A part of this road has already been built using local money, but 
much work is left to be done.  This part of the country lacks interstate access, 
even though this interstate has been planned for years.  

I urge you to consider awarding TIGER grants to large transportation infrastructure 
projects that have been given a status of nationally significant, yet remain 
unfinished.

Title: Seattle Displacement Coalition
Comment:
June 1, 2009, 6pm Seattle Time

To whom it may concern:

Re:  Our Comments on Docket ID  DOT-OST-2009-0115  
Docket Title  Supplemental Discretionary Grants for Capital Investments in 
Surface Transportation Infrastructure  
Document ID  DOT-OST-2009-0115-0001  
Document Title  Funding Availability; Request for Comments on Grant Criteria: 
Supplemental Discretionary Grants for Capital Investments in Surface 
Transportation Infrastructure, etc.  

My name is John Fox and I'm writing on behalf of the Seattle Displacement 
Coalition, a 30 year community advocacy organization here in Seattle to comment 
on grant criteria for supplement discretionary grants for capital investments in 
Surface Transportation Infrastructure.  I'm also writing on behalf of a larger 
coalition of over 16 community, small business, and democratic party 
organizations and over 100 community leaders opposed to the use of federal 
stimulus monies (TIGER funds in this case) for Seattle's Mercer Corridor Project.  

Already the Mercer Corridor project is 100 million dollars over original cost 
projections and the City is simply seeking to alter criteria you use for granting 
these funds so they can secure these funds to cover cost overruns.  The Mercer 
Corridor Project also does not meet a real transportation need in Seattle and will 
actually make traffic congestion worse in the Eastbound Direction. The project is 
located in Seattle's South Lake Union - it is home to developer Paul Allen's plans 
for a biotech hub in this area - and merely serves as a beautification project to 
enhance land values in this growing area.  I've attached a letter identifying coalition 
members opposed to this project.

The City of Seattle will be seeking 50 million of TIGER funding for this project and 
it does not meet grant criteria for receipt of these funds.  

Regarding criteria for use of these stimulus funds, economic recovery monies 
must serve a purpose in this case a real transportation purpose which this 
application does not but most important of all, these funds are designated 
for "economically distressed areas". We want to emphasize that this must remain 
the highest priority and key criteria for use of these stimulus monies. 

In order to skirt this key requirement, and you may check the Seattle City Council 
record Monday June 1st 930 AM Council Briefing, our City has asked you to de-
elevate the importance of this criteria and instead give priority to "economically 
growing areas".  This is a clear attempt to skirt the key criteria and direct funds 
precisely where they are not needed in Seattle and for a project that will do 
nothing to reduce traffic congestion in our city as indicated by 3 independent and 
even city sponsored studies.  It's simply a beautification project serving one large 
development company and aimed at moving traffic away from his key waterfront 
properties.  Already, the State Legislature decided not to provide stimulus funding 
for the Mercer project precisely because it did not meet recovery act criteria.

In Seattle there are an identified 30 bridges in critical need of repair - many of 
them located in parts of SE and SW Seattle - truly low income and distressed 
areas.  This does not include a backlog of over one-half billion in road and street 
and sidewalk improvements mostly in these distressed communities. Yet our city 
will forgo seeking stimulus monies for these projects in favor of a 50 million dollar 
request for Mercer - primarily to serve the developer agenda of one man - Paul 
Allen - and his development company Vulcan Inc.  

We urge you to retain as your most important criteria for use of these funds - 
economically distressed communities. It would be a breach of the voters faith and 
the recovery act to do otherwise. Only these communities deserve these funds. 
Sadly our city doesn't seem to care and would abuse this program.  They are 
seeking to have you change criteria that would undercut the intent of these 
recovery funds.  

On behalf of the Coalition opposed to use of stimulus funds for Mercer
John V. Fox for the Coalition
4554 12th NE 
Sea. Wa. 98105
206-632-0668    mailto:jvf4119@zipcon.net

Also see following letter providing more detail as to why no stimulus funds should 
be used for the Mercer Corridor Project.  Instead of meeting current proposed 
criteria, the city is seeking to alter the criteria to move it's application up as 
priority - here is our letter submitted to oppose use of stimulus funds to local 
officials:

Organizations and Community Leaders Opposed to Use of Stimulus Funds for 
Seattle’s Mercer Corridor Project

March 12, 2009

The Honorable Julia Patterson, Chair
Transportation Policy Board 
Puget Sound Regional Council
1011 Western Avenue 
Seattle, WA 98104

Dear Ms. Patterson:

As residents and community leaders from across Seattle, we are writing to 
strongly urge you to deny the City's $80 million dollar request for federal dollars for 
the "Mercer Corridor Project".  The City has submitted this request for at least 
that amount in federal funds drawn from the stimulus package now being initiated 
by the President Elect Obama. Our mayor is seeking these funds to fill a growing 
funding gap given that project costs have skyrocketed from $90 million four years 
ago to over $200 million today.

Earmarking monies for the Mercer project would represent a gross misuse of 
stimulus package dollars given that this plan does not address either a regional or 
local transportation need in our community. Under the Mayor's plan, Mercer would 
be widened and turned into a 2-way tree-lined boulevard where it runs through the 
South Lake Union Neighborhood between I-5 and the Seattle Center. Valley Street 
that now absorbs much of the westbound traffic from I-5 would be narrowed with 
that traffic funneled onto Mercer.  

City Council staff and the City's Department of Transportation (SDOT) have 
acknowledged that these costly changes will do absolutely nothing to reduce 
traffic congestion along that corridor and will at certain intersections make it 
worse. In fact, there are at least three studies now that have been done which 
confirm that this preferred two-way Mercer plan will exacerbate traffic problems in 
South Lake Union.  One study done as part of the preliminary environmental 
review cites delays of traffic by as much as 7-18 minutes in the eastbound 
direction if this plan is implemented. 

The Mayor's planners also have tried to argue that reconfiguring Mercer will help 
move traffic through downtown during State Route 99 and Alaskan Way Viaduct 
construction.  According to the City Council’s analysis, no research shows that 
the proposed changes will in any way alleviate congestion during this construction.

By contrast, in 2000, there was a plan preferred by the community and by our 
former Mayor Paul Schell that was called the "small and simple" fix which, if 
implemented, would have cost only $10 million (in 2000 dollars). That plan also 
would have done more to reduce congestion in the area, but it was dropped from 
consideration after our current Mayor took office and after the City sold all the 
properties along Mercer to billionaire Paul Allen.  
Put simply, today’s Mercer two-way alternative is a 'pork barrel' project that was 
devised to mesh with redevelopment plans now occurring in South Lake Union 
where Mercer is located. That plan is driven by Paul Allen's Vulcan development 
company which owns nearly 50% of all developable land in that area and 
especially along Mercer and Valley streets. The Mercer project is designed to 
redirect traffic away from Paul Allen's view properties located along Valley street 
closest to the lake and push it all on to Mercer - at a cost of over 200 million 
dollars (and climbing).  Paul Allen will also benefit when the City buys back land 
along Mercer he owns - now very expensive land the City sold to him only seven 
years ago at rock bottom prices.

This is precisely the kind of project the Obama administration has said they would 
not support for use of stimulus package dollars.  It also would be the wrong first 
step for the incoming administration to take, especially when there are so many 
real pressing transportation needs in our region with a price tag of over 15 billion 
dollars, including nearly a one billion dollar backlog of critical road, sidewalk, and 
bridge repairs in our city's neighborhoods.  These are the kinds of projects that 
desperately need these stimulus funds not the Mercer project. 

City engineers have identified 33 bridges in our neighborhoods in serious need of 
repair, some bordering on unsafe.  To preference Mercer over these needs strikes 
us as a serious breach of the voters' trust. These are projects that have been 
waiting years for promised dollars and meet the president elect's most important 
criteria for receipt of stimulus funds - they are shovel ready, i.e., ready for 
immediate start-up. By contrast, the Mercer Project faces months if not years of 
extensive environmental review and likely litigation due to community opposition. 

It's time to pull the plug on the Mercer project. Some of the constituent and 
neighborhood groups directly affected by the two-way Mercer plan that already 
have gone on record opposing it include:

 
Magnolia Community Club
Rainier Beach Community Club Executive Board
Queen Anne Community Council
Southeast Seattle Crime Prevention Council
Othello Neighborhood Association
Columbia City Community Council
North Seattle Industrial Association
Aurora Avenue Merchants Association
Fremont Chamber of Commerce
Ballard District Council
Seattle Community Council Federation
Northeast District Council
Metropolitan Democratic Club
Seattle Marine Business Coalition
36th District Democrats
Seattle Displacement Coalition
University District Community Council.

Title: Douglas Pelman Wendel
Comment:
The TIGER grant program will fund infrastructure projects that are of significant 
economic importance to projects of regional and national importance.  The 
proposed I-73 Project is one of those projects.  This is because of the following 
reasons:

Myrtle Beach is the only major tourism destination in the nation that is not 
accessible by a direct national highwy.  It has thus not been able to develop 
appropriately to realize it's true economic potential.  

Further, this proposed road would run through 3 major counties of the State.  
These counties have the highest unemployment (double digits) in the State of 
South Carolina.  This national road would have a dramatic positive impact on the 
economic development of these counties and the current and future employment 
and health and well being of it's current and future residents.

Further the State has seen fit to designate it as a major road of significance to the 
State's economic development and the nation has designated it as a road of 
national significance.  The State has illustrated it's ongoing support of this project 
by provideing funds for it's planning, right of way acquisition and development each 
year for the last several years and is committed to providing what it must to make 
it a reality.

Lastly, this road is crucial to the health and well being of the area since it will also 
provide a method of escape for the hnudreds of thousand of residensts and 
hundreds of thousand of visitors during times of natural threats/disastors such as 
huricanes and thus should be funded not only for economic development purposes 
but for safety and health reasons as well!

For all of the above reasons it is respectfully requested that this project be funded 
ASAP!

Thanks for your consideration of funding this important project.

Title: Alan Clemmons
Comment:
In as much as TIGER grants have been identified by Congress as being made available to 
facilitate significant projects of national significance, I would suggest and encourage that the 
regulations governing TIGER grants give priority status to those infrastructure projects which 
have heretofore been identified by the US Congress as Projects of Regional and National 
Significance.

One such project is Interstate 73, which is the shortest route between the manufacturing states 
of Michigan and Ohio and the warm-water ports of Savannah, GA; Charleston, SC; Georgetown, 
SC; and Wilmington, NC. It traverses the states of SC, NC, VA, WV, MI and OH, commencing 
in the East Coast's resort vacation mecca of Myrtle Beach and terminating at Sault Saint Marie, 
MI. Myrtle Beach is the Nation's only major resort destination, with approximately thirteen million 
visitors annually, without an interstate connection. Over the past significant federal funds have 
been allocated to this project across the corridor states, and in the last highway reauthorization 
bill it was identified by US Congress as a Project of Regional and National Significance, and has 
also been identified as one of the top five projects nationally. 

In South Carolina, the South Carolina General Assembly and the South Carolina Department of 
Transportation have identified as I-73 as the highest priority new road project in the state. This 
was reaffirmed by the South Carolina General Assembly in the last few weeks by concurring 
resolution which was recently forwarded to the attention of Secretary LaHood of the US 
Department of Transportation. The resolution also identifies the first phase of the project as the 
six mile segment between the "Intersection of Hope" at its' intersection with Interstate 95 in 
Dillon County, SC and US Highway 501. The starting point, the Intersection of Hope, is so 
named because of the dire economic situation of this region of South Carolina which has known 
some of the highest unemployment rates of all of South Carolina for years as a result of the 
regions' loss of mainstay industries, ie: tobacco farming and textile manufacturing. Today's 
unemployment rates in three of the four South Carolina counties that this highway traverses 
suffers from unemployment greater than twenty percent. Truly, the I-73 project is seen as a 
symbol of economic hope for those economically disadvantaged counties.

The first phase of construction of I-73 can commence upon completion of the wetlands 
mitigation for the project and final permitting, which SCDOT has opined should take no more 
than twelve months. Acquisition of right-of-way has commenced in the area of the first phase 
and should be complete within this same time frame.

South Carolina has financially committed its' financial resources toward construction of I-73 by 
annual allocation from our state budget and the approval of tolling as a state-match funding 
mechanism.

South Carolina's unemployment currently rank as the nations third worst. The chief economic 
driver of the state is tourism, with Myrtle Beach being the heart of that industry. With no 
interstate access, growth of tourism in Myrtle Beach is hamstrung due to choked highways 
leading to the coast, especially during the busiest tourist seasons. Such gridlock hampers 
tourist ingress and egress, as well as that of the labor pool that commutes hours every day from 
the aforementioned rural areas of the state. Without direct interstate access, Myrtle Beach is a 
disaster waiting to happen during periods of evacuation due to emergencies such as hurricanes. 
There is simply no easy way to move the hundreds of thousands of citizens and visitors over 
the existing road system in a timely manner between the declaration of an evacuation and a 
hurricane strike during peak tourist seasons.

My intent of this comment is two-fold: first, to preface an application by the state of South 
Carolina, and other states in the I-73 corridor, for TIGER grants in hopes that such applications 
will be granted by USDOT at the highest funding levels; and second, to encourage the 
establishment of regulations whereby infrastructure projects already identified by US Congress 
as Projects of Regional and National Significance be given priority access to TIGER grant 
funding.

Thank you for affording me this opportunity to comment.

Representative Alan Clemmons
South Carolina House of Representatives

Title: North Texas Tollway Authority
Comment:
June 1, 2009



Secretary Ray LaHood
Office of the Secretary of Transportation
U.S. Department of Transportation
1200 New Jersey Avenue, SE
Docket Operations, M-30, Room W12-140
Washington, DC 20590

Sent via web-site: www.regulations.gov

RE: 	Docket Number OST-2009-0115
	Grants for Transportation Investment Generating Economic Recovery

Dear Secretary LaHood:

On behalf of North Texas Tollway Authority (“NTTA” or the “Authority”), I express 
the Authority’s support for the Grants for Transportation Investment Generating 
Economic Recovery (“TIGER Discretionary Grants”) program.  After a thorough 
review of the guidelines published in the Federal Register dated May 18, 2009, 
NTTA wishes to provide the Office of the Secretary of Transportation with 
comments.  Specifically, the Authority’s comments relate to the SH 161 Project 
(the “Project”) in the Dallas-Ft. Worth region in North Texas and the Authority’s 
work on the SH 161 Project with the TIFIA program over the last year.

The SH 161 Project, which is being developed as a partnership between NTTA and 
the Texas Department of Transportation (“TxDOT”), is an important regional project 
that will provide significant congestion relief.  The Project is currently shovel-ready 
and will be fully open to traffic in 2012 if financial close can be achieved in 2009.  
The project will provide immediate job creation and economic stimulus to the North 
Texas region and be an impetus to development along the new SH 161 corridor, in 
the heart of the DFW Metroplex.

The SH 161 Project is roughly a $1.5 billion project that requires an approximately 
$460 million TIFIA loan.  To further the Project, the Authority submitted a Letter of 
Interest (“LOI”) to the TIFIA program office on September 12, 2008.  We received 
positive feedback from TIFIA staff, a clear explanation regarding TIFIA’s limited 
resource for 2009 and subsequently, we have been periodically briefed about the 
status of TIFIA and Stimulus funding.  The TIFIA staff is fully familiar with the 
Project as it has gone through various development iterations; initially as a TxDOT 
Comprehensive Development Agreement (“CDA”) project (i.e. public-private 
partnership) and now as a public-public partnership between NTTA and TxDOT.  
NTTA believes this project strongly fulfills both the TIGER and TIFIA objectives.  
As TIFIA’s staff is aware, the proposed financing structure of the Project now 
incorporates support from TxDOT with a Toll Equity Loan that will likely result in a 
strong “AA” category credit rating for both the publicly sold debt and the TIFIA 
loan.  The Project would accordingly represent a very low risk, minimum credit 
charge for the TIFIA program.  NTTA has most recently received an Investment 
Grade Rating Indication letter and is now in a position to submit a fully completed 
TIFIA application.

The Authority’s understanding of the process for the TIGER program is that a new 
LOI would need to be submitted to the TIFIA program office, followed by the 
submission of both a TIFIA application and a separate TIGER application, both of 
which will not be accepted until roughly six weeks prior to the Application Deadline 
of September 15, 2009.  Receiving a TIGER and/or TIFIA allocation shortly after 
September 15 would fit within the Authority’s deadline with TxDOT for final project 
commitment by early 2010 and with our schedule to open the Project by 2012.  
However, the TIGER process, as currently proposed, will create significant 
difficulties for keeping the SH 161 Project on schedule.

Our current plans call for reaching a Project financial close by the end of October 
2009.  To line up the other financing components necessary for the Project to 
close it is imperative that we receive a preliminary indication of funding availability 
prior to the September 15 Application Deadline.  We are asking for a review of the 
proposed process as it seems inconsistent that a program specifically focused on 
shovel-ready projects to be completed by 2012 would require us to slow down and 
back-off an aggressive timetable to finance and complete this vital project.

Separately, the Authority understands the 2010 fiscal year TIFIA funding process 
may open up in the late summer.  While receiving a TIFIA loan through this 
process is also a possibility, delaying the start of the process to late summer will 
similarly hamper NTTA’s ability to achieve financial close in 2009.  The Authority is 
also aware that the TIFIA program office is considering allowing TIFIA applicants to 
pay their own credit charge through a premium payment at financial close – NTTA 
is interested in this option if it will help in gaining greater certainty to meet NTTA’s 
timeframe.  Working with TIFIA on multiple routes – TIGER; TIFIA 2010 fiscal year; 
TIFIA credit charge payment – simultaneously and receiving an indication during 
the summer that NTTA will receive a commitment through one of these options will 
provide the Project with certainty of being fully funded and will greatly aid in 
achieving financial close by our October 2009 target.

NTTA hopes to continue to bolster economic growth and job creation in the North 
Texas region with the development of the SH 161 Project.  Your support is critical 
in helping NTTA achieve this goal.  

Sincerely,



Janice Davis
Chief Financial Officer, North Texas Tollway Authority

Title: Thomas Raub
Comment:
Dear Secretary LaHood,

As the president of a regional employee training and development firm 
headquartered in Myrtle Beach, SC I must stress the importance of Interstate 73 
to the economic progress of this region.  Much attention has been given by the 
Obama Administration to workforce development initiatives as we work diligently 
to extricate ourselves from the current economic malaise.  I can think of no project 
with greater economic development and job-creating potential to this region than 
Interstate 73.  With our region facing double digit unemployment, the construction 
of Interstate 73 in South Carolina would not only create jobs during the 
construction phases, but serve as a long-term economic development tool for this 
region for many years to come.  Speaking from a personal perspective, the greater 
the level of economic activity in this region, the more opportunities I will personally 
have to hire new employees.  I am confident the construction of Interstate 73 in 
South Carolina will provide the economic impetus for my company to expand.

Mr. Secretary, as an entrepreneur and small business owner I am respectfully 
asking you to help me and my region create new jobs.  I respectfully ask and 
submit my comments in hopes that you will agree that the South Carolina portion 
of I-73 should qualify for the TIGER Discretionary Grants program.

Sincerely,

Tom Raub
President and Founder
The Raub Group, LLC

Title: Brookings Institution
Submitter Representative: Robert Puentes, Senior Fellow and Director,
Comment:
To: 	Office of the Secretary of Transportation
	OST-2009-0115 

TIGER Discretionary Grants Program Manager
U.S. Department of Transportation
1200 New Jersey Ave., SE
Docket Operations, M-30
Room W12-140
Washington, DC 20590

Via U.S. Government electronic docket site: www.regulations.gov

On behalf of the Brookings Institution's Metropolitan Policy Program I am pleased 
to respond to the request for comments on the Interim Notice of Funding 
Availability for Supplemental Discretionary Grants for Capital Investments in 
Surface Transportation Infrastructure Under the American Recovery and 
Reinvestment Act.

The Brookings Metro Program is based on a simple premise: The United States is 
a metropolitan nation. Metropolitan areas are home to 83 percent of the U.S. 
population, 85 percent of the nation’s jobs and 92 percent of all college graduates. 
They are our hubs of research and innovation, our centers of human capital, and 
our gateways of trade and immigration. They are, in short, the drivers of our 
economy, and American competitiveness depends on their vitality.

The TIGER grants, with their explicit invocation of metropolitan areas in the interim 
notice, have tremendous potential to put the nation on a new path for 
transportation thinking and decision making.  We appreciate and recognize the 
significant effort and importance of the TIGER grants. To improve the value of the 
initiative we respectfully offer several recommendations.

1.  Provide more clarity and direction about the types of projects eligible for funding.

There needs to be much more clarity and a narrower definition about the types of 
projects eligible for TIGER grant funding. We applaud the program's purpose—as 
defined in the Recovery Act—to fund "projects that will have a significant impact 
on the nation, a metropolitan area, or region." For too long the federal program has 
not truly focused or lead in those areas where there are clear demands for national 
uniformity or else to match the scale and geographic reach of certain problems.

However, there appear to be little no limits on the types of projects that are eligible 
for TIGER grants. Opening the program up to all title 23 projects, for example, is 
potentially inconsistent with the desire for nationally/metro/regionally significant 
projects.
 
Restricting the grants to no less than $20 million may help avoid hyperlocal 
investments. Nevertheless, the broad eligibility criteria and potential waiver of the 
minimum level of grant funding could result in applications that include a range of 
projects that do not meet the department's perception of 'significant.' There should 
be a tighter connection between the evaluation criteria and the explicit goal for 
nationally/metro/regionally significant projects, and there should be more clarity 
about the conditions under which a waiver would be granted. Without which, the 
waiver provisions should be struck altogether.

2.  Reconsider a rigid requirement for benefit/cost analyses.

We associate ourselves with the comments submitted by Smart Growth America 
to ensure appropriate use of, and role for, benefit/cost analysis. At the Metro 
Program we have called strongly for comprehensive analyses of this sort.  It is 
astounding that formal benefit/cost considerations are not used and regular 
evaluations of outcomes are typically not conducted with respect to current 
transportation funding.

As an unfortunate byproduct, we are now unequipped to conduct such analysis in 
a routinized way. Credible data largely does not exist on the conditions, 
operations, and performance of our transportation network. And the tools that are 
employed today for tracking federal transportation spending and performance data 
are archaic and out of step with today’s needs.

Without solid data and information transportation decisionmaking is often made 
based on ideology. We are therefore concerned that the analyses—while well-
intended—may focus on traditional measures like travel time savings, number of 
passengers, or standard cost effectiveness. We strongly believe that outcome 
measures should go beyond these traditional metrics and consider the full range of 
impacts including the benefits of agglomeration and economic development, as 
well as the social and environmental costs of emissions like carbon. Without 
factoring the full scope of impacts, the economic benefits are likely to be 
overstated. A comprehensive British economic study found remarkable returns for 
certain projects when these impacts are considered. 

The automatic waiver for < $20 million projects should be struck. If these projects 
are to be included they should be held to the same standards as larger projects.

3. More forcefully make the connection between transportation and other policy 
areas.

The TIGER grants are an excellent opportunity for the department to assist states 
and metropolitan areas in one of their hardest tasks: transcending the stovepiping 
of disparate transportation, housing, energy, and environmental programs that 
remains a serious cause of undesirable transportation-related outcomes. The 
integrated and interdependent nature of the new challenges and issues contrast 
sharply with the nature of the institutions that exist today. These institutions tend 
to be independent, fragmented, and working to relatively narrow mandates with 
closed decision processes.

While the interim notice does recognize the connection between transportation 
and greenhouse gas emissions the integration goals should be more cross-
cutting. In this regard, the "Disciplinary Integration" subheading under the 
Partnership criteria should include policy areas such as housing (beyond public 
housing) energy independence, labor markets, competition, and land use, for 
example. The U.S. DOT should be open to microeconomic drivers that are more 
qualitative than quantitative. The brief mention of the effects of transportation on 
household spending in the Long Term Outcomes section should also be reinforced 
here.

4.  Require partnerships that cross jurisdictional borders.

Surface transportation is so evidently and inherently metropolitan that it is a 
natural start for cross-border collaboration. Simply put, truly achieving projects of 
national/metro/regional significance is impossible without demonstrated 
collaboration both vertically among governmental levels (e.g., state, metro, local) 
and horizontally among neighboring jurisdictions. Therefore, the partnerships 
section should require applicants to engage in partnerships that cross 
jurisdictional borders.

There is also considerable interest in private sector companies and investors to 
engage in partnerships with the public sector to deliver transportation projects. 
Such partnerships should be recognized and encouraged.

5. Outline a process for program evaluation.

The U.S. DOT is taking a bold and important step with the TIGER grants. In 
addition to tracking the success of the TIGER projects, the program itself should 
be evaluated. The program should outline how U.S. DOT will establish its own 
performance measures for program evaluation. Applicants should consider what 
steps they will take including the collection of baseline and post-implementation 
data. A national evaluation team is needed to be responsible for the evaluation 
design and analysis and reporting of findings.  They should work closely with each 
applicant in the collection of the evaluation data.

 - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - -

Thank you for your good work and for the opportunity to provide these comments 
on this excellent program. Please do not hesitate to contact me if you have any 
questions or comments. 

Respectfully submitted,
Robert Puentes
Senior Fellow and Director, Metropolitan Infrastructure Initiative

Title: Brant Branham
Comment:
Interstate 73, established as High Priority Corridor #5 in ISTEA, remains an 
uncompleted national priority.  The South Carolina portion of this corridor was 
named a project of national and regional significance in SAFETEA-LU for good 
reason:  the project will reside in 3 counties in northeastern South Carolina where 
average unemployment is more than twice the national average.  This interstate 
will also extend the national interstate system to Myrtle Beach, SC, the nation’s 
busiest vacation destination without interstate access.  

A significant portion of this road has already been built using local tax 
collections.  The State of South Carolina has made a recurring investment to I-73 
every year for the past five years.  The South Carolina General Assembly has also 
approved legislation authorizing tolls to be collected upon its portion of I-73.  A 
TIGER grant will allow the project to make considerable progress on the ground, 
creating jobs that are badly needed.  Key benefits of I-73 include job creation, 
both from construction of the road and surrounding economic development, in 
nearby areas that are economically distressed, Improved safety, especially for 
hurricane evacuations from the South Carolina coast, economic growth of the 
nation’s busiest vacation destination without interstate access.  

With so much state and local funding already invested in this project, the USDOT 
should give serious consideration to funding Interstate 73 in South Carolina 
through a TIGER grant.

Title: Pauline Levesque
Comment:
The TIGER grant program will fund important infrastructure projects that deliver 
significant economic benefits to projects of national and regional significance.   
Interstate 73, established as High Priority Corridor #5 in ISTEA, remains an 
uncompleted national priority.  The South Carolina portion of this corridor was 
named a project of national and regional significance in SAFETEA-LU for good 
reason:  the project will reside in 3 counties in northeastern South Carolina where 
average unemployment is more than twice the national average and where one 
community's educational system is known as the "Corridor of Shame".  This 
interstate will also extend the national interstate system to Myrtle Beach, SC, the 
nation’s busiest vacation destination without interstate access.  

A significant portion of this road has already been built using local tax 
collections.  The State of South Carolina has made a recurring investment to I-73 
every year for the past five years.  The South Carolina General Assembly has also 
approved legislation authorizing tolls to be collected upon its portion of I-73.  A 
TIGER grant will allow the project to make considerable progress on the ground, 
creating jobs that are badly needed.  Key benefits of I-73 include:
 

Job creation, both from construction of the road and surrounding economic 
development, in nearby areas that are economically distressed; 
Improved safety, especially for hurricane evacuations from the South Carolina 
coast; 
Economic growth of the nation’s busiest vacation destination without interstate 
access.  

With so much state and local funding already invested in this project, the USDOT 
should give serious consideration to funding Interstate 73 in South Carolina 
through a TIGER grant.

Title: HTC, Inc.
Comment:
It is the understanding that the TIGER grant program will fund infrastructure 
projects that deliver significant positive economic impacts.  Interstate 73 is such a 
project and already recognized as such as High Priority Corridor #5 in ISTEA.  
The project, involving three counties in northeastern South Carolina, will provide for 
the first time, an interstate system directly servicing one of the most popular 
tourist destinations in the country.  More importantly, it will provide a critical 
evacuation need.  If a major hurricane was to hit Myrtle Beach, SC, the amount of 
time needed to evacuate the area because of the lack of an interstate artery to 
move people out could potentially put in danger a signficant numbers of lives.  

The State of South Carolina has tried to proactively address the need for an 
interstate leg in this area for the past five years.  Local tax collections have been 
used to build a portion already.  A TIGER grant will progress the project and the 
timing couldn't be better in that our area has an unemployment average that far 
exceeds the national average. 

Job creation, improved safety and advancement of a catalyst for economic growth 
are all justifications of why I-73 in South Carolina should be awared a TIGER 
grant.

Title: Kevin Blayton
Comment:
Criteria should include, at a minimum, projects that have environmental
clearance through the issuance of a "Record of Decision" resulting from the
appropriate environmental impact study or environmental assessment. This will
ensure timely expenditure of funds and construction of the projects.

Comment: see attached.

The TIGER grant program will fund important infrastructure projects that deliver 
significant economic benefits to projects of national and regional significance.   
Interstate 73, established as High Priority Corridor #5 in ISTEA, remains an 
uncompleted national priority.  The South Carolina portion of this corridor was 
named a project of national and regional significance in SAFETEA-LU for good 
reason:  the project will reside in 3 counties in northeastern South Carolina where 
average unemployment is more than twice the national average.  This interstate 
will also extend the national interstate system to Myrtle Beach, SC, the nation’s 
busiest vacation destination without interstate access.  

A significant portion of this road has already been built using local tax 
collections.  The State of South Carolina has made a recurring investment to I-73 
every year for the past five years.  The South Carolina General Assembly has also 
approved legislation authorizing tolls to be collected upon its portion of I-73.  A 
TIGER grant will allow the project to make considerable progress on the ground, 
creating jobs that are badly needed.  Key benefits of I-73 include:
 
	Job creation, both from construction of the road and surrounding 
economic development, in nearby areas that are economically distressed;
	Improved safety, especially for hurricane evacuations from the South 
Carolina coast;
	Economic growth of the nation’s busiest vacation destination without 
interstate access.  

With so much state and local funding already invested in this project, the USDOT 
should give serious consideration to funding Interstate 73 in South Carolina 
through a TIGER grant.

regarding distribution of funds, primary and secondary selection criteria, and

Title: S. Kline
Comment:
I'm writing to give my support to the TIGER grant. The State of South Carolina as 
well as local taxing authorities have funded this project for the past 5 years due to 
the importance of Interstate 73. In these poor economic times, the project would 
give a boom to the SC economy by creating much needed jobs in the surrounding 
areas. It would allow Myrtle Beach to have a connection to I-95 allowing visitors 
interstate access to this very popular vacation destination. It would also provide a 
needed escape route for Hurricane evacuations from the South Carolina coast.

A good portion of the road has already been completed using local tax collections. 
I urge you to give serious consideration to funding Interstate 73 in South Carolina 
through a TIGER grant.

Title: The North Eastern Strategic Alliance (NESA)
Comment:
Secretary LaHood:

On behalf of The North Eastern Strategic Alliance (NESA), a nine county regional 
economic development organization based in Florence, South Carolina, I would 
like to express my support for the construction of the I-73 Interchange of Hope 
using funds from the TIGER Discretionary Grants program.  From past economic 
impact studies and other research, we are confident that this project will make a 
tremendous economic impact on the region that we represent.  We believe that 
this project fully meets all four of the key objectives stated in the overall plan for 
national economic recovery.

1.	Long Term Outcomes – I-73 will provide a new thoroughfare from Myrtle 
Beach, South Carolina to Sault Ste. Marie, Michigan, connecting six states with 
more than 900 miles of roadway.  I-73 is currently designated as Congressional 
High Priority #5 and is the top priority for the South Carolina Department of 
Transportation.  I-73 will serve not only as a new corridor for increased passenger 
and freight commerce between Myrtle Beach and all of the states involved but also 
as a hurricane evacuation route. I-73 will intersect with I-95 and connect several 
metro areas.   
2.	Job Creation and Economic Stimulus – A Coastal Carolina University 
economic impact study shows that the construction of I-73 will create nearly 
5,000 construction jobs and $170.8 million in new household income annually 
during the construction period.  The annual construction impact on the regional 
economy is estimated at $818.9 million and an impact of $277.8 million on 
household income.  3,040 additional jobs will be created as a “ripple effect” and 
will boost employment, lower unemployment, reduce the strain on the state’s 
unemployment insurance fund, and generate additional tax revenue for state and 
local governments.  
3.	Innovation – 74% of the 14 million visitors to the Myrtle Beach area 
travel there via I-95 but there is no direct connection between I-95 and the coast of 
South Carolina (roughly 75 miles). The southernmost section of I-73 is partially 
completed and will connect I-95 to the coast.  During peak tourist season, I-73 will 
alleviate strain on local roads, increase the ease of travel to the coast, and 
significantly reduce travel time.  By reducing travel time to the coast, I-73 could 
increase visitation by 575,000 visitors annually, creating an annual economic 
impact of $1.15 billion. 
4.	Partnership – The I-73 project represents a multi-state partnership via 
the I-73 Association.  For more information on the I-73 Association, please visit 
http://www.i73.com/default.html.
Given the broad positive ramifications of this project, I sincerely believe that this 
project is conducive to the overall purpose of the recovery act.  I appreciate your 
consideration of this project.

Respectfully Submitted,

Jeff McKay
NESA Executive Director

Title: Yurok Tribe
Comment:
YUROK TRIBE
190 Klamath Boulevard ● Post Office Box 1027 ● Klamath, CA 95548






June 1, 2009



Mr. Ray LaHood, Secretary of Transportation
Office of the Secretary of Transportation
Department of Transportation
1200 New Jersey Avenue, S.E.
Washington, DC  20590



RE: 	Comments of the Yurok Tribe on the interim notice of funding 
availability for supplemental discretionary grants for capital investments in surface 
transportation infrastructure under the American Recovery and Reinvestment Act 
and Request for comments on grant criteria – Docket No. OST-2009-0115


	The Yurok Tribe (Tribe) is pleased to offer these comments in response 
to the Department of Transportation’s (Department) Interim Notice of Funding 
Availability for Supplemental Discretionary Grants for Capital Investments in 
Surface Transportation Infrastructure Under the American Recovery and 
Reinvestment Act and Request for Comments on Grant Criteria, published in the 
Federal Register on May 18, 2009.   The discretionary grant program, referred to 
as “Grants for Transportation Investment Generating Economic Recovery” 
or “TIGER Grants,” represents a unique opportunity to address the critical 
economic development and transportation needs of tribal applicants.  

	With a tribal population on and off the Reservation of 5,500, the Yurok 
Tribe is the largest tribe in California, and resides primarily on a reservation 
spanning over 64,000 acres along a 35-mile reach of the Klamath River.  Much of 
our transportation infrastructure is either incomplete or in dire need of repairs as a 
result of the extreme isolated geographic region of our ancestral territory.  The 
absence of safe and direct transportation routes between reservation communities 
and to nearby employment centers has hampered the economic development 
necessary to lift the Tribe out if its nearly 80 percent unemployment rate.  In order 
to help the Department meet the statutory objective of promoting long-term 
economic growth under the American Recovery and Reinvestment Act (ARRA), 
the Yurok Tribe submits the following comments and recommendations to ensure 
that tribal governments are able to benefit from this important program.

	The Tribe strongly supports the explicit inclusion of “tribal governments” 
within the TIGER’s class of Eligible Applicants.    The program’s complementary 
purposes to facilitate long- and short-term economic growth through infrastructure 
development are well matched to the general needs of Indian Country and the 
Yurok Reservation in particular.  By including Tribes within the definition of Eligible 
Applicants, the Department meets its statutory obligations and provides tribal 
governments the chance to address severe transportation and economic 
development needs that are otherwise likely to go unmet.   

	In addition to treatment as Eligible Applicants, the guidance for TIGER 
grants should be adjusted to clarify a number of other points.  First, the guidance 
should make clear that, in appropriate circumstances, grants can be awarded 
directly to tribal applicants – not passed through state agencies for distribution to 
tribal applicants.  Second, the guidance should establish that funds awarded to 
Tribes will not be counted towards ARRA’s 20 percent limit on the total funds 
awarded to projects in a single State.  The rationale for each of these requests 
appears below.  

	First, while the Yurok Tribe is independently eligible for many 
Department programs, we do not generally receive federal transportation dollars 
until they pass through the California Department of Transportation’s funding 
allocation formula.  The Department’s treatment of Tribes as Eligible Applicants, 
as proposed above, would strongly suggest that TIGER Grants will be awarded 
directly to successful tribal applicants.  Because this approach deviates from the 
Department’s standard practice, however, we feel that additional clarification 
regarding the direct distribution is merited.  Much of TIGER’s potential arises from 
its discretionary nature and ready availability to applicants.  The Yurok 
Reservation’s need for transportation infrastructure has been underserved because 
the bulk of federal roads funding is both non-discretionary and must compete with 
other priorities for funding by a state agency.  This approach makes the Yurok and 
other similarly situated Tribes subject to rigid formulaic factors which often fail to 
capture the severity of tribal needs.  Because the TIGER Grant program is not 
linked to a formula and the Secretary may make awards directly to project 
applicants, the program presents a significant opportunity to assist traditionally 
underserved communities and to provide exactly the kind of long-term economic 
recovery ARRA is designed to engender.  

	Second, we respectfully submit that any grant to a tribal government 
within a particular state should not be counted against the 20 percent cap on total 
TIGER funds available to recipients within that State.  Under TIGER’s total $1.5 
billion allocation, the 20 percent cap implies a maximum State allocation of $300 
million.  Placing State and tribal applications within the same narrowed funding 
pool will make it more difficult for the Secretary to pursue ARRA’s directives and 
to fund all projects that best meet the proposed grant criteria.  If grants to tribal 
governments are counted within the State cap, the viability of any tribal application 
will be closely tied to its ability to convince the surrounding State to reduce its 
other TIGER requests.  In addition, the unique sovereign status of tribes, who are 
responsible for countless miles of road across the nation and some of whose 
reservations encompass areas larger than some states, suggest the need of tribal 
eligibility as separate from or parallel to States.  

	Finally, and as a supplement to the more general comments above, we 
submit the following specific recommendations to ensure that the final grant 
criteria fully reflect the status of tribal governments as Eligible Applicants.  

	Both primary selection criteria, Long-Term Outcomes and Jobs 
Creation and Economic Stimulus, include a number of sub-criteria that generally 
reward projects that can demonstrate advanced planning and have already 
received or show a high probability of receiving approvals required in addition to the 
TIGER discretionary grant application.  However, none of these sub-criteria 
explicitly acknowledge the active and important role that tribal governments can 
play in the project planning and approval process.  The criteria therefore should 
include the following amendments:

	The Long-Term Outcomes sub-criterion of “State of Good Repair” 
should be amended to include tribal efforts. As proposed, the criterion only reward 
projects that are “part of, or consistent with, relevant state, local or regional efforts 
to maintain transportation facilities or systems in a state of good repair.”   We 
recommend that the above enumeration of planning entities should be expanded 
to include tribal governments.  

	The Job Creation & Economic Stimulus sub-criteria favoring projects 
ready to start quickly require a number of amendments to properly reward projects 
supported by advance tribal planning procedures.  Section II(B)(1)(b)(i)-(iv), 
pursuant to ARRA’s statutory preference for quick-start projects, lists a number of 
sub-criteria within the Jobs Creation criteria designed to help the Department 
assess how quickly a TIGER Grant recipient can proceed with the project 
proposal.  We submit the following changes for your review:

1.	Sub-criterion (ii), Environmental Approvals, militates in favor of projects 
that can demonstrate “[r]eceipt (or reasonably anticipated receipt) of all 
environmental approvals necessary for the project to proceed…including 
satisfaction of all Federal, State, and local requirements.” 74 Fed. Reg. 23231 (II
(B)(1)(b)(ii)).  The list of Federal, State, and local entities should be expanded to 
include Tribes to account for the responsibilities many tribal governments have 
undertaken to manage their environmental resources.
2.	Sub-criterion (iii), Legislative Approvals, favors projects that can 
demonstrate “evidence of support from State and local officials, including relevant 
governor(s) and/or mayors.”  Id (II(B)(1)(b)(iii)).  Projects submitted for approval by 
tribal governments are typically subjected to a tribal approval process. Expanding 
this sub-criterion to be more Tribe inclusive would better ensure that project 
proposals enjoy tribal support and reward tribal applicants who participate in more 
detailed planning and approval process.
3.	Sub-criterion (iv), State and Local Planning, rewards projects that are 
included “in the relevant State, metropolitan, and local planning documents.”  Id (II
(B)(1)(b)(iv)).  The sub-criteria should be expanded to include Tribal planning 
documents.

	We believe the TIGER discretionary grant program provides a unique 
and important opportunity to stimulate long-term economic development in tribal 
areas long underserved by the conventional formulaic approach.  The Yurok tribe 
has been struggling for many years to undertake a substantial and absolutely 
necessary roads repair projects.  Without supplemental funds to do so, our 
access to employment opportunities on and off the reservation will continue to be 
highly constrained.  TIGER, if administered in a way that preserves the program’s 
discretionary nature and consistently recognizes the unique challenges and 
characteristics of tribes, could bring enormous benefit to the Yurok and throughout 
Indian Country.  

Respectfully,

Javier I. Kinney
Transportation Manager					
	
Yurok Tribe

Title: The Metropolitan Washington Airports Authority
Comment:
Dear Sir or Madam:

The Metropolitan Washington Airports Authority would like to comment on Docket 
No. OST-2009-0115, TIGER Discretionary Grants.

1.  Section III.B describes the conditions under which a component of a project 
could be considered.   The Airports Authority recommends tht an engineering and 
design project be an eligible component of a project if it can be demonstrated that 
advancing the engineering and design would create positive economic impacts 
and jobs by advancing the project’s construction. 

2.  The Airports Authority also recommends that the Department consider the 
benefits of the advanced construction of the full project, not just the engineering 
and design phase.

3.  The Airports Authority recommends that transit projects being developed 
without the use of Section 5309 funds (New Starts and Small Starts), still be 
considered an eligible transit project.  

4.  The Metropolitan Washington Airports Authority is a public body created by an 
interstate compact between the District of Columbia and the Commonwealth of 
Virginia.  It wishes to apply for funds even though its project is not in the approved 
State Transportation Improvement Program (STIP) and is not being funded with 
state funds.  Note that the Airports Authority’s Chief Executive Officer, rather than 
the Governor of Virginia, signed the Airports Authority’s Section 1511 certification 
for an application for funds from the American Recovery and Reinvestment Act of 
2009 Public Transportation Capital Investment Grants Program Appropriation and 
Allocations. 

5.  The Airports Authority concurs in the comments of Jennifer Strehler of Avon, 
Colorado, and Sherry Bohnert Earley of Hampton Roads, Virginia, with regard to 
the requirement that the project be in the State Transportation Improvement Plan.

Thank you for the opportunity to comment and for your consideration.

Sincerely yours,
Philip G. Sunderland
General Counsel

Title: Jane Morris
Comment:
1. Priority for projects completed by February 17, 2012 (74 FR 23231) 

As required by the Recovery Act, “priority” will be given to projects that are
expected to be completed by February 17, 2012. Please describe the scoring
impact resulting from a project with spending after February 17, 2012 compared
to projects that will be “complete” by February 17, 2012.

Please confirm that “substantial completion” occurs when a contractor turns over
the project funded with TIGER Discretionary Grants to the owner.  In other
words, it means that TIGER grant funds for the project elements have been
obligated and expended and that construction of the project element is
substantially complete even if further installation and testing of systems
follows.  

2. Cognizant Modal Administration (74 FR 23234) 

As the Secretary exercises his discretion to delegate grant administration
responsibilities (i.e., Cognizant Modal Administration) to the modal
administration, we support consideration of the FAA as Cognizant Modal
Administration for projects involving a surface transportation system connector
to airport facilities.

Please contact Jane Morris at (602) 273-4036 if additional information would be
helpful.

Title: City of San Antonio’s City Council
Organization Name: City of San Antonio’s City Council
Comment:
DEPARTMENT OF TRANSPORTATION
Office of the Secretary of Transportation
[Docket No. OST-2009-0115]

Transportation Investment Generating Economic Recovery (TIGER)

On March 05, 2009, the City of San Antonio’s City Council adopted the Funding 
Strategy Plan for economic stimulus projects.  The Funding Strategy Plan serves 
as a guide for stimulus funding grant submissions. The City’s goal is to move 
forward with due diligence in and effective and efficient manner in the 
implementation of stimulus funding projects.  The City respectfully offers the 
following comments:


1.	The Notice of Funding Availability (NoFA) states that priority will be 
given to projects that are completed on or before February 17, 2012.  In addition, 
the NoFA states that the Department of Transportation may announce selected 
projects to receive grant funds no later than February 17, 2010.  A two year 
completion timeline for large projects requiring approximately (12-18) months of 
project design plus (18-24) months to receive environmental clearances will 
present completion challenges, such as accelerated construction schedules.  We 
recommend this requirement be reconsidered and that project timelines be 
evaluated on an individual basis to meet the completion needs of larger 
construction projects

2.	The City supports the secondary selection criteria of “partnerships.”  
The City plans to explore and incorporate collaborative partnerships with relevant 
regional entities such as VIA Metropolitan Transit.


Thank you for the opportunity to comment.

Title: Pam Wright
Comment:
The TIGER grant program will fund important infrastructure projects that deliver 
significant economic benefits to projects of national and regional significance.   
Interstate 73, established as High Priority Corridor #5 in ISTEA, remains an 
uncompleted national priority.  The South Carolina portion of this corridor was 
named a project of national and regional significance in SAFETEA-LU for good 
reason:  the project will reside in 3 counties in northeastern South Carolina where 
average unemployment is more than twice the national average.  This interstate 
will also extend the national interstate system to Myrtle Beach, SC, the nation’s 
busiest vacation destination without interstate access.  

A significant portion of this road has already been built using local tax collections.  
The State of South Carolina has made a recurring investment to I-73 every year for 
the past five years.  The South Carolina General Assembly has also approved 
legislation authorizing tolls to be collected upon its portion of I-73.  A TIGER grant 
will allow the project to make considerable progress on the ground, creating jobs 
that are badly needed.  Key benefits of I-73 include:
 

Job creation, both from construction of the road and surrounding economic 
development, in nearby areas that are economically distressed; 
Improved safety, especially for hurricane evacuations from the South Carolina 
coast; 
Economic growth of the nation’s busiest vacation destination without interstate 
access.  

With so much state and local funding already invested in this project, the USDOT 
should give serious consideration to funding Interstate 73 in South Carolina 
through a TIGER grant.

Title: Lejin Huang
Comment:
I have reviewed the proposed rules under this program designed to provide a 
solution during our economic problems. Unfortunately, I do not believe that the 
proposed process and regulations proposed by the Department of Transportation 
reflect the best short-term interests of the public, nor do they convey the intentions 
of the Congress. A simple reading of the Recovery Act and the proposed rules DO 
NOT match! Moreover, DOT has tried to inject some of its old and, unfortunately, 
ineffective ideas into a new program designed by the Congress. DOT, it seems, is 
working for some other government or entity, but completely for the US Congress!

There are a few things that DOT should do to fix this problem. First, do not try to 
inject its old long term objectives into a short-term program. By the time any of 
these funds are committed, the economy will well on its way to recovery on the 
bodies of those who have already sacrificed enough! These funds need to be 
available immediately. This is the new standard that the Congress has set in the 
context of the Recovery Act. Indeed, this specific program is discretionary. Thus, it 
does not need the enormity of the DOT juggernaut to get the ball rolling. To much 
has been injected in a very simple concept. Indeed, it looks as though DOT has 
intentionally subverted the will of the Congress. Do we still have a constitution or 
what?

As an Asian American, I am concerned about how minorities and minority 
business will benefit. The vague outline of DOT's already bankrupt DBE program is 
simply embarrassing! The program does not work; and, DOT should improve these 
sections so that minority business will benefit. It is really not a matter for 
discussion. These ineffective provisions will permit big contractors to "eat" minority, 
small, veteran-owned, and women owned businesses as they have in the past 
under the watchful eye of DOT and State governments. It is, after all, small 
business that is the major employer in the USA.

One interesting proposal from another commentator is the idea of partnership. 
Private sector partnerships should be strongly encouraged. This is a way to build in 
sustained jobs using these short-term jobs. After a utility or infrastructure element 
is complete, the jobs go away or are radically reduced! Partnerships can extend 
this employment opportunity and the effectiveness of the government's contribution. 
It is an important new proposal that should be actively explored and expanded.

In general, this proposal is in no one's best interest. The rules should be withdrawn 
and revised -- as Congress and the President expected.

Title: Elaine Michaud
Comment:
In the 22 years that since I moved to Myrtle Beach (and the 20 years before that 
when I visited) I can't remember a time that we have not been working to get a 
main Interstate completed into the beach. After the first Hurricane I encountered 
here, and trying to get out of the beach,  I realized how important an interstate 
was to our area for not only the locals safety but all those tourists that visit us to 
be able to exit the beach safely and in a timely manner.    It is also next to 
impossible for growth to this busy vacation destination without interstate access.   
I feel that jobs will be created both from the construction of the road and the 
surrounding economic development in areas around us that are economically 
distressed. The other point that I want to stress is that Myrtle Beach relies soley 
on Tourism and we cannot attract any manufacturing or other types of industry as 
we are very hard to reach without an interstate.

Interstate 73, established as High Priority Corridor #5 in ISTEA, is I believe a 
national priority.  With so much time, effort and money already invested and  so 
much of this road already having been built using local tax collections, and the 
states recurring investment to 1-73 for the past five years the TIGER grant 
program will fund important infrastructure projects that deliver significant economic 
benefits to projects of national and regional significance and will allow the project 
to make considerable progress on the ground.   

The South Carolina General Assembly has also approved legislation authorizing 
tolls to be collected upon its portion of I-73.  

Its my personal opinion that the USDOT should give serious consideration to 
funding this project in South Carolina through a TIGER Grant. 


Sincerely
Elaine Michaud

Title: Community Comments Barkley Regional Airport Authority
Rugby Aviation, LLC d/b/a Northwest Sky Ferry
Comment: Response of Rugby Aviation, LLC d/b/a Northwest Sky Ferry to e-mail from U.S. DOT dated November 30, 2009.

Title: Edward Perkins
Comment:
I support complainant's position. Allegiant's imposing an additional fee for online booking is an obvious attempt at an end run on DOT policy. For an airline, online booking through the airline's own website is recognized as the lowest-cost transaction. Requiring travelers to visit an airport ticket counter -- that might be open and busy only a few hours a week -- as the only way to avoid a hefty "convenience" fee is clearly a de-facto fare increase and a blatant flouting of DOT's principles for honest pricing. In fairness to Allegiant customers, DOT should take immediate and strong enforcement action to require honest fare presentation.

Ed Perkins
Consumer Advocate
Founding Editor, Consumer Reports Travel Letter
Syndicated columnist

Title: Donald L. Pevsner
Comment:
TYPO CORRECTION:

At Page 1, Paragraph (1) of the Complaint, at Line 5 of a quote of Respondent Allegiant Air, LLC's "boilerplate" website
language concerning its so-called "convenience fee", STRIKE the words "may be" so that the CORRECTED TEXT READS:

    "Purchases made at any Allegiant Air Airport Ticket Office
     will not incur a convenience or call center fee."

The identical langauge is already present in APPENDIX A,
which is a copy of Respondent Allegiant Air, LLC's website text on point.

Title: Edward Perkins
Comment:
Additional comment in rebuttal to Allegiant's response.

Petitioner Pevsner contends that most consumers are, in fact, unable to avoid Allegiant's poorly-disclosed "convenience fee," which amount Allegiant should therefore be irequired to nduce in its featured base prices. Rather than rebut petitioner's claim, Allegiant's response actually substantiates it. In its earlier filing (DOT-OST-2008-0031), Allegiant alleged that the fee should not be considered mandatory because 1500 people per week avoided it. What Allegiant failed to mention is that those 1500 people represent about 2% of Allegiant's total traffic -- a fighre that, in fact, substantiates petitioner's allegation that the fee is unavoidable to the great bulk of Allegiant's passengers.

To avoid the $16 fee, passengers must drive to the nearest airport (which could be many miles away), park (probably in a high-charge short-term lot), and stand in line with with boarding passengers for a considerable time to buy a ticket. 
In effect, Allegiant has deliberately created a financial and time barrier to avoidance of the fee that only a very small number of passengers would be willing or able to overcome. Allegiant's policy is an obvious ploy to charge almost all of its travelers $16 more (each way) than the base fare, as presented. This is a clear violation of DOT policy on airfare displays and shold be prohibited immediately.

Title: Carl S. Beckman
Comment: The proposed application of Hellenic Imperial for a foreign air carrier permit seems, as far as I can tell, to be an issue that should be approved.  After reading through the proposal, it is my opinion that as long as the Hellenic Imperial Airways acts in the way that has been decided between the EU and the United States air transport agreement as well as acting in the way that meets the safety requirements of the FAA as well as the EU's requirements, then in no way should this airline be barred from flight.  As to my knowledge after reading the proposal, there are only added benefits for the public as well as the industry.  In our economic system, we need competition and this will be just another carrier to compete with.

Title: Economic Development Corp. of Chippewa County
Organization Name: Economic Development Corp. of Chippewa County
Comment:
Formal Ojection to consideration of the Prospectus submitted by Intrepid International Airlines, as a bona fide, proposal in response to USDOT Order #2009-10-8.

Intrepid Int'l Airlines has NO authority to operate interstate air service and NO agreement with airlines to provide air service in its stead.

Intrepid Int'l Airlines Prospectus FAILED the EAS statutory guarantee of 2 round trips per day; and FAILED the EAS statutory guarantee of limit of 1 interim stop.

An appropriate course of action would be USDOT's rejection of Intrepid's clearly deficient submission as "non responsive" immediately upon receipt and initial review.

Instead, as a consequence of USDOT's treatment of the Intrepid International Airlines Prospectus as a valid RFP response - our community, its various Boards and Agencies, as well as USDOT itself, have wasted precious time and money in this matter.

Title: Cathy Edgerly
Comment: Hello, I just wanted to let you know how important Mesaba air service at CIU is to my business and personal travel needs.  I travel by air around eight times per year.  As you know, living in an isolated rural area makes travel scheduling a little more complicated.  Two flights in and out of the CIU ariport a day are barely enough to adequately allow for weather delays which are very common during our long winter months. It is essential to have a minimum of two flights.  Please do not consider any bids that only have one flight per day.  I am also concerned about losing code share, ticket, baggage, and mileage agreements with major carriers. I hope you will consider the needs of you frequent flyers and your less frequent ones.

Title: Richard Todd Haverkate
Comment: I am writing to let you know how much I rely on the airline service that Mesaba Airlines provides to Sault Ste. Marie, Michigan at the Chippewa County International Airport. For the past 12 years I have been a very frequent flyer from CIU. In the past 5 years I have flown a minimum of 50,000 miles each year and in 2009 I flew 125,000 miles.  The vast majority of these domestic and international flights began and ended at CIU.  The convenience of flying from CIU directly to Detroit Metro (DTW) is beyond description.  If Mesaba is not award this contract, I will forced to make a flight to Midway via APN and LAN, with no code-share, no baggage agreement, and no international access.  This would be an incredible hardship.  By keeping Mesaba (Delta) in our home airport (CIU) you would be allowing a large amount of people to have access to the world via DTW.  I can't image using CIU if I have to fly to Midway with absolutely no benefits.  I will certainly use PLN. Please keep Delta and their partner Mesaba at CIU.

Title: Office of the Governor of Guam
Organization Name: Office of the Governor of Guam
Comment: On behalf of the people of Guam, we hereby submit this letter of suppor for Jin Air Company, Limited's application for exemption and foreign air carrier permit to operate between Seoul, Korea and Guam.
